We are also particularly grateful to the National Endowment for the Humanities, which has generously awarded the project a three-year grant under the auspices of its Scholarly Editions program. The grant provides funding for the maintenance of the Carlyle Letters office at the Duke University Press and the conversion of existing volumes to an electronic format, The Carlyle Letters Online. A generous grant from the Research Libraries Program of the Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation defrays part of the cost of digital conversion. The editors again express their gratitude to the British Academy, which made the Carlyle Letters a British Academy Research Project and continues to support us with an annual grant, and to the members of its Committee on Academy Research Projects and its assistant secretary, Ken Emond.

We remain extremely grateful for the advice of Paolo Mangiafico of Information Technology Services at Perkins Library, Duke University; and we extend our thanks for early critiques of the electronic edition to David Chesnutt, formerly of the Model Editions Partnership at the University of South Carolina, and to Natalia Smith of the DocSouth project at the University of North Carolina. Brent E. Kinser serves as coordinator of The Carlyle Letters Online in addition to his editorial service to the print edition. DNC Data Systems of Mumbai, India, has electronically encoded volumes 1 through 35 of the Carlyle Letters.

The letters in this volume cover the thirteen-month period from October 1860 to October 1861.This volume includes 196 letters, of which TC wrote 129 and JWC 67. In somber moments both JWC and TC frequently lament that they are entering their twilight years and withdrawing from life, but the epistolary evidence collected here suggests that they continue to engage in the social hubbub of their times with animated perspicacity. Invariably, they are able to shake off claustrophobic bouts of self-pity by observing and recording their impressions of the world around them. JWC curses TC for his nearly inhuman devotion to his history of Frederick the Great, while TC feebly pledges to “finish my Slavery … and rest … for the remainder of my time! “ (TC to JCA, 6 Nov. 1860). Yet the fruitful aspect of this perversely deadlocked relationship is that it inspires them to seek freedom through the act of writing, the readiest means by which they can gratify their mutual desire to release their imaginative energies from the emotionally cramped surroundings of 5 Cheyne Row. It is the written word that enables them to channel their frustrations toward constructive purposes.

In her letters JWC bewails the fleeting quality of experience as she seeks to preserve tangible mementos of her vanishing past. News of the sale of beloved Sunny Bank, the home of the Donaldson sisters, where she spent “the gladdest, loveliest time in my life,“ brings her closer to William Dods, the last living link to “deathly silent Haddington“: “Should I not draw nearer to you, and hold you faster, as the night closes in on my early Life, and one after another of my early companions disappear in the darkness!“ Curiously anticipating the wistful narrator of Marcel Proust’s À la recherche du temps perdu (Paris, 1913–27), she asks Dods for “a hawthorn seedling,“ the smell of which she identifies with the golden days “when I went about ‘at my own sweet will’ jumping over ditches—or into them!“ The memory quickly fades as the preoccupations of the present intervene. She is disgusted by the efforts of the “Craven Hill Donaldsons“ to secure their share of the property, and resents the “sacred relicks“ being desecrated “by [their] covetous hands and eyes.“ Tormented by influenza and still seething from the miscommunication that had forced her to interrupt her holiday in Cheshire and rush back to Cheyne Row to prepare the house for TC, JWC cannot resist an allusion to her husband, that “wretch of a man“ who did not come home “till three or four weeks later“ and who had “never intended sailing from Thurso to London
direct; and considered I ought to have known that by instinct!“ (JWC to WDWDO, [6? Oct. 1860]).

A more serious loss, the death of her protégée Kate Ross (previously Sterling) on 27 November 1860, prompts reflections on mortality that echo Alfred Tennyson’s In Memoriam (1850). Writing to Kate’s younger sister Julia Sterling, JWC dispenses with the etiquette of mourning and conjures up a vivid impression of her final glimpse of Kate and “her living face,—as it looked when we parted at Brighton,—wasted, and wan, and wistful; but with all the old love and truth shining out of it! all the old heroic spirit in it!“ Eschewing the “so-called consolations, which some people would ‘feel it their duty’ to offer you, and have the face to offer you,“ JWC pledges to sustain her anguish as a mark of true love for her young friend: “It has often struck me as the saddest part of our poor human bereavements, that the pain which so identifies itself with the Love, and which feels at first so infinite and eternal, gets blunted, whether we will or no, and finally effaced, by the mere friction of the Hours!“ (JWC to JSJMS, [3 Dec. 1860]). As Tennyson had defiantly declared, “Let Love clasp Grief lest both be drown’d, / Let darkness keep her raven gloss“ (In Memoriam 1:9–10).

Some “consolation“ is available to JWC through the presence of her two maids, the “restored“ Charlotte Southam and the newcomer Sarah Piggott, who complement each other perfectly “in a world where perfection is not to be looked for!“ For JWC, their youthful presence strikes a welcome note of camaraderie and frivolity amid the moribund atmosphere of the house: “[I]f the work … does not get done with as much order and method as under the tall Charlotte; it is done with more thoroughness and infinitely more heartiness and pleasantness.“ In a revealing comparison she adds, “It is a curious establishment with something of the sound and character of a nursery! Charlotte not nineteen till next March and Sarah seventeen last week! And they keep up an incessant chirping and chattering and laughing—and as both have remarkably sweet voices it is rather pleasant to hear“ (JWC to MW, 8 Dec. 1860). JWC’s winter confinement no longer seems quite so oppressive. Through these lively companions, she glimpses images of her own cherished adolescence. In January she delights in reporting the scene from her garden window, from where she watches the sudden outbreak of “both girls, playing at snowballs!“ (JWC to JCA, [1 Jan. 1861]). Perhaps wisely, TC refrains from commenting on this melodious new arrangement.

He deeply sympathizes with JWC’s predicament and frets constantly about her health, but he barely comprehends the extent of her disillusionment. In a letter to Lady Louisa Ashburton in February, JWC lays bare the numbingly monotonous environment in Chelsea: “[N]othing can be more dull—not to say dismal,—than the life we lead! And if it were only dull! but there is an amount of worry, to temper the dullness, which begets many floating notions
of—suicide! If I weren’t so very sorry for Mr C with the ‘time out of joint’ for him … I think I should go quite ‘to smithers’ with sorrow for—myself!“ There continues to be no relief from the omnipresent paralysis created by TC’s Prussian millstone. Lady Ashburton’s invitation to the Carlyles for a visit to the Grange over Easter painfully reminds JWC of the futility of escape: “It would be a good Easter Monday if one spent it at the Grange! But the Grange now looks to me much like the garden of Eden after one had eaten the Apple! fenced round by Cherubims with flaming swords—till the day of deliverance arrive when the last ‘proof’ of Frederick (the pity that he was ever born!) shall have been sent to press“ (JWC to Lady A, [23 Feb. 1861]).

Fortunately, occasional shafts of outside light did manage to penetrate her inner gloom. She warmly welcomes the inquiries of the novelist Margaret Oliphant, who is preparing to publish a biography of Edward Irving. Describing herself as “a practical woman,“ JWC urges Oliphant to speak with other friends of Irving, including Thomas Erskine, John Carlyle, and Irving’s brother-in-law Robert Dickson (JWC to MO, [12 Dec. 1860]). When Oliphant tells JWC in April that she intends to move from Edinburgh to London, JWC responds with a salty denunciation of the Scottish capital. In language that would have shocked Irving and may have surprised her correspondent, JWC scornfully dismisses Edinburgh as a backwater of provincialism and religious bigotry: “I could stand the dulness there; but I can’t stand its narrowness, its paltriness, its prejudicedness, its self-conceit, and above all its religious cant. … I never feel so well disposed towards London, so thankful to it for the real comfort and furtherance of being well let alone, as after a course of Edinr Free-Churchism“ (JWC to MO, [29 April 1861]). Such outspokenness impressed and intrigued Oliphant, and must have led her to hope that JWC would be equally forthright in her recollections of Irving.

Oliphant could not have been disappointed, for JWC cooperates to a degree, at once reveling in the authority attributed to her as a confidante of Irving and in the opportunity to share her memories of a very private and delicate subject with another woman. The past could liberate, as well as oppress her. In her coy attempts to deflect Oliphant’s questions about her relations with Irving, she conveys a vertiginous sense of emotional and even erotic excitement: “It is mildly and modestly that you ask for these ‘details,’ But nevertheless—the effect produced on my Imagination is that of—a loaded pistol at my breast. … I lose all presence of mind! When trying to recollect things thus to order … the blood gets into my head; my heart falls to beating; my memory becomes blank. … If you were here—beside me—I dare say I might give you some of the details you want. … But to write them down—to order—all in a row … Oh my Dear! I can’t indeed! the thought makes me like to scream!—and makes me tingle from head to foot!“ She then promises to provide Oliphant with a letter “written soon after [Irving] had
renewed his acquaintance with me—as a grown girl and before he had—!“ JWC rather bravely discusses the decision with TC, who persuades her not to delete the word “lovely“ from the phrase, “my dear and lovely pupil.“ He approves of her choice, discreetly overlooking Irving’s slightly florid closing wish in the letter to have JWC as a “dear companion through eternity“ (JWC to MO, [29 April 1861], and Oliphant, Irving 1:134–36).

A more exotic and dangerous new friend of JWC’s is Charlotte Cushman (1816–76), the renowned American actress who had sometimes played men’s parts such as Hamlet or Romeo and who was known for forming strongly romantic attachments to younger women, including Geraldine Jewsbury. JWC had known of Cushman since the 1840s, but she had refused to meet her, in spite of Jewsbury’s encouragement. When they at last come together in 1861, Cushman writes to her niece, on 7 September 1861, that Jane is “a person whom I have longed for 12 years to know—Mrs Carlyle wife of Thomas Carlyle. We were near meeting many years ago, but a Miss Jewsbury was then so injudicious in her praise of me, that Mrs Carlyle took a true womanly antagonism to me & would not know me“ (CC to Emma Crow Cushman, 7 Sept. 1861; see JWC to CCCCU, [6 Sept. 1861], and Fielding and Sorensen xxvi). JWC and Cushman were brought together by Sarah Dilberoglue (formerly Anderton), actor and feminist, whose husband Stauros had long been a friend of Geraldine Jewsbury and JWC. Their first meeting is intense, immediate, and dramatic. Soon after JWC writes provocatively, “I do wish to see you; do wish to hear from you; do love you; (you know that; why make me say it?) And, further I mean, deliberately and imperatively, that we Two should be friends for the rest of our lives. … Set yourself against it if you can!“ (JWC to CCCCU [6 Sept. 1861]).

This was unusually electric language, even by the standards of JWC’s correspondence with Jewsbury, Lady Louisa Ashburton, and Margaret Oliphant, and Cushman can perhaps be forgiven for interpreting JWC’s belief in “Spiritual Magnetism“ as a veiled form of animal magnetism, or mesmerism as it was then currently known (see also Fielding and Sorensen xxvii). To her niece she exults that JWC “has come to have the wish to know me better—well dear, she came—she saw & I conquered! … I wish you my darling could have seen this unhandsome, clever, keen, witty, scathing Scotchwoman come entirely down from her proud Eminence to sit at Aunties side—with her hand seeking hers & occasionally giving it a nervous clutch—as though she had found warmth and nature there“ (CC to Emma Crow Cushman, 7 Sept. 18601861; see JWC to CCCCU, [6 Sept. 18601861]). For her part, JWC soon back-pedals from these initial effusions, and begins to distance herself from Cushman when the latter expresses more intimate feelings. Was JWC striving to repress persistent lesbian inclinations? It is more likely that she was frightened of straying too far from the familiar patterns of domesticity, which she so
often derided, but which simultaneously provided her with a precarious illusion of security and routine in an otherwise increasingly fragmented, isolated, and lonely existence.

Similarly, TC himself clings to the work that he repeatedly denigrates. He wallows in the challenges inherent to writing the third volume of Frederick, and he concedes to John Forster that “I am too sensible what the nature of the journey is, and what the strength of the animal’s legs, not to feel in a most down-trodden mood, and to ‘join trembling’ with any ‘mirth’ I may have!“ (TC to JF, 7 Oct. 1860). He also confesses to Lady Sandwich that “sometimes I think, ‘In 7 or 8 months more, why shd it not be all over; and nothing but going in grass, with the shoes off, ever after!’— This is too sanguine a computation“ (TC to Lady SLS, 6 April 1861). In August he had reported to Forster, “No man, not the weariest of the Greeks before Troy, ever was so weary of a Task whh has fairly broken my heart“ (TC to JF, 17 Aug. 1861). But TC’s exile is far less remote than he pretends. Mentally and physically, he remains in good health. JWC confides to Alexander Gilchrist that “Mr. Carlyle is become so enamoured of the retirement he enjoys—beside the water-barrel, under that ten shillingsworth of calico—that I don’t think a farm-house even within a stone cast of the sea … would tempt his imagination!“ (JWC to AGAGI, 31 July 1861). TC continues to enjoy the idea of himself as a being cut off from humanity, and he never tires of trying to elicit sympathy from those who are privileged to move “among the living.“ Still, he is too honest and scrupulous a historian to apply such self-serving distinctions to his own labors. On the contrary, he realizes that the only history worth writing is that which absorbs the controversies of the present in the recreation of the past.

Paradoxically, therefore, TC had to be immersed in his own time to fathom the environment of Prussia in the eighteenth century. Few reviewers of the early Frederick volumes grasped the topical aspect of TC’s great epic, or the wider repercussions of the question that he posed in the opening “Proem“: “What part of that exploded Past, the ruins and dust of which still darken all the air, will continually gravitate back to us; be reshaped, transformed, readapted, that so, in new figures, under new conditions, it may enrich and nourish us again?“ (Works 12:16). Apparently, Emerson alone understood the paramount importance of the present in TC’s vision of the past. In a lecture he delivered in Boston in 1859, for example, he astutely refers to the History of Frederick the Great as “a book holding so many memorable and heroic facts … with a range, too, of thought and wisdom, so large, so colloquially elastic, that we not so much read a stereotype page as we see the eyes of the writer looking into ours … stereoscoping every figure that passes, and every hill, river, wood, hummock and pebble in the long perspective, with its wonderful mnemonics, whereby great and insignificant men are ineffaceably marked and medalled in the memory by what they were, had
and did“ (“Art and Criticism,“ R. W. Emerson, Works, ed. E. W. Emerson [Boston, 1904] 12:298–99). This conception is generated by TC’s “stereoscopic “ judgment of the present, which discloses the major social, political, and philosophical conflicts of Frederick’s era as they are “reshaped, transformed, [and] readapted“ (Works 12:16) in mysterious and unpredictable ways, with unknown consequences and possibilities.

Contrary to the image that he likes to project, in these letters it is evident that TC continues to be a pivotal figure in the “condition of England“ debate. For him the dominance of liberal ideology and laissez-faire economics stand as enduring signs of the moral and spiritual bankruptcy of Victorian society. His opposition to “political economy“ was reinforced by his study of Frederick the Great’s policies. The Prussian king had been hostile to the notion of “unlimited Competition“: “Probably in the world there was never less of a Free-Trader! Constraint, regulation, encouragement, discouragement, reward, punishment; these he never doubted were the method“ (Works 16:307). TC vigorously influenced and championed Ruskin’s attack against contemporary economic theory in essays that the latter published in the Cornhill Magazine beginning in August 1860, later collected in Unto This Last (1862). Ruskin’s denunciation of “political economy“ provoked a flood of abuse and vituperation, and the publisher George Smith and the editor W. M. Thackeray were eventually forced to stop publication of the series after the fourth installment, “Ad Valorem,“ in November. TC is overjoyed by the outcry, and relieved “to find myself henceforth in a minority of two at any rate!“ After receiving an advance copy of “Ad Valorem,“ he congratulates Ruskin for disrupting the digestion of the respectable classes: “You go down thro’ those unfortunate Dismal-Science people, like a Treble-x of Senna, Glauber and Aloes; like a fit of British Cholera,—threatening to be fatal! I have read your Paper with exhilaration, exultation, often with laughter, with ‘Bravissimo!’ Such a thing flung suddenly into half a million dull British heads on the same day, will do a great deal of good“ (TC to JRJRU, 29 Oct. 1860).

TC is particularly pleased by the nimble manner in which Ruskin had disputed the arguments of John Stuart Mill in Principles of Political Economy (1848). In “Ad Valorem“ Ruskin ironically praises Mill for contradicting the cardinal tenet of economic liberalism: “He deserves honour among economists by inadvertently disclaiming the principles which he states, and tacitly introducing the moral considerations with which he declares his science has no connection“ (Ruskin’s Works 17:79). TC savors this swipe at the Utilitarian thinker and his acolytes: “The Dismal-Science people will object that their science expressly abstracts itself from moralities, from &c &c: but what you say, and show, is incontrovertibly true, That no ‘Science’ worthy of men (and not worthier of dogs or of devils) has a right to call itself ‘Political Economy.’“ Less satisfied with the Christian slant of Ruskin’s argument in the conclusion
of the essay, “[G]o thou forth weeping, bearing precious seed, until the time come, and the kingdom, when Christ’s gift of bread, and bequest of peace, shall be ‘Unto this last as unto thee’“ (Ruskin’s Works 17:114), TC cautions his friend and disciple: “On yr last page, and never till then, I pause slightly, not too sorrowfully, and appeal to a time coming. Noble is the spirit there … but alas it is not Philanthropisms that will do then,—it is Rhadamanthisms“ (TC to JRJRU, 29 Oct. 1860). Haunted by the “long perspective,“ TC apparently sees no salvation in the altruistic message of Jesus.

His antipathy to “mammon-worship“ reached a vitriolic crescendo in June 1861, soon after Lionel Nathan de Rothschild (1808–79; ODNB), banker, philanthropist, first Jewish member of the House of Commons, and Liberal M.P. for the City of London, began to build a house at 148 Piccadilly. TC entertains Dickens with an anti-Semitic pantomime on the subject. The novelist, evidently amused, describes the episode in a letter to the actor William Macready: “Carlyle has greatly intensified his aversion to Jews, and is greatly enraged by beholding the gradual rise of a Mansion that Rothschild is building next the Duke of Wellington’s. He was with us the other day, representing your old friend King John as an enlightened Sovereign in respect of drawing the teeth of Jews, to make them shed their money; and was comforting himself with an imaginary picture of Rothschild haled to the Court of Queen Victoria, and having several double teeth drawn“ (DL 9:425). David Alec Wilson, who paraphrases the contents of this letter accurately in his biography of TC, seeks to soften the remarks by reporting TC’s response to the inquiry of “Sancho-Panza-Froude“ to determine “whether Rothschild was objectionable personally or as a Jew.“ Notes Wilson, “The reply was reassuring,—it was neither the man nor the Jew, it was only the too profitable financeering that was loathsome“ (Wilson, Carlyle 5:430). Twenty-first century readers might not find such an explanation so “reassuring“—TC himself would live to regret such casual and cruel prejudice following the death of his loyal Jewish friend and secretary Joseph Neuberg in 1867–but the depth of his opposition to the economic orthodoxies of his age cannot be doubted.

In these months TC discovers another potent condemnation of the “Dismal-Science“ in Emerson’s The Conduct of Life (Boston, 1860). In a letter to the poet and essayist, he is expansive in his praise: “I read it a great while ago, mostly in sheets, and again read it in the finely printed form,—I can tell you, if you do not already guess, with a satisfaction given me by the Books of no other living mortal. I predicted to yr English Bookseller a great sale even, reckoning it the best of all your Books.“ Emerson is as scathing as Ruskin about a “political economy“ that confuses ethics with wealth: “The subject of economy mixes itself with morals, inasmuch as it is a peremptory point of virtue that a man’s independence be secured. … A man in debt is so far a slave, and Wall Street thinks it is easy for a millionaire to be a man of his
word … but that in failing circumstances no man can be relied on to keep his integrity.“ TC recognizes a less sentimental Emerson in such passages as this: “You have grown older, more pungent, piercing;—I never read from you before such lightning-gleams of meaning as are to be found here.“ TC is especially impressed by the conclusion, with its conviction that “[t]here is no chance and no anarchy in the universe. All is system and gradation.“ In the “leave-it-alone“ industrial democracy, the “mad crowd drives hither and thither, now furiously commanding this thing to be done, now that.“ The man who pledges to act for himself is at a loss, “when, by and by, for an instant, the air clears and the cloud lifts a little, there are the gods still sitting around him … they alone with him“ (R. W. Emerson, Works, ed. E. W. Emerson [Boston, 1904], 6:90–91, 325). For TC, this “finale“ is a “Fiat Lux“ of revelation (TC to RWE, 29 Jan. 1861).

Typically, TC at first feigns a lack of interest in the outbreak of the American Civil War, yet as the tragedy unfolds, he is gripped by its progress. He informs his New York friend and stockbroker Charles Butler—TC had no difficulty in reconciling his contempt for the “Dismal-Science“ with his quite lucrative investments in American railway bonds—that “[t]o my own poor private thot the controversy is pretty insane on both sides, (’Big-indian versus Little-Indian,’ when I look at it well); and only the issue is momentous“ (TC to CBCBU, 21 Jan. 1861). He does not elaborate the distinction, possibly out of deference to Butler, a Unionist sympathizer and an abolitionist. But TC was never an outright apologist for the Confederacy, notwithstanding his notorious slurs against “Quashee“ in “The Negro Question“ (1849) and Latter-Day Pamphlets (1850), and his equivocal support of slavery. The real “issue“ underlying the American conflict would prove to be inseparable from the great theme that he had outlined in the “Proem“ to Frederick the Great: the fate of true “Kingship“ and government in the aftermath of the French Revolution. It was the iconoclastic Prussian king who had precipitated the “formidable Explosion, and Suicide of his Century.“ He is unique for being “the last of the Kings; … he ushers-in the French Revolution, and closes an Epoch of World-History“ (Works 12:6). Unwittingly, according to TC, Frederick had cleared the ground for “Democracy,“ a necessary transition from “Sham Kingship“ to just rule, but one that contained the elements of its own destruction, as the great American drama was in the process of demonstrating.

For TC, neither the North, with its commitment to what he identifies as “laissez-faire“ and democratic individualism, nor the South, with its allegiance to a slave-owning feudal aristocracy, represented the future. Though its larger significance in relation to “World-History“ was still unknowable, the American Civil War was nonetheless a startling proof of the perpetual nowness of history. The densely textured battlefield dispatches of the Times correspondent W. H. Russell (1820–1907), which shifted the editorial bias of
the paper as well as popular opinion in favor of the South, played powerfully on TC’s own imagination. Russell’s description of the Confederate rout of the Union Army at Bull Run on 22 July 1861 moved him especially: “The Yankee fight sung by Homeric Russell is superb in the Annals of War!“ (TC to JAC, 9 Aug. 1861). To Joseph Neuberg TC exclaims, “Nothing in military annals equals that of Bull’s Run—except indeed it were the Taking of Fort Sumter, whh ought to be memorable as that of Troy! On the whole, I believe many persons are abt opening their eyes to the real Beschaffenheit [condition] not of Yankeeland alone, but of England & all lands; and we shall see alterations“ (TC to JN, 17 Aug. 1861).

Inevitably, these potential “alterations“ coalesce in TC’s mind with scenes in Frederick the Great. He announces to his brother John A. Carlyle in March that “I am fairly into Book XV (halfway or more); Robson Printer is nearly thro’ Book XIII,—chasing me along;—and if I cd hold out 6 months farther at this rate! But I dare not promise anything. I am become ‘a crazy vehicle’ in comparison; and shake at the roads still ahead“ (TC to JAC, 27 March 1861). By July he has finished the third volume, which marks the end of the second Silesian war and the peace of Dresden in December 1745. At this juncture in the history, TC pauses to consider Prussia under the leadership of Frederick. The key test of nationhood has been passed: “‘Are you able to defend yourselves, then; and to hang together coherent, against the whole world and its incoherences and rages?’ A question which has to be asked of Nations, before they can be recognised as such. … Question which this Nation … under this King, it answered to the satisfaction of gods and men. “ In surviving, Prussia has staked a claim to being the nation of “Teutschland,“ a claim that “Teutschland may be perhaps now, in our day, beginning to recognise; with hope, with astonishment“ (Works 16:196, 197). The interweaving of past and present persists throughout TC’s narrative, in “spasm after spasm“ (TC to JN, 17 Aug. 1861), luminously showing the impact of his own time on the plot and the style of his history.

In moments when he was able to free his mind from his bondage to Frederick the Great, TC exhibits a compassionate and charitable side to his character that he often took pains to conceal in public. He tirelessly seeks to help and to encourage his brother John, “spending the winter in Edinr;—has still no hearth of his own, but lives in lodgings, shifting about“ (TC to JCHJCHA, 28 Feb. 1861). He also praises the work John had done to prepare the manuscript of David Irving’s A History of Scotish Poetry (Edinburgh, 1861), and urges him to take up his earlier plan to translate Dante, “a subject on whh you have no peer in Britain, and whh has a real and lasting utility!“ (TC to JAC, 21 Dec. 1861). TC had previously offered financial help to his brother Alexander in Canada, to help his son Tom purchase a farm (see 36:95TC to JF, 13 April 1860). In spring 1861, Alexander accepts, and TC asks John to manage the affair. He
sends him a check for £250—duly noted in TC’s checkbook stubs held by the National Library of Scotland—and advises him “to choose what sum of mine (the whole or the part of that £250); but send at once what you judge right; and whatever you send I will be good for“ (TC to JAC, 4 June 1861). TC rarely refused any request for help, no matter how irritating and time-consuming. On 15 April he sends £5 to Samuel Langley, an “Indigt Litr man“ and part-time clerk at the British Museum “for the real requirements of yourself and parents“ with the admonition that “you are totally mistaken abt my feelings to you; and may at once cease to distress yourself on that score“ (TC to [SL][SLA], 15 April 1861).

For a man who claimed to abhor and to avoid newspapers, TC was well informed about the events of the day. The death of Inspector James Braidwood (1800–1861), superintendent of the London fire brigade, in a conflagration that broke out in warehouses packed with inflammable materials in Southwark on 22 June, provokes an outpouring of grief. In a letter to the Times, TC praises this popular expression of sympathy, “of deeper sort than usual. … It is a beautiful emotion, and apparently a perfectly just one, and well bestowed.“ Braidwood’s family, TC suspects, “is not left in wealthy circumstances.“ He recommends the formation of a “Braidwood Testimonial,“ and promises that “if it be acted on, will, with great satisfaction, give my mite among other people; but must, for good reasons, say further, that this [is] all I can do in the matter … and that, in particular, I cannot answer any letters on the subject.“ A committee is established and a public subscription is launched, but subsequent payouts by the fire office and Braidwood’s own personal property render these efforts redundant. But TC’s letter brings into sharp focus his own inestimable gift to his age—his ability to arouse ordinary people to recognize and to acknowledge “singular worth,“ and to honor those “[t]horoughly skilled in his function, nobly valiant in it, and faithful to it—faithful to the death“ (TC to Editor of the TimesEOT, 30 June 1861).

div1.p: October 1860–October 1861
Numbers in parentheses refer either to the date of the event or to the date of the letter.

1860 October. JWC writes cheerfully to William Dods to thank him for his good wishes: “how few besides yourself are left me of those I began Life with!“ She asks for plants from the garden of Sunny Bank to remind her of Haddington (6). TC, having returned to Chelsea from Scotland 22 Sept., thanks Frederic Chapman for looking after his horse while he was on holiday and asks him to “forward to its terminus“ the packet of books which he had arranged to have sent to Thurso (7). TC reads proofs of book 11 of Frederick “(for ‘the seventh and last’ time!)“ (7). He writes to Lord Ashburton to report his return; to Forster (7); and to Sir George Sinclair to tell him of his journey, reporting JWC “extremely weak“ from influenza but “steadily mended ever since“ (10). French anecdotes arrive, forwarded by James Carlyle Jr., and TC writes to thank him and everybody “in my dear old native circle“ (12). He thanks Coventry Patmore for sending to him the third part of The Angel in the House (14). Eggs, butter, and cheese arrive from Scotland (17), and JWC writes Mary Austin to thank her and to tell her of her new servants (18). She writes Mary Russell with domestic news, “mistress of two servants, and ready to hang myself!“ (22). TC writes to Froude about Cromwell history and to David Macrae declining a religious argument (23). He sends his sister Jean payment for ordered winter necessities (28). Ruskin’s Unto This Last raises great controversy in the Cornhill Magazine; TC writes to Ruskin to encourage him and to John Forster about historical MSS (29).

November. TC invests another £1,000 in U.S. bonds (4). Robson is printing Frederick, and TC is “up to the eyes in bother at all moments“ with proofs of book 12 (5). Both TC and JWC feel in better health, though JWC has a “hacking cough“; the weather is poor; TC rides his horse, Fritz, “vigorous beyond wont,“ and JWC slowly finds the household with two servants easier to manage. They dine with the Forsters (8), along with Dickens and his daughters, Mary and Kate. TC, “up to the nose in rubbish,“ is glad of Joseph Neuberg’s help (17). Giovanni Ruffini visits (23). Kate Ross dies (27). TC orders four gross of tobacco pipes from Scotland for Henry Taylor (28). JWC writes to thank Mary Smith for her poems.

December. JWC writes to console Julia Sterling (3), who visits her (7) after Kate Ross’s funeral. TC describes the weather as “mere liquid mud“; he thanks John Hill Burton for a copy of Alexander Carlyle’s Autobiography; and first encourages his brother John A. Carlyle to edit The Kingis Quair (4), then discourages him and suggests that he continue with his Dante project (21). JWC tells Maggie Welsh of the new domestic harmony with maids Charlotte Southam and Sarah Piggott (8), and writes to thank Margaret Oliphant warmly for The House on the Moor (12). TC continues to work on proofs, though the printer works “at a tortoise-pace“ (20). The weather turns very icy (21). James Aitken visits. TC sends New Year wishes to Charles d’Eichthal (23) and to his sister Jean (30). JWC sends Kate Stanley (28) an account of the cat chasing the canary, writes to Lady Ashburton (ca. (28 and (31) enquiring about the baby Mary Florence’s health, and to Mary Russell (30) and Jane Dods ((30 or (31) with New Year wishes.

1861 January. JWC sends New Year greetings to Jean Aitken thanking her for gifts; TC dines with Lady Sandwich (1). TC sends New Year greetings to John A. Carlyle (2), reporting his good riding habits and sleep: “I rub on; rather more tolerably than in months prior.“ Mary Austin sends New Year gifts, and JWC writes to thank her (7), reporting some bad health, while TC tells Lord Ashburton the continued cold weather is affecting him (9). TC allows James Hannay to dedicate his volume of essays to him (13) and congratulates him on leaving London for an Edinburgh editorship. TC and JWC leave for The Grange in icy weather (15), though JWC has to write to Charlotte in Chelsea to send on her forgotten keys. TC is very restless at The Grange and soon leaves with JWC (19); he writes Lady Ashburton to apologize and encloses a pamphlet on James Keith (26). TC visits the Ruskin family (27) and writes to thank Emerson for The Conduct of Life (29). He estimates he is still twelve months from the end of Frederick.

February. JWC tells Mary Russell she wishes Frederick “had never been born!“ and thanks Neuberg for a present of tea (1). TC tells his sister Jean that as far as Frederick is concerned he feels as if “the back of the Task were really broken“ (1). TC complains to his brother John of sleeplessness and ringing in his ears (3); tries to borrow law books from Lushington (4); thanks Helps for a book (13); and complains to Hutchisons about the quality of the spirits they sent (14) and returns them to Edinburgh (23). JWC writes very cordially to Mantell in New Zealand (22). TC and Neuberg urgently rearrange the contents of the current volume of Frederick (22). Lady Sandwich visits (22). TC sends a money gift to his sister Janet Hanning in Canada (28).

March. TC tells Neuberg he hopes to finish book 14 of Frederick “this week“ (4) and thanks Ruskin’s father for his help in procuring his favorite kind of
brandy. TC writes more cheerfully about his health and progress to his sister Jean (16). TC and JWC dine with the Milneses (25) and visit the Forsters (26). By (27 March TC is well into book 15 of Frederick and the printing of book 13 is almost complete.

April. JWC is visited by the Blunts, who become firm family friends; she has the chance to hear Spurgeon preach but is prevented by bad health (3). TC congratulates Lady Sandwich on her birthday, reflecting that he has become “an old man“ (6). TC reassures his brother Alick he will be glad to help his nephew Tom financially (7). TC asks Larkin urgently for some copying assistance (7) and, pleading pressure of work, declines an invitation from the duchess d’Aumale (8). JWC writes cheerfully to William Dods in Haddington (ca. 15). TC and Alexander Gilchrist go to hear Ruskin lecture on “tree twigs“ (19). JWC writes to Isabella Barnes arranging to visit an exhibition of stuffed gorillas in the British Museum (26), to Margaret Oliphant to congratulate her on her decision to move to London from Edinburgh and to give her details for her Life of Edward Irving (29).

May. TC tells his sister Jean how “tied up and tumbled about“ he is with writing and with “bad proofsheets“ (1). He writes a letter of recommendation for John MacRae Moir (6). JWC has a servant crisis, Sarah having to leave through ill health, and Charlotte being dismissed at the same time (7). TC has almost finished the proofs of vol. 3 of Frederick, aided by Chorley; he still thinks he will finish it with one more volume (8). Neuberg is in poor health; the current proofs are finished at last (13). TC declines an invitation from Sir George Sinclair to revisit Caithness, and another to a Mansion House dinner, but rides out to visit Ruskin in fine weather (14). He thanks his sister Jean for a parcel from Scotland (19).

June. More proofs of vol. 3 arrive (2). TC arranges with his brother John to send their nephew Tom in Canada a gift of money (4). Matilda and Margaret arrive as the new servants in Cheyne Row. Mrs. Johnston of Grange dies. TC reports a great fire in Tooley Street to his brother John (24) and writes to the Times in support of an appeal for the superintendent of the fire brigade, James Braidwood (30).

July. Servant Matilda suddenly goes into hospital with a tumor (3); JWC visits her almost daily. JWC writes Mary Russell explaining that her proposed holiday in Scotland will have to be postponed (3). Larkin is still helping TC; Neuberg is too ill, though he visits TC and takes him for a drive (7). Proofs of vol. 3 of Frederick are completed, after much labor; TC still thinks all will be finished “this time twelvemonth“ (9). TC works in the open air during good summer weather, but remains very irritable indoors; asks John A. Carlyle to send him a supply of biscuits from Edinburgh (20). He declines an invitation
to lunch from Lady Sandwich (23) and thanks Richard Trench, dean of Westminster, for his mother’s account of her travels in Germany (24). JWC has given up her plan of going to Scotland (26), though she tells Alexander Gilchrist she might go to Ramsgate with Geraldine Jewsbury (31).

August. JWC leaves for Ramsgate, despite ill health, for a week of sea air (3), while TC tackles his next piece of writing, “vol. 4th and last.“ Emilie Venturi visits (4). Ramsgate turns out to be noisy, though JWC feels in better health. Woolner visits and tells TC of Sydney Herbert’s death (6). TC writes to the Custom House requesting that they release a copy of the German translation of The French Revolution (8), and works with Larkin on maps for Frederick (9). JWC visits Margate for the day (8), but rain spoils the visit; she returns to London (10). TC writes to Forster about Elizabeth Barrett Browning’s death, saying that he would like to see Browning (17). JWC writes to Jane Dods for news of Scottish friends (23), and TC suggests to his brother John a visit to Chelsea (23) while the good weather lasts. The Carlyles prepare to go to Sunninghill with Lady Sandwich for a holiday. JWC tells Mary Russell she would have preferred to go to Scotland on her own, but TC, “much more like a spoiled Baby than other men,“ needs her in London all the time (27). Lord Ashburton writes from Blair Atholl.

September. Fritz the horse is injured, so TC gives up riding temporarily (6). The Carlyles leave for Sunninghill to join Lady Sandwich, TC on Fritz (12). JWC writes to William Dods, offering to go to London for the day to meet him (16), and enjoys country quiet. TC rides in Windsor Park, but is restless and irritable until they return to Chelsea (23).

October. TC invites Henry Parkes, introduced by letter from Gavan Duffy, to visit (2). John A. Carlyle visits for a week and then goes to Cambridge (14) to look at the Maitland MSS, with introductions from TC to two professors. Matilda is out of hospital and convalescing in Walton-on-Thames. TC asks his sister Jean for clothes from Scotland (17). JWC writes Walter Mantell with news and good wishes (19). She finds life back in London “heavy and difficult“ after the country air. She thanks Henry Parkes for his poems inscribed to her (22) and writes to cheer up Anne Gilchrist, whose eldest da. has scarlet fever (27). In spite of a chest cold, TC accepts an invitation to dinner with John James Ruskin (29). He tells his brother John of his low spirits: “Oh if I were but done!“ (30).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-UC, [Oct.?]. MS: D & D Galleries, Box 8413, Somerville, N.J.; catalog 5. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee might possibly be either Henry Larkin or George Cooke, to both of whom JWC signed herself as “yours affectionately,“ using “Jane Carlyle“ at times (e.g., JWC to HL, 14 July 1859, and JWC to JGCO, 2 Sept. 1859) and “Jane Welsh Carlyle“ at other times (e.g., JWC to JGCO, 9 July 1859, and JWC to HL, 23 Aug. 1859); otherwise unidentified. Dated conjecturally in a month when JWC, TC, and Joseph Neuberg were all in London. “The Beauty“ was a nickname applied to Neuberg, who often visited the Carlyles on Sundays. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 October 1860.]
div3.head: JWC TO AN UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p: All right—to remind you that at four tomorrow the Beauty will await you here—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WD[WDO], [6–7? Oct.]. MS: NLS 1797. Quot: Ireland 268. Dated conjecturally by the announcement in the Times, 4 Oct., of the death of George Cunningham.
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p: Good morning! I couldn’t desire a finer day to write to you on! Soft sunshine, bracing air, and everything as clear as a bell!— Besides, it is more than time you should be written to; dont you think?William Dods had written to JWC 29 Aug.; see 36:203JWC to WDO, 25 Aug.— I think so; at the same time, I feel no need—not the least in the world to begin with apology! when one has been true to a childish affection thro’ a tolerably long life time—has kept on caring for a man (or perhaps I should say rather a Boy) some twenty years long, without once seeing him, or exchanging words with him,They had met each other again at the Haddington railway station in 1857; see 33:79JWC to GEJ, 11 Sept. 1857.—nothing to remind one of him except old memories in one’s own heart; one must surely have earned in the opinion of that man (or Boy) at least, a faith in one’s constancy (whatever else) which nothing one may do after, or may fail to do, can shake!— Is it not so?— If, by ill luck, you should never set eyes on me again, never get the scrape of a pen from me again; you should know now, all the same, should you not? that so long as you had not heard I was dead or out of my wits, I should still have my affection of long ago for you—only without the longagoness; alas!—

For myself, I am always heartily glad of any outward, visible signs of remembrance from those I love; but I dont depend on the outward and visible signs for belief in the remembrance!— That comes to me by—divination!—a faculty, inherited from my Great Ancestor John Welsh The Covenanter,JWC wrongly claimed descent from the Protestant reformer John Knox (1505–72) through his son-in-law John Welsh (1568–1622); see 32:13JWC to RMM, 17 Oct. 1856, and 34:137JWC to CSO, 17 Aug. 1858.
and worth all my other faculties put together—in matters of feeling; which are indeed a woman’s most important matters on this Earth!— Yes! you may smile at my pretending to preternatural powers; but, it is as true as you live, that my Divination never misleads me, while my Understanding makes a fool of me every day of my life! so I trust and have trusted and will trust in this my preternatural heritage! whatever anyone may think or say!
Sunday [7? October 1860]
At the bottom of last page an interruption occurred—providentially.—as I seemed about to lose myself in metaphysics of The Imagination!

Poor absurd George Conningham; I couldn’t have believed it possible beforehand, that an announcement of his deathGeorge Cunningham (ca. 1802–60; see 2:45–48JBW to EA, 20 Feb. 1822, and 24:170–71JWC to MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849), one of JWC’s schoolmates in Haddington. The Athenaeum noted, 6 Oct.: “[He] was only known to the public by his ‘Lives of Eminent and Illustrious Englishmen,’ published in early life [1837]. The subsequent contributions to literature are chiefly in the departments of geography and topography. Of these, the best known are ‘Bell’s System of Geography’ [1832] … and the ‘Gazetteer of the World’ [1850–56]. … His retiring habits and fastidious taste made him shrink from publicity, and, except in the instance referred to, he withheld his name from his productions.“ would have made me quite sorrowful for a whole day!— When he came to see me a year ago,His visit is untraced. I had a presentiment he would soon die. His whole nature seemed changed; grown tender, affectionate, sentimental even! he that had used to be a perfect little marble of self conceit and self-love! And he told me, I remember, with a solemnity which now seems no longer ridiculous that he had had “a monition“ to go and“see my face once more.“ in fact my “apparition had stood over him in his study at WindermereCunningham had lived at Ellerlay Bank, Windermere, in the Lake District, NW England. one evening“ &c &c! All that now is sad—not laughable to recall; as indicating morbid action of the Brain.

Dear William Dods! how few besides yourself are left me of those I began Life with! Should I not draw nearer to you, and hold you faster, as the night closes in on my early Life, and one after another of my early companions disappear in the darkness!Jean and Jess Donaldson, old family friends, and George Rennie and Robert McTurk, friends from JWC’s childhood, had all died since late March. Oh if it were not for you—still living—and caring for me, more or less—I couldnt bear to think of Haddington—with Sunny BankThe old name, which JWC persisted in using, for Tenterfield, the Donaldson sisters’ home. passed into other hands!— But thank God, anyhow, that bag of vanity
and vulgarity, Stuart Donaldson, did not purchase it!Stuart Donaldson, nephew of the Donaldson sisters; William Dods wrote to JWC, 29 Aug.: “That vain fellow Stuart Donaldson had never intended buying it although he said he would to myself & several others, but at the sale there was no appearance made for him or anyone else & Mr Todrick got it at the price asked.“ Thomas Todrick (ca. 1813–90), banker and procurator fiscal (public prosecutor). It would have been enough to have made the House haunted, such a representative of my beloved old friends!—

The wretches! to leave the print of Mr Carlyle and all those awful photographs of me to be sold by Auction! I hope you got the print? I shall like better to know it in your house than in any other—and as for the photographs, I think you would have sufficient feeling for me to burn them?Dods continued: “There is an engraving of your Husband which I will buy & if there are any of your own Photographs exposed for sale I will take care of them also.“ 11. Anthony Coningham Sterling; he took many photographs of JWC in the early 1850s (although this particular one is untraced); see 28:52–53JWC to MR, 24 Feb. 1853. There was a picture of our room too, done by Sir Anthony Sterling,Anthony Coningham Sterling; he took many photographs of JWC in the early 1850s (although this particular one is untraced); see 28:52–53JWC to MR, 24 Feb. 1853. whose likeness of me was so unlike that I covered the face with a photograph! producing a most ghastly result!— Did you become the generous purchaser of that master-piece also? If so, oh do burn it!—

No No! I would not care to have the shawl and brooch now,Dods had asked about the “Shawl & Brooch that were intended for you? It is real dishonesty in the Donaldsons’ keeping these but you should ask for them & tell them that you understand from Mrs. Dods (if you please to say so) that these were laid aside to be sent you and they all know it.“ if I could get them for the asking!— Coming with “airs“ from Miss Jess’s drawer, the things would have been prized, as sacred relicks—but, desecrated by the covetous hands and eyes of the Craven HillWhere Stuart Donaldson’s mother and sisters lived in London. Donaldsons, I would rather be without them. If I needed any visible thing to put me in mind of the life-long motherlove of these dear women for me; I have on my finger day and night a little old diamond ring they gave me eight years ago!Jess Donaldson gave her a diamond ring in Aug. 1856; see 31:178JWC to TC, 19 Aug. 1856. I may look at that, and think it a fit memorial of their love—; without a flaw, and not to be dimmed by time! and Miss Jess placed it on my finger herself, with a living kiss.— God keep me from having any more to do with the Craven Hill Donaldsons! They are a bad lot!—

You asked was there anything you could put aside for me that I would like. Yes—I would like some flower or shrub out of the garden—if you could find one able to live in my soilless and airless bit of ground. Would hawthorn live here do you think? If it would; I should dearly like a little hawthorn seedling from Sunny Bank! The smell of hawthorn reminds me always of the gladdest,
loveliest time in my life; when I went about “at my own sweet will“Coterie speech; cf. Wordsworth, “Composed upon Westminster Bridge“ line 12. jumping over ditches—or into them!— But is there any hawthorn at Sunny Bank? If not—there is, or was, plenty about “Babbies Butts“?Babbie’s Butts, Haddington footpath; see 24:163JWC to MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849. I should like it from that locality quite well—and you might send me something else—of a hardy nature—from the Sunny Bank garden. with some moss about the root, the thing could come safely by post— That Jessamine you saw covering half the Garden wall,William and Jane Dods had visited JWC at Cheyne Row 8 Aug.; see 36:171JWC to JCA, 11 Aug. came by post—originally.

After my abrupt return from Cheshire, and renunciation of a sight of Dumfrieshire; that wretch of a man did not come home till three or four weeks later!JWC visited Lady Stanley at Alderley in Cheshire 22–28 Aug.; after a misunderstanding over TC’s travel arrangements, she had returned to Chelsea instead of going on to Scotland as planned; see 36:200–201JWC to MR, 25 Aug. Had never intended sailing from Thurso to London direct;TC visited Sir George Sinclair at Thurso Castle 4 Aug.–7 Sept., and then stayed with his family in Dumfriesshire until 23 Sept. and considered I ought to have known that by instinct! So I had plenty of time to make the necessary preparations and to transact a bad Influenza, over and above.— I am now getting back my strength—or, as Jackie Welsh of Haddington expresses herself,“am happy to say I am in my frail ordinar“JWC’s cousin John Amelia Welsh; coterie speech; see 36:18TC to EF, 30 Nov. 1859.—after having taken iron enough, to have made—what shall I say?—a small saucepan in my stomach!

And now I want to know, how are you, and your “nice wife“? Consider how deathly silent Haddington must be for me now, unless you give it a voice! and how heavy that silence must lie on my heart, being the foolish, clinging, back-looking heart it is!
And so God bless you both—
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

ps.p: Tell me how Mrs Davidson and “old Mary“Janet Davidson and her servant, Mary Jeffreys (b. ca. 1790; her death date was wrongly noted as 1857; see 32:196JWC to TC, 23 July 1857, and 3[4]:27434:biographical note). are?

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 7 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: You send me a cheery little Note, bright of hue in these grey times; whh has been very welcome to me. The only questionable point is that lingering residue of gout; but of that, tho’ it must be mortifying in the haunts of the Deer,The Ashburtons were at their Highland estate, Kinlochluichart, near Dingwall; see 36:221TC to LLA, 2 Sept. you appear not to make much; and indeed one can hope the change of scene, change especially to a milder latitude where “snow“ is far from our thots, will send that to the Autumn winds, were you once on Abbotston DownRiding country near the Ashburtons’ Hampshire home, The Grange; see 26:229TC to LA, 14 Nov. 1851. again. The Journey must be ticklish, surely, for one small but invaluable Individual,—the little Citoyenne,TC’s mischievous name for the Ashburtons’ da., Mary Florence Baring; the word, meaning female citizen, is most commonly associated with the antiaristocratic French revolutionaries; see Works 3:245. TC also once had a horse of that name; see 11:129TC to MAC, 19 June 1839. whom we often think of! Of course you will neglect no possible precaution. May she and all of you reappear among us, safe and soon;—the sooner the better.

I quitted Thurso on the set day, 7 Septr, exactly a month ago; cut off the immense elbow of the Moray FrithMoray Firth, large sea inlet, NE Scotland. by virtue of the sea;For TC’s voyage to Aberdeen, see 36:233TC to JWC, 9 Sept. and was shoved out at Aberdeen in the hollow of the Night ensuing;—lost all my sleep there in the doleful caravansera provided for human nature; and indeed have hardly ever yet got into such a gift of sleeping as I shewed at Thurso, lying by the Pentland Frith,Pentland Firth separates the Orkney Islands from the Scottish mainland. with the “Old Man“ (Orkney-man) “of Hoy“The Old Man of Hoy is an isolated column off the cliffs of Hoy, one of the Orkney Islands; see 36:163TC to RMM, 7 Aug. keeping watch over me. I spent two days with Erskine;Thomas Erskine, at Linlathen. pleasant pious kind of days as these always are; smoked one cigar, lying solitary in the once “Nor’ Loch“ (now green Pleasure-Garden) of poor old Edinr, with its ancient chimney-potsThe North or Nor Loch, Edinburgh, was drained from 1759 and redesigned as public gardens between Princes St. and the castle and High St. The chimney pots were those of the buildings on the N side of High St. in sight and all else (nearly all, I think) gone invisible forevermore;—dashed off into Annandale, considerably tumbled by my railwaying; and for a fortnight was sickly and melancholic among the poor remnant of old friends there. Nine mortal hours shot me out from Carlisle into Cheyne Row; by no means
the soundest man in her Majesty’s Dominions,—tho’ I have been slowly improving ever since, and even getting to work and to print, in the blessed quiet there still generally is. Cabs with luggage atop begin now to be frequent; but mostly, for the last fortnight, there has been a more solitary London than I ever saw before.— — My poor Wife has had Influenza; is out of that, but as weak as you may suppose. I too am somewhat do; my Influenza, Printers,Robson, Levey & Franklyn. and a task very formidable indeed.TC was again producing material for the printers for vol. 3 of Frederick, having given up in the previous Feb.; see 36:57TC to WMV, 4 Feb. I cd now do it, better or worse, if my bodily strength wd hold: but will it? That is becoming a sad new question! We must hope, we must try; there can no other “answer“ be given to it, by the afflicted son of Adam.— I saw RousJames Rouse, the Ashburtons’ doctor. the other day; fatter, I shd say, growing fatter, than most whales; his skin shines, and he is all tending visibly to the globular. For Garibaldi &cGiuseppe Garibaldi (1807–82), Italian patriot and soldier of the Risorgimento; in alliance with Victor Emmanuel II (1820–78), king of Piedmont-Sardinia, he had liberated Sicily in the summer, entered Naples, 7 Sept., and eventually routed the Neapolitan army at the Volturno River, 2 Oct. (except it be that delightful Irish Brigade)Sardinian troops were attacking the Papal States, so Pope Pius IX (1792–1878) had recruited Catholic volunteers and mercenaries to his defense. Among these was the Irish Battalion of St. Patrick, who, 17 Sept., heroically held the fortress of Spoleto against a vastly superior force until the town was in ruins, when “the Papal delegate, with authority that left O’Reilly [the Irish commander] no resource but obedience … ordered him imperatively to capitulate“ (Times, 3 Oct.). I care not a doit! No “news“ at all.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 Oct. MS: NLS Acc.7988. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I got both your Notes, the second of them last night: I intended at any rate to write today,—not sooner, being unwilling to bother you with my paltry little confusions attendant on re-incipiency here (on kindling the smithy-fire again, and setting Smith and hammers in working order) till once the process were completed. Whh I hope it now nearly is. My sleep has all along been broken, rather scanty; but I hope it is improving; I have been out twice on horse-back, with sensible amelioration each time; indeed I have been almost daily growing sensibly better than I was in Annandale; tho’ up to this date my last Thurso sleep is beyond any I could since manage to have.— The Horse I did
not actually get in hand till Friday last, Fredk Chapman not having finished his breaking experiments upon him,Frederic Chapman had tried unsuccessfully to train Fritz to run in harness; see 36:169–70JWC to TC, 10 Aug., and 193JWC to MCA, 10 Aug. and the other really great and obliging trouble he was taking with him:—the result of all is, Fritz “will never break to harness“ (it seems), at least never to poor Jane’s satisfaction, or indeed safety; I lose certain Pounds Stg (under £10 somewhere) and all F. Chapman’s multifarious outlays;Silvester’s livery stables (see 35:193TC to HL, 5 Sept. 1859) had initially tried breaking Fritz to harness; Chapman then kept him from about 19 Aug. until 4 Oct. TC noted: “5 Octr 1860 / (horse began agn, 4th) / to Sylvester for (futility of) Horse! / £15..2..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). and get back my Horse in good riding conditn, tho’ a little spirited in his paces for the first week or two. “As you were!“ comes at that expense; my “Riding-master“Unidentified. here having been a — No matter what the poor devil was: that affair is over.

Above ten days ago I began correcting (for “the seventh and last“ time!) the proofs of “Book XI“;Bk. 11, “Friedrich Takes the Reins in Hand. 1740,“ the first bk. of vol. 3 of the first edn. of Frederick (Works 14:278–413). and on friday last, after a great deal of fash, fairly despatched it;—except running over the thing in the form of sheets, nothing more to do with it! That is a real comfort to me; a 10th part of my deadly task done:—courage, let us try (wisely) for the other nine tenths: they too, if Heaven permit, shall be got done, one day!There were eventually 21 bks., so TC had completed the first of the final 11; for the vol. divisions of the first edn., see Appendix.

I have seen ChorleyJohn Rutter Chorley, who helped TC with proofreading; see 34:146TC to JWC, 19 Aug. 1858. (his first “sheet“ will come perhaps today); he is stane-cherking, (do you know that bird, the stane-cherker?Stonechat, a small bird with a grating, scolding voice, like pebbles being crushed. It must resemble Chorley in tone), stane-cherking in his usual way; sorry abt the death of LockJoseph Locke (1805–60; ODNB), railway engineer, d. at Moffat, nr. Dumfries, 18 Sept. &c; Neuberg, whom I have not yet seen, is coming tonight, and some rubbish of a YankeeUnidentified. with him. I am not to do an Emerson Preface;—no more sheets have yet come;Smith, Elder & Co. wrote to TC, 13 Sept., asking him to contribute a preface to the forthcoming British edn. of Emerson’s The Conduct of Life, and enclosing several proof sheets of the work; see 36:247TC to JWC, 14 Sept., and TC to S, E & Co.SEC, 8 Oct. when they do, you shall see them. Adieu, dear Brother: affectionate regards to everybody where you are. Much hurried for the moment.— Yours ever T. Carlyle

Young Jamie of Scotsbrig sent me two voll. of the French AnecdotesProbably referring to a series of volumes of anecdotes from various countries pbd. Paris, 1767–74. HCC lists TC as owning Pierre-Antoine de La Place, Antoine Hornot, and Jean-François de La Croix, Anecdotes du Nord, comprenant la Suède, le Danemarck, la Pologne, & la Russie; depuis l’origine de ces monarchies jusqu’à present (Paris, 1770), with the autograph “Geo. Fred. Nott“; and two copies of André-Guillaume Contant d’Orville, Anecdotes germaniques, depuis l’an de la fondation de Rome 648, et avant l’ère chrétienne 106, jusqu’a nos jours (Paris, 1769), one with the autograph “T. Carlyle, Chelsea., 1855,“ the other with the autographs “Geo. Fred. Nott“ and “Thomas McGregor., 1854.“ Possibly George Frederick Nott (1767–1841; ODNB), cleric and scholar, whose extensive library was auctioned at his death. The other volumes of Anecdotes included Guillaume Bertoux, Anecdotes françroises (Paris, 1767).
Series;—tell him when you have a chance; and send the 3d vol. (also his) whh I left at The Gill. No haste with that at all!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 7 Oct. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd. Letters obscured by binding are enclosed in square brackets.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
Your excuses must be admitted to be valid, your letter is all loyal and andThus in MS. faithful: I recd it, as you know, in Annandale; a man broken by 300 miles of miscellaneous (in good part sleepless) voyaging and railwaying; a most rusty, sickly, melancholic man;—whose sad humours your brilliancy could enlighten only for a few hours. Had you written to Thurso, I could have told you many things, of Pictish Cairns, of John O’Groat’s House,—generally of the Oe (or Landing Place) of Thor,For Thurso and John o’ Groats, see 36:212TC to JWC, 30 Aug., and 220TC to LS, 2 Sept.—and of a modern Individual “walking gloomy by the shore of the many-sounding Sea“See Iliad 1:34–35. in the middle of all that. Out of Annandale, in my bankrupt conditn, I would not write; nor since, till I had summed things up again into clear schedules, and begun a new score;—whh has never been till now, if even now it be. The truth is, I seem to have thrown away all my past accumulation of “new health“ by the 700 miles of confused jolting and jumbling that la[y] between home and it? No; that is not quite the fact either:—and in short, I will say no more of all that, except that I did get home yesternight gone a fortnight, head and soul made “like unto a wheel“Cf. Ezek. 1:15–21 and 10:10–13; see CL 7:73. by the whir[l] from Carlisle; that I have been gently, ver[y] gently, yet diligently sweeping litter aside recovering my talent of sleep (to a certain hopeful extent) in the blessed calm there oftenest is in this place at present;—and th[us] by way of practical outcome, the Printer has got a bit of that unblessed Chaos again; nay that “a tenth part of the whole“ (so I proudly name it) is abt fairly to Press, and out of my hands forever and a day! That is my one comfort;
that properly is all my “news.“ I must go next upon that alarming bundle whh was lately in your hands:The early drafts of bks. 14 and 15 of Frederick; see 36:189TC to JWC, 21 Aug.—you know what that is! I refuse to be daunted altogether; but I am too sensible what the nature of the journey is, and what the strength of the animal’s legs, not to feel in a most down-trodden mood, and to “join trembling“ with any “mirth“Cf. John Galt, Annals of the Parish (Edinburgh, 1821) 380 (chap. 48). I may have!—

My poor Wife got a bad Influenza that very day she was to have dined with you;JWC had canceled two dinners with the Forsters due to ill health; see 36:234JWC to EFO, 9 Sept., and 250JWC to TC, 17 Sept. had never been out again, at the time of my arrival: she is now better much, but still very weak. I have seen nobody, done nothing but what I say;—and will not, at this time, speak a word more, except simply, “When O Forster, is your cheery face to be seen here again?“ Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC, 7 Oct. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p: I have been twice upon the Horse “Fritz“; find him in excellent case, very much improved by the “clover“ and other good usage he has had;—and am obliged to you, beyond what I will say at present, for the great quantity of trouble you have taken off me, and laid upon yourself, in regard to Fritz and his interests! He has not been in such health, I believe, these four years past. We will now altogether (much to his joy) give up the enterprise of breaking him to harness;—enough if, by “handling his hoofs“ (as the Irish say), he will carry his poor owner, at any kind of pace, thro’ the Prussian Adventure, which also bears the name of Fritz, or Frederick, in the common speech of men: don’t we wish we may see that!Coterie speech; see 29:307TC to JCA, 11 May 1855. Many thanks to you at any rate.

There is another business, that of the Thurso Packet of Books,TC had asked Chapman to send some of his works to Sir George Sinclair; see 36:227TC to JWC, 5 Sept. whh I wish you now to help forward to its terminus. So far as appears, the Books have never yet got to Thurso,—tho’ there is weekly from Edinburgh one Steamer direct to Thurso (distance 24 hours) and there are two to Wick,The Hamburg sailed on Tuesdays to Wick and Thurso, and the Prince Consort sailed on Fridays to Wick. whh is 20 miles short of Thurso, with a daily coach between them! Most probably the Packet is lying in the Office of the Steamer you sent it by, with a lazy Clerk gone to sleep over it. I wish you would immediately direct some sure hand to dig it out of the Edinr-Steamer Office,The Aberdeen, Leith and Clyde Steam-Shipping Co. had offices at 6 South St. Andrews St. and Granton Pier. and at once book it (prepaid) in the
Thurso do,—by whh it will go within a week at farthest. Prepayment is also a point I am anxious abt (the thing, being a Gift, shd not ask money at the first glance of it): pray enjoin on yr man the importance of that point—I shd be right happy to repay him by return of post, wd he send us the Thurso Booking-Receipt, giving assurance that the paltry affair were finished. Please let me hear so soon as you learn anything definite.— Yours with sincere thanks / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-S, E & Co.[SEC], 8 Oct. MS: NLS 23180. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO SMITH, ELDER & CO.

docBody.p: I was honoured with your Letter and Request, some time ago, while in Scotland; and since my return home, have read the Emerson Proofsheets you were kind enough to send.Smith, Elder & Co. wrote, 13 Sept., asking TC “if it would consist with your engagements to oblige us with a short preface, or introduction“ to the English edn. of Emerson’s forth-coming book The Conduct of Life and enclosing some proof sheets (MS: NLS 607.562). By whh latter I prognosticate that this will be perhaps the best of all the good Books Mr Emerson has yet given to the world.

The question of writing a Preface to it I have often turned over in my mind. The temptation is great;—and alone of existing men, Emerson cd tempt me at all, in existing circumstances. Had not I written a Preface once already;TC wrote a preface to the first English edn. of Emerson’s Essays, pbd. by James Fraser, 1841; see 13:163TC to RWE, 25 June 1841. were not I so overwhelmingly busy, in these months, with affairs of my own! The result of my deliberations is, I must by no means undertake to do it. The Book, I persuade myself, will on its own strength go into the Libraries of all thinking Englishmen: and as to your Editn, all that could be done for it (certifying, namely, that it is the real Edition, not stolen, not bungled in the printing),One of the reasons that the publisher wanted TC to write the preface was to prove that theirs was the authorized edn.: “From the publication of the edition the author will derive a pecuniary advantage, and we are therefore desirous of its having a distinctive character which may cause it to be preferred to any other English reprint.“ you can yourselves do, directly and indirectly.
A sight of the remaining Proofs, when they are thrown off, wd be welcome, if quite convenient.
With many thanks, I remain / Gentlemen / Yours sincerely
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-RMM, [8 Oct.?]. MS: Trinity Coll., Cambridge. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 253. Conjecturally dated in 1860 after the return of TC’s horse, Fri., 5 Oct. (see TC to JAC, 7 Oct.)
div3.head: JWC TO RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES

docBody.p: I dont know the particular gossip to which you allude. I have not read Varnhagen’s correspondence;Karl Varnhagen von Ense, Briefe an eine Freundin. Aus den Jahren 1844 bis 1853 (Hamburg, 1860). Saturday Review, 25 Aug., criticized strongly the anon. ed., Amalie Bölte (1811–91; see 16:177–78JWC to JW, 20 May 1843, and 22:17JWC to HW, 15 July 1847), for publishing confidential letters written to her by Varnhagen von Ense (1785–1858) between 1844 and 1853, when she was closely acquainted with both JWC and TC (see 22:x—xiintroduction). The reviewer commented that Bölte “appears to have been living in Mr. Carlyle’s family, and to have sedulously hived up, for the amusement of her old friend at Berlin, both the gossip and the opinions of the circle in which she lived. Varnhagen replied with the freedom of a man who does not write with the fear of the printing-press before his eyes, and the young lady, as soon as he is dead, sets to work to publish his letters. Thus censures from his pen on people yet alive, which he himself would evidently have rather died than print, are given without scruple to the world.“ The reviewer observed about Milnes: “Varnhagen writes to his young lady friend [26 April 1850] some worldly-wise advice, which she has not been coy enough to sup-press:—‘I hope the acquaintance with Mr. Milnes is now made, and to the satisfaction of both sides. Such threads easily spin themselves farther, and lead to other ties. My best wishes thereto!’“ The reviewer also commented on Varnhagen’s attitude to TC: “As long as [he] sticks to his hero-worship, Varnhagen’s admiration for him knows no bounds. … But when Carlyle publishes a pamphlet recommending greater severity to prisoners, this, being a backsliding from humanity-worship, stamps him as an apostate; and from that time forward Varnhagen thinks very little of Carlyle.“ having no patience to spare from domestic purposes, and being deeply impressed with an idea that I should find it Twaddle! For it has always been born in on me that Varnhagen was a vain finical, pasteboard-and-varish sort of make-believe Man.

But this “Freundin“ who exhibits “a particular dislike to Miss Wynn“Charlotte Williams Wynn, whom Bölte disliked because of her intimacy with JWC (see 16 March 1844; Varnhagen von Ense, Briefe 88). Shortly after the publication of the Briefe, Wynn wrote, 23 June, to Varnhagen’s niece Ludmilla Assing (1821–80; see 33:267TC to JWC, 30 June 1858): “I was about to write to tell you how exceedingly charmed I was with the Bölte Letters.— A great breach of confidence I must always think their publication, but the letters themselves are most beautiful. … On the other hand the allusion to the Carlyles it is shameful to publish, because it will annoy them and do no good.— Your uncle said nothing but what was kind in itself, but all his remarks show that Miss Bölte was in the habit of living intimately with them … and sending off daily reports of what they said, and did, and of his singularities and odd opinions,—which we should call neither more, nor less, than a Household Spy.“ She wrote again to Assing, 28 Aug.: “Mrs. C. had not seen Miss Bölte’s book and did not intend to do so. There is a most violent attack upon it in the Saturday Review of Saturday last, sneering and cutting right and left, which is just what that paper delights in an opportunity of doing“ (Walther Fischer, “Thomas und Jane Carlyle im Spiegel der Briefe Amely Böltes an Varnhagen Von Ense (1844–1853),“ Englische Studien 64 [1929] 424–25). can
be no other than a Miss Bölte, whom you must surely have seen at Mrs Buller’s,Barbara Isabella Buller, b. Kirkpatrick (1784–1849); see 2:4–5TC to JCE, 12 Jan. 1822. when she officiated as governess to “Tizzy“Theresa Revis (b. 1832), the Bullers’ adopted da.; see 12:54TC to MAC, 24 Feb. 1840, 17:212JWC to AB, 23 Dec. 1843, and 18:288–89JWC to JW, 18 Dec. 1844. She was in frequent correspondence with Varnhagen, by force of flattery on her part and flatterability on his.— She particularly disliked Miss Wynn because at their first (and I think last) interview Miss Wynn did not, in the enthusiasm of their mutual love for Varnhagen, drop into her arms and “swear everlasting friendship“ with her! and She certainly was “much with me“—as the old man of the mountain was much with Sinbad the Sailor!— Of course it is She!

I know you have “got a pony“— I saw you on it the other day; out of my “neat Fly“Coterie speech; see 35:2JWC to MCA, 3 Jan. 1859.—And I thought to myself; ‘I wish to Heaven he would come and ride with Mr C!’ Riding with him is the only “delicate attention“Coterie speech; see 34:50JWC to TC, 16 July 1858. to which Mr C remains sensible,—the only human intercourse to which he lends himself! It is a dreadful time for him—and me!
But if you would loom in the street on that pony, some early day at half after four—good might come of it!
In the evenings we are always at home—unless Mr C go out for a solitary walk—which he would not do if he had the least hint of your coming.
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Sir GS[SGS], 10 Oct. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Square bracketed words are missing or faint because of a fold in MS.
div3.head: TC TO SIR GEORGE SINCLAIR

docBody.p:
I have recd both your Notes addressed thither; for whh kindness I am again much obliged. The second Note (of yesterday) was especially opportune; as I had concluded that the Book-Parcel must have misgone, and had, just a few hours before, directed the Bookseller to stir up some Edinr Agent or other to look after it and at once expedite it by the Thurso Steamer. I was very glad it had come;—and now it is a fact you could do me another little favour in regard to it, and if you are magnanimous you will: it is to tell me punctually to a penny what the carriage from Edinr cost you, that I may pay the same in stamps: the strict order was, “Frank all the way“; but the Bookseller
has told me he could not farther than Edinr,—and there is no doubt the thing is not done, as it shd properly have been. Be magnans to that length now if you can!

I wd not write from Chelsea till I cd report myself re-anchored here, and things adjusted about me into the route they are to follow. Whh, with all my endeavouring, has hardly yet taken effect,—certain of the elements (state of one’s nervous-system for example, and decline hitherto of sleeping talent) not being under one’s control altogether. I came home, Saturday gone a fortnight;TC arrived home 22 Sept. and have been deliberately doing my best and wisest ever since; success not yet declared as you see, but alone possible by steadily persisting in that style. I found my Wife extremely weak, still under the skirts [of] Influenza; but she has steadily mended ever since, and is now at least as well as when I left her: there is one fine thing to be recognised. I have also, after various troublesome adjustments, fairly set my Printer going again; at a leisurely pace; they [must] not catch me if I can help it. Here is one leaf of a Proofsheet; take that lest you get no more. I am not to be called in ill health, not [exactly] yet: but at Thurso itself I believe I slep[t by] virtue (call it vice if you like) of bile and liver,—whh latter is now presenting [its ac]count agt me, and I must pay. Cour[age! I] have got my Horse again last week; strong [as an] elephant; and find him very beneficial. We will h[ope;] we will try!— Adieu dear Sir; I have not a [mo]ment’s time, never have. To the Lady Camilla & Miss Sincl[air] my grateful homage; upon you all, my blessing. Yours always T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC[JACA], 12 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE THE YOUNGER

docBody.p: Your Two French Volumes of Anecdotes came punctually to hand; I was gratified by that mark of yr attention;—and write a hasty word, lest the Dr may have omitted to inform you.See TC to JAC, 7 Oct. One of the Volumes is a duplicate; but of that too I will make some use by and by. Thanks for your unwearied kindness to me,—yours, and everybody’s in my dear old native circle!—

I have recommenced printing; am dreadfully busy, and likely to be, for many, many long months to come, if I can but hold out. That is now the important condition,—for in truth I am a good deal fallen into disrepair; not so weathertight, by any means, as I used to be half a century ago; and specially
quite worn down with this present long sad business! But I must do my best; and “keep a hank and a spingit“A saying of Joe Elliott, servant at Craigenputtoch; see 5:90TC to JAC, 10 April 1830. (heart and a spirit, as perhaps your Father can explain to you), till I do get the ropes all cut, and be at freedom again. Don’t I wish we saw it!—

My Horse is in fine order; and does me evidt good. All along hitherto I have continued ticklish as to sleep, a little, not very much;—I am trying my very best in regard to that matter, and hope always to get it well settled again;—after whh all might go well, and the grand operatn conclude handsomely in its time. Let us hope, let us hope.— Your Aunt is grown considerably better since I returned. All else goes on, as it shd do; rather better (Printing and all) than one could expect.

We have had near a fortnight of a “St Martin’s Summer,“ bright hard weather, alway bright, and often very cold;—whh seems now breaking down into the November type again; tho’, as your and everybody’s Harvest, is now, I trust, over, weather is a less importt matter.— I must not steal any more time! I send my affectionate regards to yr dear Father (ever-dear to me also); my wishes and blessings to all of you great and small; and amSignature cut away.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TE, 12 Oct. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:242, inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 492.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS ERSKINE

docBody.p: I got home nearly three weeks ago.
