Jane was not weaker than I expected; her house, poor soul, all set in order on an improved footing as to servants,Charlotte Southam had been dismissed early Aug., and her replacement, “Old Jane,“ lasted less than a month; see 36:206JWC to TC, 26 Aug.; the Carlyles now had two servants, “Tall Charlotte“ and Sarah Piggott; see JWC to MR, [22? Oct.]. almost pathetic as well as beautiful to me. I am happy to report that she has grown stronger ever since, and is now once more in her usual posture. I have got my smithy fire kindled again, and there is sound of the hammer once more audible. I have sunk silent, humiliated, endeavouring to be quietly, wisely, not foolishly, diligent with all the strength left to me. ‘Frederick’ is not the most pious of my heroes; but the work awakens in me either piety or else despair. Why have I not a more pious labour to end with? perhaps not to be able to end. But one must not quarrel with one’s kind of labour. To do it is the thing requisite. My horse is potent for riding, and one of the loyallest quadrupeds. That perhaps is the finest item in the horoscope.

div3.sourceNote: TC-CP, 14 Oct. MS: Princeton Univ. Lib. Pbd: Athenaeum, 17 July 1886, 81–82; Basil Champneys, Memoirs and Correspondence of Coventry Patmore (1900) TC to JBW, 26 March 1823. Coventry Kersey Deighton Patmore (1823–96; ODNB), poet and essayist, friend of Tennyson, Ruskin, and Woolner; he began sending his works to TC in 1850; see TC to CP, 22 July 1850.
div3.head: TC TO COVENTRY PATMORE

docBody.p: I am very glad to be reminded of you in this glad and victorious way; and return you many thanks for your welcome Gift. Last night I read the new Poem;Patmore’s poem Faithful for Ever (1860), pbd. early Oct. He had sent TC the previous two poems in The Angel in the House series, The Betrothal (1854) and The Espousals (1856); see 29:239TC to CP, 18 Jan. 1855, and 31:145TC to CP, 31 July 1856. I can truly say, with a great deal of pleasure;—and, as you know my aversion to that form of composition when not inexorably necessary, and with what horror I avoid the things commonly entitled “Poems,“ you may fairly take to yourself a very considerable credit out of that fact alone! The question whether it had not been better that a man of your powers had trained himself to prose, as exquisitely as you have to verse, and stood by the rigorous fact as the gods have unalterably made it, instead of floating, in this light beautiful way, rods and miles above it; the question whether, even in verse itself, with this admirable power of execution, you should not now take some more robust class of subjects, & close the Troubadour Enterprise as well finished; these and other questions are still open with me (and I hint them to you, at a venture, and because you are no common object to me nor to the world’s interests in this time): but the above truth is beyond question with me, That I spent such an evg over yr Book as I have not had for a long time from any other. Refinement of feeling, purity, tenderness, mild magnanimity,—seasoned too with a dash of fine humour, and with plenty of discernment, acuteness, picturesqueness:—these are a pretty element, and an unusual, to pass one’s eveng in! I admire the cleverness with whh you have made a few touches tell your story; the style is wrought to the highest pitch (in this age of slovenliness), and fills a fellow-workman with respect; keeps itself unshackled, too, and with wonderful dramatic aptitude fits the several characters each with his proper dialect. In short there is a great deal of talent in the Work; the execution of it nearly perfect; and the sentiments and doctrines set forth in it generally excellt and noble:—what a pity they went soaring miles above the rugged contradictory facts instead of standing amid them, toilsomely constraining them into melody! Good be with you always. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [18 Oct.]. MS: NLS Acc.7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:62–65 inc. Quot: Han-sons, NE 489; Holme 172–73. “I seem to have got home again, September 22. Halted at Alderley a couple of days; of Annandale, the Gill, or Dumfries I remember nothing whatever, except the last morning at the Gill (which is still vivid enough), and my wandering about in manifold sorrowful reflections, loth to quit that kindly, safe tugurium [cottage]; and also privately my making resolution (seeing the fitness of it), not to revisit Scotland till the unutterable Frederick were done—resolution sad and silent, which I believe was kept“ (TC’s headnote in Froude, LM 3:62). TC did not stop at Alderley on his way home, though he had done so the previous year; see TC to LST, 27 Sept. 1859, TC to JWC, 28 Sept. 1859, and TC to JWC, 30 Sept. 1859.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: The Box arrived last night, “all right“Coterie speech. —almost too right, for it was such a strong box, and so emphatically nailed, that for the first half hour it was doubtful for the maid and myself if we should ever succeed in getting into it! But “perseverance“ (as the copy line has it) overcomes all difficulties“Proverbial; cf. Virgil, Georgics 1:145. Such improving quotations were often used as writing exercises for children.—and at last the cheese disclosed itself and then the eggs and the rest followed easily. What a nice little cheese! and so unexpected! Catch you ever failing to exceed ones expectations. The eggs were a success this time—only two absolutely wasted—a few more (not many) were broken, or cracked but quite capable of being boiled. And very well timed they are these eggs! for just that morning “the Boy,“Unidentified. who supplies us with new laid eggs, had called empty-handed to say his hens had “left off“— The meal is excellent I had some porridge of it to supper. (I have had porridge to supper ever since I returned to dining at two oclock). As for the butter it also looks first rate; but having put pickleJWC salted the butter so that it would keep longer. to it this morning (“with my own hands“Coterie speech, a phrase of Edward Irving’s; see 6:44JWC to MAC, 12 Nov. 1831. notwithstanding my two maids) I tied it up and set it aside till it should have a touch of frost. That was the right thing to do, was it not? Many thanks Mary dear—

The things from Dumfries are also all right; but I will write to tell JaneJean Aitken. about them tomorrow. What a thing! to have to send to Dumfries for drawers in such a place as London! Miss DunwoodieProbably Marion Dinwiddie (1819–95), hosier, living at 131 High St., Dumfries. should feel elated!

Mr C doesn’t seem to have benefited from his long sojourn by the seaside so much as I had hoped, and at first thought. He still goes on waking up several times in the night—when he bolts up and smokes, and sometimes
takes a cold bath!—and all that is very dismal for him—to whom waking betwixt lying down and getting up is a novelty. For me my own wakings up some twenty or thirty times every night of my life, for years and years back, are nothing compared with hearing him jump out of bed overhead, once or sometimes twice during a night. Before he went to Thurso that sound overhead used to set my heart a-thumping to such a degree that I couldn’t get another wink of sleep—and I was on the brink of a nervous fever when he left.“Poor loving soul!“ (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:63). Now that my nerves have had a rest, and that I am more “used to it“Coterie speech; see 20:153JWC to MAC, 28 March 1846.—I get to sleep again when I hear all quiet.— But god knows how long I may be up to that! And when he has broken sleep, and I no sleep at all; it is sad work here I assure you!

You will have heard of my setting up a second servant, and think perhaps that I must be more comfortable now, with two people to work and run for us— But I would much rather have made less working and less running do; and kept to my accustomed one Servant. I have never felt the house my own since my Maid-of-all-Work was converted into a “Cook“ and “Housemaid“; and don’t feel as if I should ever get used to the improvement. It is just as if one had taken Lodgers into one’s lower story, often in the dead of night, when lying awake, I am seized with a wild desire to clear the house of these newcomers, and take back my one little Charlotte!—who is still hanging on at her Mothers, in a wild hope that one or other of them, or both, may break down, and she be reinstated in her place!

Poor little Charlotte! If I had foreseen how miserable she was to be at leaving us, I couldn’t have found in my heart to put her away—tho’ she was so heedless and “thro other“TC glossed “thro’ other“ (Scots for muddled) with “Durcheinander [muddled] (German) as an adjective“ (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:63); see also 10:158JWC to TC, 30 Aug. 1838.!— With a grain of method she could have done all the two do—as well or better than they do it! she was so clever and willing.

The new tall Charlotte (the cook) said to me one day after “little Charlotte“ had been here, “What a fool that girl is Maam! I said to her today you seem to like being here; and says she, “of course I do, I look upon this as my home“— But says I, you are a nice looking healthy girl, you will easily get another place, if you try.— “Oh, says she, I know that—I may get plenty of places but I shall never get another home“!— What a poor spirit the girl has! If anybody had been dissatisfied with me; it’s little that I should care about leaving them“!!— “I can well believe that“ said I—with a strong disposition to knock her down.

But I have no pretext for putting the woman away altho I dont like her. She is a good servant as servants go—and I cant put her away merely for being
vulgar minded, and totally destitute of sentiment!—and after all the faults for which I parted with little Charlotte, after twelve months of considering wont have been cured but aggravated by three months muddling at her Mother’s—Heigh ho!— I feel just in the case of the Edinr Meat Jack: “once I was happ-happ-happ-y! but now Im mee--e--serable“!Coterie speech; see 36:207JWC to LS, 27 Aug.
If one’s skin were a trifle thicker—all these worries would seem light!— But one’s skin being just no skin “to speak of,“ no wonder one falls into the meatjack humour!

closer.salute: God bless you and all your belongings / Kind regards to your Husband

docBody.name: Jane. W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [22 Oct.]. MS: NLS 607.568. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:236–39 inc; Bliss, JWC 284–85 inc. Quot: Holme 172–73.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Now, dearest Mary, suppose you were to write me a letter? It is your turn. But perhaps, and very likely, you think any letters this good while back haven’t deserved to be counted,—have been so hurried and unsatisfactory, that you are only nominally in my debt. I am somewhat of that opinion myself! But what could I do you see? A nice long comfortable letter couldn’t proceed out of a hurried and unsatisfactory state of mind—and what with illnesses—one on the back of another—and worries all in a heap—I should have been more than mortal to have preserved my equanimity thro the last three or four months!

The illnesses I needn’t go back upon— But the worries, since I am putting them forward as an excuse still need a little explanation. I told you, I believe, that Mr C had got into the not-sleeping line, and was all out of sorts for some time before he went off to Thurso—but I dare say I would not go much into the effects of all that on myself—for when I am very anxious about anything I dont like putting my anxiety into words till I can do it in the past tense— However, what with the actual disturbance, of his roaming about the house in the night time, describing his sensations with his accustomed exaggerative eloquence; and the mental disturbance, which my anxiety about him, and my excitable Imagination together caused me; I got so sleepless and so nervous as I never was in my life before! and but for his departure, and the news of his immediate improvement in sleep and spirits I must have ended
in brain fever. My DoctorAlfred Barnes. expected nothing less for me. And during this wretched time, a change of servants had to be transacted! Had I foreseen it—(the time) I would have kept on with poor little Charlotte, for tho’ she was needing to be put under some stricter superintendence than mine, still she was and is warmly attached to us—and loving kindness at such a time was to have been kept near me, tho accompanied with ever such muddle! But things were going on as usual when I gave her warning and engaged a (so called) “Treasure““Old Jane.“ in her stead, and also a girlSarah Piggott was 16.—who was to come on Mr C’s return—the Treasure being 71 years old, and requiring to be supplied with a pair of young legs. Well my Dear the Treasure, for whom I was remodeling my “establishment,“ turned out—as Treasures are too apt to do—an arrant old Humbug! Couldn’t speak a word of truth—couldn’t even cook—and finished off by stealing eight bottles of ale! A great comfort for poor Charlotte! who came and nursed me, and cooked all my food when I was too ill to take care of myself. I was weak enough to wish to take her back—but not weak enough to do it!— She, who couldn’t rule herself, would have made a sad mess of ruling a girl nearly her own age!—so I had to engage a middle aged servant“Tall Charlotte“ was 34. to be head to the girl. Both of whom were installed on my return from Alderley, and the old Treasure dismissed with not a blessing.
That was one of the things I had to hurry home for—

So now I am mistress of two servants, and ready to hang myself! Seriously the change is nearly intolerable to me, tho both these women are good servants,—as servants go— But the twoness! The “much ado about nothing“!Coterie speech; see 24:159JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849. I hate and cannot use myself to! With one servant—especially with one Charlotte; we were one family in the House—one Interest and one Power!— Now it is as if I had taken in Lodgers for down stairs; and had a flight of crows about me up stairs!— I ring my bell—this one answers but it is “the other’s business“ to do what I want— Then the solemn consultations about “your dinner“ and “our dinner“—the everlasting smell of fresh turpentine, without anything looking cleaner than used to be—the ever recurring “we“ which in little Charlotte’s mouth meant Master and Mistress and self; but in the mouth of the new tall Charlotte means—most decidedly—“i and Sarah“— Altho’ you have had two women yourself,For Mary Russell’s servants in April 1861, see JWC to MR, [14 Oct. 1861]. you cant understand the abstract disagreeableness of two—any two London servants in one’s kitchen! A maid-of-all-work, even in London, will tolerate your looking after her, and directing her; but a ‘Cook’ and ‘Housemaid’ will stand no interference— You
mustnt set foot in your own kitchen unless you are prepared for their giving warning! Either of these servants by herself—provided she were up to the general work of the house—(which neither of them is)—I could be tolerably comfortable with— But together—oh dear me!—shall I ever get used to it? In sleepless nights I almost resolve to clear the premises of them both, and take back little Charlotte, who has kept hanging on at her Mother’s all these months in the wild hope that one or other of the new ones would break dow[n],Letter omitted. and she be taken in her stead— “What a fool that girl is“ said tall Charlotte to me one day—“I told her she should look out for a place, that a nice looking healthy girl like her would easily find one—and she answered—“Oh yes! I may get plenty of places—but never a home again, as I have had here“! (meaning with us) Tall Charlotte could see only folly in such attachment. “She is very different from i am,“ said she—“if people hadn’t been satisfied with me; its little i should care about leaving them“!— That I can well believe!
And now surely I have given you enough of my household worry—

I hear such charming accounts of the beauty of your new houseThe Russells had moved to Holmhill, near Thornhill, Dumfriesshire, the previous autumn; see 35:244–45JWC to MR, 26 Oct. 1859.—and the warmth of your old kindness!—

Do write me a nice long letter, and mind to tell me about poor little Mrs McTurkJanet McTurk, widow of Robert McTurk; see 36:127JWC to JDO, 2 June. whom I often think of with deep sympathyTC wrote “(1860 / Winter / ?)“ upside down on the last page of MS.—
I sent Mrs GriersonHelen Grierson; see JWC to Lady ALAI, 24 Oct. a book of poems the other day which struck me as quite her style of thing.
Love to “the Doctor“Mary’s husband, Dr. James Russell.—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-DM, [23 Oct.]. Pbd: David Macrae, Twelve Sunday Lectures (Glasgow, 1884), part of the eighth lecture, “Thomas Carlyle and His Gospel“ 11–12 (each lecture was paginated separately); Wilson, Carlyle >5:403–4. David Macrae (1837–1907), began studying theology, Edinburgh Univ., 1860, but interrupted his studies to pursue a career as a writer and journalist. He finally graduated in 1871 and was licensed by the United Presbyterian Church as minister at Gourock in 1872. He had already been asked to succeed George Gilfillan (1813–78; ODNB; see TC to JCA, 12 Jan. 1855) in Dundee, 1879, when he was expelled from the United Presbyterian Church for denying scriptural authority on the doctrine of eternal damnation. The Dundee congregation then withdrew from the UPC, appointing Macrae its nondenominational minister; he stayed until his retirement in 1897. See George Eyre-Todd, Who’s Who in Glasgow in 1909 (Glasgow, 1909) 135–37.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID MACRAE

docBody.p: I have read your letter with real sympathy. I can but too well conceive the sorrow and uncertainty in which you have to struggle till these vital matters be settled.Macrae wrote: “I was a young student at the time, struggling with doubts and difficulties, from amidst which I wrote to Carlyle, as to one who might throw light into the darkness. His reply will have its interest and practical value to many, as it had to me“ (“Thomas Carlyle and His Gospel“ 11). My wish to help you need not be doubted; but, alas! there is literally as good as nothing to be done. This is one of the numerous cases in which the patient must be his own physician. To no other of mortals is the case wholly known (even if this were all) except to him.

Luther said long ago—‘It is neither safe nor prudent to do ought against Conscience’Luther’s concluding remark in his speech to the Diet of Worms, 1521; see Works 5:135.—a motto you abundantly recognise as valid everywhere, especially where things sacred are the question. Of this I need not remind my present correspondent. On the other hand, may not I perhaps say withal that there is a morbid punctiliousness of conscience, which should not be indulged upon details, the heart of the matter being once settled and out of peril. Strict silence will remedy many details; and for silence there is no end of demand upon us in any kind of life which we will lead wisely! I cannot advise as to your Divinity studies and profession; indeed I cannot; no man can understand another in regard to such a thing; no man’s practice can be a rule to another.

Something—by no means the whole, yet something, and that very considerable—will depend on the question, ‘What other outlooks of a life have you, should you quit theology?’ If there lay open to you an honest unspeaking profession, or course of commended industry, I should almost say at once, ‘Quit this speaking one.’ Speech is wholesome to very few in these times, to perhaps fewer than ever before! If on the contrary you have nothing at all of definite elsewhere? The prospect of drifting into ‘literature’ and living by ‘the
Press’ ought to be very horrible to you, and, I can well assert, is apt to be more perilous to moral well-being than any Church that is not wholly a false one!

You will, of course, do nothing rashly; take long, earnest, frequent, and oftenest silent counsel with your own mind—perhaps still for months and years to come. Be valiant to adopt the wise course, whether flesh or blood repugn or not; in the end, if you be faithful, I can promise you a good deliverance. …
docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAF, 23 Oct. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES ANTHONY FROUDE

docBody.p: Thanks for remembering me in Brussels among the cobwebs;Froude had been working in the royal archives in Brussels on his forthcoming edn. of The Pilgrim: A Dialogue on the Life and Actions of King Henry the Eighth (1861) by William Thomas (d. 1554), clerk of Edward VI’s privy council 1550–53. on any terms I am glad to hear of you again, especially after so long a silence.TC’s last recorded contact with Froude was 14 Jan. 1857; see 32:75TC to LA, 14 Jan. 1857.

This Cheppeuys,Eustace Chapuys (1489–1556), ambassador of the Holy Roman Empire to England 1529–45. of whom I never heard before, seems to be worth very little as a Biographer of Cromwell the Malleus Monachorum [hammer of the monks];Thomas Cromwell (ca. 1485–1540; ODNB), influential secretary and chief minister to Henry VIII (1491–1547; ODNB); he had been instrumental in securing Henry’s divorce from Catherine (also Katherine) of Aragon (1485–1536; ODNB) and the break with Rome in 1533; the formal dissolution of the monasteries began in 1536. his LetterFroude had sent to TC the letter from Chapuys to Nicolas Perrenot de Granvelle (1484–1550), chief minister to Emperor Charles V, 21 Nov. 1535. Chapuys is responding to a request from Granvelle for personal details about Thomas Cromwell: “Master Cromwell … is the son of a poor blacksmith, who lived in a small village four miles from this place, and is buried in a common grave in the parish churchyard. His uncle, the father of a cousin whom he has since enriched, was cook to the late Archbishop of Canterbury. The said Cromwell, in his youth, was an ill-conditioned scapegrace. For some offence he was thrown into prison, and was obliged afterwards to leave the country. He went to Flanders, and thence to Rome and other places in Italy. Returning after a time to England, he married the daughter of a wool-comber, and lived in his father-in-law’s house, carrying on the business. Afterwards he was a law-pleader, and thus became known to the Cardinal of York [Wolsey], who, perceiving his talents and industry, and finding him ready at all things, evil or good, took him into his service, and employed him in the demolition of five or six religious houses. On the cardinal’s downfall Cromwell acquitted himself towards him with marked fidelity. … Cromwell contrived with presents and entreaties to obtain an audience of the King, whom he undertook to make the richest sovereign that ever reigned in England. … Since that time he has risen above every one … and the world says he has more credit with his master than ever the cardinal had“ (Froude’s trans.; The Pilgrim 106–7). seems to be the mere transcript of the idle angry babble
he found in the air round him (from the Opposition or Orthodox Parties), and doubtless he was right in thinking Cardinal GranvellaIt was Antoine Perrenot de Granvelle (1517–86), the son of Nicolas Perrenot de Granvelle, who was a cardinal,. wd take a momentary pleasure in it, and therwith enough.

It is curious (if exact, as he says, whh perhaps it is not) that there was a Cromwell Blacksmith poorly buried in the Churchyd of Putney.Chapuys does not mention Putney in his letter; TC describes Thomas Cromwell as “called always ‘the son of a Blacksmith at Putney’“ (Works 6:24); his father was Walter Cromwell (d. ca. 1516), who lived in Putney and had at various stages been a blacksmith, fuller, and cloth merchant, as well as the owner of a hostelry and a brewery. On the other hand what he says abt T. Cromwell’s blackguardism, felony (or something like it) banisht to Italy, and the genl style of his appearance there, directly contradicts whatever one has got to know or guess otherwise (see Biogria Brita ;ica,Biographia Britannica, 6 vols. (1747–66). The entry on Thomas Cromwell notes: “His honest parents gave him a good and strong constitution; which, accompanied with excellent endowments of mind, and an uncommon industry, raised him to that high pitch of honour he afterwards arriv’d to. … When he grew up, having a very great inclination for Travelling, he went into foreign countries … and, by that means, he had an opportunity of seeing the world … which proved of great service to him afterwards“ (3:1531). for instance); and that abt Richard Willms Cromwell being the “son of C.’s uncle“ is an ignorant piece of blunderRichard Williams Cromwell (ca. 1496–1546) was Thomas Cromwell’s nephew, the son of his sister Katherine (b. ca. 1477) and Morgan Williams (b. ca. 1477), m. 1494. Richard later changed his name to Cromwell and served under his uncle Thomas in the suppression of monasteries. He was the great-grandfather of Oliver Cromwell (1599–1658; ODNB). (capable still of being nailed to the counter); while that of Rd’s Father being a Cook may, since Leland is at the pains to mention the Old Welsh Castle where he dwelt & where Rd was born,John Leland (ca. 1503–52; ODNB), Itinerary, 9 vols. (Oxford, 1710–12) 4:24; Leland cited the parish of Llan Isen (Llanishen, now part of Cardiff) as Richard Williams Cromwell’s birthplace but does not mention a castle; see Works 6:31. be considered as a do do of the malignant type. In short I consider this old scoundrel to deserve nothing, or almost nothing, but a switch or two of the horsewhip, besides what Granvella gives him, for what he has written on T. Cromwell at the time of those importt operations!— There are two words I cannot make out; we will read it together, if you like, some night when you are here.

RamsgateFroude was spending time in Ramsgate with his dying friend John Ashley Warre (1787–1860). Another close friend, John Parker (1820–60), also was dying, in London, and Froude was alternating his attention between them. Parker d. 9 Nov.; Warre d. 18 Dec. at Ramsgate, a resort on the E coast of Kent, 74 mi. (119 km.) E of London. I conclude is only an alighting place; and must mean, at lowest, frequent journeys to London. I bespeak you punctually for the first evg you
find yrself in Town: it is by no means fit I shd be so long a stranger to you. Come then, and witht fail: that may be one thing Cheppeuys may plead in extenuation of what he has done!

closer.salute: Yours ever truly (in great haste, & ill he[alth)]

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LAI], 24 Oct. MS: NLS 20767.37. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p:
Bless you “Oh Lady fair“—and dear!— The sight of that dashing handwriting of yours is to me always “a good joy“Coterie speech; see 10:167JWC to TC, 9 Sept. 1838.—as of old were the sight of “daisies“ and “sky so blue!“ to Leigh Hunt’s children! I do wish you had been at Alderley when I was thereLady Airlie was one of Lady Stanley’s das.; Alderley was the Stanley family home.—tho’ I candidly own that without you I enjoyed my visit extremely— In the first place it came off at the moment when I was just recovered from something of the nature of nervous fever; so that the mere greenness and quietness of Alderley Park were in themselves delightfully soothing to my wearied brain! And then those “Bright Young Beings“See 36:214JWC to LST, 30 Aug., and 216JWC to TC, 2 Sept. (as Mr C calls your siserts)Thus in MS. were so kind to me, and so charming; that I felt quite humanized, for the time being!—underwent what the St Simonians“Saint-Simonianism“ is the name given to a movement based on the political and social ideas of Claude Henri de Rouvray, comte de Saint-Simon (1760–1825; see 5:134–39TC to GE, 9 Aug. 1830). Christian and socialist in nature, it was banned in France in 1832. TC was sympathetic to their views in the 1830s; he trans. Saint-Simon’s Nouveau Christianisme (Paris, 1825), although the MS is now lost (see 6:3TC to GE, 3 Oct. 1831). JWC was also much impressed by them; see 6:100–101JWC to JCA, 23 Jan. 1832. John Stuart Mill believed Saint-Simonianism “sowed the seeds of nearly all the Socialist tendencies which have since spread so widely in France“ (Mill, Principles of Political Economy [1848] 1:250). called (for I suppose they are now in the past tense) a “Rehabilitation of the Flesh“The rejection of the idea that the flesh should be mortified in order to purify the soul; instead, a desire to celebrate the physicality of the body.—believed once more in youth, and young hopes, and aspirations, and all that poetical sort of thing, which I lose sight of at Cheyne Row, and hardly think of even as a myth! And then Lady Stanley too was so kind to me and so charming! In the Country she always looks to me like an escaped Bird; The natural woman in her comes out there in a way quite refreshing to see! She is not made, your Mother, for being caged up in a London circle—she is
too large for it and too real! I assure you I came away with the warmest, gratefulest feelings towards them all—even the white dogsSee 36:214JWC to LST, 30 Aug. were parted from with regret; for they too had been good to me; besides being very pretty.

I saw your Mother and SisterProbably Maude Stanley. at Dover Street, on their way to Bath; your Sister having written to tell me they were there. Mr Carlyle called the day after me, and what do you think he said?— It was at night—hours after his return—he had been lying on the sofa—asleep, I fancied. And he suddenly broke out in a tenderly reproachful tone; “These people dont like me nearly as well as I do them!“ “What people? I said, what on Earth are you talking about“?— “The Stanleys I mean—I dont think they care a bit about me!“— I was far gladder to see them today than they were to see me!“— “Well, I said, I dare say Lord Stanley cares nothing about you—but I am sure Lady Stanley does—she has always professed to do so, and I am sure she is sincere in whatever she says“— “Ah—h— Well—l—I used to think she liked me very well—but today she didn’t seem to care rigmarree for me!“—“and I am sure Miss Stanley likes you; only she is very undemonstrative.“ I went on comforting him!— But he turned over on his side, and murmuring—“I don’t believe any of them like me half as well as I do them“—went to sleep again! You can’t appreciate the singularity of this human outburst of Mr C’s unless you had had my opportunities of observing how he never troubles his head whether people “like him“ or not!

The fact is,—as to the nonappearances of liking,—that he has been very bilious since he came home, seeing every thing in black—I dare swear nothing was missing in his reception at Dover Street but poor Lady Stanley’s accustomed good health and liveliness.

I am going off to lunch with Miss Farrer,Annie Louisa Farrer. and help her to entertain Syme the Edinr Surgeon!James Syme (1799–1870); see 29:292TC to JAC, 20 April 1855. In a moment of enthusiasm she had begged of him to stop in London on his way to some patient in Devonshire; that he might examine Lady Tierney,Mary Tierney, Annie’s sister. about whom she was in a dreadful fright, poor Soul! And now Lady Tierney declines being examined by him, and he is to have luncheon instead. That poor woman has a dreadful life with that idiot HusbandMatthew Tierney, whom JWC had always disliked; see 30:261JWC’s Journal, 30 June 1856, and 31:96–97JWC to KS, 14 May 1856. of hers! And when he dies, as he is expected to do this winter,He d. 28 Dec. you will see, she will be an inconsolable widow! Women always suffer more in losing a husband who has wholly depended on them, and painfully occupied every moment of their lives, than in losing one whom they have been “at ease
in Zion“See Amos 6:1. beside, and had no bother at all with— I have seen this more times than I can count! One of the loveliest womenHelen Grierson (1789–1862), whom JWC sometimes visited when staying with Mary Russell; see 34:210JWC to MR, 1 Oct. 1858. I ever knew was promised at fifteen, by a mercenary Brute of a MotherFrances Davis Sibbald, b. Bontein (d. 1836). to a little fat vulgar rich manWilliam Grierson (1772–1852), a merchant from Dumfries who was taken by the poor childs Beauty. Bred up in a scotch WildernessShe lived in Johnstone, a village in Dumfriesshire, where her father, William Sibbald (1760–1833), was the minister. the girl had seen no men to compare him with,—was grateful for the trinkets and “sweeties“ he gave her,—and when her Mother accepted him for her, hadn’t courage to say no. A year or two later, when transplanted to a Town,The family moved to Haddington in 1808 when William Sibbald was appointed minister there and where JWC knew them; see 2:130JBW to TC, 15 June 1822. where there were numerous men, she was claimed by her Betrothed whom she had not seen in the interim, and was horror-struck at his fatness and vulgarity—as for his riches, having taken, poor girl to thinking and writing Poetry, they (the riches) were no consolation whatever— So she wept, and remonstrated, and postponed,—did every thing except what she ought to have viz: kick her foot thro’ the whole “burble“— She had a very nice conscience unfortunately, and they persuaded her it would be dishonourable to fling the man over, and moveover he worked on her timidity by threatening to “prosecute“ her and publish her child-letters to him!! So after some five years of vain struggle to get out of the thing, she let herself be married to the odious little man. And from the day she married the brightness went out of her face for ever!— Well—(what a long story I have got into!) She did all her duties of Wife,—obeyed him at a word, studied his humours, was gently impassive to his ill temper and vulgarity. But for the rest, she looked dead and buried! Her voice sounded always as if it came from a great distance—nothing seemed ever to amuse, or please; or pain or excite her. Beautiful as she was she gave one the sensation of a night-mare dream. People tired of trying to be any comfort to her, and, she was left to the seclusion she courted—with nothing to live for, that any one could see, but one horrid little sonThomas Boyle Grierson (1818–89), doctor, naturalist, founder of the Thornhill Institute, 1850, and the Thornhill Museum, 1852; known for his gentle and attractive personality; her first son, William (1816–17), had d. in infancy.—whom she indulged to the foolishest lengths. Her Husband seemed to weary of her deadness and lived much away from her— She never said an unkind word of him, or a complaining word of herself—but it was easy to see she loathed him, and was slowly dying of him. This was the state of things when the Husband’s “affairs“ went to the dogs, and himself was struck with paralysis in consequence,
or at least in sequence.William Grierson had retired from business in 1828, and the family went to live in Grovehill, a house on the Baitford (now Boatford) estate just outside Thornhill, which Grierson had inherited from his father. He continued his many activities in the community: he was a founder member of the Dumfries Burns’ Club, secretary of the society formed to build the Burns’ Mausoleum, a founder member of the Dumfries and Galloway Horticultural Society, a church elder, director of the poor house, member of the police board, and a J.P. from 1838 (Apostle to Burns: The Diaries of William Grierson, ed. John Davies [Edinburgh, 1981]). Apparently financial troubles forced him to sell Baitford in 1839, and they moved to Noblehill Cottage near Dumfries; from 1849 they lived with their son at 31 Drumlanrig St., Thornhill. Then the true woman in her rose up tender and strong! She devoted herself to nursing the helpless little (now old) man who had been the curse on her young Life. Slaved to supply him with the comforts he could no longer afford, shook off her long lethargy to cheer him up—was nurse, servant, comforter Guardian angel to him for three years—till he died—and then one saw another instance of what I was remarking— Her grief was near killing her!! The Doctor,Probably Dr. James Russell. who was present when the miserable wretch of a Husband expired, told me he had never seen a woman suffer so terribly on a similar occasion—that he felt “perfectly ashamed of himself“ for the thoughts in his own breast, about how happy she ought to be to be rid of him! And I know she perfectly loathed the man when she was forced to marry him, and all the years she lived in affluence with him, and up to the time that he became a helpless, mad-tempered, disgusting burden on her!— Nor was it only at first that she regretted him— When I saw her in Dumfrieshire two years after his death;Probably four years, as JWC visited TC’s family in Dumfriesshire in July 1853 but did not visit her own friends there until Sept. 1856; see 32:28JWC to MR, 5 Nov. 1856. she told me with a look of inconsolable woe—that there could be no mistake about, that “her Life on Earth was darkened for ever—and that she lived on merely in the one hope of being reunited to Mr Grierson in Heaven“!

I said to the Dr above mentioned: “good gracious! If it were possible for her to conceive Mr Grierson in Heaven one might have thought she would almost have wished to go to the other Place,“ But he answered very sensibly. “a woman always regrets the man who gave her plenty to do—and God knows she had a busy time of it, while she had him paralysed on her hands and no money in the house“! Have you read this far? Since I don’t write Novels, I may be permitted to tell a true story, by way of safety valve may I not—otherwise such a long yarn in a letter is inexcusable.
Of course I did not fill all this paper before lunchtime with Miss Farrer— I left off and began again after tea at home

Lady Tierney did “see“ Syme and well that she did; for he has made her mind quite easy, the “lump“ in her side is nothing he says of the least moment,
a mere enlargement of a particular bowel—which will probably go away as it came—insensibly—and at all events can do her no harm while it lasts.— What an unspeakable relief for her—and for her sister too poor soul! Even I feel immensely relieved—I have such poignant pity for people with “tumours“— Will you write to me again—and will you please to believe me always your sincerely attached wellwish[er]
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 28 Oct. MS: NLS 517.7. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I here send you the moneyTC sent a check, 30 Oct.: “Sister Jean (for / shoes &c to us) / £3..0..6“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). you have paid away for us in liquidation of the various necessaries you have taken so much bother to get sent all right. Thanks;—and may never waur be amang us!Proverb; see 15:178TC to AC, 13 Nov. 1842.

Jane finds her ArticlesPresumably the “drawers“ JWC had bought from Marion Dinwiddie of Dumfries; see JWC to MCA, [18 Oct.]. very cheap, and very good: in regard to the leather slippers (the price of whh was fixed beforehand!) that too is my feeling; and in regard to the snow-boots, I will only remark, “Always fix beforehand with this Mr Nibloe!“William Nibloe (1815–89), boot and shoemaker, 86 High St., Dumfries; see 36:262TC to CAW, 24 Sept. His account in that latter Article surpasses in exorbitancy anything I remember to have experienced from a Son of CrispinSt. Crispin and his brother, St. Crispinian, were the patron saints of shoemakers. in this world! The price, in shops here, for this Article, rough but firm and ready, is from 2/6 to 4/6: a pair made to order, in every respect neat and perfect (except that the wretch for neatness had made them too tight) were charged me 7/6 or 7/,—while Nib’s modest demand is £1. 6. 0; the price of a pair of Hessian Boots!— Never mind the beggarly Son of Beelzebub; only be careful always to know his price beforehand.— I am still wearing the old 7/6 snow-boots, as being used to them; but the others will fit too, so soon as I like to apply and break them in.

I have written nothing to you all this while,—in good part because I had nothing comfortable to write. My talent of sleep had quite left me; ever since I left Annandale and before, my bother abt sleep has been very great! Yet I always thot, and think, it is not anything peculiar “in the head,“ but only my old friend the liver getting out of all patience from bad usage. Thank God, that does, at long last, begin to seem really possible or probable! Last night,
for the first time since quitting Thurso, I have had a good sleep all in one piece: I tremblingly hope this may continue so; for it is the lifeboat in my present sore adventure! Other things are all well; I am better than usual; my Book fairly in motion, &c &c if only this old TabernacleThe human body as the temporary abode of the soul. hold out a little. Blessings to you all. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRU], 29 Oct. MS: Yale. Pbd: Wilson, Carlyle 5:406–7; Cate 89–90. Quot: English Illustrated Magazine (Nov. 1891) 9:105–6; E. T. Cook, Life of John Ruskin (1911) 2:8–9; TLS (16 May 1935) 313.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: You go down thro’ those unfortunate Dismal-ScienceTC’s derogatory term for political economy; see “Occasional Discourse on the Negro Question“ (1849) (Works 29:354). people, like a Treble-x of Senna, Glauber and Aloes;Popular purgatives. like a fit of British Cholera,—threatening to be fatal! I have read your PaperRuskin had sent TC an advance copy of “Ad Valorem,“ the fourth of his essays being pbd. in the Cornhill Magazine. They were collected as Unto This Last (1862). with exhilaration, exultation, often with laughter, with “Bravissimo!“— Such a thing flung suddenly into half a million dull British heads on the same day, will do a great deal of good.Very few people agreed with TC; Ruskin’s essays were greeted with such hostility that the Cornhill refused to publish any more. In the preface to Munera Pulveris (1872), Ruskin’s second series of essays on political economy, he wrote: “The editor of the Magazine [Thackeray] was my friend, and ventured the insertion of the three first essays; but the outcry against them became then too strong for any editor to endure, and he wrote to me, with great discomfort to himself, and many apologies to me, that the Magazine must only admit one Economical Essay more“ (xxii). The hostile comments included one from the Saturday Review, 10 Nov.: “the way in which [Ruskin] writes of the relations of the rich and poor is worse than ridiculous. It is positively wicked, for it can produce amongst the poor nothing else than bitter and causeless hatred“ (583). Ruskin was personally devastated by the harsh response to his essays. He wrote to Charles Eliot Norton, 4 Nov.: “I am resting now, and find myself in a general state of collapse. I hate the sight of pen and paper, and can’t write so much as a note without an effort. I don’t think about anything, and feel consequently like Nothing,—my chief sense of existence lately having been in thinking or trying to think. … When I begin to think at all, I get into states of disgust and fury at the way the mob is going on (meaning by mob, chiefly Dukes, Crown Princes, and such like persons) that I choke“ (Cook, The Life of Ruskin 2:10).

I marvel, in parts, at the lynx-eyed sharpness of yr logic, at the pincer-grip (red-hot pincers) you take of certain bloated cheeks and blown-up bellies:—more power to yr elbow (tho’ it is cruel in the extreme)! If you chose to stand
to that kind of work for the next 7 years, and work out there a result like what you have done in Painting: yes, there were a “something to do,“—not easily measurable in importance to these sunk ages.— Meantime my joy is great to find myself henceforth in a minority of two at any rate!—

The Dismal-Science people will object that their science expressly abstracts itself from moralities, from &c &c: but what you say, and show, is incontrovertibly true, That no “Science“ worthy of men (and not worthier of dogs or of devils) has a right to call itself “Political Economy,“ or can exist at all except mainly as a fetid nuisance and public poison, on other terms than those you now shadow out to it for the first time.One of Ruskin’s chief targets in the essay was John Stuart Mill; Ruskin argued that the word “value,“ which Mill saw as “a relative term“ (Mill, Principles of Political Economy [1848] 1:584), subject to laws of supply and demand and devoid of morality, derived from the same root as “valour,“ defined by Ruskin as strength in life: “a truly valuable … thing … which leads to life with its whole strength. … The value of a thing, therefore, is independent of opinion, and of quantity. … For ever it avails, or avails not“ (Ruskin, Unto This Last [1862] 118–19). Without mentioning Mill by name, TC apparently welcomed Ruskin’s attacks on Mill’s ideas; having shared many ideas in the 1830s, such as Saint-Simonianism (see JWC to Lady ALAI, 24 Oct.), Mill and TC were increasingly out of sympathy with each other.

On yr last page, and never till then, I pause slightly, not too sorrowfully, and appeal to a time coming. Noble is the spirit there too, my friend; but alas it is not Philanthropisms that will do then,—it is Rhadamanthisms (I sorrowfully see) whh are yet at a very great distance!Ruskin argued that while many in the world continue to suffer poverty and deprivation, “luxury at present can only be enjoyed by the ignorant; the cruelest man living could not sit at his feast, unless he sat blindfold“; he appealed to man’s compassion for his fellow man. TC had a greater faith in the stern lawgiver epitomized by Rhadamanthus, than in what he saw as misguided philanthropy; see “Model Prisons“ (1850), Works 20:48–86. In Greek mythology, Rhadamanthus was a just but stern king who became one of the judges of the underworld. Go on and prosper. I am yours always (sleeping a little better, & hoping an evng soon) T. CarlyleRuskin wrote in the dedication to Munera Pulveris (1872): “Let me inscribe [this volume] to the friend and guide who has urged me to all chief labour, Thomas Carlyle“ (xxvi).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 29 Oct. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: I rode thro’ Montague Square yesterday; but No 46 still locked in dark slumber, the soul of 46 still wandering in the Country.

I have had a baddish time since you heard last; but hope I am now getting round a little. I am in the hideous Insolubility of a ms whh you know so well; the very sight of whh makes me shudder!The MS of bk. 13 of Frederick. Forster often read TC’s drafts; see 36:189TC to JWC, 21 Aug. A small questn about that is what makes me write a word a[t] prest.

Did you or did you not (I think you did) speak to me abt a Mayor of Landshuts Speech and Installatn? I cannot find that Piece;—do you remember whereabout it lay at all?Chap. 6 of bk. 13 is entitled “New Mayor of Landshut makes an Installation Speech“; see Works 15:276–81. TC cited Helden-, Staats-, und Lebens-Geschichte des aller-durch-lauchtigsten und grossmächtigsten Fürsten und Herrns, Friedrichs des Andern, 11 vols. (Frankfurt, 1758–64) 2:416–22. TC’s copy: HCC; see 33:22TC to KAVE, 12 Aug. 1857. I have not yet looked much;—and indeed I fly nearly mad (or tend to do so) when I get upon that thrice beautiful portion of my employment!

In another place, I see a fascicle beginning with ‘p. 2’, and no p. 1 discoverable. Perhaps it ought to be so?— Neuberg has not yet been called in; but [is] to be, on Tuesday; the great likelihood is he knows his way throughout. But I wanted first to hear you say you had at least found nothing wanting in the sad Farrago, and had read the Landshut affair.
Adieu dear F.; if I live to get thro’ this Red Sea of Pharaoh,Exod. 14:16–29. what a blessed meeting we two will again have on the other side! But alas, alas—
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL[DLI], 30 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. David Little (ca. 1788–1866), miller of Satur Mill, Dumfriesshire, about 2 mi. (3 km.) E of Ecclefechan. That TC wrote “Memorandum for Mr Little / Satter Mill,“ on the reverse of the letter suggests, the note was probably enclosed with a letter to one of TC’s relatives.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LITTLE

docBody.p: Revd Thomas Wilson 13. St James’s Street, Gray’s Inn LondonThe 1860 London post office directory listed Mrs. Frances Douglas, silversmith, living at this address; perhaps Thomas Wilson was lodging with her. By June 1861 he lived in Blackheath; see TC to JAC, 2 June 1861.
Wants 8 stone of the best Oatmeal, from Mr Little, Miller, Satter,—so soon as convenient; Account to be sent to Mr Wilson, as above whenever the meal is booked in the railway. Payment assured.
(Chelsea 30 Octr 1860) T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WD[WDO], [31 Oct.?]. MS: NLS 1797.199. Hitherto unpbd. Dated before the return of Charlotte Southam, mid-Nov. (see JWC to ETW, [17 Nov.]) and while Sarah Piggott was still “the new girl.“
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p: This isn’t the first letter I have written you, since I received yours, with the plants.JWC had asked Dods to send her a hawthorn seedling and some other hardy plant from the garden of Sunny Bank (Tenterfield); see D, JWC to WDWDO, [6 and 7? Oct.]. I have written you several—in my head—while sitting alone here—looking into the fire! That is the sort of letter-writing that suits me best; only, that it brings no answers! and such good letters one writes in one’s head! emancipated from all considerations of grammar, and spelling, and pens, and formalities! Pity you couldn’t have had one of them daguerrotypedJWC was regretting that thought processes could not be transferred to paper by a technique similar to Daguerre’s photographic process; for Louis-Jacques-Mandé Da-guerre, see 35:237–38JWC to SS, 21 Oct. 1859. by the fire-light—just for a sample!—

Now however it is isRepeated by JWC. full time to write on paper,—under the usual conditions of human correspondence;—full time, by the moral clock I have set up for myself,—as a check on the impetuosity and irregularity of my natural woman! ‘Festina lente [Make haste slowly]’ has been inculcated on me by People and Things, till I have actually come to do it to a certain extent—with inward protest and appeal to Posterity!— Oh dear yes! it was the first lesson Mr C tried to drive into me; and within a year of my marriage, I had it engraved—not on my heartMary I of England, Wales, and Ireland (1516–58; ODNB) supposedly said that “Ca-lais“ would be engraved on her heart because of the loss of that city to the French, Jan. 1558. certainly; but—on my seal! in German; “Ohne Hast aber ohne Rast“ (without haste and without rest). For emblem; a Star encircled by the Serpent of Eternity!!!In Aug. 1831, five years after their marriage, TC had the seal made for JWC; see 5:353TC to JWC, 22 Aug. 1831; for its impression, see Ritchie 192. It was a copy of the seal that he and others had sent to Goethe for his 82d birthday, 28 Aug. 1831; see 5:305–308FEF to G, 17 July 1831. The quotation is from Goethe; for TC’s trans., see Works 27:432. Therein conforming to a rule which I have since observed to be a general one in this strange world; that of (literally and figuratively) taking for one’s motto exactly the quality one is most deficient in! The greatest Liars for example invariably sealing with “Truth“—the greatest Flirts with two Birds tied by the leg with a mutual string, and the words “The further apart the closer drawn“ or some such nonsense to denote Constancy!—and so on, ad Infinitum!— But I don’t pretend to have discovered
this principle in Human Nature! It was but appending a corollary to the Proposition set down in a Book by a wise German author; “If you wish to know a man’s besetting vice; listen for that which he most rails against“!!Unidentified.

In the meantime, 100,000 thanks to you and your wife, for taking usThe photographs of JWC and TC; see JWC to WDWDO, [6 and 7? Oct.]. away and giving us honourable shelter! And also, please to thank Mr FermeJohn Ferme (b. ca. 1797); see 32:24932:biographical note. in my name. It is not the first time Mr Ferme has exercised a beneficial influence on my Fortunes! It was to him, in his “little Dohey“Possibly a child’s pronunciation of John. phase, that I was indebted for having the measles, and the hooping cough, and the mumps, and every disease that human child is ‘heir to,’Cf. Hamlet 3:1. all in “a mild form“ and at “a favourable season“! He was the best child for “taking“ things in “a mild form,“ and timing them favourably, that ever I heard of! so that there was never the least restriction put on my playing with “Dohey Ferme,“ all thro’ his successive natural maladies and “catching“ them from ‘him’ if I liked!!—And now,—after more than half a Century,—here has the same individual Dohey saved me from the indignity of being sold by auction! from a winding up of my concerns at Sunny Bank, which would have been most unnatural and shocking! Don’t you think so? Fancy the dear old Ladies seeing, from where they are now,Jean and Jess Donaldson had d. in March and June 1860 respectively. those portraits they had prized so highly, knocked down to the highest bidder—(even tho’ yourself)! Would it not have gone to their hearts (one fancies) even there—“where the wicked cease from troubling and the weary are at rest“!Cf. Job 3:17.

Any how, it was a monstrous impiety on the part of these Craven Hill Donaldsons, to put such a slight on the Life-long affection of their dead aunts for me and mine! Not that I would have had them keep the pictures to themselves, who cared nothing about them; but it would have been so easy to give them away! knowing, as they did, several people at Haddington who would have been pleased to have them. my illigitimate Cousin,John Amelia (“Jackie“) Welsh. for example—to look no higher!— It was the idea of making a shilling or two by exposing the things for sale that I find so revolting—worse even than taking possession of the shawl and brooch.

The course to be adopted with such people is to avoid and forget them. Which course I was pursuing without hindrance; when two or three weeks ago, there arrived a note from Mrs George Donaldson,Emma, wife of George Hay Donaldson and sister-in-law of Eliza Donaldson. and two days after
Miss Eliza called with a “cousin“;Cousin not further identified. and in spite of a standing order that I was always to be “not at home“ for the Miss Donaldsons; they were admitted, not being known by sight to the new girlSarah. who opened the door. I had not moral courage enough to send them away, after they were established in the drawingroom; so I compromised the matter, by going to them with bonnet and shawl on, and treating Miss Eliza (who was decked out in the brightest colours!) with marked coldness.— The sister-in-law’s note I laid aside at the time, to show your wife.— Bear in mind that I had seen this woman just twice in my life; that she knows nothing whatever, from me, of my relations with the Ashburtons; and that her “friend Mrs Shetky“Unidentified, unless possibly “Shetky“ is a mistake for Mrs. Shickle, of 37 Queen’s Gardens, Bayswater, close to the Donaldsons’ home. was a name to which I couldnt possibly attach any idea, hearing it for the first time in my life!— Cool! dont you think? And my answer was cool too! being to the effect that I wouldn’t trouble Lord Ashburton about the Boy MurdochPresumably a relative of Mrs. Shetky; otherwise unidentified. to save the said Boy from perdition! that was the meaning, tho’ expressed in a less concentrated and startling form!— Setting aside my private grounds of discontent with the present family of Donaldsons I have no patience, ever, with that philanthropy which exercises itself at other peoples expence; supposing in every body the same readiness to ask favours which it finds in itself! I could hardly keep from quoting in my answer to Mrs Donaldson, the opening sentence of a charity Sermon once preached by Sidney Smith “Benevolence is a sentiment common to Human Nature! A never sees B in distress, without wishing C to relieve him“!!Sydney Smith (1771–1845; ODNB), author, canon of St. Paul’s 1829–40; see 8:189TC to JAC, 10 Aug. 1835. The quotation is widely attrib. to him, but as a saying, not as part of a sermon; cf. Sayings of Sydney Smith ([1908?]) 10.—
Some of the plants look alive; two of them give no sign—but I am told there is no telling what will live or what die till Spring comes round.

If you are busy; write quite briefly, or make your wife write. I know a man is not always in the humour to write letters, nor has he always leisure for it. And I am more considerate than you perhaps think.
Love to your wife Affectionately yours ever J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CB[CBU], 4 Nov. MS: EUL. Pbd: Southern 272–73 inc. “No 14“ written at the top of the letter, presumably by Butler.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES BUTLER

docBody.p: The day before yesterday, your Letter of October 16, with the Forty-nine Pounds in it, and nothing but good news, came to hand; and was right welcome, as a finis to considerable anxieties (lest something had befallen you, for the rest of the matter was evidently safe sooner or later) which was annoying me from day to day. What has become of the former letterTC expected to hear from Butler in Aug., when his half-yearly interest was due; see 36:79TC to CBU, 28 Feb. I cannot guess; nor is it now of the least moment.

By way of avoiding similar accidents, and ridding my poor mind of money-concerns, whh are eminently unfit for me at the present junction of affairs, I have instructed Mr Robert Adamson,TC wrote the next day; see TC to RA, 5 Nov. of Dumfries N.B (a very punctual good man, Banker and Lawyer, who manages all other such things for me) to put himself into communication with you, and to receive (thro’ safe and ever-flowing channels whh he and his British Linen Company Bank people no doubt have) these half-yearly interests for me, and lock them in their place, direct, witht interference of mine. Whh will be a notable relief to me, and will save you also from a small trouble whh you have never grudged. I have sent Mr Adamson the Original Document (big yellow star of a thing) whh you not long since conveyed to me:The certificate of purchase for $5,000 worth of railway bonds, which Butler had sent TC in Feb.; see 36:79TC to CBU, 28 Feb. this he now holds in keeping, “master of the situation“; and a Letter and Answer between you two, I calculate, will be all that is now needed to wash my inexperienced hands of it for the time coming.

From you personally I shall expect, as heretofore, a little Bulletin once in the six months or so, while we continue both in this world; but our Letters henceforth will need to contain nothing except friendly greetings and the little stock of news we may have amassed from time to time. This (considering what your Correspondent is, in the Ledger departt) will be a real improvet to both of us.

I have also instructed Mr Adamson to send you (on hearing thus will receive it and how) another Thousand Pounds for investment either in that same stock or in any other whh you may think good, on my behalf;—and, I need not doubt, you will be so obliging as exercise again for me your Official judgt on this small matter, and settle it to the best advantage. My own judgt about it may be considered as a minimum or nearly so, and yours as a maximum;
I will therefore leave it wholly in your hands;—Papers &c all to be sent to Adamson, and I to hear nothing about it, except finally that it is properly “fixed“ (in the English and in the New-English sense), and intends to pay its interest with quiet punctuality thro’ Adamson, and give us no farther trouble.— Do all this, Dear Sir, in yr old helpful way; and I shall feel that I am once more not a little obliged to you.

My case here at present is none of the joyfullest,—up to the chin, at all hours, in Prussian rubbish, and for the last year especially often thinking I shd never get out, but that it wd verily be the death of me! For indeed the old Tabernacle repugns agt such treatment:—nevertheless I am at prest a little better; printing my unblessed Book; and do hope, perhaps in abt a year, to get done with it, and come out still alive!

My wife is also very perceptibly better better,Word repeated on turn of page. so far as we are yet gone this winter; let us hope, let us hope, in this “Place of Hope“!See Carlyle, Sartor 121. With many real regards from both of us,— Yours, dear Sir, always T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-RA, 5 Nov. MS: Hornel. Pbd: Southern 273 inc.
div3.head: TC TO ROBERT ADAMSON

docBody.p: Inclosed here, lying in one of those Yellow Covers, is a Draught for Forty-nine Pounds (£49..0..0), which please negociate for me—and put to acct as usual.

Inclosed farther, are Three other Documents; two of whh (those on the English Railway)TC had invested £4,000 in Brighton railway debentures, Nov. 1858; see 35:40–41TC to CBU, 24 Feb. 1859. will require no explanation, but will merely need to be laid by in safe keeping for me, & managed by you as you have been wont;—and the Third of whh (that on the American Railway) will need only these few words: Namely, That I wish you henceforth to draw and reposit for me the interests on that American Bond as you do on the two English; and that I have written to Mr Butler (“Charles Butler Esq, 12. Wall Street New York“) stating that you are my Representative in the matter, and that you will straightway write to him, and settle how the monies are to [be]Word omitted. remitted. The Three Documents will then be all on one footing, safe in your hand; and I shall need no farther trouble with them, I hope, except merely the Bank-Clerk’s Announcement from time to time that the interests come duly in. Please write
to New York accordingly, and settle all that for me,—as well as something more whh I am now to tell you of.

By the same Letter I have written to Mr Butler, requesting that he will invest another Thousand Pounds (transmitting you the Documents, the management &c &c); and bidding him expect the money from you whenever he writes for it. Please therefore to write to him upon this point also; and to take from my Account with you the Thousand Pounds (£1,000..0..0) and send it to Mr Butler for investment as above.Butler enclosed the semiannual interest on TC’s American investments to Adamson, 5 Feb. 1861, and wrote: “Mr. Carlyle … had requested you to make a further remittance to me of 1000£ Stg for his benefit. … I have not received any such remittance and if any has been made it has … miscarried“ (Kimball 290); see TC to CBCBU, 21 Jan. 1861. If this is not sufficient Authority (whh I hope it is) for your sending off said money, I will sign and return anything you send to me to that effect. — — But, if I have made my meaning perfectly intelligible to you, I could like very much to have no (or next to no) writing farther to do on the subject,—being, as you perhaps know, so overwhelmingly occupied with other very different things.

I register this Letter; request you to Acknowledge it; and to gather up into due business form the things I have written, and with your old punctuality and kindness to perform the same. If I could hear at last, “They are all duly done,“ and next to nothing at all in the interim, it wd be the agreeablest way.

My Brother wrote to me abt settlet of Craigenputtock,John A. Carlyle who generally spelled Craigenputtoch with a final “k.“ as you were kind enough to request! It shall, the instant I am free to think abt such things, be put on some deliberate footing: in the mean time we understand that in case both of us were to be called away witht farther writing or settling, Craigenph wd go to the one son of the late Robert Welsh:JWC had inherited Craigenputtoch from her father, John Welsh; Robert was the only surviving son of JWC’s paternal uncle Robert Welsh. is not that so? If that is so, that seems to us,—at least till we get the young man inquired into, or hear something against him,—a conditn in whh the matter may be safely left till we get a little leisure. Many thanks for your kind care in that and other matters.
Much driven for time, I remain

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: TC wrote a check for JWC, 5 Nov.: “To Jane (Pocket money / chiefly for self / £10..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

ps.p: R. Adamson Esq &c &cBrith Ln Cy Bank, Dumfries

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have recd your 3 successive little Notes; whh were very welcome to me, and for whh I am very much obliged. (The last Note had either lost its Stamp, or never had one,—this let me mention too, as nota-bene).

I am very glad to learn that you are taking to yr lodging,At 67 Hanover St., Edinburgh, where John A. Carlyle had been lodging since at least March 1858. and gradually becoming superior to the noises— In a certain state of health they become entirely indifft, sometimes a kind of help to sleep (as, no doubt, you well know), tho’ in other cases they are such an annoyance and even torment! Edinr seems to me always, I know not why, a more natural place for you than London; I mean a pleasanter, as to lodgings &c.

Henry WattOne of John’s stepsons. wrote to James junr of Scotsbrig a distracted rumour he had heard from Mrs FraserPresumably Mrs. William Fraser, an old friend of John’s (see 17:280TC to JC, 21 Feb. 1844, and 17:288JWC to GEJ, 29 Feb. 1844), at whose house in Montpelier Sq., London, he had lodged in 1855 (see 30:73TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1855). of “Jane’s having broken several of her ribs“:JWC had bruised her side and broken a rib at the end of April; see 36:111–12JWC to JAO, 9 May.—have the goodness to contradict this (as James junr requested me to do, and I have not yet had time),—it is mere nonsense, made by the multiplying glass of a bad memory taking the long past as still present after year and day!— We are both tolerably well; better than when you last heard of us, not worse.

My first month here was somewhat ominous: sleep apparently gone again; victory in my poor Enterprize totally hopeless in that case: I am (or shd very much be) grateful to Heaven that there is some considerable change in all this; that (hoffentlich [it is to be hoped]) I am to have a modicum of sleep, and may therefore hope as well as toil.— A violent biliary crisis was at last brot on (by a blue-pill witht Castor); this produced the fine change:—I do not think “regularity“ (whh I am very studious of) &c has much to do with the phenomn;—and I have privately dismissed from my mind the terror of “congestion in the brain“ &c, finding brain & head to be much what they were. RobsonCharles Robson of Robson, Levey & Franklyn. is printing; I am up to the eyes in bother at all moments (as now, near 11 p.m. with Proofs just done),—You will excuse us,“Coterie speech; see 7:199TC to MAC, 30 May 1834. dear Brother. Ruskin came the other night; there is an awful barking abt his Article in Thackeray.Cornhill Magazine, of which Thackeray was the editor; see TC to JRJRU, 29 Oct. Adieu dear Brother; write you who can. Ever yours affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CS[CSTA], 6 Nov. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Charles Stanford (1823–86; ODNB), baptist minister, author of Joseph Alleine: His Companions and His Times; A Memorial of “Black Bartholomew,“ 1662 (1861). Addressee identified on MS in an unknown hand and by the reference to Loss’s book in Stanford’s forthcoming book.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES STANFORD

docBody.p: I am afraid you will have yr difficulties in finding Dr Loss’s Notebook.Friedrich Loss, Observationum Medicinalium (1672). It is certain I never saw it, or heard of it except, transiently tho’ indisputably, in some of those old Books;—and so far as I can now gather the mention of it in iii.15Page reference, 1857 edn. of Cromwell, referring to Dr. Loss; see Works 8:101. must have been got from the Book there referred to, Wood’s AthenaeAnthony à Wood (1632–95; ODNB), antiquary and historian, Athenae Oxonienses (1691–92). (Dr Bliss’s Edition),Philip Bliss (1787–1857; ODNB), antiquary, ed. of 3d edn. of Wood’s Athenae Oxonienses, 4 vols. (1813–20), the edn. that TC used in Cromwell. whh see.

If this is the case, then indisputably the Notebook itself must have been in Antony Wood’s possessn; and, had the accurate Dr Bliss been still alive, he perhaps cd have at once directed you to it; but he is dead, some years ago, and I know not who now stands in his place. It is possible still, or even probable, the Notebook may be in existence somewhere,—among Ay Woods Mss.; whh, I shd guess are in the Bodleian LibraryWood’s MSS and books had been in the Bodleian since 1858; see 29:14TC to UC, 12 Jan. 1854. Loss’s book is listed separately. (well catalogued, or it may be not well). Your own good chance I shd think is, To inquire pointedly there, after looking well into Bliss in the passage referred to.Stanford was writing about Joseph Alleine (bap. 1634–, d. 1668; ODNB), nonconformist minister and devotional writer; it was his contribution to the bicentenary of “Black Bartholomew,“ the Act of Uniformity that took effect on St. Bartholomew’s day, 24 Aug. 1662, when nonconformist ministers were ejected from their livings. He wrote: “There lived at Dorchester, in those days, ‘a very worthy and reverend physician,’ one Dr. Loss, a great helper to the persecuted ministers, whose Latin memoranda respecting them afforded assistance to Antony Wood. Unhappily, that note-book, though much searched for lately, cannot be found. Most likely it contains some account of Mr. Alleine’s last days, for the doctor became his kind friend“ (Stanford 355). Loss’s book does not mention Alleine.
Sorry I can do no more for you, and in much haste,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: TC had received a previous request for this information from an unidentified correspondent; see 29:13–14TC to UC, 12 Jan. 1854.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 6 Nov. MS: NLS 517.8. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Having, what is very rare with me, five odd minutes (literally almost no more), I set down for you a word of intelligence, whh I know will be welcome. Your Note came; thanks for it: you will not be hard with me for returns till the times become a little less stringent, I know! You are all of you very good to me.

We have terribly fierce weather here; loud totally grey wind from the North-East, temperature on the edge of frost. This is not kindly for poor Jane; nor is it for me, tho’ I care less abt weather. I am happy to tell you, nevertheless, we are still in a tolerable way, both of us; Jane sleeping a good deal better than I have seen her do, in sad seasons now past; I too, nothing like so wretched as I was on that head for the first month here,—tho’ unluckily again last night, I slipped stays (owing to accidts of various kinds), and had strictly speaking no sleep at all, tho’ I lay quiet in a kind of dog-sleep for most part, and did not madly rove about in the dark and cold as sometimes. I don’t feel much worse today; and will, of course, do my utmost to get into trim again tonight. Our Printing rolls on, keeping me like a cock on a spit; but it is infinitely comfortable to see pieces of the accursed stuff actually dropping off from me, not to blister my poor skin they again while Time is; this is my chief or one solace in the days that now run, and a precious one it is. If my nervous-system (especially my poor modicum of sleep) will but hold out, I shall finish my Slavery, not dishonourably, after all;—and rest (Oh how I mean to rest) for the remainder of my time!—

The snow-boots I have got well lined with flannel,See 36:7TC to JCA, 13 Nov. 1859. the uppers of them lengthened a bit which were very scanty, the buttons shifted; and I ride with them (fine & handy for that object) in the less cold days. Your old HareskinSee 36:24TC to JCA, 10 [11] Dec. 1859. I nightly wear, with benefit to the “Baltic“ breast,TC refers to the cold he caught after sea-bathing in the Baltic at Rügen; see TC to JCA, 17 Oct. 1861. —whh is again sensible, tho’ very slightly. Three Nightshirts, my thickest, are of your making; and these I have set apart for exclusive use, since this weather came.— Thanks to you all, blessings to you all: here is the hour come, & more.— Your ever affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 Nov. MS: NLS 525.70. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Tho’ accidentally in very bad fettle today, and with time quite gone to a few minutes, I send you half a word.

In general I am doing better than a month ago; and have hopes abt finishing my sad Problem one day. The Printer goes leisurely, but never stops; he has now finished fairly to p. 160,—whh is perhaps not the 8th part of the whole:—the one comfort possible, and it is really an invaluable one, is to see the ugly mass diminishing; to think, “I have done with you to all eternity!“—were the “you“ only a few pages of print.— I sleep still rather badly; but not by any means so badly as for a month after my return. In short you may fancy me puddling and pluistering along, on painful enough terms, but need not bother your imaginatn with fears abt me, more than usual. I have still probably a bit of strength in me; fit to hold out for the months ahead, tough as they are like to be.

The house is visibly more trim and comfortably kept since we had two servants: Jane keeps tolerably well, whh is a great point. My horse is vigorous beyond wont, the weather very cold, but dry, sometimes clear, and good for the season we have reached. Last night (owing to urgency of the friendly Forster) we went to dine with him (no avoiding it,—and this is the chief cause of my ill fettle; some burbles of Neuberg’s “revisal of Book XII,“Bk. 12 of Frederick. revisal worse than nothing, whh have wasted my time, are another!) Dickens with daughtersCharles Dickens and his das., Mary and Kate. &c was at Fuz’s; evening not unpleasant, tho’ far from salutary, or even happy at the time (in one’s secret heart).— — Adieu dear Brother, I have to break off thus abruptly.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 17 Nov. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 17 Nov. 1860. MS: NLS 553.226. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Let us see you Tomorrow Evg, if you can,—since we missed yesterday. Up to the nose in rubbish
docBody.name: T.C. (Novr 17th, 1860)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-ET[ETW], [17 Nov.]. MS: Harvard. Dated by Ellen Twisleton’s letters and by the return of Charlotte Southam mid-Nov.; see JWC to MW, 8 Dec.
div3.head: JWC TO ELLEN TWISLETON

docBody.p: How nice! and how odd! I dont mean the cream but the transaction! tho’ the cream too is nice!

Certainly you do little gallantries which no other woman here but yourself is up to! Who but yourself, of all my London acquaintance, would have imagined, when confined to the house, and worried with a hacking cough,—“in the gloomy month of November“ too, “when (according to the French Novelist) the people of England hang and drown themselves“Coterie speech; Voltaire (1694–1778) cited an unnamed doctor in London as his source; see 30:119TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1855. Joseph Addison (1672–1719; ODNB) recorded an early version in the Spectator: “A celebrated French Novelist, in opposition to those who begin their Romances with the flow’ry Season of the Year, enters on his Story thus: In the gloomy Month of November, when the People of England hang and drown themselves, a disconsolate Lover walked out into the Fields, &c.“ (Spectator, 24 May 1712); French novelist unidentified.—would have imagined to pleasantly surprise and cheer up a fellow-creature with pink cream?!— Bringing a suggestion of—what shall I say?Coterie speech, Mazzini’s expression; see 17:36JWC to TC, 11 Aug. 1843.—Arcadia(!) from the resources of London cookery to beguile one into not “hanging or drowning“ oneself for some days longer!— Oh you Dear!

I had meant, independently of the pink cream, to go, this day, to inquire for you and see you, if permitted— But what is the use of meaning anything in “the gloomy month of November; unless to hang or drown oneself? Such a day!— But Mr C says “if it keeps up overhead“ (whatever that may mean) he “will walk up and see if it is possible to get a glimpse of you both, again,“ this evening. To tell you a secret; Mr C always talks of your goings away and stayings away so many months together as if it were a personal slight—to him!In a letter to one of her sisters, 10 Nov., Ellen Twisleton implied that she had recently returned to London and wrote that her husband, Edward, called on the Carlyles about 9 Nov. (Twisleton, Letters 299).
I have a gloomy presentiment that some dreadful Bore will drop in to tea, and hinder him! In which case I must just send this note,—meant for him to take,—by post.

My little Charlotte is come back, and dancing about the House like a burst of living sunshine! It is a sight to see—the happiness of that girl! And already
she has quite humanized my young Housemaid!Sarah Piggott.—and the House no longer feels to me a Lodginghouse, but Home again! To say nothing of the “Bread-puddings“ being unsurpassable!
God bless you Darling—
I hope to see you very soonJWC visited Ellen Twisleton by 24 Nov. (Twisleton, Letters 300).
docBody.name: Jane Baillie Welsh Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LS], 19 Nov. MS: NLS 19.3.52.16. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: When you said “Friday“ to me this afternoon, I had a kind of misgiving; and before getting to the bottom of the stairs, it had become clear to me that I was already engaged for Friday,— Two Literary Persons coming to tea with me (one of them a lion, John Ruffini,Giovanni Domenico Ruffini (1807–81), formerly a member of Mazzini’s Young Italy movement; he lived in England, 1837–41, and had been particularly fond of JWC; see 13:67–68JWC to MSC, 25 March 1841. He returned to Italy in 1848, became Sardinian ambassador in France in 1849, and from 1850 lived variously in England, France, and Italy. The other “Literary Person“ is unidentified. Italian by nation, whose NovelPresumably Lavinia (1860), reviewed in the Athenaeum 8 Dec.; he pbd. various works in English, 1853–72. you will be reading soon, whom I have not seen for many years)!
This is the adventure destined to me, then, for “Friday night“;—by no means so agreeable a one, as that other you proposed! You may pity me, if you like:—nobody can escape his fate

Pray offer my respects to Lord Lothian,William Schomberg Robert Kerr (1832–70), 8th marquess of Lothian, a noted bibliophile; he was ill for much of his life. TC was to become friendly with him. too; and say, what is very true if it were important, that I am heartily sorry at missing the pleasure I had anticipated.

I came home, muddier even than when you saw me;—thro’ deluges of rain rattling on my Mackintosh & wide-awakeA wide-brimmed, low-crowned felt hat, which TC always wore (see 34:50JWC to TC, 16 July 1858); according to the Oxford English Dictionary, it was named from a punning reference to the felt having no “nap.“ all the way;—but, except for this bit of bad news, consider myself improved by the operation.
Keep well within doors, you, till the weather dry!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 19 Nov. MS: NLS 517.9. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:208–10 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Your Note shd have been answered before now: but, alas, you know how I am bothered;John A.
