Carlyle replied, 22 Nov.: “I am always glad to have a letter from you, but I by no means expect you to answer every one I write to you, pestered as you are with other work.“—and indeed there is generally almost nothing that I can tell you, if it be not how my health stands. That I ought to do, especially if the bulletin is not unfavourable,—as is the case in this present instance.

The inclosed Letter came last night late (from some Merchant, I think, who had sent it to Chapman, there being no Address on it but “London“):—it is from “Dushtie“;Baron Charles d’Eichthal had first visited the Carlyles in Dec. 1835 (see 8:277TC to MAC, 24 Dec. 1835) and again in June 1851 (see 26:91–92TC to JAC, 17 June 1851). “Dushtie“ was possibly a mispronunciation of d’Eichthal’s name by the Carlyles’ servant at the time, Anne Cook (see 8:228TC to JWC, 19 Oct. 1835). Charles d’Eichthal was the cousin of Gustave d’Eichthal, who had introduced the Carlyles to Saint-Simonianism; see JWC to Lady ALAI, 24 Oct. John A. Carlyle lived with the d’Eichthal family in Munich, 1827–28; see 5:277TC to GE, 17 May 1831. For the d’Eichthal family, see 5:134TC to GE, 9 Aug. 1830. who but recollects poor Dushtie!Charles d’Eichthal wrote, 12 Nov.: “You will be surprised after 24 years lapse to hear from me & to get a letter from a person you have perhaps forgotten. / I have not forgotten you & Mrs Carlyle I have frequently remembered your great kindness towards me / I have read a week ago your books & an article about your excellent writings & I have decided ex-pressing to yourself all my admiration.— / I have been poorly for the last 5 months. … / … Now I begin to be in better health—but not restaured!“— Parts of it in cursiv-schrift I have not yet got time to decipher: if when you have done with it, you wd write above the cursiv what the common-alphabetical equivalent is,German system of orthography, now largely obsolete; however, none of d’Eichthal’s letter is written in cursive script; most of it is in English, and the two German phrases are written in the same script. John wrote out the German words in pencil on the letter and in neat writing on a separate piece of paper. you might stick it into the first Envelope that is coming, for my use. At any rate pray write a word to München on my behoof and your own;Charles d’Eichthal continued: “Pray tell me, Dear Sir, where is Dr Carlyle your brother & shall we never see him again here? Pray tell him all our compts & that I should so like to hear from him?“ John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 22 Nov., that he sent d’Eichthal “a brief letter by this day’s post, knowing that it will be a comfort to him.“ and make my due compliments &c there; adding, if you like, what my address is: the old place whh Dushtie knew.Charles d’Eichthal had visited the Carlyles in Cheyne Row but perhaps had not realized that they still lived at the same address.

I was glad to hear anything definite of poor Dr Irving’s Son, whom I remember as a lad, but had never heard the ulterior of;TC is probably referring to David Irving’s eldest son, Robert, now dead. TC knew Irving in the 1820s and early 1830s when he was librarian of the Advocates Lib., Edinburgh. John A. Carlyle wrote, 22 Nov.: “Mr Constable called after your letter came, & from him I learnt that only the youngest of Dr Irving’s sons, named James, is now living—youngest by the second marriage. He is at Allahabad, is rather more than thirty years of age, was married to a Miss Fraser about six years ago, & is a Surgeon by profession. The old doctor’s second wife & one daughter are living somewhere in Edinr; & it is they with the son in India who desire to get the History published. The MS has been sent to Macmillan of Cambridge, to see whether he can undertake the publication.“ Irving’s 2d wife and da. were both called Janet.—I hope Constable
may publish the History of Scottish PoetryDavid Irving’s The History of Scotish Poetry (Edinburgh, 1861) had been begun in the 1820s; it was ed. and completed by John A. Carlyle and pbd. by Thomas Constable (1812–81; ODNB). John A. Carlyle explained in his preface: “As to the Editorship, since no one else was ready to undertake it, I consented—chiefly from love of the subject and respect for the memory of the Author—to superintend the last proofsheets, and very speedily got more deeply entangled in the business“ (v). you speak of; whh is likely to be of use in that department. The qualities you recognise in it are much what I shd have expected: the hard gritty Doctor was a solid man; whose information was apt to be good, where he pretended to have any. Now that I remember, I will ask you to give LaingDavid Laing wrote a memorial preface to The History of Scotish Poetry. my compliments; he too is a man of some worth in his province. We got a Book (one of the many Books, I think it is Boswell’s) on The Douglas Cause,James Boswell, The Essence of the Douglas Cause (1767). not long since; and were reading it: I wonder if the Signet LibraryThe Signet Library, founded 1722, is owned by the Society of Writers to her Majesty’s Signet, the professional body of Scottish solicitors; Laing was its librarian from 1837 until his death in 1878. (shd one survive, and have liberty to read for amusement!) has got all the Books on that Douglas Cause? This of Boswell’s, whh is merely the spoken opinions of all the Judges leaves one quite in doubt as to the Yes or No of Spurious Birth. But another Book, a Pamphlet whh GilchristAlexander Gilchrist. lent me, consisting of Letters from Lady Jane (the professed Mother) to her Husband, many of them dated “Chelsea,“ and nearly all addressed to ‘The Rules of the King’s Bench Prison,“—nearly altogether convinced me that spuriousness was inconceivable, on the part of two such persons, especially on her part;Lady Jane Stewart, Letters of the Right Honourable Lady Jane Douglas (1767). In opposition to the wishes of her brother, Archibald Douglas (ca. 1694–1761; ODNB), 3d marquess and 1st duke of Douglas, Lady Jane Douglas (1698–1753; ODNB), m., 1746, Col. John Steuart of Grandtully (1687–1764), and fled to the Continent with him; in 1748 she gave birth to twin sons, Archibald James Edward (1748–1827) and Sholto Thomas (1748–53). Almost immediately rumors began to circulate that she was not the children’s mother and that the babies had been acquired so they could stand as heirs to the Douglas estates. Her brother refused to see her or to give her any money, so she appealed to George II, who granted her an annual pension of £300. Meanwhile Steuart had been incarcerated in the King’s Bench prison for debt. After the duke’s death, his nephew Archibald’s claim to the Douglas estates was contested on behalf of James George Hamilton (1755–69), 7th duke of Hamilton, the closest male heir, who inherited the Douglas title. The case went before the Scottish Law courts, 1762–67, resulting in a decision against Archibald; he subsequently appealed to the House of Lords, and the decision was reversed in 1769, Archibald being declared the rightful heir to the Douglas estates.
and have left with me the notion of looking into “ the 1200 Quarto pages“ of Evidence, some day when I can lay hold of that Publication, and have time for such a recreation,—alas!John A. Carlyle replied, 22 Nov.: “I gave your message to Laing at the Signet Library. All the documents, he says, respecting the Douglas case are in the library & may amount to even more than 1200 quarto pages. Would that you were free even now to look into them!“

Our printing goes on here, and my writing, and puddling and jumbling with intent to write (one of the horriblest operatns ever known): we do not stop; but our rate is very slow. It is only a week ago that Book 2d (Book XIIBk. 12, “The First Silesian War … Begins,“ was the 2d bk. in vol. 3 of the 1st edn. of Frederick; see Works 15:1–198. properly) was fairly got into; and of it nothing at all is yet quite done. If my sleeping talent, or some other indispensable one, do not quite desert me, I do count on holding on till finis; and seldom fall into the desperate view of things. My head keeps sounding many tunes; continually at it, sometimes loud as a pair of bagpipes, sometimes low and more melodious like the gush of infinite waters thro’ an infinite colander:John A. Carlyle replied, 22 Nov.: “one hopes they may only be symptoms of indigestion, though very uncomfortable ones.“ but the dirty topheavy feeling, whh was attended with pain if I trotted, or otherwise shook my poor head, is pretty much, and sometimes nearly altogether, away; and, in a divided manner (cut in four, for most part) I generally get an allowance of sleep that is tolerable hitherto. Stand to it: wir heissen Euch hoffen [we command you to hope]!—

I have written to Adamson about CraigenputtochSee TC to RA, 5 Nov. and what you said. At the end of us both, it wd go, as things now stand, to a Son of Robt Welsh’s; whom Jane knows to exist (some kind of Engineer, she thinks), but does not know the character of: I told Adamson that, if such was the purport of the Papers he held, we wd let them stay so till this hurry of mine passed, when that and other kindred matter shd all be deliberately settled, as our hope was. As he answers nothing on that point, I take his silence to mean assent as to the significance of those Documents; and so it may rest for a while. I have sent Adamson my American &c Bonds; he is to receive the dividends all & sundry henceforth, & deliver me from bother.
Enough, dear Brother; I am writing upstairs here, heated mainly by wool (not so cold a night as some lately have been); and may as well end. Yours ever
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [21 Nov.]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 21 Nov. 1860. MS: NLS 553.227. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I think you must have got the Buch für Jedermann [Book for everybody]Johann Preuss, Die Lebensgeschichte des grossen Königs Friedrich von Preussen. Ein Buch für Jedermann (Berlin, 1837); see 36:51TC to JF, 24 Jan. (to whh one of yr Notes refers me here, “p. 100 vol i, abt the Opera“):The opening of Frederick’s new opera house in Berlin, Dec. 1742; see Works 15:366–67. pray let me have it again,—sorrow on it, and on the Opera!
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TW[TWO], [22 Nov.]. Pbd: Woolner 201–2; Bliss, JWC 285–86 inc. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 255.
div3.head: JWC TO THOMAS WOOLNER

docBody.p:
I can’t make up my mind yet which of the Photographs I like best. The little one is the most characteristic; exactly the attitude in which you stand on our hearthrug! But the larger one will be best for hanging on a wall. So I mean to frame both, the little one alongside of Kate Stanley. I will ask the immortal Mr. Tait,Robert Tait, painter and photographer. the first time I can get up the steam to go to his house, if he have an unspoiled copy of Lady A.Probably Lady Louisa Ashburton. I was vexed, after promising you one, to have none better than that to give you. I am sorry for your cat’s Influenza (It is a clear case of Influenza!) but it would have been worse if she had given way to passion, as her mother has just done, and done no end of mischief in attempting a great crime! For several days there had been that in her eyes when raised to my canary,Kate Stanley had given JWC a canary when she left Alderley after visiting in August; see 36:214–15JWC to LST, 30 Aug., and 225JWC to KST, 5 Sept. which filled my heart with alarm. I sent express for a carpenter, and had the cage attached to the drawing-room ceiling, with an elaborate apparatus of chain and pulley and weight. “Most expensive!“ (as my Scotch servant exclaimed with clasped hands over a Picture of the Virgin and Child in the National Gallery!)Coterie speech; phrase of Helen Mitchell, servant at Cheyne Row Dec. 1837–Nov. 1846 and Oct. 1848–Feb. 1849. For JWC and Helen’s visit to the National Gallery in April 1841, see 13:101–2JWC to TC, 15 April 1841. JWC also quoted Helen as approving “a Lady in black with a baby in her lap“ (13:102). There were at least nine paintings of the Virgin and Child in the National Gallery in 1841; Helen possibly saw one acquired that year, The Virgin and Child with Saint Anne and Other Saints by Francesco Francia (1450–ca. 1517), which shows the baby on Mary’s lap, reaching toward Saint Anne, who is dressed in black. and there had it swung for two days, to
Mr. C.’s intense disgust, who regards thy pet as “the most inanely chimerical of all“—the cat meanwhile spending all its spare time in gazing up at the bird with eyes aflame! But it was safe now—I thought! and went out for a walk. On my return Charlotte met me with “Oh! whatever do you think the cat has gone and done?“ “Eaten my canary?“— “No, far worse!—pulled down the cage and the weight, and broke the chain and upset the little table and broken everything on it!“— “And not eaten the canary?“— “Oh, I suppose the dreadful crash she made frightened herself; for I met her running down stairs as I ran up—tho’ the cage was on the floor, and the door open and the canary in such a way!“ You never saw such a scene of devastation. The carpet was covered with fragments of a pretty terra cotta basket given me by Lady Airlie—and fragments of the glass which covered it, and with the earth and ferns that had been growing in it and with birdseed, and bits of brass chain, and I can’t tell what all! That is what one gets by breeding up a cat!— She had rushed right out at the back door and didn’t show her face for twenty-four hours after!— And now I don’t know where the poor bird will be safe. Come soon.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 28 Nov. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—There was something you got to copy whh we called The Dodge of a certain English Admiral agt the Spaniards.Probably referring to Admiral Nicholas Haddock (1685?–1746; ODNB) and his command of the British fleet during its blockade of Cadiz, Oct. 1741; the fleet left, pretending they were going for a refit, allowing the Spanish fleet to sail out and attack the Milanese, who were thus compelled to resist and so ally themselves to Britain and Austria; TC described Haddock’s removal of the British fleet as a “Machiavellian stroke of Art“; see Works 15:383–85. I hope you still have it; for yesterday when much in want of it, I cannot find it here at all!— — The little Dictionary wd also be welcome; but there is no such hurry about that. Yours ever / T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HT, 28 Nov. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY TAYLOR

docBody.p: The man’s name, I think, is MacDougal;D. McDougal, pipemaker in Glasgow; see 32:155TC to JA, 29 May 1857. Henry Taylor had been very ill with asthma in 1859; he cured it by smoking tobacco: “It was … a case of singular severity in the disease; and … nothing could seem more strange than that, with the use of a few cigarettes, it should all go off in smoke!“ (Henry Taylor, Autobiography of Henry Taylor 1800–1875, 2 vols. [1885] 2:152). By the end of 1861 he was “smok[ing] tobacco or stramonium, or both, three times in the day and twice in the night“ (Taylor, Autobiography 2:166). See also TC to [H]HT, 20 Dec.—but that is perhaps not quite the cause of the delay.

A gross (144 of these Pipes) costs only 3/6; better we shd send for 3 or 4 gross,—whh saves carriage. Wait a little (send to me for a farther supply if you fail):—I will get a certain (middleman’s)Unidentified. Address at Glasgow; a[nd] your Pipes shall come to East-SheenSuburb of Richmond, where the Taylors had lived since 1853. without farther trouble to you.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

ps.p: Give the man a fortnight or so; he sends by sea. I write off instantly now

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MS, [late Nov.]. Pbd: Mary Smith, The Autobiography of Mary Smith, Schoolmistress and Nonconformist (1892) 1:313–14. Dated by Smith’s letter to JWC, 17 Nov., JWC’s reference to Nov., and her admission that she had not replied immediately. Mary Smith (1822–89; ODNB), schoolmistress and writer, had corresponded with JWC since 1854; see JWC to MS, 16 Jan. 1854. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 29 November 1860.]
div3.head: JWC TO MARY SMITH

docBody.p:
The pleasant surprise of your letter and bookMary Smith wrote, 17 Nov.: “Having taken the liberty of dedicating my Poems which are just Published to you I thought I ought to send you a copy and have accordingly done so by the post which brings this.“ Smith’s book was pbd. as Poems by M.S. (1860). was enhanced for me by a coincidence really very curious! Only a few minutes before the postmanJohn Bullock. left them, I had said to my husband as we sat at breakfast: “I wonder what Miss Smith is about? I have heard nothing from her since I saw her in Carlisle more than two years ago!“JWC had written about the possibility of meeting in Carlisle, Aug. 1858 (34:149JWC to MS, 19 Aug. [1858]), but her very full account of her journey (34:163–65JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1858]) does not mention any meeting with Smith; this would have been the only possible opportunity for such a meeting.— And even while I spoke the postman had turned
into our street with the letter and book! Was that chance? or magnetism?For JWC’s experience of “magnetism,“ see 18:283–85JWC to JWE, 13 Dec. 1844. or what? Anyhow, it was something out of the jog-trot routine of one’s life, and very acceptable! especially in this, “the gloomy month of November, when the people of England hang and drown themselves,“ (according to the French novelist!).

As for the Dedication;The dedication reads: “To Mrs. Carlyle, Wife of Thomas Carlyle, Esq., of Chelsea, this volume is respectfully inscribed, in remembrance of her goodness, and as a tribute of esteem, by the Author.“ it could not but give me the warmest pleasure, that you should entertain such kind thoughts of me, and own to them before “the public;“ at the same time I underwent a little spasm of what we used to call, when children, “thinking shame!“Coterie speech; see 30:220JWC’s Journal, 21 Nov. 1855. I felt so little deserving of what you say there!

Dear Miss Smith! I have no goodness “to speak of.“Mary Smith wrote, 17 Nov.: “I have no idea at all of my Book being fit reading for one whose literary skill and tastes are as high as yours nor do I wish to trouble you to give any opinion about it as I have no doubt you have little leisure to attend to such troublesome requisitions but I hope from what I already know of you that you will be generous enough to believe that my remembrance of you and acknowledgement in this Public Manner of your goodness is really what it assumes to be—a reality.“ In your intercourse with me, you have not seen me tried. Had you been a stupid, commonplace woman, there is every reason to believe you would have found me impatient, uncivil, sarcastic, anything and everything but good. As it was, I did but gratify myself in entering into correspondence with you—and whatever goodness you have seen in me has been goodness towards myself.

I have delayed writing from day to day in the wish to have “some reasonably good leisure“Coterie speech; see 24:104JWC to TC, 7 July 1849.—that I might first read the book, and write a long letter. But my husband’s friends, “the Destinies,“ alias “the Immortal Gods,“Coterie speech; see 36:214JWC to LST, 30 Aug. have laid their heads together to overwhelm me with little worries, and with what Mr. C. calls “a pressure of things,“Coterie speech; see 33:119TC to EC, 18 Nov. 1857. till I hardly know what I am saying or doing.
You must excuse this scrubby note in the meantime, and perhaps another day, when you are in danger of forgetting me, the long letter will come into your hands.
docBody.name: JANE WELSH CARLYLE.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JS[JMS], [3 Dec.]. Addr: Bath Hotel / Bournemouth. PM: 3 Dec. 1860. MS: NLS 3823.191. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 256 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO JULIA STERLING

docBody.p: My dear kind Julia—There is not a minute of my life just now that KatieKate Ross, Julia Sterling’s sister, had d. 27 Nov. at Bournemouth. Her husband, Alexander Ross, wrote to JWC, 28 Nov.: “From no heart will deeper sympathy be yielded than from yours, in this hour of black desolation. You loved and were loved by her, as You well know. That glimpse we had of You in Brighton was a bit of genuine sunshine, of which my darling often spoke with thankfulness. / We came down here exactly a fortnight ago, yesterday. Katy recovered, wonderfully, from the fatigues of the journey. She got out twice, and was cheered by the warmth, brightness and beauty of the weather and place. My hope, seemingly well-founded, was, that here her long failing strength would come back to her. But it was not to be. On Thursday last She was seized with a sudden prostration of the small amount of energy that still remained. She appeared, however, to rally a little from this attack. But it was only in appearance, and, yesterday about half past 12 in the afternoon, my brave and beautiful one fell asleep. The End was marvellously peaceful. There was not a sigh, not a sign of unrest.“ is out of my head. Her face seems to float between me and every thing I set myself to try and do, or say, or think of! her living face,—as it looked when we parted at Brighton,JWC had visited Kate Ross in early July; see 36:144TC to JAC, 4 July, and 145JWC to CSO, 5 July.—wasted, and wan, and wistful; but with all the old love and truth shining out of it! all the old heroic spirit in it! But the more I see and feel her near me, the less I am disposed to speak about her; Words—the strongest one can seek out of one’s heart—fall so flat and trivial!—a mere mockery of the thoughts and feelings one would express by them.— As you too have experienced!

As for the so-called consolations, which some people would “feel it their duty“ to offer you, and have the face to offer you; I hate the very sound of them! People, who can so much as dream of consoling under a loss like this, have never known a great grief; for the very first lesson real grief teaches, is that “the heart knoweth its own bitterness and the stranger intermeddleth not therewith“!Cf. Prov. 14:10.— Even I, who loved Katie as much as any one unless those of her own blood, and her Husband, could possibly love her, even I should feel it an impertinence to suggest to you and him any ground of comfort in this heavy calamity.

For myself I feel in no haste to be comforted! It has often struck me as the saddest part of our poor human bereavements, that the pain which so identifies itself with the Love, and which feels at first so infinite and eternal, gets blunted, whether we will or no, and finally effaced, by the mere friction of the
Hours! It may take longer or shorter to do it, but if one live long enough it will be done!

I want very much to see you. I feel as if it were a message from Katie I had to give you— Some things she said to me about you at Brighton, to which her death has now given a certain sacredness and authority—so that they look to my imagination almost a message to you from her, beyond the grave; tho’ she did not mean them to be repeated at the time.

Will you come when you return? or shall I go to you—in Russell SquareThe Sterling sisters lived at 5 Russell Sq., London, with Rev. Frederick D. Maurice (1805–72; ODNB, who became their guardian in 1853; see 28:318JWC to KS, 19 Nov. 1853. or where you like?

Tell dear EdwardJulia’s brother Edward Sterling. with my kindest love; I thought it much that he remembered to bid George Cook tell me—at such a moment— Poor Lotta!Julia’s sister Anna Charlotte Sterling; her other trials are not known. She has more than one womans share of trial in this world
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JHB, 4 Dec. MS: NLS 9396.120. Hitherto unpbd. John Hill Burton (1809–81; ODNB), historian, political economist, and journalist; see TC to JHB, 8 Dec. 1854.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN HILL BURTON

docBody.p: I was just about sending off for that Carlyle Autobiography,Alexander Carlyle (1722–1805; ODNB), Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle, Minister of Inveresk, Containing Memorials of the Men and Events of His Time, ed. John H. Burton (Edinburgh, 1860). Inveresk village is about 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SE of Edinburgh. when your Note came, beneficently announcing that there was a Copy under way for me as Gift. The Copy itself arrived last night; and I have spent all my leisure time since in reading at it. I am surely very much obliged, in more senses than one; & must heartily return you thanks for such remembrance of me. Indeed it is beyond dispute the whole world, more especially the Scotish, is your debtor: to secure such a Work (whh might have been burnt by accident any time these four-score years) from the risk of destruction, and print it in a genuine form, was and will long continue a truly meritorious piece of labour. Thanks, in the name of all Scochmen;Thus in MS. in my own name very specially. I had heard of this Piece, as an unattainable desideratum, from boyish days upwards; and now, after half a century, live to sit reading it, much at my ease,—with more entertainment than any Book has given me for a very long while back.

The Narrative is charmingly simple, vigorous, distinct;—the man has a great deal of sharp sense in him; a well-balanced, stout, solid man; very fit for this function, and does it admirably, since he had no other. Long life to the “Jupiter Carlyle“ of Inveresk!Burton quoted Sir Walter Scott’s comment on Alexander Carlyle: “the grandest demigod I ever saw was Dr Carlyle, minister of Musselburgh, commonly called Jupiter Carlyle, from having sat more than once for the king of gods and men to Gavin Hamilton“ (Carlyle, Autobiography 567). Burton thought it an apocryphal story, and there is no record of Alexander Carlyle ever having been painted by Gavin Hamilton (1723–98; ODNB), Scottish neoclassical painter. Inveresk is on the outskirts of Musselburgh.—

I find there is little doubt I may claim to belong to him in remote cousinry,—tho’ I never heard of him in my old circles in that capacity. His birth-parish (Cummertrees,Alexander Carlyle’s father, William Carlyle (1690–1765), was minister of Cummer-trees until 1724. Tre, or Town, of the Kymric, stretching over from Cumberland, in patches, thus far) is contiguous to mine; that “Laird of Bridekirk“ (a most flagrant, thunderous old fellow, whose renown is not yet dead in those parts,—tho’ his Brandy-bottle Spouse’s is)Adam Carlyle (d. 1734), laird of Bridekirk, a descendant of the Lords Carlyle of Torthorwald. Alexander Carlyle described his tour of Dumfriesshire with his father, summer 1733: “Among the places we visited was Bridekirk, the seat of the eldest cadet of Lord Carlyle’s family, of which my father was descended. … We did not see the laird, who was from home; but we saw the lady, who was a much greater curiosity. She was a very large and powerful virago, about forty years of age, and received us with much kindness and hospitality; for the brandy-bottle—a Scotch pint—made its appearance immediately, and we were obliged to take our morning, as they called it, which was indeed the universal fashion of the country at that time. This lady … was said to be able to empty one of those large bottles of brandy … at a sitting“ (Carlyle, Autobiography 23–24); the wife is not further identified. used to have my grandfather,Thomas Carlyle (1722–1806). still a young man, much abt him, as pet and “cousin“ (of whh I heard enough in my boyhood),—not much to the profit of grandfather’s affairs, as I have understood:See Carlyle, Reminiscences 17–18. and then that Carlyle of Brackenthwaite;James Carlyle of Brakenwhate (1647–1736); Alexander Carlyle described him as “an old gentleman, a cousin of my father’s … who had been an officer in James II’s time, and threw up his commission at the Revolution rather than take the oaths. He was a little fresh-looking old man of eighty-six, very lively in conversation, and particularly fond of my father“ (Carlyle, Autobiography 25); James II of England and Wales and VII of Scotland (1633–1701), reigned 1685–88. that do of LimekilnsIn Nov. 1743 Alexander Carlyle went to study in Glasgow; soon after arriving “[I] went to the dancing assembly with some of my new acquaintance, and was there introduced to a married lady who claimed kindred with me, her mother’s name being Carlyle, of the Limekiln family“ (Carlyle, Autobiography 71–72); not further identified.— In short, I cd tell a long story abt all that; and perhaps shall, some day when we meet.
I conclude at present my congratulingThus in MS. on what you have done, and by returning many thanks whh are due.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 4 Dec. MS: NLS 525.71. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

figure.p: Autobiography of Dr. Alexander Carlyle of Inveresk (1910)

p.hi: Autobiography of Dr. Alexander Carlyle of Inveresk

docBody.p:
Strikingly like a certain old “Peter Carlyle of Windy-Knowe,”Peter Carlyle (ca. 1735–1811); not further identified. and perhaps
also resembling one “John Carlyle”Unidentified; possibly a relative, but presumably not their uncle John Carlyle (ca. 1754–1801); a mason like his brother James (TC and John A. Carlyle’s father), he was unable to work for long because of asthma; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 25. (a kind of old Herdsman at Pennersaughs)Pennersaughs is ½ mi. (1 km.) SE of Ecclefechan; TC’s great-grandfather John was buried there; see 16:24 TC to HD, 20 Jan. 1843
. whom I, not you, can remember. I did not mention this to Burton, in acknowledging his Gift (half an hour ago); nor is it worth mention, unless when it happens to turn up.

figure.p: “Revd Dr Alexander Carlyle. Minister of Inveresk ” by David Martin
Autobiography of the Rev. Dr Alexander Carlyle (1860)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
If you can see your way into and thro’ those Two “Royal” Scotch Poems;“The Kingis Quair” [“King’s Book”] (ca. 1423–24) and “Christ’s Kirk on the Green,” poems attrib. to James I of Scotland (1394–1437; ODNB ), king from 1406. The first printed edn. of these poems was by William Tytler (1711–92), Poetical Remains of James the First, King of Scotland (Edinburgh, 1783), but he did not consult the MS in the Bodleian, relyingon an earlier transcript. TC gave his brother a copy of the poems: The Works of James the First, King of Scotland (Perth, 1827), based on Tytler’s 1783 edn., containing “The King’s Quair,” “Peblis to the Play,” “Christ’s Kirk on the Green,” “Remarks on the Scots Language,” and “Dissertation on Scottish Music.” TC inscribed it: “To Dr Carlyle (from his Brother, / T. Carlyle / Chelsea 1860)” (Houghton Lib.). This was possibly the copy that Alexander Gilchrist gave TC, 1 Jan. 1860; Gilchrist noted in his diary: “Talk fell on the two Scottish books that I left for Carlyle on New Year’s Day: ‘James the First’s Poems’ and ‘Pennycuick’s Poem’; pleased with both, especially with James the First’s Christ’s Kirk on the Green, which was on the model of Chaucer” (Gilchrist 82). John A. Carlyle used David Laing’s collations of the Tytler edn. and the Bodleian MS in his edition of David Irving’s History of Scotish Poetry (see TC to JAC, 19 Nov. ), and apparently copied Laing’s collations into his copy of James I’s poems; see Grover Cronin Jr., “Two Bibliographical Notes on ‘The Kingis Quair,’” Notes and Queries (20 Dec. 1941) 181:341–42. Modern scholarship identifies “Christis Kirk on the Grene” as anon., ca. 1490–1510; see Allan H. MacLaine, The Christis Kirk Tradition (Glasgow, 1996) 10. and take them heartily in hand, I shall be very glad,—confiding in your foresight and calculatn as to means & result. There is no doubt you wd give a better editn than any that is: but is there fair chance of a good, that is, a completely intelligible one? Tell me what you have decided on, or are meditating for the sake of deciding. I shd be very glad to know you fastened to a
useful and generous employment of that kind,—since you will not do the Dante, John Carlyle translated Inferno, pt. 1 of Dante’s Divine Comedy, in 1849 but not the other two pts.; see 22:5 TC to AC, 3 July 1847
, and 24:16 TC to AC, 6 April 1849
. whh all people wish.— — I suggested the Task, of the 2 Poems, to Craik when last here;George Lillie Craik and his das., Georgiana and Mary, had been in London in June; see 36:139 JWC to GMC, 18 June
.—but I did not quite so much care whether Craik succeeded or not! I don’t suppose he has much intention, still less has done anything:—but before quite starting, you may write some slight word to Craik on the subject.John A. Carlyle did write to Craik, as Craik replied, 14 Dec.: “It was a real pleasure to me to receive your letter this morning. Your mere handwriting would have been a welcome sight, even if the subject of your communication had not been one in which I feel so strong an interest. I well remember the conversation you speak of; nor was that the only time that your brother has spoken or written to me to the same effect. But even if I had the qualifications necessary for the undertaking he suggested, my hands at present are full. I shall be delighted, therefore, to see it in yours. Do set about it forthwith. The old poetry will be fortunate indeed in such an editor. For this work—wanting at once a learned and a loving spirit—we may say, as Nathan said unto David, ‘Thou art the man.’ … At any rate, I suppose you would give us a text of the Quair founded on the MS. in the Bodleian. Do you know an edition of the poem published some years ago by an ingenious man, who was still alive when I was in Scotland in the early part of the present year, Ebenezer Thompson, formerly Latin Master in the Academy at Ayr … ?” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). Ebenezer Thomson (ca. 1783–1861), scholar, d. 12 Jan. 1861; the first editor to consult the MS, his edn. was The King’s Quair, a poem, by James the First, King of Scots (Ayr, 1815).
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MW, 8 Dec. Addr: Auchtertool Manse / Kircaldy / N. B. PM: 10 Dec. 1860. MS: NLS 607.570. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:65–69 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET WELSH

docBody.p: Having made no sign of myself for the last month; you may be fancying I have succumbed to the general doom; seeing that it has been “the gloomy month of November, in which the People of England hang and drown themselves“!— But I am neither hanged nor drowned yet; (in virtue perhaps of being born in Scotland) only, all my energies having been needed to stave off Suicide; I had none left for letterwriting. It is now December, and the suicidal mania should have passed off; but I can’t see much difference between this December and the gloomiest November on record! the fog and the mud and the liquid soot (called rain in the language of flattery) have not abated. And the blood in ones veins feels as thick and dirty!— But shame of my silence must serve instead of inspiration, impossible under the circumstances! and you, dear good little Soul, as you are, will not be critical!

In the first place you will be glad to hear I am “about,“ anyhow. Except for one week that I had to lie on the sofa on my back with Neuralgia, (differing in nothing so far as I can see from the old fashioned “Rheumatiz“) I have not been laid up since you heard of me.Thomas Woolner wrote to Emily Tennyson, 9 Dec., “I forget if I told you in my last note how remarkably well Mrs. Carlyle is this year, and generally she is laid up an invalid the whole winter“ (Woolner 203). and I have had a great fret taken off me, in the removal of that vulgar conceited woman,“Tall“ Charlotte. and the restoration of little Charlotte. Upon my word; I havn’t been as near what they call “happy“ for many a day; as in the first flush of little Charlotte! She looked so bursting with ecstasy as she ran up and down the house, taking possession, as it were of her old work—and as she showed in the visitors, (not her business; but she would open the door to them all, the first time; to show herself; and receive their congratulations) that it was impossible not to share in her delighted excitement!

Most of the people shook hands with her!, and all of them said they were “glad to see her back!— I had trusted that she would, in time, humanize the
other girl. and that the two would be good friends when the other girl got over the prejudices, the woman who had left had inspired her with! But it needed no time at all! Sarah was humanized, and the two sworn friends in the first half hour!! In the first half hour Sarah had confided to Charlotte that if I hadn’t given the tall Charlotte warning, she (Sarah) would have given me warning. She disliked “tall Charlotte“ so much!

It is now three weeks since the new order of things; mistress and maid have subsided out of the emotional state, into the normal one; but are still very glad over one another; and if the work of the house does not get done with as much order and method as under the tall Charlotte; it is done with more thoroughness and infinitely more heartiness and pleasantness. and the “bread-puddings“ are first rate! Sarah’s tidiness and method are just what was wanted to correct little Charlotte’s born tendency to muddle; while little Charlottes willingness and affectionateness warm up Sarah’s drier more selfish nature. It is a curious establishment with something of the sound and character of a nursery! Charlotte not nineteen till next March and Sarah seventeen last week! And they keep up an incessant chirping and chattering and laughing—and as both have remarkably sweet voices it is rather pleasant to hear! The twoness is no nuisance to me now.See JWC to MR, [22?] Oct.— As neither of them can awake of themselves, I dont know what I should have done about that:hadn’t Charlotte’s friends come to the rescue! an old manJohn Godby (b. ca. 1802). who lodges with Charlottes “Mother“ (aunt)Elizabeth Southam. raps on the kitchen window till he wakes them every morning at six (!) on his way to his work, and Charlotte’s “Father“ (uncle)Thomas Southam. raps again on the window before seven, to make sure the first summons had been attended to!!—to say nothing of an alarm which runs down at six, at their very bed-head, and never is heard by either of these fortunate girls!— So I dare say we shall get on as well as possible—in a world where perfection is not to be looked for!
I shall be glad to hear that your domesticities are in as flourishing a state!

I hope we shall go to the Grange by and by, and make a longer visit than last year.The Carlyles had stayed with the Ashburtons at their country home in Hampshire the previous winter, 5–13 Jan. 1860. It is such a good break in the long dreary Chelsea winter! and stirs up ones stagnant spirits, and rubs up ones manners! But Mr C won’t stay anywhere, if he can’t get work done—and tho Lady A says he shall have every facility afforded him for working I don’t know how that will be when it comes to be tried. I never saw any work done in that house!— Meanwhile I have
sent an azure blue moiré that Lady Sandwich gave me last Xmas day to be made in case.

I saw Mrs Godby some ten days ago, and did not like her looks so well as the first time I saw her after her illness.Mary Godby was very ill in Sept. 1860; see 36:255JWC to TC, 18 Sept. But her MotherMary Binnie. who dined with me last Monday said it was merely the effect of natural causes. She (Mrs Godby) has not the slightest recollection of her illness—the whole time is a blank to her! She remembers having a lady at tea and complaining of pains in her legs, and tho she continued up after that, and wrote various letters “to be delivered in case of her death“ she recollected nothing of these letters till they were shown her, nor of anything else, till, weeks after she had been so far convalescent as to be removed from her bed to a sofa!

Mrs Binnie is going home the end of this month— SophySophy Welsh, wife of Maggie’s brother Alexander. wished her to go by Liverpool, she said, but “it would be too fatiguing for her.“ She is quite as enthusiastic about “Mr Cooke“John George Cooke. as Mrs Godby is!

My dear beautiful Kate Sterling (Mrs Ross) was buried last week at Bournemouth where she had been taken for the winter. I had long been hopeless of her recovery but did not think the end so near and that I should never see her sweet face again. Julia came to see me yesterday on her return, looking miserably ill— Poor Mr Ross wrote me a sad kind letter.See JWC to JSJMS, [3 Dec.]. I am very sorry for him—and none of the family treat him as if he had anything to do with their loss. He was not a man one would ever have wished Kate to marry but he has been the most devoted husband and tenderest nurse to her—and she said to her Sister Lotta the day before her death, that she had repented doing many things in her life but she had never for one moment repented her marriage! Surely that should have made them all less hard for him! But no!— Kindest love to Walter and StarMaggie’s brother Rev. Walter Welsh and her sister Mary, nicknamed “Morning Star“ (see 17:294JWC to JW, 5 March 1844).— Remember me to the LiddlesJames Liddell (ca. 1792–1867) and his sisters, Isobel (b. ca. 1790) and Eliza (b. ca. 1801), of Kirkton farm, Fife; he owned Auchtertool House, where the Carlyles had stayed Aug. 1859. no Ellen LiddleProbably Helen Liddell (1808–75), cousin of James, Isobel, and Eliza. ever appeared—
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

ps.p: Geraldine is become a regular “diner-out“! How her health stands it I cant imagine!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—I shd have sent you that Letter of Jean’s on Saturday Night:TC wrote on Mon. you wd now have had it;—but I postponed, saying “Tomorrow will be all the same“; and then something intervened, and spoiled Tomorrow!— I write now, down stairs here; just about running out for my night’s walk.—

This Letter came an hour or two ago, with some totally worthless Canadian Books.TC’s letter was written on a single sheet, probably part of “This Letter,“ as it has a torn edge. The Canadian books are unidentified. A “red Mr Geikin“The Rev. Mr. Geikin, presumably a friend of their brother Alick’s family, unidentified further. wrote in the morning that he wd call with it; but I took care to be out. Our NephewOne of Alick’s sons. seems to be a rather self-satisfied young man; but to be, in his way, doing really well. I cannot write to him in these times;—nor will I ask you. Cui bono [to whose benefit], after all?—

I have got thro’ Carlyle;Alexander Carlyle’s Autobiography. he flagged upon me, before ending. Burton might have considerably elucidated him by better editing. There shd an Index be added at any rate, in case of a 2d edition. I think it is getting extensively read even in the South here.

Emerson’s Book, complete, is come to hand;The Conduct of Life, just pbd.; Smith, Elder & Co., Emerson’s British publisher, sent TC proof sheets, which he had passed on to John; see TC to JAC, 7 Oct. I am this night at it, when the Proofs left off. Very ingenious, unexpected, queer; very good reading;—has all the faults you enumerated; a sad tendency to apologize for the Devil one of the most tiresome. I will send you the Book, if you wish it, in a day or two.

All well, or as well as usual; Robson and I chacing one another like tortoise & tortoise, at a most deliberate rate; but never altogether stopping. The unutterable mud of the weather is tucking itself up a little.— Good Night, dear Brother. / T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MO, [12 Dec.]. Addr: Care of Mr Blackett / 17 Fettes Row / Edinburgh. PM: London, 12 Dec. 1860. MS: NLS 23210.42. Quot: J. A. Haythornwaite, “‘That False and Odious Impression’: Mrs. Oliphant, Froude and the Carlyles,” Carlyle Newsletter 3 (Oct. 1982) 27; Trela, “Unsung Friendship” 33–34; Trela, “Margaret Oliphant” 155; Fielding and Sorensen 257–58.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p:
First and foremost let me give you a hearty kiss! Never mind about our having met only onceThey met in London during summer 1860 before TC left for Thurso. Oliphant had called on TC to ask if he could give her information about Edward Irving for the biography she was writing. He said that his wife would be of more help, and a day or two later JWC called on her. Oliphant wrote: “I … found in a homely little brougham a lady with bright eyes and very hollow cheeks, who … asked me to come and drive with her that we might talk about Irving. … She must have been over sixty at this time, but she was one of those women whom one never thinks of calling old; her hair was black without a grey hair in it … her features and aspect very keen, perhaps a little alarming.” Oliphant was reminded of her own mother, Margaret Wilson: “not outwardly … but in her wonderful talk, the power of narration which I never heard equalled except in my mother, the flashes of keen wit and sarcasm, occasionally even a little sharpness, and always the modifying sense of humour under all” (Oliphant, Autobiography 97–98). Oliphant had already written “Edward Irving” for Blackwood’s Magazine 84 (1858): 567–86; The Life of Edward Irving was pbd. by Blackwood (Edinburgh, 1862), 2 vols. “here down” (as Mazzini translates quà giù);Coterie speech; see 17:33 JWC to TC, 9 Aug. 1843
. there is no saying but we may have met plenty of times in a previous state of existence! and I certainly didn’t feel to be seeing you that day, at Bayswater,Oliphant was staying in Bayswater, N of Kensington Gardens. for the first time! Besides; you know the old saying “Kissing goes by favour”!Proverbial.—not by the length of people’s acquaintance! There are women with whom I have been what is called intimate these dozen years whom it never entered my head to kiss!—never!

Next, I have to thank you for your Book—“forwarded by desire of the Author”—your Book The House on the Moor (1861) already published; reviewed by Jewsbury, Athenaeum, 1 Dec. : “[T]he story is very interesting, and the interest deepens as the story proceeds. … There is a quiet tragic power in the picture of the lonely house, the joyless fireside, the unloving household, which is better than anything we remember by the same author.” which I like best of all your Books for perhaps no better reason than this same; that it is come to me from yourself, “all to myself,”Coterie speech; see 34:233 JWC to MR, 30 Oct. 1858
. as the children say (not but that grown people are quite as much
alive to the joy of absolute possession as the poor ‘children’ are; they only dont avow it so ingenuously)!.

Long, however, before the Book came to hand, indeed ever since you were here, vague little ideas of writing to you “out of my own head”Coterie speech; see 33:87 JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857
. had been floating thro’ my mind! Yes, what the Book has had to do with my writing to you has simply been affording a point d’appui [basis] for it;—like the thread let down into a bottle of the solution of alum!

But I waited till I should have read the Book; so that I might thank you for the pleasure of reading it, as well as for that of receiving it. I knew that in the case of a Book of yours I was safe in risking the delay!

Now, I will just tell you what happened, and if that does not convey the highest praise of your Book, to your own ears; then you cannot hold the same opinion as Jeffrey,Francis Jeffrey (1773–1850; ODNB ), judge, author, politician, and cofounder in 1802 of the Edinburgh Review; friend of the Carlyles from 1827. “that first of critics,” who said to myself, some five and twenty years ago, “The first and last question to be asked about a novel is; “Does it make the heart beat? See also 30:206 JWC’s Journal, 28 Oct. 1855
. — If that can be answered in the affirmative then has the book the highest merit a novel is susceptible of, and is certain of success”!

Not only did The House on the Moor make my heart beat; but made it bang against my ribs in such a thundering way, that when I lay down in my bed at three in the morning,—(having sat up like an idiot to see out Mr Scarsedale!)The embittered owner of a small farm in The House on the Moor; passed over in his father’s will in favor of his son Horace, in retaliation Scarsdale subjected the boy to a brutal upbringing; he later poisoned his son but was subsequently destroyed by guilt. I couldn’t go to sleep—couldn’t even lie still—for the thump-thumping! Had to get up and take cold water; then try again!—then had to get up and take brandy on a lump of sugar! That also failing to quieten me, had to try something else, and decided on treating myself homeopathically—that is; vulgarly speaking, on taking “a hair of the dog that bit me!”— So I drew a little table to my bedside, placed two lighted candles on it, threw my fur-cloak round my shoulders, and sat up in bed to read out the third volume! It had struck six before the Dramatis Personae being all settled in Life, I subsided into brief “Dog-sleep”!Light, fitful sleep.—Ach!—and please to take along with you the age of the “Party” thus acted upon!—and not my age only but all I had gone thro from what my Scotch servant called “just rale mental A—gony in my ain inside!”Coterie speech; see 33:65 JWC to TC, 2 Sept. 1857
.—

Yes Dear! not a doubt of it! your novel is a most successful novel—and now I should like to know what you are doing with the Biography?Oliphant’s preface to The Life of Edward Irving acknowledges thanks to “Mrs. Carlyle, Chelsea” (1:viii).

I have often reflected, since that drive with you in the “neat Fly,”Coterie speech; see 35:2 JWC to MCA, 3 Jan. 1859
. what a distracted mess I made of the business in hand! You were seeking information about Edward Irving to put in a Book, and almost everything I told you about him was “betwixt woman and woman”—under seven seals of secrecy! And yet I pique myselfCf. 19:193 JWC to TC, 15 Sept. 1845
. on being a practical woman—I do indeed!— Well—if I have the pleasure of meeting you again while the Biography is being written, I
shall endeavour to avoid that Sancho-Panza-dinner style of thing!Presumably the passage where Sancho Panza jogs along behind Don Quixote while eating and drinking; see Miguel de Cervantes, Don Quixote (1605), pt. 1, chap. 8. For a recent representation of Sancho Panza by John Gilbert (1817–97; ODNB ), reproduced in Illustrated London News, 18 Feb. 1860 , see opp above . and draw upon my recollections of Edward Irving to better purposes.

figure.p: “Sancho Panza ” by John Gilbert
Illustrated London News, 18 February 1860

docBody.p: Meanwhile I would suggest to you three men to be spoken with, who could tell more about Edward Irving than almost any other of his acquaintance yet alive— The first is Thomas Erskine (of Linlathan). The second Mr Dickson (Edwards Brother-in-law)Robert Dickson (b. 1783), provost of Annan 1821–23, m. to Janet Irving (1794?–1849). the third my own Brother in law Dr Carlyle,According to Oliphant, it was John A. Carlyle who had first suggested that she approach TC: “One of my people whom I went to see on this subject was Dr Carlyle, whom I found surrounded with huge books. … My recollection of him is of a small, rather spruce man, not at all like his great brother. (Mrs Carlyle used to say of Dr John that he was one of the people who seemed to have been born in creaking shoes.) It must have been he who told me to go and see Carlyle himself who could tell me a great deal more than he could about Irving” (Oliphant, Autobiography 96). JWC wrote “J Carlyle)” in the bottom lefthand corner of the envelope. whose address I will enclose. He is intimate with the other two, one of whom (Mr Erskine) is residing in Edinr for the winter. Mr Dickson lives at Glasgow I believe— Dr Carlyle will go with you to Thomas Erskine or arrange a meeting for you. Thomas Erskine is a very dear friend of my own, and an angel of a man, well worth knowing on his own account.

And now I must conclude rather in haste— Since I began this letter I have had a note to tell me that the youngest childBinnie Godby, Mary and Frederick Godby’s youngest child, d. 13 Dec., age six. The Times reported the death, 15 Dec. of a friend of mine is at the point of death—and I must go off to her—tho—alas alas! what can one say or do to comfort any one under calamity like that!—
God bless you— Dont forget me—and dont give up London— Edinr is too formal and narrow a scene for the like of you
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JA, [14 Dec.]. MS: Alexander Turnbull Lib., Wellington, NZ. Hitherto unpbd. Dated the Fri. before TC to HT, 20 Dec.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear James,—I am very glad you have got the Pipes so far: no doubt Mr Taylor has by this time got them, or will directly. Please to pay them; and so
soon as you have got the receipt, bring it to me (any evg 7½ p.m) and I will pay you.— I am in breathless hurry.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HT, 20 Dec. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY TAYLOR

docBody.p: I am very glad you like the pipes, and grow in talent for tobacco. Macte novâ virtute, puer [Good luck with your new resolve, young man]!See Virgil, Aeneid 9.641; “puer“ presumably a joke as Henry Taylor was four years younger than TC.—
I paid MacDougal,See TC to HT, 28 Nov. so soon as Notice came that the goods were got into the Richmond Railway. Receipt is not yet come,—has to pass thro’ intermediates.James Aitken. Acct was
3/6 x 3 (gross of pipes) + 1/6 for box) = /in all;—for whh you (I am satisfied to think) will never be sued in any Small-Debt or other Court Below or Above.
When your stock is out “MacDougal Pipe-Maker, Glasgow“ will supply you direct (or I, if I be more accessible).

My miseries here, with sordid kinds of labour and chagrin, are very great; but the Printer at a tortoise-pace shoves me always on,—and sleep, tho’ precarious a little, is not forfeited hitherto. Patience, for one long Year!

closer.salute: Yours ever truly (intending to come out again soon) /

docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 21 Dec. MS: NLS 517.10. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Your Letter came this afternoon; a brief message but a welcome: I am thankful for any authentic news from the native side, being myself so very bad a correspondent. There has a Letter since come from Jean; which I inclose, on the chance that there may be something in it which you have not already heard. Perhaps you cd send her that Carlyle Autobiography?See TC to JAC, 4 Dec. Never mind if you cannot; my Copy is lent to Lady Sandwich, good old Lady;Lady Sandwich asked JWC, 13 Dec., if she could “take the Biography to read in the Country“; “I am going to Hinchingbrook about the 20th my Son wishes me to join him there & be with those poor little Motherless girls.“ but will be disengaged before long.

We are in the middle of foul frost with its sleets and snows, and streets all dangerously glazed (when I was last out). It has lasted “3 days“ out; is now snowing and sleeting again,—and I shall be right glad to find that there is at least a ride possible again tomorrow. For 3 days I have not seen my horse at all; very dangerous the last night I had him: but I have sent to Manchester for some plan of roughening whh the great Whitworth has;Joseph Whitworth (1803–87; ODNB), pioneer of modern industrial engineering, whom TC had met in 1847; see 22:57TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1847. For “roughening“ (screwing studs to the horse’s hooves to prevent slipping on ice), see 5:52TC to E, 1 Jan. 1830, TC to JAC, 2 Jan. 1861, and TC to Lord ALOA, 9 Jan. 1861. I cannot get on at all if the horse-exercise be cut off. The streets here are merely one wild dance of Cab and Cart horses: nobody seems to attempt dealing with frost on his horses; merely gives up if he can, and shuffles madly, with frequent falls, if he cannot. Poor Jane has got cold (not very bad yet), I am getting short for sleep again (my formidablest foe at present); but the current of things, a miserable fraction of work included, struggles on as before, up to this time. We are at the shortest day, nadir of the year; perhaps things generally may take a turn in favourable direction.

I do not see that you will ever do much good with that King’s Quair &c,—that much good is capable of being done with it, or good worth the very great trouble of investigation &c whh will be necessary. How much better were it cd you be prevailed upon to grip to your Dante again; a subject on whh you have no peer in Britain, and whh has a real and lasting utility! I know it will take labour, plenty of labour; but you might have it done, years before you are my age; and it wd be a thing to look back upon all the rest of yr life! “No money for it“ say you? “Do you need money then?Closing quotation marks omitted. John A. Carlyle had independent means, having inherited his wife Phoebe’s £4,000 a year. is the ansr. Forgive me, dear Brother: I have done. Your affectionate
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 21 Dec. MS: NLS 517.11. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Thanks for your Letter; whh has just come to hand. Take a word of reply (downstairs here, with the table all to myself, and a bright fire burning, amid the silence of the outer sleet and snow): a short word is better than none.

This frost of ours has lasted now to the fourth day; very disagreeable; difficult to do with by weak creatures, like us. Jane, a close prisoner, has fallen a little into cold; but keeps up her heart. I am off my horse these 3 days,—sleep again a kind of problem (woe’s me!)—but I am taking measures for roughened feet: with my horse under me, I shall be again as before. Printing is slow, slow; but it never ceases; inch by inch we shall get the hill of difficulty,Cf. John Bunyan, Pilgrim’s Progress. whh is like to kill us, eaten away; and be alive again for our remaining years.

I have just been writing to John, from whom also I had a Letter today. I mentioned the Carlyle Autobiography to him, of whh he has a copy: if it be doing nothing, perhaps he may send it you. If not I have a copy quite, done with so far as I myself am concerned, but unluckily gone out on loan for a while: be patient a bit, and you shall have that, if still unsupplied. The bit you have seen is one of the best; but it is all worth reading more or less. I used to hear of him and it when a boy in Edinr; but did [not]Omitted by TC. know he was so expressly Annandale before

I shall be right glad to hear of your getting that eligible House;Possibly the “large and commodious dwelling house in capital repair, containing Dining Room, Drawing Room, Parlour, Four Bedrooms … Orchard, Kitchen Garden, Vinery and small Garden attached“ advertised in the Dumfries and Galloway Advertiser, 4 Dec.; otherwise unidentified. the acct you give of it is quite tempting to my own taste. If a loan of a little money wd forward you at all, tell me at once;—but I but IWords repeated on turn of page. doubt it will not.

We saw James lately, and expect on Sunday night to see him again. He looks douce and snod, a likely young article in his way; and seemed in fair health of body as well as mind, tho’ with less of florid colour than the Country gives. I think he is really doing very well, poor fellow. The PipesJean’s son James had helped organize the delivery of pipes to Henry Taylor. have come all right.

I have still some Printer work to do, not very much; then I have a walk to take (in spite of the sleet); and it is striking ten. Good night, therefore; I intend to write again before many days. With love to all. Your affecte brother T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 22 Dec. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 22 Dec. 1860. MS: NLS 553.228. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Will you venture across tomorrow night, in spite of the Frost-Embargo.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JS[JMS], 23 Dec. Addr: The Revd J Maurice’s / 5 Russell Square. PM: 24 Dec. 1860. MS: NLS 3823.194. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JULIA STERLING

docBody.p: I am very anxious to hear how you are. I had hoped that Edward“Her brother Edward Sterling. would perhaps come today and tell me. But for several days back I have seen nobody to ask. And I cannot go myself to Russell Square, as I meant to do; having fallen ill the day after Edward was here, and been a Prisoner ever since.

Even if you are much better as I pray god may be the case, I dont want you to answer yourself, but if you would ask HesterHer sister Hester Sterling. to write me two lines, it would be a great favour.

I would have written to Edward instead, only that his number in Sloan StreetEdward Sterling lived at 104 Sloane St. has quite gone out of my head, and I dont like sending a note for him to South Place, never knowing what unexpected results may follow from any step of mine in the direction of that fateful locality!Their uncle, Anthony Sterling, lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge; his wife, Charlotte, suffered from insanity. JWC’s visits to the Sterlings’ house in the past had prompted Charlotte into jealous rages; see 18:267–68JWC to HW, 12 Nov. 1844.
Oh my Dear be careful of yourself for the sake of so many who love you, if not for your own sake. I was sure you were going to be ill the day I saw you.

Mrs NewtonSarah Anne Newton (b. 1821), m., 1837, Robert Nodes Newton (1813?–64; they separated bitterly after 1852 (see 29:95JWC to JAC, 9 May 1854, and 35729:biographical note), and she worked as a nurse and a lady’s companion (see 29:67JWC to JAC, 18 April 1854, and 30:261JWC’s Journal, 29 June 1856). She was listed in the 1861 census as a visitor in the Sterling household. called some days ago and told me things were going on most favourably at South Place, Mrs S wonderfully well. I hope it will last. and that
the disposition she imputed to your Uncle to begin the newyear in better fashion towards you all may not have been merely a fancy of hers.

closer.salute: God bless you and comfort you Darling! is the prayer of your ever loving friend

docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-CE, 23 Dec. MS: Goethe-Museum, Dusseldorf. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES D’EICHTHAL

docBody.p: Accept from me, what is all I have to send just now, many kind New-Year’s wishes; assurances that you and all yr good ways are well remembered here,—your old antagonist at ChessJWC; for her chess playing, see 15:99TC to ES, 21 Sept. 1849. holding pleasant remembrance of you as well as I. Being quite overwhelmed, in these months, with pressing occupation, I must leave you to my Brother,TC had sent d’Eichthal’s letter of 12 Nov. to John A. Carlyle to answer; see TC to JAC, 19 Nov. and hope for occasional intelligence by that channel. With many regards,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR[JRU], 24 Dec. MS: Yale. Pbd: Sanders, “Carlyle’s Letters to Ruskin“ 217; Cate 90.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: I am very sorry I did not write on Saturday,Sat., 22 Dec. as it was my thot to do: but the old groomPresumably from Silvester’s livery stables. predicted “a thaw tomorrow,“ and that there wd be riding for an unroughened horse.See TC to JAC, 21 Dec. Hence—these unpolite phenomena! I much regretted my bright Sunday; but in fact it wd have been at night;—and, please Heaven, there are others coming.

As yr carriage horses must have got prepared before this,—the plan will now be that you come across (positively!) one of these silent evenings. No Xmas here; perfect seclusion,—but great readiness for a visitor of luminous type.
The wife is prisoner; I too in a sense;—but am to ride to day, and hope to recover soon. Yours ever truly / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-KS[KST], [28 Dec.]. MS: NLS 1797.44. Hitherto unpbd. Dated the Fri. after Christmas 1860 by the Downshire story; for a more detailed narrative by JWC, see JWC to MR, [30 Dec.].
div3.head: JWC TO KATE STANLEY

docBody.p: What a bright, good thought of yours, to write me a Xmas letter! Bless your little Heart and all it cares for!

I think there must have been spiritual magnetism at work; more or less. For I had been wanting to write to you, for a good while back; to tell you a ‘Tale of Horror’ about the Canary!See JWC to TW, [22 Nov.]. and should have anticipated your letter; but that the end of the year brings me always such a heap of letters to be written in the Course of Nature, and little parcels to be made up for old friends [in]Word omitted. the North, which (not the friends but the parcels) have come, by length of habit to be a sort of moral necessity. Then these duties (such as they are) have this year had to be “pursued under difficulties“Coterie speech; see 27:179JWC to TC, 23 July 1852.—a severe cold; involving confinement to the house. For the first touch of frost as usual knocked me over—like a nine-pin!

I am pretty well thro’ my Labours of—what shall I say? Love? (Well I suppose so!) now however. Besides all the letters and parcels already sent; I have three long letters already written for Newyears morning, and some half dozen Books made ready for the Post! That is what I call “taking time by the forelock,“Proverbial. a rule of conduct strongly impress on me at an early age by the Frontispiece to one of my Story-Books.Untraced. It represented (or meant to represent) an excited Boy, crossing the page with long strides, and pulling after him, by a tuft of hair on the forehead (the rest of the head being bald as an ivory ball), a lean ill conditioned looking old Man (Time); while the Boys other hand carried, (with ostentation) a sealed letter.

But you are thinking all the while; “what is it about the Canary?— Has the Cat—?“—Eaten it; you would ask; and the question is by no means an irrelevant one!— No—my Dear! your Canary is not quite eaten; but I am bound to say; no other Canary past, present, or to come, ever had such an affair with a Cat, and came out of it without being eaten. Nor could this one, unless your Guardian Angel, or mine, or the Canary’s own had worked a miracle on its behalf!

The Cat had taken to studying the Bird, at its first elevation, with a degree of interest that made one’s blood run cold! so I had sent for the Carpenter,Probably Mr. Parsons or Joseph Morgan; see 36:165JWC to JN, 8 Aug. and made him suspend the cage from the Drawing-room ceiling with a pully and brass chain. That done, I had no misgivings about leaving the Two alone together; having no idea what a Cat, under the influence of strong desire was up to! Returning from my walk one forenoon I was met at the door by Charlotte in the wildest excitement! “Oh! she said, whatever do you think the Cat has gone and done?“— “Eaten my Canary“? I answered, with calm desperation,—“No! far worse“! “She must have sprung off the little table on to the cage, and dragged it down, for the chain is lying in a hundred pieces! and the table is tilted over, and broken in two! and oh! Lady Airlie’s basket is broken to shivers! and the ferns all about! and the glass cover is broken to shivers! and every thing is all over the carpet“!— “And the Bird safe?“— “Well yes—tho’ the cage door was wide open, she hadn’t staid to eat it! The noise of the lead and everything falling must have frightened herself; for I met her rushing down the stairs, as I ran up at the row“!

What a mess when I entered the Drawing room! for “the Row“ had just come off, and nothing was cleared away yet; the cage on its side still, on the floor; the table in two separate pieces; the carpet strewn with earth, and ferns, and bird seed, and water, and fragments of earthen ware, glass, brass-chain &c &c! and amidst all the Bird hopping about rather grave, but otherwise “as well as could be expected.“ I was very sorry about my ferns; for they too were a sort of live pets, and had been given me when I was confined, spring gone a year, by Lady Airlie.

The Cat probably had not only frightened herself, but hurt herself, in the general crash of doom she had unexpectedly created. For she had rushed right out at the back door, and never showed herself for 24 hours after, tho a most domestic cat in general,

Relying (Ah too much) on the analogy between feline fools and human ones, I hoped Experience would have taught this individual fool wisdom! So did not at once send the Canary out of the House; seeing that the Cat herself could not be put away—for both practical and sentimental reasons. on the practical hand, We are never catless for a single week but hosts of very little mice troop in to us, out of the drains. Not only does this Cat keep us free of the mice, but she is cleanly, and moral, and honest—except under the temptation of a live Bird. Then, on the sentimental hand; was she not loved by my little Dog,Nero, put down on 1 Feb.; see 36:55–56JWC to ABB, 2 Feb., and 60–61JWC to RST, 6 Feb. as tho’ she had been his own Sister or wedded Wife? stirring him up to games of romps in his old age, and the chief delight of his old age! For his dear little sake, I couldnt put her away!

So a second time I sent for the carpenter; and had the cage fixed up against
the window shutter at the very top—the brass chains of the present day, being it seems (as Mr C says) “like every thing else, an article that the man who made them ought to have been hanged for“!

The cat pretending to take no further notice of the Bird, I thought she had made up her mind that attempts on its life were not only perilous but hopeless, but one night while I was saying something to Charlotte, She suddenly Sprang at one perpendicular leap to the cage and hung on to it with her claws!! I couldnt have believed in such a leap if I hadn’t seen it! I flung my sofa cushions at her, and screamed, and frightened her into dropping down. But I kept the poor Bird under lock and key, after that, till I found her a safer home.

Miss FarrersAnnie Louisa Farrer. Bird had escaped out of the window one day, and its pretty cage was swinging empty, so I sent the poor thing there, where it is now enjoying a life without shocks! I was very sorry to part with the Bird but should have been far sorrier to have it eaten.

The Downshire Story is equal to the “Six-black-crows“ story.Untraced. I was like to cry about it while I was believing it. It seemed such a fatality that a kindhearted simple, straightforward man like Lord Downshire, should be always happening to kill somebody!The first published account of Arthur Hill, 4th marquis of Downshire, and the Downshire story appeared in the Manchester Guardian, 21 Dec.: “[I]t has been the matter of constant comment in all the clubs and West-end houses for the last few days that London may soon look forward to the strange and solemn sight of the trial of a British peer by his brother peers in Westminster Hall. / The Marquis of D —’s yacht, now at Naples, has been the scene of one of those tragedies of real life which we are apt to think, in these dead-level days, lie far away from the region of real life, in the domain exclusively appropriated by the dramatist and the tale writer. The Marquis had been for some time cruising with some members of his family, including a youthful daughter, Lady Alice —. The yacht was commanded by a half-pay Lieutenant of the Royal Navy. The Marquis coming on board unexpectedly, from an excursion on shore, if I am rightly informed, found his captain at the feet of his daughter, kissing her hand. The indignant father—a man of Herculean strength-seized the offender, and let it be hoped, intending only to tear him away from his unseemly place and action, flung him over the bulwark of the yacht into the sea, when he went down at once, in spite—add some of the versions of the story—both of the Marquis’s and his sailors’ efforts to save him.“ On 28 Dec., two days after the Times had dismissed the story as being “without foundation,“ the Guardian’s “Private Correspondent“ wrote: “If it should turn out, as suggested by the editor of the Times, that the report has originated in a misunderstanding of the figurative expression ‘thrown overboard,’ the matter deserves to be remembered as a capital illustration of the magnifying, transmuting, and ‘circumstantialising’ power of rumour. … / Probably readier credence might be given to the report, not only from the fact of the Marquis being a man of quick and hot temperament and extraordinary strength, but from his having been engaged while at Eton in a memorable boxing match, which resulted in the death of his antagonist.“ And poor Lady AliceFor Alice Maria Hill’s visit to Cheyne Row in 1857, see 32:104JWC to MR, 15 March 1857. was too young and pretty to be thought of without emotion as having occasioned a murder.
You have heard perhaps how the story arose?

A Miss RussellMiss Russell apparently wrote to her brother; see JWC to MR, [30 Dec.]; neither are identified further. who was yachting with the Downshires, wrote to her family here, amongst other news, that EarlProbably Arthur Maxwell Earle (ca. 1833–63), brevet-major in the 57th Foot. (one of the Party) had been making such a fool of himself—“looking so spooney at my Lady, that my Lord had finally wearied of him, and flung him over at Civitta Vecchia“Civitavecchia, seaport, 50 mi. (80.5 km.) WNW of Rome.— This repeated magnified itself into “flung him overboard“ Then the Dramatic Personae in the Spooneism(!) were changed from Lady DCaroline Frances, marchioness of Downshire; JWC had visited the Downshires at Easthampstead Park, Berkshire, in 1857; see 32:149JWC to MR, 18 May 1857, and 160–61JWC to MR, 5 June 1857. JWC’s friend Richard Plattnauer had been tutor to two of their children; see 32:151TC to JAC, 22 May 1857. and Major Earl into Lady Alice and the Skipper (a worthy plain old sailor of sixty!)Capt. John Samuel William Grandy, R.N. (b. 1812), captain of the Sylphide.—a Mr HammondPresumably Edmund Hammond (1802–90; ODNB), permanent undersecretary at the Foreign Office 1854–73. mentioned the improved report to AzelioVittorio Emmanuele Taparelli, marquis d’Azeglio (1816–90), Sardinian ambassador in London 1850–68; see 28:96TC to JAC, 1 April 1853. who said, “Oh yes it had been officially communicated to him from Naples“—whereupon Mr Hammond made an official despatch of the news to Lord Cowley at Paris!Henry Richard Charles Wellesley (1804–84; ODNB), 1st Earl Cowley, ambassador to France 1852–67. And now they talk of prosecutions— But I dare say it will all end in that dear, good, Savage (Lord Downshire) thrashing somebody (Azelio perhaps) within an inch of his life! They say Mr Hammond called Azelio to account for his words, and Azelio simply denied that he ever said “officially communicated.“
And now I see it is within a few minutes of posttime. I must wind up abruptly—

I dont think anyone, even Mr Carlyle, could be disinclined towards worked Slippers—provided the Lady who worked them was young and charming. But I will frankly tell you that of three pairs of slippers worked for him in my time, not one was ever worn!— Two came made up, and the third pair he had made up by his own shoemaker, and all three pairs were too short for him. So he has it now a fixed idea in his head, that it is an inseparable fault in worked slippers to be too short.
My kindest regards and the best of good wishes to Lady Stanley and your sistersMaude and Rosalind Stanley. and self
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

ps.p: Remember me to the white DogsSee JWC to Lady ALAI, 24 Oct.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA], [ca. 28 Dec.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. Dated between Christmas 1860 and New Year’s Day 1861 by JWC’s references to her “fortnights confinement to the house with a bad cold“ and the “wishes of ‘the Season.’“
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: A LadyUnidentified. called for me yesterday who had just had a letter from Miss Emily Baring;Lord Ashburton’s sister. and she told me that “the Grange Baby“Mary Florence Baring. had been “excessively ill,“ and given you all “a dreadful fright.“— Beyond this, I could extract nothing of certain; neither as to the nature of dear wee Baby’s illness, nor as to the extent of her recovery from it.

Now, you will admit that “had been excessively ill“ is not exactly news to rest satisfied with; especially when a fortnights confinement to the house with a bad cold has lowered one’s spirits generally, and given a morbid action to one’s Imagination!

So, at the risk of troubling you,—I must beg for two lines, just to tell us how Baby is, at the present time; I would not have you write yourself, unless most perfectly convenient; but only to direct some one in the House to do so.

Mr Carlyle, went up to Lady Sandwich yesterday and asked Her. But she knew no more than had been told ourselves; that the Baby had been very ill. She believed It was now better, but had no authentic intelligence to that effect, and was going to write herself to ask.
So you see I could not get at the real state of the case without troubling you. You will forgive me?

Mr Carlyle too wished me to write. He “wouldn’t for the world that any harm should come to that little atom of a Creature! It was quite a peculiar bit Child! and quite a precious commodity for Lord Ashburton“!
I wont go into other matters—for if the Child be still in the least ailing, all other matters would be indifferent—tiresome to you—I know!—
So with the heartiest good wishes of “the Season“ and all seasons, for you and yours, I remain dear Lady Ashburton / Yours faithfully / Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 30 Dec. MS: NLS 517.12. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Jean, —I got yr Note last night. Sorry to hear of yr disappointt about the House:See TC to JCA, 21 Dec.
but what help was there, after chasing the object even beyond bounds? By sharply looking out you are sure to fall in with something else of eligible before long. Or why shd not James select a little bit of feu or purchase, for House and Garden ground; and have a Dwelling built, more expressly in his own image than any bought one cd be? This wd be a fatal operatn (I know too well!) for the like of me; but he understands all mechanical arts, and the ways of tradesfolk.

Inclosed is a small Newyears remembrance,—£1 of it for poor old Mary TaitTC regularly sent money to Mary Grierson, b. Tait; see 36:124–25 JWC to ETW, 29 May
. in any figure or method you judge best:—the £10 are for yrself;TC sent checks to both sisters in Scotland: “31 decr 1860 / Sister Jean (plus / Mary Tait’s £1) / £11..0..0” and “31 decr 1860 / Sister Mary / £10..0..0.” TC had written a check for the household, 29 Dec.: “to myself (House &c for / Jane 73£ of it) / £86..0..0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20573). a very poor expression of my thanks to you—for existing in this world, and for being at all times so unweariedly good to me. Take it, dear Sister; and imagine, by yr own kind heart, all the kind feelings that go along with it.

This morning we have “a glorious thaw,”—if it only hold, as I hope it will. Such a scene of grim frozen darkness for a fortnight past;The Times, 26 Dec. , reported that Hyde Park was “20 deg. below freezing point” on 24 Dec. —and in danger of getting yr brains broken, not to speak of yr bones, at every step! Streets all of glass; Thames tumbling big cairns of ice (heaped together in that form by the tide); “thrilling regions of thick-ribbed ice,” that too (as Shakespeare has it)See Measure for Measure 3.1. wd be an effectual Place of Torment.
