However, I did wonderfully; got at last my Horse effectually rough-shod (sharpened, by a plan of my own, tried at Craigenputtoch 30 years ago, improved now & perfected by Whitworth the Manchester great gun); rode out, last night, for the first time quite victorious; & saw such a scene of torching, of skating on the SerpentineThe Serpentine, an artificial lake in Hyde Park, created in the 1730s; the Times, 5 Jan. , reported: “the scenes upon the frozen surface [on 3 Jan.] resembled a great fair, owing to there being over 3,000 persons upon it, and a long range of bazaars and tents for the sale of ‘creature comforts’ for the skaters; the blazing fires for cooking chestnuts, and the large number of skaters with lighted flambeaux at night, with occasional discharge of fireworks and coloured fires, produced an exciting scene”; see opp above . (say 50,000 there about sunset, 10,000 till I
tired riding round them):— on the whole, I am stronger and less wretched than perhaps you suppose. Jane too:—and now here is the thaw from the west come. Courage! Perhaps I shall get my Book done, after all, and be restored to friends. Blessings on you all, for the Newyear and all years! Your affecte Brother,
T. Carlyle

figure.p: “The Weather and the Parks: Night Scene on the Serpentine”
Illustrated London News, 19 January 1861

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [30 Dec.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N B. PM: London, 31 Dec. 1860. MS: NLS 607.571. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:69–72 inc. Probably written on Sun., 30 Dec., to be ready for posting on 31 Dec.; less probably, one of the three long letters mentioned in JWC to KST, [28 Dec.], as “already written for Newyears morning“ and held for posting on 31 Dec. for arrival on New Year’s day at Thornhill. All of TC’s New Year checks (see TC to JCA, 30 Dec., and below) were written on 31 Dec.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
If there were no other use in a letter from me just now, it will serve the purpose of removing any apprehensions you may have, as to the frost having
put an end to my life! “Did you ever“?— “No I never!“Coterie speech; see 30:210JWC’s Journal, 1 Nov. 1855.—felt such cold! But then, there being no question for me of ever crossing the threshold, and my time thrown altogether on my hands (my visitors being mostly away, keeping their Xmas at Country-Houses, or, like myself, shut up with colds at home, or too busy with “the festivities of the Season“ to get as far as Chelsea; and my two maids leaving me nothing earthly to do in the business of the House) I have time, enough and to spare, for adopting all possible measures to keep myself warm. To see the fires I keep up in the Drawing room and my bed room; an untopographical Observer might suppose we lived within a mile of a coal-pit; instead of paying 28 shillings a cart-load for coals! then I wear all my flannel petticoates at once! and am having two new ones made out of a pair of Scotch Blankets! And Lady Sandwich has sent me a seal-fur pelissePresumably one of Lady Harriet Ashburton’s; Lady Sandwich wrote to JWC, 13 Dec.: “Here is a souvenir from the Tomb, which you will wear for her sake—I think you will find it comfortable particularly when Mr C. ‘Writer of Books’—opens the window behind your back & under the Blind!“ (a luxury I had long sighed for, but, costing 20 guineas, it had seemed hopeless!) and a Greek MerchantStavros Dilberoglue. has sent me the softest grey indian shawl. And if all that cant warm me I lie down under my coverlid of racoon skins!— (My Dear! if you are perishing; act upon my idea of the Scotch blankets! no flannel comes near them in point of warmth).

My Dr told me, in addition to all this outward covering, to drink “at least, three glasses of wine a day!“— But I generally shirk the third. and the cough and faceache which I had the first week of the frost, is gone this week, at any rate.

Have you seen that Tale of Horror which ran thro the Newspapers about the Downshires.See JWC to KSKST, [28 Dec.]. Every body here believed for some days that the Marquis of Downshire had really found the Skipper of his Yacht“The Sylphide yacht, belonging to the Royal squadron, and the property of the Marquis of Downshire, arrived last week from Messina, having Lady Downshire, her daughter Lady Alice Hill, her two sons, and Major Earl on board. The size and beauty of this vessel, ship-rigged, gave her the appearance of a man-of-war, and great was the surprise of the officers of the health department when they learnt she was the private property of a private individual“ (30 Oct.; Rear Admiral Sir Rodney Mundy, H.M.S. “Hannibal“ at Palermo and Naples [1863] 263). kneeling at the side of Lady Alice (his only Daughter, a lovely girl of seventeen) and really pitched him into the sea; and so there was an end of him!— I was dreadfully sorry, for one; Lord D is such a dear, good kindhearted Savage of a Man! and it seemed such a fatality that he should be always killing somebody!! He had killed a school companion, without meaning it! and afterwards (they say) a coalheaver!
who was boxing with him! The fact is, he is awfully strong, and his strokes tell, as he doesn’t expect! But if you knew what a simple, good man he is; you wouldn’t wonder that I felt sorrier for him than the skipper who after all had no business to be “kneeling“ there surely! and the little Darling Daughter! that her young life should be clouded at the outset with such a scandal! I made all sorts of miserable reflections about them all. And the story all the while a complete fabrication—equal to the proverbial story of the “six black crows“!

I have been told how it arose and who set it a-going. A young Lady-friend of Lady Alice’s who was yachting with them in the Mediterranian wrote home to her Brother here, amongst other news, that “Earl“ (a gentleman also of the Party) had been making such a fool of himself, looking so spooney (the young-Lady dialect of the present day is wonderful!)The Oxford English Dictionary lists the first use of “spooney,“ meaning sentimentally or foolishly amorous, as 1836. at my Lady (the Marchioness); that my Lord got quite weary of him, and, in his off-hand way threw him over at Civitta Vecchia.“— This repeated amplified itself into “threw him overboard“—and with further repetition the Dramatis Personae in the “Spooney“-business were changed from Lady Downshire and Major Earl, into Lady Alice (seventeen) and the Skipper (a rough, worthy sailor upwards of sixty!). In this form the story was told to Azelio (the Sardinian Ambassador) who, to give himself importance, said “Oh yes! it had been officially communicated to him from Naples,“ And the man he said it to, being secretary of legation,Probably Edmund Hammond; see JWC to KSKST, [28 Dec.]. made an official despatch of the story to Lord Cowley at Paris!!! Then it flew like wildfire, and people couldnt help believing it! and of course all sorts of details were added—that Lady Alice was “struggling and screaming“—that Lord D “wouldn’t let a boat be lowered, to pick the man up“ &c &c. One knows how a story gathers like a snowball!— They went the length of stating that Lord D was being brought home to be tried by the Peers—“the offence having been committed on the High Seas“!!!— The talk now is all of Prosecutions of certain Newspapers and certain people— But I shouldn’t wonder if it all end in Lord Downshire giving somebody a good thrashing!The marquis of Downshire issued a denial in the Irish Newry Telegraph, reprinted in the Times, 18 Jan. 1861: “The statement of what is said to have occurred on board my yacht … is false, and totally devoid of a vestige of foundation. … [I]f I catch this scoundrel, I will throw him overboard.“

I received a gracious note from Mrs Pott announcing the Birth of a sonJanet Pott; her son, George, was b. 21 Dec.— She is capital at sons that woman!There were three sons from Janet Pott’s previous marriage. I wonder if they read ‘All the year round’?
I have sometimes thought if they did; how annoyed they would be at the last story in it—going on week after week, all the point in it lying in the hero’s absurd name ‘Potts’ and his own shame at it!Algernon Sidney Potts, the itinerant apothecary and narrator of A Day’s Ride: A Life’s Romance by Charles Lever (1806–72; ODNB), pbd. in weekly installments in Dickens’s journal, All the Year Round, 18 Aug. 1860–23 March 1861. The story was not successful and later installments were relegated to the back pages of the magazine. and Potts isnt nearly so bad as Pott. It wasn’t like “the Drs idea of her clevernessFor Dr. James Russell’s reference to Janet Pott’s cleverness, see 35:145JWC to MR, 11 July 1859. to take a name, so open to ridicule. She could never be a grand Lady, however rich, with such a name!

Please to give my good wishes “of the Season“ to all my friends at Thornhill and about. And to attend to the old women on new-years day. I send a check this time,JWC sent money each year for old Templand servants (see 34:258TC to JMC, 31 Dec. 1858): “31 decr / Mrs Russell (Jane / paying) / £1..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

The japanese trays are for the new drawingroom if you think them worth a place in it. I took them as far as Alderley, on the road, in Autumn.JWC visited Alderley en route to Scotland, Aug. 1860, but had returned to Chelsea, believing that TC was on his way home; see 36:200JWC to MR, 25 Aug. They are a popular drawingroom ornamen here at present. kindest regards to the Dr
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD[JAD], [30 or 31 Dec.]. MS: NLS 1797.176. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the Downshire scandal; written in time for posting 31 Dec. for arrival in Haddington 1 Jan. 1861.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p: “Nice Woman!“—How are you?— I mean to be your “First Foot“—your and his—(William Dods’s)—First Foot!— And you couldn’t have a better, believe me; I am so lucky—to others!

But besides this whim of being your First Foot; something stirs me to write you a letter, as another year is just passing “to the greater number“!— Not the same ‘something’ (let us hope)—the “quelque chose plus fort que moi [something stronger than me] that makes such a figure on French criminal trials, as sole cause and “Extenuating Circumstance“ of the worst atrocities!In 19th-century France a plea of “crime of passion“ was regarded as a valid excuse.—but an altogether different fibre of the Magnetism of the Universe, running thro’ prettier places than Criminal Courts!

Oh my Dear! isn’t it Cold?! In spite of having on all my flannel petticoats at
once! (three white, and one red) and a seal-fur pelisse;—And piling up fires, till an untopographical stranger might suppose, we lived within a mile of a coal pit, instead of paying 28 shillings a cartload for our coals! And in spite of taking three glasses of wine a-day (by order of my Doctor) I feel from morning till night and from night till morning like a living lump of ice! and then, while so many “poor Gardners“ are bawling about the streets that they are “froze out,“See 9:110TC to JCA, 29 Dec. 1836. I am decidedly “froze“ in! The first touch of frost set me off coughing, and then I have to be what is called “very careful,“ and keep the house till a warmer time comes.

Ach! and I am the same woman—at least I suppose I am—who used to delight in fighting with snow-balls and skating on the Tyne!River Tyne, running through Haddington. Who would get up in the Dark of a Winter morning, and, with our groom (James Roberton),James Robertson, servant and groom of JWC’s father; see 24:166 and 169JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849. carrying a stable lantern and besom, trot off surreptitiously to the Lang Kram,Lang Kram, a wide stretch of the Tyne beside the Nungate Bridge. and get a space cleared of the snow that had fallen over night, and have some skating “all by myself“ before breakfast.

I recollect once finding John WilkieJohn Wilkie (b. 1787), younger brother of Jane Dods’s father, William Wilkie (b. 1775). there before me, similarly equipped with a lantern and besom: When the ice had been swept it was slippery as glass, and your uncle advised me to “hold on“ by his “coat tails“—to “steady“ myself—(I needed a good deal of steadying one would say!) It was hardly day-light when we proceeded to shoot over the Lang Kram like “the Gowk and the Tittlin“The SND notes the phrase as applying to “two inseparable companions or to an incongruous pair, esp. a tall and short person seen together.“—I holding fast by his coat-tail! But he had now and then a—what shall I say?—diabolic inspiration, your Uncle John! and certainly he had one that morning and acted on it! For in turning the figure of 8 he suddenly jerked his “tails“ out my clutch, and down I clashed on one side, like a ninepin! Ugh! I think I feel it now!— I had to go my ways home ignominiously with a black eye! and wouldn’t speak to John Wilkie for weeks after! That is the sort of things that come into one’s head, when one sits down to meditate a moment, beside another mile-stone in ones life— It isn’t over the last miles that ones mind runs; but away to the far, far back ones!— God bless them!

I should have liked you to see a letter I had the other week—from Miss Jane Donaldson!Eldest niece of JWC’s old friends Jean and Jess Donaldson; see JWC to JDWDO, [6–7? Oct.]. But my first impulse on reading it was to toss it into the fire; with as near an approximation to an oath as was admissable for an English
gentlewoman of the present Century. (Confound your impudence!). I can tell you however the most that was in it, so far as meaning went.

First came a long rigmarole of Apologies for not having been to “call“ for me, and ‘hopes’ and promises to “soon make amends for seeming neglect“! Bless us! Who is Jane Donaldson; that she should suppose it possible for her to neglect me?— That was an impertinence to start with, and reminded me of a JackanapesUnidentified. I once saw get himself demolished with two words, for indulging in the like. It was at an evening party—Someone said Mrs MontaguePresumably Anna Dorothea Montagu (ca. 1781–1856), wife of Basil Montagu (1770–1851; ODNB), old friends of the Carlyles; see 2:451JBW to TC, 14 Oct. 1823, 29:94–95JWC to JAC, 9 May 1854, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 285–90. was expected; “Indeed“! cried a youth of the Jane-Donaldson stamp, “You don’t mean that Mrs Montague is coming here to night? What shall I do? I shouldn’t have come if I had known! It is such an age since I have been to her House, that she must be furious at me“! Before he had ceased speaking the Lady expected to be furious walked grandly in, and stood still in the centre of the room, calm and cold, as was her way; to receive obeisances. For she looked a queen among women this old Lady and was everywhere treated as such.For JWC’s last meeting with her, July 1856, see 30:262JWC’s Journal, 4 July 1856. Nevertheless up went the Youth to her, and declared he “really didn’t know how to look her in the face; it was so long since he had been to see her“! Is it? said she quite simply, and turned to some one else.

You never saw a young Gentleman look more absurd! To return to the letter, after the apologies, came details of the family health and prosperity—(especially the health and prosperity of “Stuart, dear fellow“)Her brother Stuart Donaldson was knighted 23 Aug. 1860. “which she was sure I would be glad to hear.“ (How little she must think it takes to make me “glad“!) And at last we had arrived at the gist of the Composition. “Would I kindly tell her which was the best likeness of Mr Carlyle and where it was to be procured? or, if I had any ever so little one, that I would give her, she could have it mounted herself (could she?) and would be so much obliged!“ Now “Did you ever“—?—“No I never—!“— The cunning impudence of the Creature!— She knows that I have heard “something to her disadvantage,“ suspects it may be about leaving the portraits for sale, and takes this plan of begging a new portrait, to mollify me for selling the others!See JWC to WDWDO, [6–7? Oct.]. For what is Mr Carlyle to her? She doesnt know him, never saw him, to the best of my rembrance! (With all this fuss about “calling“ she (Jane Donaldson) was never in my house but once, since we have lived in the same London!)— And I have reason to believe she suspects something is wrong between me and
them. Because, in replying to their Sister-in laws (Mrs George’s) note,Emma Donaldson; see JWC to WDWDO, [31 Oct.?]. I intimated my intention of having no further intercourse with the Craven Hill people, “for reasons which, if she wished to know them I would tell her, if we met.“ Mrs George frankly and openly dislikes all the family she has married into—except her own Husband—and would, I felt sure, take a malicious pleasure, in confiding to them these my words. And when Eliza Donaldson “called“ soon after she must have seen that I was intentionally repelling.

I hesitated whether to answer Miss Jane’s letter in three lines; to the effect that “the best Likeness of Mr Carlyle“ was the one left for sale at Sunny Bank. And as it had never been in the Shops, and, I had no copy of it for her; her wish to “add Mr C to her Collection“ (one of her expressions) would have to remain ungratified for the present— Whether to answer that, or to make absolutely no answer at all. I took the latter course—made absolutely no anwer at all!—on the principle that “Silence is more expressive than speech“!Cf. Cicero, In Catilinam 1:21.

What a long yarn about Jane Donaldson! I might have found something more worth your thinking about on a new years morning! But, to make amends, I will send you the best new novelMargaret Oliphant’s The House on the Moor; see JWC to WDWDO, 29 April 1861.—

If you have read in the newspapers a startling Tale of the Marquis of Downshire having found the Master of his Yacht kneeling at the side of his young Daughter Lady Alice Hill, and taking him by the neck and flinging him into the sea, and so there was an end of Him! you neednt be wasting either horror or sympathy on it: for it is a story of the “six-black-Crows“ sort, founded on next to nothing! All London has been ringing with it for the last fortnight; and I was at the crying about it! For I know these people, and couldnt bear to think of that kind hearted, simple, strait forward Lord Downshire being tried for manslaughter, and beautiful little Lady Alice breaking her little heart. As for the drowned man, I had never seen him, and what business had he to be kneeling there of all places in the world! Besides his troubles were over—and those of the others to come! So my sorrow was all for the Downshires. who are good people—if they had chanced to kill even several men among them!

But the story began to be contradicted and then came a LadyUnidentified. who told me all how it arose. A girl who was yachting with the Downshires, wrote home to her friends amongst other news, that a certain Major Earl who had been also of the Party had been “getting so spooney towards my Lady (the Marchioness) and making such a fool of himself, that my Lord had finally
wearied of it, and thrown him over at Civitta Vecchia.“ This repeated amplified, itself into “thrown him overboard,“ then the Dramatis personae in the lovemaking were changed from the Marchioness and the Major, into Lady Alice (aged seventeen) and the Skipper (a rough worthy old sailor upwards of sixty) Then the remodeled report being mentioned to the Marquis Azelio (Sardinian Ambassador) he, liking to be better informed of everything than his neighbours said ‘Oh yes he had had the news communicated to him officially from Naples—’ and the man he said it to, a member of Legation, made an official despatch of it to Lord Cowley at Paris!! and so it spread like wild fire over all London and Paris, with ever new additions, such as that Lady Alice was struggling and screaming, that Lord Downshire wouldnt let a boat be lowered to pick the man up &c &c. And I suppose we havent heard the last of it yet. They talk of prosecutions of newspapers and of Individuals And Lord Downshire being the terribly strong, impulsive man he is, will surely give somebody a thrashing! It is very hard on the family to have been made the subject of such calumnies, for they are more simple in their ways and more attached to one-another, than any great people I ever saw!
Mercy what a letter for length! But a newyears day letter should be long should it not?
I will stop now however—with love to your husband and the best of goodwishes to you both
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA], 31 Dec. Copy: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 267–68 inc; dated “[1861].“ Dated 1860 by JWC to LLA, [ca. 28 Dec.], which inquired about the reported illness of “the Grange Baby“; this letter is presumably in response to Lady Ashburton’s reply; also by JWC’s reference to the many letters and parcels that she had to write and “make up for friends in the North“ and by the Carlyles’ coming visit to The Grange, planned for 14 Jan. 1861.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
“a good new year“ to you dear Lady. “and many of them“! and a good—a perfectly exquisite new year to Baby! The only Child in the World! Or, what comes to the same thing, the only Child that ever touched my Heart, or kindled my Imagination, or was distinguishable for me from other Children of the Period! I have often wondered that Babies didn’t (so far as one knows) get mixed, and misappropriated! that Mothers and nurses seemed able to tell their own particular Baby from the general flood of Babies! It must be by the
clothes (I thought) or some private mark, such as Gentlemen put inside their hats! for, in point of fact, the little creatures were all alike as peas! and equally uninteresting!— But now!—were all the Babies in Middlesex and Hampshire collected in one place; in puris naturalibus [stark naked] (if you can imagine anything so shocking!); and I should be asked to point out “The Grange Baby“ among them all; I venture to modestly affirm, that as soon as my eye found her, I should say; “that is she! The Darling“!

Mercy! what a thing it would have been, had she been spillt, thro’ sheer stupidity and carelessness! I am afraid I should have pitched that nurse into the Lake; by way of curing her fancy for wandering by it in winter evenings, with the only Baby in the World in her arms!

Now that is a nurse whom Dr FranciaDr. José Gaspar Rodríguez de Francia y Velasco (1766–1840), dictator of Paraguay; see Carlyle, “Dr. Francia,“ Works 29:261–321. would have ordered to be “walked three times beneath the gallows! with intimation, that if she didn’t mind what she was about, she should certainly be hanged!“— and such fact about her transmitted by Mr C to Posterity with the plaintive Commentary! “alas! that there is no Dr Francia among us at the present day!“
But oh dear! dear! I mustn’t be chattering; or I shall miss the post, and along with it the honour and pleasure of offering you my best wishes (such as they are) on new years morning!

I have had so many letters to write in the last week, and so many little parcels to make up for friends in the North, which (the letters and parcels) have by length of habit come to be a sort of moral necessities; that I am run to a minute for time.

Mr C would be right glad to go to the grange on the 14th or when you please—if only he could go on correcting his proofs there. But he “never could work at the grange yet“!—he says. I suggested that you, being as good as the angels, would let him breakfast in his own room, and keep himself au secret there till two oclock (as they let him do at Thurso); and the answer to that was— “Yes!—if it could be arranged in that way; I should like nothing better.“— as you were so amiable as grant him “a window to get out at in the middle of the night,“ I think you will permit him this new indulgence also. and then I see no other obstacle to our being with you on the 14th or when you like—to stay a whole fortnight—if that does not frig[h]ten you. Oh I shall be so glad! God bless you Baby! I am coming to Play with you,
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JCA, [1 Jan.]. MS: NLS 1763.271. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.dateline: 5. Cheyne Row Chelsea Newyear’s day [1 January 1861]
docBody.p: In settling my affairs, moral and material, at the years end; I made a note, to write to you; and I wish I had done it a day or two ago, as it would then have come with better grace, than now, when I have got something to return thanks for. But I miscalculated the time it would take me to write all those letters which I have accustomed myself to write, for years and years back, to my relations, and old Haddington friends, &c, so that they (the letters) have come by length of habit to be a sort of moral necessities; or—Providence was particular[l]y adverse this year in sending interruptions—for yesterday found me within four of the end of my list! and meanwhile came your wonderful looking package! which excited my curiosity extremely! it was so long before I could disentangle the intricate cordage, and what I saw in the process was so light, and yet it was so heavy to lift! while there peeped out at one end what I took for a bunch of Lavender, which smelt exactly like salt fish! All these contradictions were pleasantly explained when the coverlid got itself unfolded, and the heavy jam-pot and lump of Salmon were brought to light!

The coverlid was soon spread on the sofa of Mr C’s study where he takes a half hour’s sleep, every day now, betwixt returning from his ride and eating his dinner, and he hanseled it by taking a sound sleep under it last night. I have had, for years, a great racoon-fur rug on my drawing-room sofa, which I have lain under so much, that it has got to feel much like an own second skin! So I can afford to let him keep this one of yours on his sofa, which will be doing it all the honour in my power; The cranberries I will keep “all to myself“—as for the Salmon; coming under the Category of “questionable Dainties“ I think I shall make a present of it to Mr Larkin;Henry Larkin. who has been very civil to your James.Jean’s son James Aitken, who lodged in Islington near Larkin; see 34:252TC to JCA, 24 Dec. 1858. And thank you for all!

James was here one evening not very long since, and I asked him, during two minutes we were tete a tete, if he had made acquaintance with any girl. “Girl?“ he repeated, in an uncomprehending, questioning, rather terrified way! “Yes! Girl! dont you know what a girl is“?— “Oh yes! I know said he gravely; “but I dont understand what you mean“!— “Why, I mean; have you at these Parties where you tell me, you were, made acquaintance with any girl“?— “No!—“ (quite decidedly)— “Were you all men then? Were there no women there? no girls.“?— “Oh yes! plenty—“ “Then, did you not speak to
any of them“?— “Oh yes! I spoke to some“!— “Then, why say you hadn’t made acquaintance with any girl?“— “Oh because—because—I thought you meant—particularly“!— “Meant what, particularly?“— “The — — the girl!— I thought you meant; had I seen any particular girl?—“ “Of course I did and your answer was no.“— “Well but I meant I had seen none in particular!!“— I burst out laughing at this point. He waited till I was done, and then asked me had I any girl in my eye? I think he was relieved when I assured him, ‘no’—that I had very little acquaintance with girls— I tell you what it is; that James won’t fall in love now, till he is turned forty, and then he will have a mad, grand passion for an—Actress! or a fast Widow! tell him I said so! and if I should happen to “know a Girl“; I should never dream of trying it on him!

I havn’t crossed the threshold for three weeks; but the cold which knocked me down the first day of the Frost was only severe for the first week—and now my cough and rheumatism are quite gone—and I stay in the house merely for precaution. That Dr has been a great blessing to me! So many illnesses have been nipped in the bud by being cared for in time. since I got into the way of having myself cared for.

For the rest; I am not so impatient, and disspir[i]ted this time, as confinement to the house used to make me! much of my contentment being due I think to my two Girls, who are extremely kind and attentive to me, and carry on the affairs of the House quite satisfactorily without my superintendence. You know that I dismissed the vulgar, self sufficient, selfish Brute of a cook“Tall“ Charlotte; see JWC to ETETW, [17 Nov. 1860]. that I got in Mr C’s absence, and took back dear little Charlotte, whom I had never ceased to miss and who had never ceased to pine for her lost place?

The Present Combination answers capitally. Sarah’s tidiness and punctuality are correcting insensibly Charlotte’s natural turn for muddle, while Charlotte’s warm heartedness and head-over-heels willingness have quite warmed up Sarah’s colder more formal nature. My ‘establishment’ is a great amusement to my visitors, and even to myself—Charlotte nineteen, Sarah seventeen; such children in everything except their work, which could’nt be done better by the fullest-grown women! But they make sport of their work—for themselves,—and are so ridiculously happy; that it often makes me laugh to look to them!

For example Charlotte went into the garden the other day to shovel the snow off the walk—I looked from my bed room window, rather sorry for her, to see how she was getting on; and there were both girls, playing at snow balls!!—amidst little shouts of laughter! when my bell rang after, both flew to answer it; all white with snow, and radiant with delight!
Mr C is to dine with Lady Sandwich today— I am sorry I had to decline—for it is dullish, dining all alone on newyears day!

Lady Sandwich gave me such a magnificent seal-fur coat at Xmas! And the same day—(lucky woman!) a Greek Merchant, of my friends took the idea to send me a lovely soft grey indian Shawl! and the Dumfries drawersSee JWC to MCA, [18 Oct. 1860]. have a good warmth in them, and I have had two petticoats made out of scotch blankets (which is a recommendable invention) so that “altogether“ (as poor Macdiarmid used to say)Coterie speech; see 16:262JWC to TC, 11 July 1843; John M’Diarmid (1790–1852; ODNB), ed. of Dumfries and Galloway Courier. I am tolerably well fortified against the cold—
I am writing in haste—to not miss another post— I can write better when I take time!
Kind regards to your Husband and Bairns
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2–3 Jan. MS: NLS 525.61. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated the year; 1861 confirmed by context and TC’s dating of the letter “Thursday Jany 3d“ in para. 3.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Thanks for your little Note (welcome always, tho’ short); and cordial return of the wishes you send us at this Season and at all seasons.

We are perhaps doing more tolerably than you suppose. Jane has never yet been out; but wd have been today (spite of the new frost), had not her “neat-fly“ (a brougham in favour with her) been preengaged. We have glassy hard frost since midnight last again; after two or three days of most flowing mud.

I have got my horse properly (At this point the horse came, yesterday, and I had to run! It is now Thursday Jany 3d, abt the same hour, and in the same scarcity of time:—“properly“)TC’s line above “properly.“ rough-shod (screw steel-points in the heels, 8 in all, according to a plan of the great Whitworths,—according to a plan of my own, tried but not perfected 30 years ago, at Craigenputtoch!)In 1830; see 5:52TC to E, 1 Jan. 1830. whh is completely sucessful; so that I can ride daily; warm enough, being well wrapt up, tho’ rather slower in genl. My sleep is decidedly not so bad of late. I did not try the “Turkish Baths“;See TC to JAC, 4 Dec. 1860 hearing of at least 3 people who had got fatal damage by them.Sir William James Erasmus Wilson (1809–84; ODNB) in The Eastern or Turkish Bath: Its History, Revival in Britain, and Application to the Purposes of Health (pbd. March 1861) was in general very positive about Turkish baths, as long as they were used properly, but warned against their abuse, citing the example of “a literary man … not equal to the demand made upon his vaporizable fluids, and the use of the bath tended to derange his nutritive functions and lower his powers“ (137). One change I have made, to whh I attribute most of the
improvet: I wrap myself before dinner, on coming in tired from horseback; and can generally sleep abt 20 minutes, then and not after dinner. In short, I rub on; rather more tolerably than in months prior. Work is dreadfully slow, and yet fast enough for me; Book ii (12th, i.e) not done yet, by abt a third part. Steady!

We are to go to The Grange in abt ten days (14th instant); they wish us to stay “a long time“; will treat me as at Thurso for work, for seclusion &c: alas, I cannot see my way into much “work“ there with any clearness; mean vaguely to stay abt 2 weeks; and shall be happy if I get no damage by the Country spell of felicity and recreation.

We heard of you as intending a trip to Auchtertool; as being called upon by the Mrs Maitland (?)Margaret Oliphant, who had written Passages in the Life of Mrs. Maitland of Sunny-side (1849) and Lillies Leaf: Being a Concluding Series of Passages in the Life of Mrs. Margaret Maitland (1855). who is abt writing Edwd Irving’s Life, and who reports thankfully of yr goodness to her.See JWC to MO, [12 Dec. 1860]. It did not seem to me she wd ever do much of perfectn in that task; but I was willing, finding her an innocent loyal creature, she shd want for no understanding of it whh I or mine cd help her to. Make my compts to Gordon;John Gordon (1797–1882), old friend of TC and also resident in Edinburgh; see 35:25835:biographical note. a fortiori [even more so] to Erskine and Household.Thomas Erskine and his sisters, David Paterson and Christian Stirling. I expect the TailorPossibly Henry Taylor. tonight, too, by way of farther acceleratn in the History of my Fritz & 18th Century Chaos! Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [7 Jan.]. Copy: NLS Acc. 7864. Hitherto unpbd. The handwritten copy is dated “[1863],“ but the Ashburtons were in Paris that winter; tentatively dated early 1861 by the mention of frost and by the Carlyles’ forthcoming visit to The Grange.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY AUSTIN

docBody.p:
This is only two lines to announce the safe arrival of the eggs and hens; and to thank you for them, with all the warmth possible, in the present temperature, which is freezing the very blood at my heart I think! It has got quite
beyond producing the customary results of frost in me; coughing, blowing my nose and all that sort of thing. The other day without the least earthly assignable reason, but the cold I was exposed to; I suddenly started off retching!! and retched (you remember of old my violent manner of exercising that natural function?)See 32:96TC to JCA, 5 March 1857. from five in the afternoon till two in the morning, with only brief pauses! When the fit was over, nothing followed; except the weariness and torn-in-pieces-ness, natural to such violent exertions. And that makes me still very good for nothing, and even less able to hold my own against the frost than I was before. Then we have the prospect of going to the Grange next weekThey went to The Grange 15 Jan.—not an exhilerating one—under the circumstances—; and I have my finery to look up, and put in order; and Mr C wants two new stocks made and a smoking cap! made!— Heaven bless the man!—as if there were none in the shops! but as for the smoking-cap! Don’t he wish he may get it! It will be much, I think, if I wash and new line his old one!

“Altogether“ I feel very bothered; and (as the Doctor says) “dont see my way!“John A. Carlyle’s saying; see 19.229JWC to JW, 29 Sept. 1845. A state of mind in which I never can write a decent letter. So wait till I get to the Grange; and then you shall hear all about us at more length and leisure.
docBody.name: J.W.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 9 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: The frost, tho’ not quite unwholesome to me, yet joining with the Prussian dust-vortexes in a frozen state, and no egress till the sun is setting (when we have any sun);—all this, with total seclusion from my fellow creatures, is really congealing to the mind as well as to the body. I hope to thaw & resuscitate (in the spiritual part of me) a little at The Grange. There was talk of “work“ there, and arrangts by My Lady for that charitable end:—well, surely: and yet, alas, except correcting Proofsheets, or the like, I have small practical hope that way; and (especially if you are riding) will take my Fortnight in fresh air and human society instead.
Pray tell me if I must bring my own Horse (must or may; yes or no is all one to me); or if you have not idle horses enough and to spare in this frost?

Also whether I may not, at any rate, send you an excellt effective plan for rough-shoeing; whh I got from Whitworth of the Great gun:Whitworth had been commissioned by the government during the Crimean War to design machinery for rifle making; see 30:119TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1855. here is specimen shoe &c with letter of directions,—if you care at all. The plan is easy: two screw holes one in the heel of each shoe; 8 holes in all; the holes are plugged up (carefully) while in stable; 8 little steel nails are screwed into them when you go out to ride. I ride so daily, & find it perfect while the nails continue sharp. You get new ones about once a week. The one difficulty is to get the groom to be punctual in unscrewing them when you return home.
docBody.name: T Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA] , [9 Jan.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 259 inc.
div3.head:
JWC
TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Is it “all right”? and we are still to come on the 15th (Tuesday.)?— If there have arisen any impediment or demur on your side; you will warn us in time?—otherwise we should arrive upon you “quite promiscuous.”Coterie speech; see 10:72 TCJWC to JCA, 1 May 1838
.—

For nothing of an “impedimental” sort (as Henry Taylor would say) has arisen here; and we look forward to being with you (and Baby of the World)The Ashburtons’ da., Mary Florence Baring. on the appointed day—if only we “be spared”!
and such pains I have been taking all this while to insure being spared, as far as it depends on oneself!

I even refused myself the gratification of going with Mr C to dine at Lady Sandwich’s on New-years day; for fear of bringing back my cold, so that the 15th might find me unfit for travelling, And I had my Dr’s leave to go—with certain precautions!— He has an extravagant idea, my Dr, of the agony of mind it must be to a female patient to be denied what he calls “a little sociality.” So he “really thought I might risk dining out on new-years-day; provided I ordered a wax candle to be burnt in the carriage for half an hour before getting into it—and kept it burning all the way!” I tell you this invention, (on the authority of a clever, quite matter-of-fact man) in case you may have some occasion to turn it to account—not for yourself, who seem perfectly inaccessible to Colds but for some less happily constituted friend.— As for me; I confess, such a style of driving—boxed in along with one wax candle!
has something quite Ghastly and funereal in it! not to be tried till one’s impatience of confinement was passing into mania!

They were skating on the Serpentine last night with torches, and a Band of music; little canvas booths dotting the ice, with flags flying; where one could have “roast-taties”. and other solid and liquid condiments!The Times reported, 9 Jan.: “The Serpentine presented an extraordinary scene last night, and it is estimated that there were upwards of 200,000 persons in Hyde Park. … [T]here [were] upwards of 50,000 skaters and sliders, nearly all of whom carried lighted torches. … The centre, as well as near the banks of the river, was lined by several hundred tents, consisting of skating booths, refreshment pavilions, &c. Near the east end was erected a large tent for the supply of wine, porter, and refreshments of all descriptions, while the vendors of hot coffee, gingerbeer, &c., drove a most profitable trade.” For skating scenes in two other London parks, see opp above . See also TC to JCA, 30 Dec. 1860 . The Londoners beat the worldMary Austin’s saying; coterie speech; see 8:223 JWC to TC, 12 Oct. 1835
. for being able to do nothing without “refreshments”! Mr C walked past the ‘festive scene’ towards midnight; and came home with a strong desire, at least a desire strongly expressed, that “somebody would take him out, and teach him to skate”

figure.p: “The Weather & the Parks”
Illustrated London News, 19 January 1861

docBody.p:
Good morning Baby! I continue to love you very much Baby! and hope it mayn’t be always, as at present, “with the reciprocity all on one side”Coterie speech; see 19:196 JWC to GCD, 15 Sept. 1845
. Baby!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JH[JAHA], 13 Jan. Pbd: George J. Worth, “Three Carlyle Documents,“ PMLA 71 (June 1956): 544; Worth thought the MS was “in the possession of the Univ. of Illinois,“ but it is untraced. James Hannay (1827–73; ODNB), author and journalist; see TC to MAC, 3 Oct. 1849, and TC to JAC, 21 March 1857.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES HANNAY

docBody.p: You are, of course, highly welcome to dedicate your new volumeHannay’s Essays from “The Quarterly Review“ (1861) was dedicated “with cordial esteem and affection“ to TC. to me, since you will do me that honour.

I heard of the Courant EditorshipHannay ed. the conservative newspaper Edinburgh Courant 1860–64. and was privately glad, on your account, to think that you had got into those duller and safer waters, out of the wild Scyllas & Charybdises that go jumbling at such a rate in these latitudes of ours. London has its charms, especially for one still young; but it is not of improving character, in a real or serious sense, rather the reverse I should say (as vain and inane tumult always is); and certainly there is no mode of existence known to me in the world, whh I could less recommend to a human creature than that of the Literary Fraternity here floating about, in the tempestuous “mother of dead dogs,“Coterie speech; see 35:68TC to RWE, 9 April 1859. at this epoch of its history!— The necessity of a solid income is itself an immense matter. You will still find Books, intelligent studious people, and abundance of other resources in Edingh; at lowest you can be silent, faithfully do your own daily work; and with whatever energy is given you improve yourself in real wisdom and insight to the pitch intended by Nature in making you!

I send you all measure of good wishes; and hope to see you again, in prosperous condition, some day when this horrible load, whh has crushed me down into the bowels of Chaos these many years, is at length off my shoulders, and I am again alive among the living.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS[CSO], [15 Jan.]. MS: Chelsea Public Library. Pbd: Blunt “CLC“ 290–91, where misdated 3 Jan. 1860.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.dateline: The Grange / Alresford Hants Tuesday [15 January 1861]
docBody.p:
Dear little Woman I havn’t a moment’s time to tell you about anything but the business in hand. I have gone and put a wrong key on my ring!!—have left the key of my writing desk behind and brought that of an old hat-box instead!—
There! that is stupider than any thing you ever did!— And I cant get my white gloves which are in the desk! and must go down in bare hands—which is about as bad as going down with bare feet—

look in the little glass drawer and I think you will find little keys and make a parcel of them and send them by post tomorrow—it is a round key—for a little bramahBramah & Co., engineers and smiths, manufacturers of Bramah’s patent locks, and water closets, pumps, stoves, 124 Piccadilly and 25 Down St.; see also 34:40JWC to EFO, 12 July 1858, and 65–66JWC to TC, 22 July 1858. lock— If you cannot find it—in the drawer where the pills lie—then I dont know the least in the worldCoterie speech. where I put them—when I took them off the ring this morning—and you must ask Mrs GilchristAnne Gilchrist, their neighbor. to buy me or must go and buy me yourself two pairs of white kid gloves of the size seven and three quarters and send them by post—
Oh dear what shall I do?
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 Jan. MS: NLS 525.72. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:243.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: We got out hither yesterday (Tuesday) as preappointed: the journey out was not uncomfortable, perfectly warm by aid of good wrapping and art, the sun shining as we came along, and what seemed strange but is common in chalk countries, all the brooks still unfrozen;—it seems they gush out from a great depth, copious and a good many degrees above frost, so that they can run 10 or 20 miles before being coolled into ice. There was, and is, such an East-wind, on our stepping out, as for virulence of cold I have seldom seen. The Ashburton Carriage being an open one (the Lady here is Highland and patronises cold), poor Jane durst not look at it; so we got a close one, and only sent the luggage in the other. I left my Horse; FarieRobert Farie (1813–82), nonpracticing barrister of independent means, known to the Carlyles since 1846; see 36:152TC to RF, 27 July 1860. to ride it now and then; I am to try one of specimens here, roughshod according to the custom of Hampshire Smiths. Half-past 2 this day: I have got one of the warmest coats in the world; but this will be a severe trial to it. I bathed, cold, soon after 8 this morning; and had a vigorous walk, considering, before breakfast. It seemed my one outlook; for the fussing & changing, the &c &c have not been propitious to me hitherto. But we are to try; we shall see, we shall see!—

Everybody, especially the Lady, is as kind as possible: our party too is small
& insignificant; nobody but ourselves, and Venables (an honest old dish)George Stovin Venables (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist, longtime member of the Ashburton circle. and Kingsley (a new, of higher pretensions but inferior flavour);Probably Charles Kingsley (1819–75; ODNB), novelist, clergyman, and regius prof. of modern history, Cambridge, 1860–69; apparently a recent addition to the Ashburton circle. He and his father, Charles Kingsley the Elder (1781–1860; ODNB), rector of St. Luke’s Church, Chelsea, 1836–60, were known to the Carlyles. these & a Miss BaringLydia Emily Baring; see JWC to CS, [18 Jan.]. are all the supernumeraries hitherto. I have my fire burning & blazing, a beautiful room (still cold), and am supposed to be “at work“: alas, I suspect there can be little working here! But we must try too.— My “Hop“ pillsHops were well known as a remedy for sleeplessness; see 32:108JWC to MR, 24 March 1857. were altogether done! Please send me a little box,—genuine, of abt half a dozen,—in charity quàm primùm [as soon as possible]! Say “The Grange.“
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-GHL, 16 Jan. MS: three pages, sold at Sotheby’s, 4 Feb. 1919, item 390.
div3.head: TC TO GEORGE HENRY LEWES

docBody.p: [No text]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC[JACA], 17 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE THE YOUNGER

docBody.p: I send back the Paper written upon as required. You might mention to yr Ecclefechan functionary, what is a literal fact, that I write every year, for London and for Country parts, quite fully several score of Bank Cheques; and from him alone of mankind has there been the least notice taken of anything wanting in any of them.Probably David Ewart (1817–76), writer (i.e., solicitor) and bank agent, Ecclefechan; he apparently queried one of TC’s checks. My advice therefore rather wd be that he better himself, & ceased to bother people with what is mere surplusage and grimace in regard to those Gladstone stamps!Since the 1853 budget of William Ewart Gladstone (1809–98; ODNB), then chancellor of the exchequer, stamp duty was payable on money orders; see 28:354TC to JWC, 26 Dec. 1853.— However, he doubtless will continue to do his own way.

We came out here (to Lord Ashburton’s, abt 60 miles s. w.) the day before
yesterday; being invited to “a change for a fortnight.“ The weather till today was of the clearest and the fiercest; such a cutting East-wind as I have seldom witnessed. Today is dull-grey, perfectly calm, and I think inclined to thaw. I wish it would.— Hitherto I have got, for my own share, no good of the “change“; tho’ perhaps I may too:—at all events one can make off home again. Your Aunt is really pretty well, and seems to take very kindly to the new mode of life.
I send my love to your Father and to all the rest of you; and am always Affectionately Yours / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS[CSO], [18 Jan.]. MS: Chelsea Public Lib. Pbd: Blunt, “CLC“ 291, where misdated 6 Jan. 1860.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.p: Luckily I didn’t give way to a too confident gladness, when I felt little keys thro’ the paper of your note; or I should have been ready to dash my brains out against the wall, on inspecting them, and recognising one as the key of an old padlock! and the other as a key found on the streets! the only thing I ever found, to the best of my recollection, except once a solitary ha’penny, in Cook’s Grounds!Cook’s Grounds, an area of open ground near what is now Glebe Place, between King’s Rd. and Cheyne Row.

But never mind! I dare say I put the right key away in some place where you couldnt be expected to find it. And in the meantime the worst difficulties of my mistake are obviated for me—by the help of friends. There was nothing in the desk absolutely indispensable for my comfort, except the white gloves and my sewing materials (needle-book reels of cotton &c)—my pearl necklace and bracelets are in the locked desk; but one can exist without these!— And, but for my absurd pride, I neednt have been put about at all—having only to state my difficulties to Miss Emily Baring, or to Lady Ashburton, and immediately Lady’s Maids were despatched to my room with more white gloves, and reels, and needles, than I should use in a year!! Writing paper and envelopes are always at the command of the visitors to any extent—so it is “all right“ in the matter of the missing key— But it is anything but all right in the matter of Mr Carlyle! He has his headache very bad—and talked seriously of going home the very first day after we came, and again he told Lady A last night that he must go home on Saturday (tomorrow) but would leave me here. That I set my face against—he might go if he would, but if he went, I
would certainly go too—and so, tho’ very angry at what he calls my perversity, he is meaning to try to stay a little longer. but I have small hope we shall make out the fortnight! and shouldnt wonder if he went tomorrow after all! However you dont need to make any preparations for our arrival unless you have had it officially intimated to you—only—take care to be in the way. that if he do start off all on a sudden, he mayn’t be put in a rage at the end of his journey by finding nobody to get him some dinner, or what he needs.
As for the cleaning—dont have more than one thing in hands at atime—and then you can’t be found in any irremediable muddle come when we may!

I have been very well since I came here—and walk out every day— The House is full of company as usualAccording to TC, the company consisted only of Kingsley, Venables, and Miss Baring; see TC to JAC, 16 Jan.—and they are people I like, most of them. The Baby is a perfect Darling—but has her own appartments in a distant part of the House—so one has to make a long solemn journey to get a kiss of her!
Lady A. is kindness’s Self!—really twenty angels melted into one couldn’t make up a kinder more loveable creature—
I hope you are both good girls, and that I shall find you well and well doing when I come home.

Poor old Sambo the first Lady’s pet dogLady Harriet Ashburton’s; see 31:176TC to LA, 15 Aug. 1856. is grown so feeble and spiritless! he reminds me so of little Nero! tho’ a big dog—and when he sets up long wailing howls, I fancy he is waiting for his old Mistress—and can hardly keep from bursting out crying—what nonsense!

div3.sourceNote: TC-CB[CBU], 21 Jan. MS: EUL. Pbd: Southern 274 inc. “No 15“ was written at the top of the letter, presumably by Butler.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES BUTLER

docBody.p:
I was in hopes Adamson had finished his Affair with you,Robert Adamson; see TC to CBCBU, 4 Nov. 1860, and TC to RA, 5 Nov. 1860. and delivered us all from those small annoyances. Poor man, I receive, just along with your Letter, the announcement from Dumfries that his good wife is dead;Ann Adamson d. 10 Jan.—probably her illness may have been concerned in these delays of his. I have written to him (enclosing yr Letter to myself) that either thro’ the “Union Bank,“ or thro some other Bank here, there can be no difficulty in having the
communication regulated, and that I expect he will immediately settle with you on that head.

I have also written That wh[en]everLetters omitted. you bid (or send him Order) he is to transmit you on my behalf One Thousand Pounds, to be invested by you in such mode as you judge fittest for me, the “Interests“ &c to be forwarded hither by the Course you settle for those already existing,—namely that Adamson, as my representative, takes care of the whole;Butler wrote to Adamson, 15 Feb., enclosing TC’s half-yearly interest payment: “I have received a letter from Mr. Carlyle under date of 21st Jany in which he says that the 1000£ Stg awaits in your hands my order. You will remit it by exchange in usual form … for my use“ (Kimball 291). and that we avoid altogether “refusals“ of hard money, and other surprising accidents of that nature,—liable to occur at this door in Cheyne Row;One of Butler’s previous letters to TC containing his half-yearly interest payment had been returned unopened; see 3[3]4:265TC to CBU, 9 June 1858. owing to Rowland Hill’s great endeavours to promote Human Correspondence,The introduction of the penny post in 1840 by Rowland Hill (1795–1879; ODNB) greatly increased the volume of mail. 99/100 of whh (at this particular door) are not of the eminently useful kind! If Mr Adamson (faithful British-Linen-Compy Official) had once got the matter in hand, I shall not need to consider it farther, except as I may do the risings of the moon, always coming in their due course witht help of mine.

We are all much interested in your American excitements,Abraham Lincoln was elected president of the U.S. 4 Nov. 1860. He was an opponent of the expansion of slavery from the southern states which were now in a minority against the increasingly powerful North. Seven states began the process of secession and established the Confederate States of America in early Feb. Four more states would join by June. The northern states did not recognize the new Confederacy. The Times reported, 9 Jan.: “Till within a few weeks hardly anybody in this country believed in the dissolution of the Union. People thought that instincts of patriotism and private interest would prevail, and that the Yankees and Southerners would quarrel harmoniously for many years to come“ and, 9 Jan.: “The excessive confidence of the Northerners that all would end well is giving place to sharp anxiety, and, though they seem still to expect the preservation of the Union, it is evident that they look for events which must be most disastrous to American society. … Civil war in a flourishing country and among a kindred people can never be contemplated without horror.“—intensely sympathetic, nearly all, with yr Northern Half of the Business— Wise men seem to be of opinion that you will not go to cutting of throats, but will settle pacifically (being a prudent People)—and also that the Severance, now or soon, must and even should accomplish itself.Butler wrote optimistically to Adamson, 15 Feb.: “Our political affairs look better and all that is required is time for the working out of the difficulties which I confidently anticipate will be without serious conflict, tho not without shock to industrial interests in the southern states particularly“ (Kimball 291). The first battle of the Civil War was fought at Fort Sumter in Charleston harbor 12 and 13 April. To my own poor private thot
the controversy is pretty insane on both sides, (“Big-indian versus Little-Indian,“Cf. the war between the “big-endians“ and “little-endians“ in Lilliput, bk. 1 of Jonathan Swift, Gulliver’s Travels (1726). when I look at it well); and only the issue is momentous.
With many thanks & regards.— Yours always truly,—T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A[LLA], 26 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Quot: Hansons, NE 492.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: By this post, I send you the Pamphlet of Formey on Keith,A Discourse on the Death of Marshal Keith (Edinburgh, 1764) by Jean Henri Samuel Formey (1711–97), prof. of philosophy, and sec. of the Berlin Academy. The French original had been pbd. as Éloges de Mm. les maréchaux de Schwerin et Keith (Berlin, 1760). James Francis Edward Keith (1696–1758; ODNB), Prussian field marshal; see 34:195TC to JWC, 23 Sept. 1858. TC had the pamphlet (including his marginal notes) bound in half calf with full red morocco case (HCC). He wrote on the title-page: “The Lady Ashburton: T.C. (Chelsea, jan 7 1861)“; see TC to [JAC], [ca. 30 Jan.]. which I had the honour to recommend, the other evening. Formey (a Berlin Frenchman, Ex-Preacher, Secretary to their “Royal Society“ &c) was no great things of a Writer; but he was a respectable industrious creature in his kind; and this is by much the best Piece I know of his. Every word of what he says of Keith is true withal;Formey wrote: “[Keith’s] demeanour was like that of a respectable father of a family, which challenged reverence, but, much more strongly challenged love; his constitution was remarkably vigorous, till weakened by the incredible fatigues which he underwent; yet the vigour of his spirit far surpassed that of his body. … But that which ought to render his memory forever precious is, that he was a hero extremely humane; never omitting to do any thing in his power, that might soften and alleviate the calamities of war, lessen the number of its miseries, and, in some measure, relieve those whom it had rendered wretched“ (Discourse 42–44). TC described Keith as “A man of Scotch type; the broad accent, with its sagacities, veracities, with its steadfastly fixed moderation, and its sly twinkles of defensive humour, is still audible to us through the foreign wrappages. Not given to talk, unless there is something to be said; but well capable of it then. Friedrich, the more he knows him, likes him the better“ (Works 16:323–24). whh is an important recommendation! I hope it will deserve a reading from a KinswomanLady Louisa Ashburton was related to Keith by marriage; see TC to [JAC], [ca. 30 Jan.]. of that distinguished man.

I am still sorry and ashamed of my sad fiasco of a visit; but there was no help! Had I held out one other day, or at the utmost two, Lord A. wd have put me on a long-legged Horse, swift as the wind, and there had been an improvement in circumstances otherwise desperate. I am about recovered,
chiefly by galloping about; and work is going on again, at the old sad rate of speed. I wish my Wife had been persuadable to stay where she was doing so well: the poor soul has done nothing but pine ever since, and has only begun yesterday to come round a little.

If it please Heaven I will see The Grange again, under better omens,—fresh weather, at least plenty of riding, for one item;—if I break down in the Summer, you shall bring me to AddiscombeThe Ashburtons’ farm and estate near Croydon. too. But on the whole there will come no good of me till I have done with this unutterable Job,—at which I labour with diminishing strength, sadly, in the one hope of getting free of it, and saving my poor life, what of it may remain.
With kindest regards to Baby, and to Papa if he behave himself,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: TC inserted Keith’s epitaph in Latin, his trans., and comments at the end of Formey’s pamphlet; see Epitaph on Marshal Keith, TC’s copy and notes, Jan.

div3.sourceNote: Epitaph on Marshal Keith, TC’s copy and notes, Jan. MS: Houghton. Pbd: Rodger L. Tarr, “Carlyle on Field Marshal James Keith: A New Impression,“ Carlyle Newsletter 7 (Spring 1986): 34–37. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 26 January 1861.]

docBody.p: [in Hochkirch ChurchHochkirch, about 40 mi. (64.5 km.) E of Dresden; see 34:195TC to JWC, 23 Sept. 1858.

lg.l: Gulielmi Com. Maresc. Hered. Regni Scotiae
Dum in Praelio Non Procul Hinc

docBody.p: that is:

lg.l: Son of Wm Hereditary Earl-Marischal of the Kingdom of Scotland
And of Mary Drummond,William Keith (ca. 1664–1712), 9th Earl Marischal, and Lady Mary Drummond (1675–1729), da. of James Drummond (ca. 1580–1611), 1st earl of Perth.
For Antique character and military virtue:—
Who, in Battle, near this spot,
By head, by hand, by voice and example,—

docBody.p: Put up first in the Churchyard, stands now in the Church, of Hochkirch (40 miles N.E. of Dresden): Urn of black marble, on a Pedestal of grey; serious, fine, appropriate,—close by the wall, behind the Preacher’s left hand. Epitaph
[t.o.

is by Ernesti,Johann August Ernesti (1707–81), prof. of classics and theology, Univ. of Leipzig. TC’s information comes from Varnhagen von Ense, Leben des Feldmarschalls Jakob Keith (Berlin, 1844) 273. a famed classical person. Monument was set up by Sir Robt Murray Keith Ambassador to Austria (2d Sir Rt of that quality,Sir Robert Murray Keith (1730–95; ODNB), commander of various Scottish brigades in Germany; ambassador to Vienna 1772, a post his father, Robert Keith (ca. 1697–1774; ODNB), had also held. Sir Robert wrote to his father, early 1771: “Lord Marischal [George Keith, 10th Earl Marischal (ca. 1692–1778; ODNB] has agreed to my erecting a decent gravestone to the memory of his late brother, and in the place where he fell. They sent me two inscriptions, but they were long and languid. I have engaged Baron Hagen and his friend old Metastasio to touch me up something manly and energetic, and in the course of this summer, my tribute of veneration for the memory of a brave and honest man will be recorded on monumental marble“ (Memoirs and Correspondence of Sir Robert Murray Keith 1:151). It is unclear whether the inscription was by “Metastasio,“ the pseudonym of Pietro Antonio Domenico Trapassi (1698–1782), Italian writer and poet, or by Ernesti; TC named neither in Frederick (Works 17:423).—of kin to the Dead), decr 1776;TC corrected the date in Frederick: “1771, not 1776 as German Guide-books have it“ (Works 17:423).—and is still (Augt 1858)TC visited the church during his journey to Germany in 1858; see 34:195TC to JWC, 23 Sept. 1858. perfectly uninjured. Hochkirch Church has been lately rebuilt: a high, white, airy structure; equal to 1,500 of Aud[i]ence Sermon is in Wendish, half of the Sunday. The old Oak-door of 1758 has been retained; firm as ever, firm as a jail-door,—with several holes of the old shot torn thro’ it, whh have not been meddled with. Abt 700 skeletons of Prussians were dug out, in these late remodellings, from a corner
of the Churchyard.See Works 17:423–24. It was near there, not in the Churchyard (I think), that Keith fell.For Keith’s death, see Works17:416. Feby 3d, 1759, his Body, whh had been honourably buried here, was removed to Berlin (Garnison-Kirche) with due pomp;See Works 17:423. and rests there.

In the Wilhelms-Platz (chief square) in Berlin stands, one of the Four set up there by Friedrich (1777–1780),Thus in MS. the statue of Keith:See Works 17:424.—a bushy-browed, stout-built man (fine black eyes, I have heard),—composure, sagacity, veracity, looking from him; and the Scotch type very visible there and in other records of him.
docBody.name: T.C. (jany, 1861)—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 27 Jan. MS: NLS 517.13. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I believe you heard that we went to The Grange on the theory of a “Fortnight of Country“; and JohnJohn A. Carlyle. tells me he has sent you my little Note, intimating that it proved a down-break; and that we are now here, again on supportable terms That is essentially all the news I have; but I supposed you wd like it from my own hand. Poor Jane was doing decidedly well at The Grange, and I wish she wd have consented to continue; she has been below par ever since we returned, and is not yet up to the old mark even, tho’ again recovering her sleep, and on the mending hand. I myself was rather unwell when we set out; and am certainly not mended by the adventure; but hope I am getting up to the old poor level again, below whh it is not good for me to be. Nothing quite terrifies me but total failure of sleep; and that, I am thankful to say, I have escaped hitherto. Work still goes on,—at a snail’s pace; and I must hold out, in the hope, slowly slowly approaching, of a very great deliverance!

Today I rode out to Ruskin’s, a very pleasant good quite family (of Scotch type, opulent, pious, rational); dined with them 4½ p.m, the old Scotch FatherRuskin’s father, John James Ruskin, although born and educated in Scotland, was from an English family. and two innocent City-People (a fortuitous Comes);Meaning arrival, rather than the Latin for “companion.“ and have just returned, riding thro’ the mild evg seven miles or so: one of the wholesomest rides, or afternoons I have had for a long time.

John, I believe, is gone to Keir, a great House nr Stirling;Keir House, ancestral seat of the Stirlings of Keir since the 15th cent., about 1 mi. (1.5 km.) SW of Dunblane, Perthshire; home of William Stirling (1818–78; ODNB), historian and book collector; see 36:245TC to WS, 13 Sept. 1860. is to be back he thinks on Monday. Tom WattThomas Watt, John’s stepson, had gone to sea in 1856; see 31:244TC to JAC, 29 Sept. 1856; see also TC to [JAC], [ca. 30 Jan.]. John wrote about his other stepsons to James Carlyle Jr., 4 Feb.: “Wm. Watt … has passed the competitive examination for Woolwich. … Arthur … does not look very well just now. Harry is quite strong, & gets on with his classes pretty well“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). (eldest of the Watts) has in the meanwhile enlisted for a soldier (strange crazy mortal), and a Telegram is off for John, whh I hope he will disregard. Nothing can be done for the poor fool of a youth; and indeed drill is what he wants. Adieu dear Sister! Yours Ever T.C

div3.sourceNote: TC-RWE, 29 Jan. MS: RWEMA. Pbd: Norton, CE 2:311–13; Slater, CEC 533–34.
div3.head: TC TO RALPH WALDO EMERSON

docBody.p: The sight of my handwriting will, I know, be welcome again. Tho’ I literally do not write the smallest Note once in a month, or converse with anything but Prussian Nightmares of a hideous, and with my Horse (who is human in comparison), and with my poor Wife (who is altogether human, and heroically cheerful to me, in her poor weak state),—I must use the five minutes, whh have fallen to me today, in acknowledget, due by all laws terrestrial and celestrial, of the last BookThe Conduct of Life, pbd. Dec. 1860. that has come from you.

I read it a great while ago, mostly in sheets,Smith, Elder & Co., Emerson’s British publisher, had sent TC proof sheets of the work autumn 1860; see TC to JAC, 7 Oct. 1860, and TC to S, E & Co.SEC, 8 Oct. 1860. and again read it in the finely printed form,—I can tell you, if you do not already guess, with a satisfaction given me by the Books of no other living mortal. I predicted to yr English Bookseller a great sale even, reckoning it the best of all your Books. What the sale was or is I nowhere learned; but the basis of my prophecy remains like the rocks, and will remain. Indeed, except from my Brother John, I have heard no criticism that had much rationality,—some of them incredibly irrational (if that matter had not altogether become a barking of dogs among us);—but I always believe there are in the mute state a great number of thinking English souls, who can recognise a Thinker, and a Sayer, of perennially human type, and welcome him as the rarest of miracles, in “such a spread of knowledge“A common phrase, though attrib. to TC by Slater (CEC 533); also used by John Stuart Mill in a letter to TC, 17 July 1832 (Francis E. Mineka, ed., The Earlier Letters of John Stuart Mill, 1812–48, 2 vols. [Toronto and London, 1963] 112) and by Samuel Smiles, Self-Help: With Illustrations of Character and Conduct (1859) 249. as there now is:—one English soul of that kind there
indubitably is; and I certify hereby, notarially if you like, that such is emphatically his view of the matter. You have grown older, more pungent, piercing;—I never read from you before such lightning-gleams of meaning as are to be found here. The finale of all, that of “Illusions“The last essay in The Conduct of Life. falling on us like snow-showers, but again of “the gods sitting stedfast on their thrones“ all the while,A reference to the final para. of “Illusions.“—what a Fiat Lux [Let there be light] is there, into the deeps of a philosophy, whh the vulgar has not, whh hardly 3 men living have, yet dreamt of! Well done, I say; and so let that matter rest.

I am still 12 months or so from the end of my Task;Frederick was not completed until 1865. very uncertain often whether I can, even at this snail’s pace, hold out so long. In my life I was never worn nearly so low, and seem to get weaker monthly. Courage! If I do get thro’, you shall hear of me again. Yours forever
docBody.name: T. Carlyle
docBody.note: Emerson replied, 16 April, thanking TC “for the cordial note which brought me joy many weeks ago. It was noble & welcome in all but its boding account of yourself & your task. But I have had experience of your labors, & these deplorations I have long since learned to distrust. We have settled it in America, as I doubt not it is settled in England, that ‘Frederick’ is a history which a beneficent Providence is not very likely to interrupt. And may every kind & tender influence near you & over you keep the best head in England from all harm.“ He also gave notice that his “friend—almost my sister,—Elizabeth Hoar, embarks again tomorrow for England.“ Elizabeth Sherman Hoar (1814–78), member of a prominent Massachusetts family, had visited JWC the previous year when TC was away, presumably Aug. or Sept. 1860; visit untraced.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JF, [29 Jan.]. MS: NLS 607.573. Pbd: Bliss, JWC 286–87.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
Mr C arrived at home soberly at a quarter before nine (!) on Sunday night, and declared himself so benefited by the “human afternoon“ he had spent, that I fondly hoped he would be induced to try the ‘human’ dodge again, next Saturday. But on Monday morning he told me he was “considerably flurried, he found, by those Ruskin enterprizes,TC’s visit to the Ruskins, Sun., 27 Jan.; see TC to JCA, 27 Jan. pleasant as they were at the time“; and so I didn’t press him to decide about Saturday; when he declared if he must make a decision “in the present state of his interior“ it would be ‘No.’— Nor today have I said anything; only fixed my eyes on him from time to time
in an inquiring manner! But now, all out of his own head, he has just bid me tell you “we must put it off a little till he is thro’ a particular welter of confusions—that he has just got to see a clearer country beyond“:— I give the message just as I got it; trusting that, by the free masonry amongst Men of Genius, you will find it quite satisfactory.

Since “it“ is only to be “put off a little“—I needn’t be tying down Mrs ForsterEliza Ann Forster. with an appointment to luncheon, but will “carry out“ my original purpose of taking my chance of finding her at home some morning—for merely a little conversation.
Mrs HawkesEmilie Hawkes. The Times reported, 30 Jan., the granting of her divorce from Sydney Wells Hawkes. says “I like that man; he is cordial and good!“
Indeed is he!
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JAC], [ca. 30 Jan.]. MS: EUL inc. Hitherto unpbd. The paper has been torn in half; the beginning of the letter is missing.
div3.head: TC TO [JOHN A. CARLYLE]

docBody.p: a little, if it wd stay with me, I cd be content with. I have had Laing’s Pamphlet on KeithTC had presumably originally acquired the pamphlet from Laing, with whom he had recently been in contact through John A. Carlyle; see TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1860. (do not tell Laing this, only kindly thank him) bound in fine form, and have sent it off to the now Lady Ashburton (with some Ms. Notes &c) who is a Kinswoman,—“descended from Keith’s sister both by Father and by Mother.“Marshal Keith’s sister Lady Anne Keith was connected by marriage to both Lady Louisa’s mother and father, although there was no blood relationship with either; Lady Anne was the first wife of Lady Louisa’s paternal great-great-grandfather, and the mother-in-law of a cousin of Louisa’s maternal great-grandfather. An honourable little fact in genealogy. No Scotchman of those times played, in his quietly valiant way, a manlier part than Keith,—or better deserves a real Life if there were anybody to write it.

A servant from the Family-HotelIn Oxford St.; see TC to JAC, 3 Feb.; unidentified further. where Tom Watt is or was, came down with a message from the Landlord,Unidentified.—I suppose you know to what effect, tho’ you say nothing of it! Poor soul,—But what help can anybody render him? I suppose to be under a drill-serjeantSee TC to JCA, 27 Jan. was really what he needed. I did not stir; especially in my present downbroken state. Jane purposes to drive up tomorrow,
and at least ask at the door. Did Henry run up to try?Henry Watt; John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 4 Feb., that Henry “had to go … last week to London to see his brother Tom“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). Perhaps not. My hope was, and is, you wd leave the helpless matter to its own course. Your affect[te] / T. Carlyl[e]

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MB, 31 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd. The letter is written on notepaper decorated with cherubs and green foliage; JWC crossed out the printed “Vendredi“ [Fri.] and wrote in her date, 31 Jan., a Thurs.; see frontispiece [available in the CLO on the table of contents page for this volume].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY BARING

docBody.p: Baby of the World! Dear, wee Jewel-Baby! God bless you! and bless your Papa and Mama! and make you a good child! So prays your most loving admirer / Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 31 Jan. MS: FC. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: Dear Forster,—Here is my Signature at the place marked.Untraced. I wd rather have put it at the bottom but there was no room.

I am really at a low pass, totally unequal to anything convivial; but the sound of your friendly voice again, wd be like a battle melody sticking into the wearied heart of me. Why have you no Horse! We must contrive something.
docBody.name: T. C.
docBody.p: Chelsea, 31 jany 1861

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [early Feb.]. MS: NLS 605.426. Quot: A. Carlyle, NLM239–40; Fielding and Sorensen 260. Dated approximately by JWC’s recovery from the chill she caught on her return from The Grange, 19 Jan. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 February 1861.]
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
I think it was I who wrote last; and in that belief, with the spirit proper to a native of a Commercial Country, I have been resting on my oars till I should get your answer. But today, while thinking of you and wondering why you didnt write, it suddenly came to my mind that in my last letter I had engaged
to write again from The Grange. Did I?— I am not sure whether or no!In her New Year letter, JWC did not promise to write; see JWC to MR, [30 Dec. 1860]. I have the worst memory of all the women I know; for not only do I forget utterly particulars of quite recent date,—but I remember particulars of no date at all! that is to say imagine to remember minutely things that never happened—never were!! Since I became aware, by repeated experience, of this freak of memory in me, I have felt a toleration which I never felt before for — white Liars!

Perhaps they are merely unfortunate people with memories like mine!— But no matter about that just now. I was going to say that whether I did or didn’t engage to write again the mere doubt is sufficient basis to write upon, instanter;

And it wasn’t much of a forget in me not writing from the Grange: as you will admit when I tell you that we staid at the Grange only four days!!— Alas Yes! All my lookings forward to a pleasant time there, and all my preparations of suitable toilets, and my lockings up of silver spoons &c at home ended in a visit of four days!— It really looks as if I were never to be allowed to go thro’ with anything pleasant again in this world!— I was feeling such a different creature in these four days! The people were almost without exception such agreeable people! Lady A so adorably kind! the Weather so propitious! above all, the escape from the valley of the shadow of Frederick the GreatCoterie speech; cf. Ps. 23:4TC to JWC, 3 April 1848. JWC began using the phrase in relation to Frederick early 1860; see 6:44JWC to LLA, 16 Jan. 1860, 47JWC to MCA, 16 Jan. 1860, and 72JWC to MCA, 16 Feb. 1860. such a happiness!— A fortnight of all that would brace me up; I thought, to hold out against the worries of Life for months to come! And behold on the fourth night Mr C was pleased to smoke and talk with some young officers in the Conservatory till two in the morning—all about the Crimea—always a too exciting subject for him! and naturally, he couldnt sleep after—and instead of just being more careful the next night, what does he do but rush into my room whilst I was dressing in the morning; and looking like an incarnation of the Gunpowder plot,The unsuccessful Catholic plot, 5 Nov. 1605, to blow up the Houses of Parliament and kill the Protestant king James VI of Scotland and I of England and Wales (1566–1625; ODNB; see 36:220TC to LS, 2 Sept. 1860). tell me that he “would and must and the whole world shouldn’t prevent him returning home that day!—sleep being impossible there!“— —

Nothing that anybody could say or do, or imagine was of the least use in altering his resolve, so there was nothing for it but to fling my elaborately prepared toilets by armfuls into the large Box (new-bought for that visit)—and go home—to a house never dreaming of us!—not a fire in any room of it!—stair carpets up, and stairs giving damp evidence of having been newly washed!— Of course I caught a fine rheumatism in my head and back by the
job, and never got a wink of sleep the night after this horrid homecoming. And of course Mr C had “a capital nights sleep—the best sleep he remembered to have had for weeks!“—a man always sleeps capitally when he has had his humour out! and the more provoking his humour the more capitally he sleeps!—

It was ten days before I got over the effects of that chill in the cold damp house— But I am now ‘about’ again—only I wish that Frederick the Great had never been born! or had died of the measles in his first years!
