Is your new cookThe 1861 census lists Mary Healady (possibly a misspelling of Headley) (b. ca. 1811). come? and how does she promise?

Have you still the housemaidJannet McKinnlee (b. ca. 1838). that I saw there? I like to know all about the surroundings of a person I love. when I am thinking about you it make the picture in my mind more lifelike.

Oh I got such a start followed by such a shock the other day! Sarah throwing the door wide open, announced, clear and loud, “Dr Russell“! I sprang to my feet with an exclamation of joy, and all but rushed into the arms of a man, not very unlike your Husband, but a man whom I should never have been tempted to embrace in his own person!John Rutherfurd Russell (1816–66), physician to the London Homeopathic Hospital; see 33:246TC to JRR, 21 June 1858. The disappointment was too marked for passing unobserved: and I didn’t smooth it off much by saying: “Oh! I thought it was a Dr Russell that is a very dear friend of mine“!!! “Which means that you don’t consider me as such!“—was the somewhat offended answer,

And this was the second time,Possibly when Dr. Russell called during Dec. 1859; see 36:32TC to JAC, 29 Dec. 1859. the same disappointment had been caused me by the same man!—a Son of old Dr RussellJames Russell (1754–1836; ODNB), first prof. of clinical surgery at Edinburgh Univ., 1803. of Edinr—a homeopathic Dr this one—who married a very rich wifeGeorgina Isabella Maxwell, whom he m. 1853; his first wife was Margaret Harriet Renny (1824–52), m. 1845. here—

Won’t you soon get the Photographing Barber (?) or Saddler?Thomas Douglas (1828–96), hairdresser and photographer, 69 Drumlanrig St., Thornhill. at Thornhill to do Holme Hill for my Gallery of sentiment?JWC’s “Gallery of Sentiment“ was apparently on the walls of her bedroom, where she hung pictures of places connected with her childhood; see 29:240JWC to JDO, 19 Jan. 1855. For a later photograph of Holmhill (Dumfries and Galloway Museums Service, Thomas Carlyle / Ref. 7), see 110above.
Kind remembrance to all my friends— Your ever affectionate / Jane Carlyle

figure.p: Holmhill, Thornhill

p.hi: Courtesy of Dumfries and Galloway Museums Service

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA], [early Feb.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Hansons, NE 492–93 inc. Dated by the recent visit to The Grange and by JWC’s recovery from her chill. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 February 1861.]
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: It was such a relief, on arriving at MarrochettisBaron Carlo Marochetti (1805–67; ODNB), Italian sculptor, living in London since 1848, at 34 Onslow Sq. yesterday; out of temper and out of breath, to find that you had not come, and—gone! That was what I half expected; to be told, that her Ladyship had been gone a quarter of an hour! All the World and its wife took a notion of driving down to Chelsea yesterday, and doing the civil thing by Mrs Carlyle; and the result was that, altho I tied on my bonnet in the street, and ran all the way, I didn’t reach Marrochetti’s till a quarter after four. He came to the door himself, and told me you would still come, with a calm certitude of belief which quite imposed on me, and persuaded me into an easy chair from which he displaced his Cat. “Do me the favour to sit down here at once; because if you dont, there is to be feared, my Cat will again take possession of this chair!“— —

The Chair commanded the best view of your Busts. The one in clay struck me as much improved since I had seen it; I could have recognised it anywhere, tho it certainly bears no trace of that power of flattery which the Baron has given such evidence of in his other female heads—as for the marble one, I can’t understand how it has happened! or what it would be at! Perhaps the tinting had something to do with the sickly, Madame Toussaud wax-workAnna Maria Tussaud, b. Grosholtz (1761–1850; ODNB), wax modeler and founder of the Madame Tussaud’s waxworks exhibition. impression it made on me. Anyhow, the lower part of the face, especially, seemed to me utterly without expression or likeness— And I had the audacity to tell Marrochetti so! He did not snub me; but agreed that “there was still much to be done—the likeness could not be judged of while it was still so unfinished.“Marochetti’s marble bust of Lady Louisa was displayed from 3 May at the annual summer exhibition of the Royal Academy: “Perhaps the most noteworthy works in this [sculpture] department were three busts, ‘The Duchess of Manchester,’ ‘Lady Ashburton,’ and ‘The Late Marquess of Waterford,’ by Baron Marochetti“ (Annual Register [1861] 67). For the bust, see Virginia Surtees, The Ludovisi Goddess (1984), and the ODNB entry for Lady Ashburton. Perhaps it will come right then after all!—the brow and upper part of the face is fine, even now. “The truth is,“ he said to me with a little air of telling me a secret,“that Lady Ashburton is veree difficult to make! She is a beautiful woman—amazingly beautiful! and her eyes—! there is in them such goodness and a something wild that is very beautiful, and difficult to make!“ He appealed to me if I didn’t think so. as to your being so difficult to make, I couldn’t say, not having ever tried; but I said I knew what he meant about your eyes, and that there was the same expression in your—Baby’s!!—a grave statement of a fact on my part which was received by him with an explosion of mirth, quite beyond what he had seemed capable of, and cries of “Oh!“—“Oh“!—“Oh!“— “So young a Babee Madame!— Such young Babee cannot yet have beauty!“— Why not I should like to know!— The Baron may be a dexterous Sculptor; but clearly he is no Poet!—and has neither sense, nor feeling, nor knowledge about Bābeěs!JWC’s scansion marks indicated pronunciation with a long first and short second syllable.

I should like much to see you dressed for the Drawing roomA Drawing Room (formal reception) held by Queen Victoria was announced for 21 March (Times, 8 Feb.) but was canceled as the queen’s mother, Princess Victoria, duchess of Kent (1786–1861; ODNB), d. 16 March.—if I might!

Oh I was so sorry to be told by Hanah (who gave me the shoes of Mr C’s that MasonJames Mason and Hannah were Ashburton servants. had brought from the Grange) that you had missed the train that day! It was enough to make you hate me! at all events to make Lord A—hate me for ever!

Is Mrs MackenzieMaria Stewart-Mackenzie, widow of Lady Ashburton’s brother George. still with you? If so, please to give her my heartiest thanks; I shall take the liberty of answering her letter the first time it falls in my way to have any thing of human interest to tell—anything entitling me to recall myself to your Sister in laws remembrance with a modest probability of not boring her thereby.
Oh “Ba-bee“! I love you! and kiss your wee wee fingers and nose!
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JC, [early Feb.?]. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Hitherto unpbd. Tentatively dated by JWC’s similar remark wishing Frederick had “never been born“ or “died of the measles in his first years“; see JWC to MR, [early Feb.]. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 February 1861.]
div3.head: JWC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have a disclosure to make to you, which I hope will not cause your hair to stand on end!— Our oat-meal is done! I should rather say my oat meal, for I have eaten right thro’ this last supply myself. Mr C being inadequate to a solid supper when he dines, as a general rule, about seven o’clock. To be sure there was only a very little bagful to begin with, and I am not sorry there wasn’t more of that Gill meal; because I didn’t like it nearly so well as the Scotsbrig sort. When you can conveniently send me two or three stones of your’n (as they say here) I shall receive it with the thankfulness of an unfledged bird gaping for crowdy!Either soft cheese or thin porridge as previously glossed at 9:109TC to JCA, 29 Dec. 1836.

We are (in the constant concluding phrase of my illegitimate Cousin who writes to me from Haddington) “I am thankful to say (!) in our frail ordinar.“ Mr C overworks himself and mismanages himself in every possible way, and if an angel from heaven were to come down and go on its knees to him to be more careful and regular; it would make no difference! He is “vara obstinate in his own way“!Coterie speech; “Cumberland man’s account of the Scotch“; see Froude, LM 3:170. But for the rest I think him rather better in health, certainly not worse than he was last year at this time. My own health and comfort suffer, I fancy, quite as much from this accursed Book as his do; by reflection, on the whole I often wish that Frederick The Great had never got born, or that he had died of measles or hooping cough in early childhood!

I had cherished a hope of seeing you all last atumn; as you might hear at the time. But the Pigs ran thro’Coterie speech; see 14:226JWC to MAWE, 15 July 1842. that project as they have done thro’ every project
for a little recreation and pleasure that I have made bold to entertain these several years back.
Kindest regards to “wee Jenny“ and “the Boys.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 1 Feb. MS: NLS 517.14. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Last night there arrived this cheery little Note from Jenny,Janet Hanning, their sister living in Canada.—betokening the hard struggle out yonder, and the nimble little nieves that are fighting it. As JohnJohn A. Carlyle had perhaps told TC that he intended to be in Dumfriesshire this weekend; 1 Feb. was a Fri. He wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 4 Feb., that he had thought for “several weeks“ of “going to Scotsbrig some saturday & staying till monday“ but his plan was “hindered by the inconvenience of the Ecclefn trains & reports of bad weather in Annandale“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). is probably at Scotsbrig today (down for a day or two, to see James Currie),James Currie or Corrie (1815–96), son of Sandy Corrie of Newfield; probably home on a visit from Mauritius; see 8:6TC to WG, 10 Jan. 1835, and 35:65TC to CBU, 8 April 1859. John A. Carlyle apparently visited them 1 March; see TC to JCHA, 28 Feb. I transmit the little Document to you in the first place.

I had a Letter long ago; and have never yet paid it.TC had not yet replied to Jean’s last letter to him. I calculate you hear in general that nothing fatal has befallen here;—and as to the details of my affairs, it is oftenest really rather a charity not to speak abt them; so monotonously miserable are they, and are like to be till (as I still hope to do) I get thro’ this unspeakable Slough of Despond,Cf. John Bunyan, Pilgrim’s Progress. where I have been weltering 10 years; far too long at such a time of life!— Nothing terrifies me, but want of sleep: that, however, is a quite hideous business, when one is in it! Like a hunted animal, one feels; a human soul in utter weakness, with all the Devils chacing it!— I had one bout (nr a fortnight off and on) since you heard last; but am, Heaven be praised, tolerably out of it again.— For the rest I feel, after all, as if the back of the Task were really broken: in june or july I may have the first vol., as it were, done.Vol. 3, the first of the second two vols. of the first edn. of Frederick. The 2d or last,Vol. 4 (1864) was not the last vol.; two more followed in 1865. I have a hope, will be far easier;—and then—!

Your Jamie never comes these several weeks: I know very well what hinders
him, the good menseful soul!James Aitken presumably thought TC too busy to welcome company. I was glad yr JohnJean Aitken’s youngest son. did not come to adventure here: better he shd be beside his Mother & kin, at least for a fair space coming.

Make my kind compts to AirdThomas Aird (1802–76; ODNB), poet, journalist, and ed. of the Dumfries Herald; old friend of TC; see 6:361TC to JAC, 29 March 1833. when he calls;—tell me of poor old Mary Grier,Mary Grierson; see TC to JCA, 30 Dec 1860. and whether she does not want money?—

Ballantyne,Thomas Ballantyne (1806–71; ODNB; see 36:27636:biographical note), author and journalist; the collapse of his paper, The Statesman (pbd. 10 Oct. 1857–23 April 1859), presumably left him with debts; see 33:182–84TC to LG, 14 Feb. 1858. Ballantyne later joined the editorial staff of the Saint James’s Chronicle. we learn, has been thro The Insolvent Court; and is as brisk as ever!—End of letter and signature cut away.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JN, [1 Feb.]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Rd / Haverstock Hill. PM: 2 Feb. 1861. MS: NLS letter 554.58, envelope 553.229. Pbd: Scudder 31. JWC wrote “J. Neuberg“ and TC added the rest of the address.
div3.head: JWC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: We think the tea excellent and shall be glad and obliged to have as large a quantity of it as you can spare—the more the better!
I caught a fine cold yesterday and am for the moment in the Profundis [depths]!
Kind regards to your Sister.Rosetta Frankau, with whom Neuberg lived.
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 3 Feb. MS: NLS 517.15. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I suppose this will get to you a few hours sooner, if despatched today; at any rate I hasten to tell you that I am up to my old mark again, nearly or altogether, and that you may dismiss your friendly anxieties for the present.
Nay perhaps I shall gather a little more strength as the spring goes on,—who knows? This I take to have been a kind of biliary crisis, in solution of the frost. At any rate it seems past. I had a better sleep last night than had been vouchsafed me for six months past. My ears still ring, continually; but there is nothing in my head; the old load of jumbling quicksilver (a very bad phasis) has been absent for a long time. Every day I contrive to have a little snatch of sleep (at least I lie down absolutely motionless for half an hour) directly after riding, and before dinner: this, I sometimes think, is perhaps the root of all the traceable improvet since Octr last.— Jane too is moderately well; sees talking friends &c; takes two drives weekly in brougham, besides inferior vehiculations.— Did I ever tell you our little Charlotte was here again, this long while back. A big Charlotte we had got, “Perfection Charlotte“ as the Missus called her, did not satisfy at all; so the little one was got in her stead,—full of penitence, of good resolution; whh she has kept well: a very nice little Lassie, full of sense, attacht and dexterity; whom it is a pleasure to see by one, in comparison. The other maidSarah Piggott. too (junior in rank & years, tho’ taller by inches) does well: so that the House is visibly in trimmer case than it was wont to be. A thing well worth purchasing, since it was purchasable.

Jane went to the Oxford-Street Tavern; found the Landlord a young civil decent-looking man, the place itself very rough-looking, gin and tobacco main elements. What she cd understand of the Landlord’s Narrative was precisely what you know,—capped always at intervals with “All right now, Ma’am; he’s all right now!“ Nothing can be made of him, but fling the bridle on his neck. Jane asserts always, and has asserted, he is a little mad even in the normal state.John A. Carlyle had written to James Carlyle Jr., 19 March 1860: “It is a sad thing to be born with such deep-rooted tendencies to lunacy as he inherits from his father“; he continued: “you will easily conceive how I am bound to silence in regard to that tendency to insanity“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).

You say nothing, this good while, of Christ’s Kirk.See TC to JAC, 4 Dec. 1860. Perhaps have given it up? Not the worst plan, I cd guess. Dr Irving’s Book,The History of Scotish Poetry (1861); see TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1860. so authentic and distinct, will, I judge, be well worth reading: my respects to his Widow,Janet Irving. if you see her. To Erskine & Mrs S.Thomas Erskine and his sister Christian Stirling. all manner of kind regards.

div3.sourceNote: TC-VL, 4 Feb. Addr: 8. Doctors Commons. PM: 4 Feb. 1861. MS: NLS letter 23167.127, envelope 23167.129. Quot: Fielding, “Vernon Lushington.“ Vernon Lushington (1832–1912; ODNB), writer and barrister, had helped TC with the editing of his Collected Works, 16 vols. (1857–58); see TC to VL, 2 Jan. 1856, TC to VL, 5 Jan. 1857, and TC to VL, 5 Oct. 1857.
div3.head: TC TO VERNON LUSHINGTON

docBody.p: There had stood in some shelf here, for four or five years, a wretched Book in 2 voll. called Codex Fredericianus,[Frederick II and Samuel Cocceji], The Frederician Code, 2 vols. (Edinburgh, 1761), trans. of their Project des Corporis Juris Fridericiani (Halle, 1749); see Works 16:238–40. Baron Samuel von Cocceji (1679–1755), Prussian grand chancellor and chief minister of justice.—whh, some months ago, finding it only a sorrow to me, I think I must have persuaded some friend to accept, & take away from my sight. Such is the dim half-recollection that dawns on me, or the dim hypothesis whh rises, now when a certain temporary and even pressing use for that Codex Freds occurs, and said Codex is nowhere to be found in this house! I think I did and must have sent it away by somebody. In a dimmer form, the question rises, Was it not perhaps by you? Nobody so likely to do me a good-natured action in the way of absorbing Law-rubbish!— In fine, if you have this old Codex, or cd borrow it anywhere among yr learned Law acquaintanceship, for a few weeks,—it wd do me a real service; and shd be returned punctually, with no wish except never to see it again.
Do what you can in this matter. My hurry is extreme, but I hope the thing is intelligible to a perspicacious mind.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 4 Feb. 1861. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—I have forgotten what it was I undertook to do for Common;John Common (ca. 1827–89); see 34:27334:biographical note. whether to write to Adamson that the sum must be allowed at Common’s next rent-day;Probably 28 Feb. (see 4:44TC to JAC, 27 Feb. 1826). or to give Common at once a Checque for the sum,—in whh latter case, I ought to have known Common’s Christian name, & do not! I send the Cheque (£25..9..6) with that deficit made good the best I can.TC wrote a check, 6 Feb.: “Common the Ten/ant at Craigenputtoch (for Lime Asst / £25..9..6“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

I am much obliged by the trouble you take:—if there is anything wrong in
the present mode of doing my part, you must send me back the Document and I will alter according to instruction. I am glad the man has got the LimeFor previous discussion of liming at Craigenputtoch, see 34:100TC to JWC, 6 Aug. 1858. actually to its place;—half the covenanted quantity if I remember rightly.

For some weeks I had been below average rather, in regard to health; but am now coming up again, and even in hopes to rise a little higher than the old line perhaps. Whh wd be of very great service in the furtherance of my working, to speak of nothing else. My one wish in the world is that I were thro’ that!— With constant love to you all, Your affectte T. Carlyle (in huge haste!)

div3.sourceNote: TC-AH, 13 Feb. MS: NLS 3823.214. Pbd: Correspondence of Sir Arthur Helps, ed. E. A. Helps (London and New York, 1917) 241. Arthur Helps (1813–75; ODNB), writer and historian; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s.
div3.head: TC TO ARTHUR HELPS

docBody.p: Many kind thanks for this kind Gift of your last volume.The fourth and final vol. of Arthur Helps, The Spanish Conquest in America, and Its Relation to the History of Slavery and to the Government of Colonies, 4 vols. (1855–61). For TC’s letter on receiving vol. 3, see 32:100–101TC to AH, 10 March 1857. It is very pretty reading, like its predecessors, where I dip into it. By and by, if it please Heaven, I design to give that work an Examination much worthier of its qualities than I cd yet bestow on it,—or anything that has appeared in its time: wretched sinner, swallowed in the Prussian quagmires (fetid as the Stygian), and swimming for life (too literally that!) as I have long been.

Yes, my friend, I do congratulate you on getting honourably done with such a Business. None feels more than myself what a blessed consummation;—nor do I know any one who has deserved it better. Euge [Well done]!

I thank you much, Dear Helps, for this volume itself, and for what it is the token of; and am always (below par in health for some days past,George Henry Lewes wrote to Helps, 21 Feb.: “I was with Carlyle the other day-grimmer than ever“ (Eliot, Letters 8:275). whh has occasioned the delay),
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[H & Co.][HAC], 14 Feb. MS: Mrs. Simon Stodart, Kingstoun House, N. Berwick, inc. Text from copy of MS. Addressee identified by TC’s check (see below) and TC to HAC, 23 Feb.
div3.head: TC TO MESSRS HUTCHISON & CO.

docBody.p: The Wine you lately sent, both Port and Sherry, proves well, and is quite satisfactory. But I am sorry to give, upon both the Whiskey and the Brandy, an altogether different report.TC had written a check, 8 Dec. 1860, to Hutchison & Co., Leith: “for Brandy Wine Whisky) £18..5..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

About the Whiskey, whh indeed I shall never drink more of, for my own share, but which is in small quantity and can easily be given away to persons here who are not so critical in that matter, I shd not have troubled you at all,—nor do I wish you to do anything further about it. But the Brandy is more important to me.

My employment of that liquor is principally what may be called medicinal; and for this I find this present sort very unfit hitherto. A glass of it, made into punch before bedtime, regularly gives me a headache (as the inferior kinds of alcohol are always sure to do);—and, in short, by various symptoms, I am driven upon the conclusion that this is not genuine grape Brandy, but a “Cognac“ done by some refiner in that part of the world from Corn-alcohol, perhaps of native Scottish production! This, I haveMS ends here.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [mid-Feb.?]. Addr: Steamboat Pier / Battersea Bridge. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Tentatively dated by TC’s citation of Voltaire’s Oeuvres, vol. 32, in bk. 14 of Frederick; bk. 14 was finished early March. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 15 February 1861.]
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Wd you call at the London Library tomorrow, and get me Vol. 32 of their “Voltaire“TC cited a letter of Voltaire from Oeuvres 32:148; see Works 15:453. TC’s own copy of Voltaire’s Works (see 31:62–63TC to JAC, 11 April 1856, and 119–20TC to BBI, 8 July 1856) did not contain the letter he wanted. (whh is in 40 volumes), and leave it as you return home. I shall want it here, for the sake of old Notes in my hand.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [19 Feb.?]. Addr: (Battea Bridge Pier). MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Tentatively dated by the completion, early March, of bk. 14 of Frederick, which contained references to Dettingen.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—I want to see you instantly (if possible); on a little Dettingen matter.For the battle of Dettingen, see Works 15:424–52.
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 21 Feb. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got all yr Notes and messages,—the last yesterday (the good solid Account of Barbour:No closing parenthesis. Possibly James Barbour (1834–1912), recently set up in practice as an architect in Dumfries; his father, Robert Barbour (or Barber) (b. ca. 1791), farmed at Shangan (or Drumshangan), about 3 mi. (5 km.) NE of Craigenputtoch (see 17:84TC to JWC, 26 Aug. 1843).—I had not heard of poor Donaldson’s death at all, only that he was suffering from “want of sleep“ &c. Poor fellow; I was truly sorry: he was the flower of all that family; a man of very considerable talent;—and, in spite of his loud contentious ways, he was always to me very friendly.John William Donaldson d. 10 Feb. in London; his Times obit., 13 Feb., recorded that he was placed “by his attainments in comparative philology in the first rank of British scholars. … But the limits of his strength, though he was not yet 50, had been reached and exceeded, and, amid the regrets of the many who enjoyed his friendship or admired his works, he has expired in the prime of his life—another victim of a hardworking age.“ The Athenaeum called him “one of the most distinguished of our English scholars, in the full maturity of his intellectual powers“ (16 Feb.). For TC’s admiration for Donaldson, see 31:90–91TC to JWD, 9 May 1856, and 31:160TC to JWC, 8 Aug. 1856. And it is one other fellow-wayfarer to whom we must say Adieu.—

I did not write to you all this while, having been, precisely since your first Note came, under trouble abt sleep again, really a bad bout; and unwilling to trouble you with what you cd only grieve for, but in no way help.TC had written to John A. Carlyle, 3 Feb.; John, meanwhile, had reported to James Carlyle Jr., 4 Feb.: “On Friday last I had a little note from Chelsea. Nothing very much amiss there, but your uncle still is less strong & less able to sleep than usual“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). I find it to be altogether the liver, and that there are crises in the state of that fickle organ. My triumphant condition, in regard to sleep, whh had lasted above a
week, was attended with great stupidity; I have been doing more work (tho’ on sad terms) during this late sleepless time;—liver having charged its hand in some way, as I interpret! Nothing is so hideous to one’s feelings; but I suppose there are worse things in reality,—many a one lies awake, for years almost, witht quite wrecking.— I believe, I am now over the bar again; and that you need not bother yourself abt me for some time again. A crisis is evidt; something like what befel in late Autumn last;See TC to Sir GSSGS, 10 Oct. 1860—perhaps something vernal too may be in this one? At all events, I have got into smoother water, and am in the hoping way again. Work does go steadily on; I can now see thro’ it in some sort, had I health! I am duly sensible of the conditn of my “scarce seaworthy bark“ (poor old herringboat that has been much abt!)—and I will try all I can to be gentle with it, and make it do. Courage!—

If you go or write to Scotsbrig, recommend to Jamie those “blown-down Craigenputtoch trees“ (Note inclosed);TC inserted here: “Note from Jamie junr whh cannot now be found!“ they have no chance of help otherwise!John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 6 March: “Here is a note from your uncle. I suppose it may be necessary some time soon to go & see about the fallen wood at Craigenputtock“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).— —My last stock of Leith Brandy proves to be whisky in disguise; whh has been a point agt me in the late insomnolent times! I am returning it upon the man;Messrs. Hutchison & Co. and both he and Ruskin Senr are on search for genuine. Adieu dear Brother. Your Affte ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WM[WMAN], 22 Feb. MS: Mantell. Quot: Hansons, NE 484, 493–94; Fielding and Sorensen 261.
div3.head: JWC TO WALTER MANTELL

docBody.p:
I knew that you would write to us in fulness of time, and, in the meantime would remember us.Mantell left Britain Oct. 1859. So your letter found me “all right,“—delighted to get it, and not mistuned by the delay. But, how did I know? Who told me? Nobody told me! God help those who know only what they are told! and God especially help those who draw their knowledge—from “Authorities on all matters of all men“!Untraced. For me, I prefer knowing things “by my own sharpness,“Cf. Bob Jakin in George Eliot, The Mill on the Floss (1860). or, still better, own divination.— Do you know I have the second
sight—moi? inherited along with some acres of peat bog from my Great Ancestor John Welsh the Covenanter; who foretold The Plague, “in three weeks,“ on a City that rejected his preaching (Orleans); and The Plague came, and justified him,—to a day!JWC’s ancestor was not John Welsh but his brother David Welsh; for this and for John Welsh’s prophetic gifts, see 16:41JWC to JW, 2 Feb. 1843.— My second sight is less positive; is, in fact the second sight of a Woman,—somewhat misty, somewhat introverted, exercising itself mostly on all about feelings;Coterie speech; see 24:148JWC to TC, 26 July 1843. still it is perfectly up to discerning what any one I know and am at the pains to think about is feeling, or will feel towards me in certain given circumstances; and this, just as well when the person is at a distance—say, at Wellington New ZealandWhere Mantell was living. (far enough for practical illustration) as along side of me—say, in Humbie green lanes.Mantell had visited the Carlyles at Humbie Farm, Fife, where they were on holiday, Aug. 1859; see 35:189JWC to WDO, 3 Sept. 1859. For the farmhouse in 2008, see 122. The Carlyles had rented the upstairs floor and had “two sitting rooms as well as two bedrooms“ (35:134); for the view, “beautiful beyond all description“ (35:134), see 122.The Carlyles had rented the upstairs floor, which had “two sitting rooms as well as two bedrooms“ and a view that was “beautiful beyond all description“ (JWC to GEJ, [5 July 1859]). For the farmhouse and its view in 2008, see above.

figure.p: Humbie Farmhouse, 2008
View of the Forth from Humbie Farm, 2008

docBody.p: Accordingly I remained calm (!) and assured in my foresight of the letter now come; the while that the AuthoritiesGeraldine Jewsbury and, probably, John George Cooke. (they are plural; “male and female created He them“)Gen. 1:27. were fluttering and croaking round me, like—not two crows—but like a whole flight of crows! because you didn’t write to “the Carlyles“! It never seemingly struck these excited persons, that “the Carlyles“ might feel other than flattered by their meddling, which moreover being the man you are, was much liklier to delay your letter than expedite it.Jewsbury wrote to Mantell, [Jan. 1861]: “Mrs C always speaks of you with great friendliness & interest. Her health steadily fails—the stress & constant unfailing anxiety to keep him happy & comfortable is gradually wearing her out, & the friction of her own nature makes it more difficult Things will be better when he has finished Frederick— I wish you wd write or at least send her some message“ (MS: Mantell).— Nor does it strike them now that their cackle of self-gratulation, over the letter I have received from you, must have spoiled all my pleasure in it as a voluntary sign of your remembrance; but that I know these mutual friends of ours so well! “have been up thro’ them and down thro’ them with a lighted candle,“Coterie speech; see 35:188JWC to JGCO, 2 Sept. 1859. (as the scotch saying is); know the things they will say “on all matters of all men“ before the words are out of their mouths; and knew that, on this matter, they would say they were “so glad you had written to me!“, so very pleased you had written to me,“ “so thankful you had thought better of it and written to me!“ “So relieved that you were in better fashion“ (whatever that may precisely mean!) Just as if your letter to me were their pet achievement!

Then there was questioning, as if said letter were also their property! “What sort of letter was it?“ “was I pleased with it?“(!) “was it in good fashion“? “You had called it to her, “a little note“; wrote the female authority (from Manchester)Jewsbury was staying with her brother Frank and his family at Broughton near Manchester. She wrote to JWC, 23 Jan.: “I had a really long letter from Mr. Mantell by the last mail … he tells me of his delight in opening some ‘sealed packet’ wh you had given him—& wh he had never mentioned before also he gives me charge to tell you how sensible he is of all yr kindness—but as he says he had already written you a little notelet just to shew how reasonable it was for him to keep silence & his inability to write or speak or express anything but his own stupidity!—I dare say he has continued to let you know all that is needful—& I misdoubt greatly whether he wd like you to agree with his expressed opinion! but I am so glad he has girded up his loins to write without grumbling.“ “but she hoped it was a nice one! what was in it?“(!!!)— The charm of questions asked by letter is, that there isn’t the slightest call to answer them! and in my case I possess a cruelty of Silence (my Husband says) that he never saw matched in any other woman“!TC’s “cruelty of silence“ probably stemmed from JBW’s humorous tale about a German gentleman beggar in 1823 who complained about her “cruel silence“; see 2:334JBW to TC, 16 April 1823.— I read your letter “all to myself“ (as the children like it) and then I read it to Mr C; and then I put it by in metaphorical lavender; considering it to have done all the service it was intended to do.— I tell you this, that you may be aware, when writing to me again, that your letters will be safe as well as welcome: attributing to you the same detestation I have myself for that community of letters our Authorities carry to excess.

Mr C was really glad to hear from you and bade me say, with his kind regards, that “anything an intelligent man like yourself (!) liked to tell him about New Zealand would be read with interest and thankfulness here, where human information on any subject was so rare!— For the rest; he (Mr C) is much overworked with his Book, almost frantic with impatience to have done with it; but, I think, not radically worse in health than when you saw him—

Yes! it is to be lamented there are none of those swift and commodious means of transit still extant, which used to be so common in The Arabian Nights!That is, flying beds and flying carpets; see 33:89JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857, 99JWC to MR, 8 Oct. 1857, 252JWC to TC, 25 June 1858, and 258JWC to JF, 27 June 1858. If Mr C could awake tomorrow morning and find himself in New Zealand, it would be new life to him,—for a while! the mere sense of being so far from London would do him incalculable good.

What I would have you write to me about is yourself; you interest me more than New Zealand does. Begin, please, by doing me a sketch of your house. (You can draw better or worse? if worse it will make no difference). Then, describe to me the furniture of your rooms,—how many chairs you have? if you sleep in a bed?—or roost?—what you are clothed with,—linen, or woolen, or skin and what is your “natural food“? My second sight doesn’t take in these
particulars, and, without them, my picture of you out there is vague as a latter-day Turner.J. M. W. Turner (1775–1851; ODNB), artist; his later works were increasingly impressionistic. JWC probably knew of his work particularly through Ruskin who was a Turner enthusiast and administrator of his estate; see 33:111–12JWC to DD, 5 Nov. 1857.

I have given you heads enough for one letter if you treat them with due minuteness another should be devoted to your daily life your occupations, your amusements, (if any), your companionships, biped or quadruped,—whether you live by any fixed plan, or just by accident as it were?— I have never made up my mind yet which way is best! Perhaps the life by rule is best for accidental natures, and the hand-to-mouth life best for systematic natures! For the rest; your “Soul, her Sorrows and her Aspirations,““Cf. Francis Newman, The Soul, Her Sorrows and Her Aspirations: An Essay towards the Natural History of the Soul as the True Basis of Theology (1849).—your Heart, her (?—or his?—c’est égal [its all the same]) good and bad “fashions“—all that I make no point of your telling me; because Geraldine claims it as her especial perquisite, and besides, I shall hear it all second hand!

I saw at the DilberogluesStauros Dilberoglue and his wife, Sarah Anderton. a bright-looking, intelligent, straitforward young Lady, in a white gown, who talked of you as if she cared for you.Rosa—? I forget—some name beginning with an M.Rosa M, unidentified further. The Dilberoglues seem reasonably happy and prosperous, and dont complain of your ‘fashions.’ George Cooke grows fat. Geraldine swears friendships. I—miss my wee dear Nero every hour of the day! and so can feel for your loss. What a loss it is to be sure! one’s dog, that is always loving, always loyal! the love and the loyalty of Man or Woman, what is it in comparison?— You may be thankful however that this grief befell you far from the cours sensibles [sentimental currents] of London! for the sympathy and condolences they would have lavished on you here, would have caused in you an instinct of murder!— “Poor dear Nero! of course you will have him stuffed?— No?—why not? he was so pretty and curious!—just a dog for being stuffed!— And then you could have him always in the room with you in a glass case! He would still be quite a companion!!“—“Dont have another Dog dear Mrs Carlyle—have a cat! Cats live longer, and one doesnt mind when they die“!— “Well I am so sorry about Nero! but you mustnt be so concerned about it; I am looking out for a worthy successor to him, and you shall have a dog quite as pretty in a day or two!“—that is a specimen of what was said to me in my real sorrow. Yes! and six dogs were offered me in succession!—two of them brought to the house!—and I wont so much as look at them! how could [I.] Ach! such experiences throw
one into the fashion of Miss Squears, who “hated the world and wished that every body was dead“!Fanny Squeers in Charles Dickens, Nicholas Nickleby (1849), chap. 12.
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

ps.p: I missed one mail thro fanc[y]ing that the 1st of the month was post day for AustraliaMail for Australia and New Zealand left London “vié Southampton, on the morning of the 20th of every month … [and] vié Marseilles, on the evening of the 26th of every month“ (Post Office Directory [1861] 2096).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 22 Feb. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 23 Feb. 1861. MS: NLS 553.229. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:424.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I have lost one of the Three Names concerned in that Austrian-Bavn Forgery of “eheliche [legitimate descendant]“ for “männliche [male descendant].“Charles Albert (1697–1745), elector of Bavaria, sent his ambassador in Vienna to examine the will of Ferdinand I (1503–64) in the belief that it specified inheritance solely for male descendants, thus upholding his claim to the Hapsburg territorial possessions in opposition to the Pragmatic Sanction of 1713 that had allowed for the succession of Maria Theresa (1717–80), da. of Charles VI (1685–1740). Learning that the will specified only that successors must be lawfully begotten descendants, he accused the Austrians of forgery; see Works 15:155. Bartenstein,Baron Johann Christoph von Bartenstein (1689–1767), Austrian statesman, instrumental in securing the consent of Europe to the Pragmatic Sanction. Ma Theresa’s Mother,Elisabeth Christine of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttell (1691–1750); see Works 13:20–21.—and who was the third? A pillar of the Church,Gottfried Bessel (1672–1749), abbot of Göttweig. according to Anemonen.Baron Joseph von Hormayr-Hortenburg, Anemonen, aus dem Tagebuche eines alten Pilgersmannes, 4 vols. (Jena, 1845–47); see 35:105TC to WAN, 6 June 1859. Pray look again; it is still in time, and will be on Sunday Evg if I have him then, but will not be if later.

Pray bring him down with you, pointedly, that Evg;—and be prepared for another urgent service in the redacting way! I find I must get the 2d Silesn War into this First vol;The first of the second two vols., i.e., vol. 3, which TC was trying to finalize. In the event, bk. 15, “Second Silesian War,“ was in vol. 4 of the first edn.; see Works 16:1–193. and that you are the man to mainly do it,—by ruthlessly cutting down, and copying fair, the Papers we already have. It must be done; and it can! By art and vigour and rigour.

I have had a very shocking time (not idle however) since our last meeting: I
am now somewhat thro’ the horrible imbroglio and the bad time together,—at least let me hope so as to the latter element.— Sunday Evg, then.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-H & Co.[HAC], 23 Feb. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MESSRS HUTCHISON & CO.

docBody.p: You are surely very civil; and I am much obliged by the liberal permission you give me.

I have had the Bottles carefully packed; 31 of Brandy, 9 of Whiskey: and have, two days ago, despatched them to your Address, “per Edinburgh Steamer,“—I could not say by what “Edinr Steamer“:Steamers left for Edinburgh “every Wednesday and Saturday, at 10 morning“ (Times, 23 Feb.). TC is writing on Sat. but here inclosed is the Carrier’s Receipt, just handed in to me;—and I suppose they will arrive by the first Edinr Steamer that sails after that, and doubt not they will be safely delivered.
As to the Whiskey, we will give that up altogether, for the present;—and ask you to change these 9 Bottles into right Brandy, so far as they will go. That will simplify yr Problem a little.

And furthermore, with regard to the Brandy I had only to say, That you are not tied up as to price; that I only request you to be strict (and if possible, certain) as to genuineness;—return me as many Bottles of indubitably genuine as all these Bottles (31 + 9) of spurious or suspected will pay for; and I shall be well content. In my present state of health and occupation, it is far more importt for me that the Brandy be right than that it be cheap,—very much mo[re]Letters in square brackets from here to end indicate where MS is worn. so indeed. And I am informed, it is ju[st] now extremely difficult to get Brandy that has not bee[n] doctored, more or less, with that inferior stuff of the Scotch Distilleries,—shame to Cognac and them! But I have no doubt you will carefully do your b[est] for me.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A[LLA] [23 Feb.]. MS: NLSAcc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: Oh my Lady! my Lady! Here have I been pen in hand (so to speak) “wanting most terribly“ to write to you, ever since Wednesday, when I had your letter—or I should rather say, wanting most terribly to write to Her,Mary Florence Baring. the little arrant Flirt!— Two Valentines on her first 14th of Feby!— Really miss Emily Baring may call Her “beginning early,“ with a vengeance! What must be predicted of Her at seventee[n] years of age, if this be the line she takes at seven months! That fact is, that “other Valentine“ sent quite a pang of actual human jealousy thro my heart! and I felt inclined to impute to Her as a triumph of coquetry, what I must believe in my soberer moments to have been the natural, ‘unconscious’ result of her charms. Bless her any how! tho’ I “ha-ha-prehend“ (as a ButlerMr. Wills; coterie speech; see 21:187TC to LHB, 24 March 1847. of Lord Ashburton’s used to be always doing) that anyone who sets his or her heart excessively on the Honle Mary Florence Baring will have cruel moments thro’ Her; if said heart have any spark of jealousy in it!

They brought a BabyPossibly Robert and Harriet Tait’s da., Mildred, b. 21 May 1860; Mary Baring was b. 26 June 1860. to show me the other day, born in the same week, and called “a remarkably fine child“—you know the style of thing? a sort of prize-Baby in fact! large, and fat, and fair, and foolish! with round, wide-open, staring eyes, expressing nothing but a stupid astonishment at being alive! Its admiring Mother asked what I thought of it, “beside Lady Ashburton’s Baby“?— I answered, with the diplomacy one learns in the world, and which some of us never learn well, that I found the Baby before us very—large!! “Larger than Lady Ashburtons?“— “Oh, much larger! almost twice as large!“— “Really? (much pleased) but they told me you were such an admirer of Lady Ashburtons Baby?“— “So I am; but the Grange Baby is admirable on quite other principles from your one!“ Her one made a wry face at that moment, and I suggested that the nurse should “take it and show it our—garden! for I was sure it was going to cry“! And so the interview terminated without a moments infidelity on my part.

You can’t imagine how your letter perplexed me! almost terrified me! till I came to the solution, of Mrs MackenzieMaria Stewart-Mackenzie, widow of Lady Ashburton’s brother George. being the writer of it! The date and the signature left no doubt as to the letter being from you—how on earth then
came the hand-writing to be so different from any writing of yours I had seen before? It never occurred to me that some one else might be writing for you; only, that you must have tired of your former hand-writing, and taken up this new one!! an inconstancy of taste and a faculty of changing which made me wretched to think of as revealing itself in you! really heartily wretched for the moment! You mayn’t see at first what business it was of mine or anybodys how often you changed your handwriting;—but you will see it on reflection; that it was of most serious interest to me, and to every one that loves you dearly, whether you were capable of such a caprice as throwing over all at once your own beautiful hand-writing, come to be a part of yourself, as it were, and whether you were capable of changing such part of yourself with such frightful dexterity and completeness! a moments thought will show you all the serious bearings of such a supposition!

For the rest, I should have liked to hug Mrs Mackenzie, with or without her leave, when I found it was she who had written! The relief was so immediate and so great! and at the same time, I went “on the knees of my heart“Cf. Rev. John Keble, On Eucharistical Adoration (Oxford, 1857) 3. to you, for having one moment suspected you of such caprice!

Ah yes! It would be a good Easter MondayEaster Mon. was 1 April in 1861. if one spent it at the Grange! But the Grange now looks to me much like the garden of Eden after one had eaten the Apple! fenced round by Cherubims with flaming swords—till the day of deliverance arrive when the last ‘proof’ of Frederick (the pity that he ever was born!) shall have been sent to press— Then!—“if we be spared“ to see that day—!— Meanwhile nothing can be more dull—not to say dismal,—than the life we lead! And if it were only dull! but there is an amount of worry, to temper the dullness, which begets many floating notions of—suicide! If I weren’t so very sorry for Mr C with the “time out of joint“ for him, and feeling himself, (whether rightly or wrongly), “not born to set it right,“Hamlet 1.5. I think I should go quite “to smithers“Coterie speech; see 33:65JWC to TC, 2 Sept. 1857. with sorrow for—myself!

lg.l: “The lands I was to travel in,
“The death I was to dree!JWC wrote “dree“ (suffer) instead of “dee“ (die); ballad of Mary Hamilton, trad. Scottish song; see 30:213JWC’s Journal, 7 Nov. 1855.

docBody.p:
A natural wail for a much “made of“ Only Child!Coterie speech; see 15:209JWC to JW, 25 Nov. 1842. But e[x]tremelyLetter omitted. little to the practical purposes of the Wife of a nervous Man of Genius! So frisch zu
[on with it]!— And as you are so winningly kind and sympathetic that you “take me off my feet,“ I shall conclude at this point; and be off to TottinghamFor Tottenham. Court Road (of all places in the world!), where I have taken upon myself to play the part of Providence in a miserable Life DramaPossibly connected with Thomas Watt; see TC to JAC, 3 Feb.—with what likelihood of success you may fancy! anyhow it is chiefly that same Life Drama which has so busied me the last three days—that I couldnt tho’ wishing it ever so much, find time to write sooner—during the day—and at nights I sit in the same room with Mr C and mustn’t fidget him with “the scratching of my pen,“ while he is reading or correcting proofs.

My adoration to Baby, thanks and kind remembrance to your pleasant Sister in law, to Lord Ashburton what you think fittest, from compliments up to devoted regards! and to yourself—! Unless you were “up thro’ me and down thro’ me with a lighted candle“ (as our Scotch phrase is) no formula of leave-taking in The Ready Letter-Writer could make you aware how sincerely and affectionately I am yours
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: Excuse the worst pen and the thickest ink and the greatest hurry

Mr C likes his rusks much has them to his hot milk at bed time. speaks of you often, and asked some week ago, if there had been “no intelligence lately of that little creature“ What little creature“ I asked? “Why the bit creature at the Grange“

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LS], 24 Feb. MS: NLS 1796.99. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: On friday Evg, coming in from my ride, Wife still out, I found yr Card on the table; a welcome, if also sad, and almost pathetic greeting for me! So very kind of you to venture out hither, to us first of all. And I had been ill, really quite below par (sleepless &c &c) and unable to call, for ten days before; and was just meaning to call next day,—and you were off. And you had such a day for travelling, too; I think it was the worst one could have picked out of this bad month, for such a purpose!— Pray have the goodness (and that is practically my whole errand at present) to tell me how you stood it; an assurance that you are not hurt, that you are safe in your old Home-HouseLady Sandwich had presumably just left London for Hinchinbrook House. wd be very welcome to me at this moment.

As to myself I have no news whatever, except those already told, and scarcely permissible to tell, that these subterranean borings of mine are of dismal nature,—too heavy for the poor old barrowman, so long excluded from daylight and friendly sights;—and that he ought to have a care lest there be wreck of barrow & him, whh are becoming “crazy vehicles“ both of them! But I do not yield to these sad prognosticatings either. In average moments, I say, “Bear a hand,A sea captains’ saying, according to TC; see 16:10TC to JWI, 7 Jan. 1843; “bear a hand“ can mean both “help“ and “make haste.“ and it will end one day!“— Oh what a glorious day that will be, when I can send you the Two volumes, fairly loose from me! Whh you will read, for my sake; you—and whh, alas, AnotherLady Harriet Ashburton. never will, who is often present with me in writing them, alas, alas!— Pardon my speaking of what shd be kept silent; but these are thoughts, too, whh I find will never altogether leave me. Pardon, pardon; and let there again be silence.

If my Oliver is with you, salute the brave Boy.Probably Oliver George Paulet Montagu, grandson of Lady Sandwich, who lived at Hinchinbrook. To Lord Sandwich, if he will have them, my sincere regards. Good be on you, and on the House where you are.— —Here is the Maid to say, “Horse is come, Sir!“—so I must end, and buckle-on my mackintoshes, defiant of wind and rain!— Yours ever truly, T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 26 Feb. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unbpd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Thanks for your prompt attention in the Canada matter. I postponed yesterday, in the hope of getting a moment’s better leisure;—but today I have to write in still worse, and enclose you the £10 Draught,TC noted: “24 feby 1861 / to John (for Jenny in / Canada) / £10..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753); see also TC to JCHA, 28 Feb. lest you begin to fancy something may have befallen the Canadn witht an extraneous word!
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCH[JCHA], 28 Feb. MS: Yale. Pbd: Copeland 226–28.
div3.head: TC TO JANET CARLYLE HANNING

docBody.p: The inclosed bit of PaperProbably a bank draft payable in Canada, sent by John A. Carlyle, for which he had sent John a £10 check; see TC to JAC, 26 Feb. This was his usual method when sending money to Jenny; see 34:256TC to JAC, 28 Dec. 1858. has lain here for some days back, in the hope that I might find leisure to write you a couple of words along with it. With or without leisure, I had determined to send it today (Friday, whh is our American Post-day):Letters for Canada were dispatched by “British Mail Steam Packets“ from Liverpool every Sat. (Post Office Directory [1861] 2098); from London the post day would be Fri. but, last night, yr pleasant little Note from Hamilton arrived; and that naturally quickens my determination. No man in all the world has less time than I, for these many months past and to come: and I write no Notes [at]Omitted by TC. all, unless, like this, in strictly exceptional cases.

Yr account of yr laying out the last little Newyear’s giftAn 1861 New Year payment to Jenny is not recorded, although TC did send £10 to his other sisters; see TC to JCA, 30 Dec. 1860. He had sent Jenny £10 in May 1860; see 36:105TC to RWE, 30 April 1860. is touching and beautiful to me: I know you are a thrifty gleg creature, and wise thrift is becoming much a rarity in our time. The image of yr tidy household, and of the valiant battle you are fighting far away, is worth many pounds to me. If the pinch become sharp at any time, fear not to apply to me. I know you are a proud little soul, and somewhat disdain not to do yr own turn yourself: all this is right;—nevertheless I expressly tell you (and pray don’t neglect it), “Send me word when the pinch threatens to be sharp,“—whh I hope it will not be; only if it is at any time, observe what I say and mean here.

We are getting very feckless, Jane and I,—partly by advancing years, partly (in my own case) by such an unutterable quagmire of a job, in whh I have been labouring for almost ten years,—and have still at least one year of it ahead, if I live! Want of sleep is the latest form of illness with me; latest and most frightful;—but I try to dodge it, and have still (in secret) a surprising toughness in me for my years. Hope is rising too, as the hideous monster of a job does at last visibly diminish.

All the kindred in Scotland are well,—under date 3 or 4 days ago. The Dr is spending this winter in Edinr;—has still no hearth of his own, but lives in lodgings, shifting about.John’s lodgings were at 67 Hanover St.; he wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 28 Feb., that he meant to stay overnight Fri., 1 March, at Newfield, home of the Curries (see TC to JCA, 1 Feb.), NW of Ecclefechan, and intended visiting Scotsbrig, 2 March, and the Gill, 3 March (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). Jean and her affairs are prosperous; thinking of
“buying a House“ &c: Jamie, her eldest boy, is a very douce well-doing Clerk in the City here for 2 years past or more. Young Jamie of Scotsbrig, owing to health, had to give up that; and is now with his Father, thinking to be a Farmer. Times are good with them at Scotsbrig; tho’ our poor Brr Jamie is in weak health, and silently feels his “herried“ conditn, poor fellow, still.— I send my good-wishes heartily to yr Robert:Jenny’s husband, Robert Hanning. I am always, dear little Jenny,— Yours truly affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JJR, 4 March. MS: The Ruskin Foundation, Ruskin Lib., Lancaster Univ. Pbd: Cate 90–91.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN JAMES RUSKIN

docBody.p: Many thanks for yr kind attentions and good offices. I have sealed up the first Bottle of yr exquisite Cognac, much more have left this second one under the wax; and have set them safe aside,—that the house, in case of real emergency, may never be witht Brandy that can be depended on. Meanwhile, the Leith people,Messrs. Hutchison & Co.; see TC to H & Co.HAC, 23 Feb. in return for my late questionable (or rather unquestionable) stock, have sent me an old sort, deep brown, whh I was acquainted with;See 28:37TC to JCA, 8 Feb. 1853.—whh, witht the least pretension to fineness of flavour, is at last genuine grape-brandy (I believe),—or at least does not give me a headache when I apply to it. That is the essential; and we may for the present rest thankfully there.

“Martel,“Martell cognac, established by Jean Martell (1694–1753); an 1857 French law required trademarks to be registered; previously, unlabeled, inferior brandies could be imported into Britain in casks and bottled and labeled with the names of London merchants. I think, was the name given to that late spurious stuff, whh came from Leith;—evidently whiskey in good part. Right Brandy, I doubt, is hardly procurable at all just now. But as matters stand,—especially with such Tobacco as I boast,—one can in some measure defy an evil world!
With many sincere thanks for your ready helpfulness, and friendliness in this and other matters, I remain always,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [4 March]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 4 Mar. 1861. MS: NLS 553.230. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—Will you send me, from Stenzel IV, the correct references to Flassan and others, who give that Treaty (Frh with France, of June 5, 1741) with wrong dates; item the page of Stenzel, where he credits RankeGustav Adolf Harald Stenzel, Geschichte des preussischen Staats, 5 vols. (Hamburg, 1830–54). Jean-Baptiste Gaëtan de Raxis de Flassan, Histoire générale et raisonnée de la diplomatie française, depuis la fondation de la monarchie, jusqu’à la fin du règne de Louis XVI, 6 vols. (Paris, 1809). Leopold von Ranke, Neun Bücher preussischer Geschichte, 3 vols. (Berlin, 1847–48). See 36:113–14TC to JN, 11 May 1860, and Works 15:218. for clearing up the thing.
I hope you are out of your Biliary Adventures, and getting on with the other Anti-chaotic do,—whh are hard enough witht addition to them.

I have got the Insertions made (better or worse) in Book XIV:See Works 15:359–501; the “insertions“ are unidentified. and,—had I but rhadamanthine severity enough, and frankness with the scissors (whh I feel is indispensable!)—might hope to be almost thro’ said Book, this week!
Come next Sunday at any rate,—unless I see you sooner too.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [14 March]. MS: Duke. Pbd: Larkin, BQR 69; Wilson, Carlyle 5:426.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Will you come to me Tomorrow:—you see Robson is fallen nearly desperate!Larkin pbd. Robson’s letter to TC of 14 March: “I send you the slips completing the chapter, but I have not been able to make out a great deal if it, though I have spent far more time over it than I can spare; and the poor Compositors are at their wits’ end. In fact, the whole of this part ought to be copied out. I never saw such imperfect copy before. Much of it is mere abbreviation, and referring backwards and forwards. I am quite out of heart with it; and fear, if there be any more like this, I shall be obliged to send it to you as it comes from the hands of the Compositors, as I cannot find time, among my many calls upon it, for deciphering such copy. I am sorry to write this, and have deferred till I can no longer get on“ (Larkin, BQR 69).

Bring the Book OrlichLeopold von Orlich, Geschichte der schlesischen Kriege, nach Original-Quellen (Berlin, 1841); TC’s copy: HCC. See also 33:45–46TC to JN, 22 Aug. 1857. with you; I sometimes need it here. FontenoyThe battle of Fontenoy, 11 May 1745; see Works 16:92–104; Larkin was possibly working on the map of the battle; see Works 16:99. I suppose is not ready yet?
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [15 March]. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 15 March 1861. MS: NLS 553.231. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—It is curious how, whenever a Book is taken away, there rises need for it, use for it, had there been none for months before!—
Please put-in (in complete form) those imperfect references to Stenzel,See TC to JN, [4 March].—whom I hope I shall not need again for a long while. Yours always / T. C.
(Chelsea, Friday)

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 16 March. MS: NLS 517.16. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: In spite of my hurries (already an hour-and-half behind time!) it is impious not to send answer of a word to yr kind inquiries after me,—whh are always precious to the poor human heart!

Know then, that I am not suffering from want of sleep, or specially otherwise, in these weeks: I had a dreadful ten days of it (or nights rather) a while before you saw John at The Gill;John A. Carlyle had been at the Gill 3 March; TC suffered from sleeplessness through much of Feb. but since that, nothing to make a noise abt. On the contrary, my head, tho’ it still sings day and night, does not ache, and never in any particular way: so that I have quite dismissed that beautiful idea, “Congestion of the brain,“ and swept it into the ashpit,—not to be numbered with my troublesome comrades any more! And in fact I am partly persuaded, my health has been improving for several months back; and am certain my work goes a little better;—so that I am drawing towards the end of “Vol III,“
whh is more than half-way thro’ (considerably more); and in short, I generally look forward with more comfort (and backwards too) upon that Algerine CaptivityPirates from Algiers had for many centuries captured Europeans and kept them as slaves, usually galley slaves; cf. Cervantes, Don Quixote, pt. 1, chap. 12–14; narratives of “Algerine Captivity“ were also used at this time in the U.S. in support of abolitionist arguments. See also Royall Tyler’s picaresque fictional memoir, The Algerine Captive; or, The Life and Adventures of Doctor Updike Underhill; Six Years a Prisoner among the Algerines (1797); for TC’s previous use of “algerine,“ see 14:123TC to JGL, 5 April 1842. in the cellars, than formerly; and hope I may be quite out of it in not very many months. Steady, steady! If I shd live a thousand years, I shd never forget it, nor expect to be in the like again. I will have a long spell of absolute rest, were I [once]Word obscured. out: that is certain.
Jane goes abt; frail & feeble, but not more so than common, less rather. And our weather is much improving.
May you get this tomorrow; and andWord repeated on turn of page. may it find you all well. As well as I wish you, you wd be well enough! Kind remembrances to all. Yr Affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-RMM, [20 March]. MS: Trinity College, Cambridge. Hitherto unpbd. Dated “’61“ in another hand on MS. Tentatively dated in March by “Monday the 25th“; the 25th also fell on a Mon. in Feb. and Nov. 1861, but Milnes is known to have been in town at this time; see JWC to RMM, [13 April].
div3.head: JWC TO RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES

docBody.p: After six hours consideration, Mr C decides that he will give himself and me the pleasure of dining with you “next Monday the 25th“—
A message is just sent down stairs to me that I am “to write and say Yes“— I hardly know how to form the letters of that almost forgotten word.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JF, [25 March]. MS: NLS 607.574. Pbd: Bliss, JWC 287. “7 March 1861“ written on MS in an unknown hand; 7 March was a Thurs.; dated 25 March by the dinner at Forster’s; see JWC to AEB, [3 April].
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p: He says; “Oh yes!—that is a clear case of coming! There is no resisting that“! So, before any pigs have time to “run thro his answer, I commit it to paper and send it off.
I am so glad!

He doesnt know what letters of Leigh HuntsForster had been a longtime friend and literary advisor of Leigh Hunt (d. Aug. 1859); he was probably helping Hunt’s son Thornton prepare Correspondence of Leigh Hunt (1862). The Times advertised for correspondence to be lent with a view to publication: “All papers thus lent are returned without damage or alteration of any kind. The request is, also, particularly addressed to gentlemen travelling abroad, who have, probably, failed to receive the notes forwarded to them privately“ (23 April). No letters between the Carlyles and Leigh Hunt appeared in the book. he may have, or where he has them; but I will look myself and try to bring you some on Tuesday.
Love to the Lady
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle
docBody.note: Alexander Welsh, son and executor of JWC’s uncle John Welsh of Liverpool, wrote to JWC, 20 March, from Vulcan St., Liverpool, about a legacy that John Welsh had left her: “If I had happened to meet you in Scotland during the last year or two or had business taken me to London when I could have called upon you it would have rendered unnecessary the explanation I now send with the enclosed— / At my Father’s death [early Oct. 1853; see 28:286TC to JCA, 12 Oct. 1853], although he left no regular will, we found a letter addressed to us with his wishes respecting his Estate— / The letter was dated 21 Oct. 1845 and I will simply give an extract from it which I know you will like the best— / ’I also wish if you feel it right among yourselves that One Hundred Pounds be paid to Jeanie Carlyle in consideration of the love & affection I have had for her’ / I need not say that such a desire was equally grateful to us all & as I had the management of the estate it was left for me to carry it out— As it was then necessary to draw money out of the business to pay Jeanie [Chrystal; m. 28 April 1853] her share & likewise for poor John [their youngest brother (d. 1860); see 28:72TC to JAJ, 12 March 1853] who was about to start for himself I proposed to wait for a little until some accounts owed Father & which were promised to be immediately settled were paid in— These have only been paid within the last few days— / I now enclose a Bank post Bill in your favor for £125 being the original amount with 5 years interest added and I trust that although this matter has been so long delayed you will not think that it has ever been forgotten.“ The letter and the enclosed “Bank post Bill“ were sent by registered mail. It is unclear why only five years’ interest was added. No other reference to the legacy has been traced, either in letters or in TC’s checkbook. JWC had been very fond of her uncle; see 28:286–87JWC to HW, 12 Oct. 1853.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 27 March. MS: NLS 525.73. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Both your Notes came duly; and I was, as usual, thankful for them. The first, directly on the back of a visit to Scotsbrig, I did not at once answer; hoping you wd perhaps send me something more detailed, before long: I despatched a Temple Bar Magazine,Temple Bar, a literary magazine est. 1860 by John Maxwell (1820–95), ed. George Augustus Sala (1828–95; ODNB). with two strokes on it, as sign of nothing wrong here:Pen strokes on newspapers (sent free of charge) signified that all was well; see 9:89–90TC to MAC, 20 Nov. 1836.—you do not say that it came, tho’ I suppose it wd: beyond the two strokes it had no claim to the least value. In this way has time slipt on, and too long a silence been.

I shd certainly have written in the course of two days more: but here, this morning, has a Note arrived; whh commands me to do it at once.— I have had no news; nothing but the old silent struggle continually going on (for my very dreams, when I have any, are apt to be filled with it); a daily ride, nearly always in perfect solitude; a daily and nightly escort of confused bafflements;TC presumably visited the Twisletons, Sun. 24, and dined with Milnes, Mon. 25 (see JWC to RMM, [20 March]); Ellen Twisleton wrote to her sister Elisabeth Cabot, 29 March: “Carlyle came just after church, & staid an hour, & shocked Georgy most dreadfully by his sceptical conversation—she grew quite white—and would hardly bow to him when he went … ‘I don’t know how you live, Ellen, and hear such things—I couldn’t bear it—I think it would kill me!’“ (MS: Houghton bMS Am 2197 (127); by permission of the Houghton). Elisabeth Cabot, b. Dwight (1830–1901), spent a year in England with the Twisletons, and knew the Carlyles; see 30:114JWC to LA, 14 Nov. 1855, and 144TC to JCA, 23 Dec. 1855. Louisa-Georgiana Leigh (b. 1829), da. of Chandos Leigh (1791–1850), 1st Baron Leigh of Stoneleigh, distant cousin of Edward Twisleton. and thots not cheerful to speak of;—yet with hope more legible at times than formerly, and on the whole with health better rather than worse: this is the whole of my history since you heard last. I am fairly into Book XV (halfway or more); Robson Printer is nearly thro’ Book XIII,—chasing me along;—and if I cd hold out 6 months farther at this rate! But I dare not promise anything. I am become “a crazy vehicle“ in comparison; and shake at the roads still ahead.

We have had not a cold March, but the wettest I can remember: surely an unpropitious seedtime; indeed I think nothing yet is sown in these parts. Whh is a bad outlook for the Harvest next coming. The days latterly are sometimes quite beautiful; but rain (now audible again, on this sky-window) is seldom long absent. Great emotion about “the Oxford Essays,“Essays and Reviews, ed. H. B. Wilson (1860), collection of essays by seven liberal Anglicans, most with Oxford connections. The book had nine edns. between Jan. and March and sold over 15,000 copies. The essays all broadly called for greater freedom in the study of religion, and the book caused a greater furor than Darwin’s Origin of Species. Baden Powell (1796–1860; ODNB) was the first clergyman publicly to endorse Darwin’s principle of “the self-evolving powers of nature“ (Essays and Reviews 139). The Guardian described both as “two books which are indications of the tendency of thought and speculation among us. Mr. Darwin’s Origin of Species marks the set of philosophical thought among a great number of our scientific men. The famous Essays and Reviews has, perhaps not the same, but still a very ominous significance in the sphere of theological inquiry“ (2 Jan.). The controversy lasted several years; see Josef L. Altholz, Anatomy of a Controversy: The Debate over Essays and Reviews 1860–1864 (Aldershot, 1994).—bless them! To me
of no more interest than rig-ma-ree.— — In perhaps two days hence you will get an insignificant Parcel or Package from me;Unidentified. at which do not scunner. I think of writing to Alick soon myself.See TC to AC, 7 Aug. [April]. One is not (except by imaginatn) tied up from a few words! Adieu dear Brother: Your ever affecte T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JJR, 27 March. MS: Yale. Pbd: Sanders, “Carlyle’s Letters to Ruskin“ 217; Cate 91.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN JAMES RUSKIN

docBody.p: Many thanks for your new Gift of Brandy: surely you are very kind to take so much trouble about that matter for me. If it do rank at present among my necessaries of life (whh unluckily it does in a small way for the time being), I must admit that I am now well provided. I hope to report favourably of this new specimen when we next meet.

The absence of the Junior Mr Ruskin has of late been frequently commented upon in this house: we request you to despatch him hitherward directly on his return from Cheshire.Ruskin was at Winnington Hall, Northwich, Cheshire, a school for girls established in 1851 by Margaret Alexis Bell (1818–89), da. of Alexander Bell (1789–1851), Methodist preacher. Ruskin’s plan to return home 28 March was changed when his father insisted he accept Lord Palmerston’s invitation to spend Easter at Broadlands; he returned to London 1 April (The Winnington Letters: John Ruskin’s Correspondence with Margaret Alexis Bell and the Children at Winnington Hall, ed. Van Akin Burd [1969] 282).

closer.salute: With many thanks & regards / Yours sincerely /

div3.sourceNote: TC-[CDLP], 29 March. MS: Syracuse Univ. Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee identified in TC to LS, 6 April; Charles de la Pryme (1815–99), lawyer.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES DE LA PRYME

docBody.p: I receive with very great pleasure the little mulberry-tree Box from Oliver’s Environment at Huntingdon; (not from his own Garden, I fear? But we will believe, he or his Father, as Lord of the Manor,Sir Richard Williams (later Cromwell) (1495–1547), great-grandfather of Oliver Cromwell (1599–1658; ODNB), bought the manor of Wistow together with other lands from Ramsey Abbey at the dissolution of the monasteries, 1539. His grandson Sir Oliver Cromwell (1563–1655), Oliver’s uncle, sold it to Sir Nicholas Pedley (d. 1685) in 1648. may have superintended the planting, and reported to his Dread Sovereign James I,James VI and I, seeking to further the silk industry by introducing the culture of the silkworm into England, issued an edict in 1608 encouraging the cultivation of mulberry trees. The experiment failed because the black mulberry was cultivated rather than the white mulberry, which silkworms prefer. in consequence):—at all events, I will keep carefully the little relic; as carrying on it, beyond doubt, some reflex of the great Oliver: and am, with many thanks,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IEB, [3 April]. Addr: C Simmonds Esqr / Overseale / Ashby de la Zouche. PM: 3 April 1861. MS: letter NLS Acc. 9086; envelope Carlyle House. Pbd: R. Blunt, CR 155–58; Blunt, Forum 66:539–40. Quot: Southern, “The Carlyles and St. Luke’s,” 25:478–79. Isabella was visiting the family of John Simmonds, her future husband, at the home of his younger brother, Christopher Simmonds (b. 1839), farmer, in Leicestershire.
div3.head:
JWC
TO ISABELLA E. BARNES

docBody.p:
You remarkably clever little Girl! — I admire this stroke of diplomacy amazingly!— My general amiability was not to be relied on; you thought—and I can’t say but you thought right—! so far as that goes— My special promise, about writing “within a fortnight” might, or might not form a part of that “general amiability,” which is “not to be relied on”—and so, being a sort of little Girl who will have her humour out—whatever that be!—you just fling a silken lásso of politeness round my neck, and twitch me up to the point! You had the little Photograph before you left—you meant to give it me—(your Father told me so, when he had taken his own out of his pocket book, as tenderly as if it were the Holy Sacraments, to show me,For photographs of Isabella and of her father, see 140 above . and been assailed by
a storm of abuse of you on my part, for not having given me one, “all to myself” But—if you sent it in a letter, I must of necessity acknowledge that letter, as a “woman of England”Coterie speech; from Sarah Stickney Ellis (1799–1872; ODNB ), The Women of England, Their Social Duties and Domestic Habits (1839); see 5:16 JWC to JAC, 31 Jan. 1850
, and 36:30 JWC to JF, 29 Dec. 1859
. whatever she does or omits to do, must never neglect “the forms of Society”—never be “impolite!”Stickney’s precepts; cf. 21:18 JWC to HW, 19 Aug. 1846
. Oh you sharp little girl! You knew that, calculated upon it, and acted upon it! And so here am I writing to you, whether I like it or not!— Anyhow I like the photograph. To such an extent; that my long wavering notion of investing in a photograph Book, took settled practical shape, in the same hour it (the tiny Miss Barnes) came to hand; and being as rapid as—yourself(!) when I have once decided on a thing; I went forthwith to Regent StreetPossibly to Auguste Marion & Co., photographic material dealers, 152 Regent St. in the rain and bought a sensible modest-looking Volume with no botheration of embossing and gilt clasps, but real Morrocco; and good paper.

figure.p: Isabella Barnes (JWC’s “Carina”) and her father Dr. Alfred Barnes, 1861
Reginald Blunt, By Chelsea Reach (1921)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
When I came in I was, if not wetted, thoroughly damped and had to change
my dress; and it being within a couple of hours of the time when I was engaged to dine at Mr Forsters,On Tues., 2 April; see JWC to JF, [25 March]. with Dickens and Wilkie Collins, I thought I had best make one dressing do for all, and thus it happened, that as early as half after four, I was sitting on my sofa in the black velvet gown your Father found so “stunning.” with pearl necklace and bracelets (!) and the smallest of make-believe (lace) caps—when, without my having heard any rap, the drawing-room door was flung open and Charlotte announced “Mr and Mrs Blunt!”Rev. Gerald Blunt, appointed rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea, May 1860, and his wife, Frances. They were to become good friends of the Carlyles; their son Reginald recalled that there were hardly any records of his parents’ friendship with the Carlyles, which began 1861, “beyond the bare entries in the diary of visits and dinings at the Rectory and No. 5 Great Cheyne Row, which was reached by a little gate at the S.E. corner of the Rectory garden opening directly on to the top of the Row. Mrs. Carlyle came much to the Rectory, and my mother became greatly attached to her, and grieved over the illness and weariness, which increasingly sapped her strength and spirit” (Reginald Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt [1911] 78). For the various meetings recorded in 1861, see JWC to [GC?, late April?][IEB], [early May?]. Mercy of Heaven! Is that man always to find me in some false position! Cf. “in a false position”; coterie speech; see 22:9 JWC to HW, 5 July 1847
. To your Father I could say I am going out to dinner, and am so ashamed to be caught with a bare head! But I couldnt enter into such explanation with these strangers—and had to stand Mrs Blunts survey of me, in a broad glare of sunlight; with inward protest against appearances and “appeal to Posterity”!Coterie speech; see 15:34 JWC to TC, 20 Aug. 1842
. As for Mr Blunt (God bless him!) I dont imagine he could have told when he left, whether I had on a velvet dress or a strait-waistcoat, whether my necklace was of pearls or butter-cups!— He looked so straight at my face all the time, with such a look of unworldly profoundly human trust and friendliness, that it was all I could do to keep from flinging myself at his feet, or into his arms, and saying; “oh Yes! I will visit your poor women—if you wish it! will even come and hear you preach if you wish it!— I restrained myself however, and for the present went no further than inviting him and his wife to tea!

figure.p: “The Rev. C. H. Spurgeon’s New Tabernacle, at Newington ”
Illustrated London News, 6 April 1861

docBody.p: Now, little Woman! mind that you dont stay away above twice as much longer as the time you fixed! I like to know you [are] here, even when I am not seeing you. I like you; my nice little diplomatist! which is more a compliment to your merits than you perhaps think! For, between ourselves, there is nothing I so much dislike in a general way as a young Miss (Jeune Mees) except indeed a young Master
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LS], 6 April. MS: NLS 19.3.52.17. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:427.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p:
I was sorry to miss you last sunday; but hoped and hope to be luckier when you come home again. The dubious Mulberry relicSee TC to [CDLP], 29 March. (not worth your own trouble) I thot you might give to my friend Oliver, or to one of the little Girls,Her grandson Oliver (see TC to Lady SLS, 24 Feb.) and one of her granddas., Anne or Emily. say the convalescent one, whom you delighted so to honour:— I know not
who or what the “De la Prymes“George Pryme (1781–1868; ODNB), lawyer and professor of political economy at Cambridge; he bought property at Wistow (about 7 mi. [11 km.] NE of Huntingdon) in the 1820s, where he built Wistow Lodge; the family lived there from 1847. Of Huguenot origin, they had dropped the “de la“ because of anti-French feeling during the Seven Years’ War (1756–63); however George Pryme decided to revive the original name and so christened his children Charles and Alicia de la Pryme (see Autobiographic Recollections of George Pryme, ed.
