Alicia de la Pryme [Cambridge, 1870]). are at Huntingdon, or whether there is the least chance that O. C.Oliver Cromwell. ever saw their mulberry. One knows only that James I did command mulberries to be planted, for the sake of getting silk; and that many were accordingly planted (about a.d. 1610 and onward, if I recollect) up and down the Southern Counties,—the survivors of whh get many fine names stuck to them in our time: “Queen Elizabeth’s Mulberry“ (still growing here in Cheyne Walk),Queen Elizabeth’s mulberry tree stood in the garden of Tudor House, 16 Cheyne Walk (where Dante Gabriel Rossetti [1828–82; ODNB] was to move in 1862); see Dante Gabriel Rossetti: His Family Letters, ed. W. M. Rossetti (1895) 1:230. “Shakspeare’s Mulberry,“Possibly referring to James Boswell’s story about his and Samuel Johnson’s visit to Jane Gastrell, 25 March 1776: “Mrs. Gastrel’s husband was the clergyman who, while he lived at Stratford upon Avon, where he was proprietor of Shakspeare’s garden, with Gothick barbarity cut down his mulberry-tree, and, as Dr. Johnson told me, did it to vex his neighbours“ (Boswell’s Life of Johnson 2:470). Francis Gastrell (ca. 1707–72), m. Jane, b. Aston (d. 1791). The tree had supposedly originally come from the mulberry gardens of James VI and I; the wood was sold to Thomas Sharp, clock maker, and made into souvenirs; see Dorothea Charnwood, “A Habitation’s Memories,“ Cornhill Magazine 43 (1927): 540. &c &c; whh are of dubious, sometimes impossible, authenticity, every mulberry of them, and not worth serious attention from grown people!

I did not forget your Eigtieth Birthday:Lady Sandwich was born 3 April 1781. “Eigtieth“: thus in MS.—dear Lady, may all your days be serene and good! You are beautiful, quietly brave, bright as the Evening Sun, in your great age;—and age is itself beautiful after a fine fashion, if we take it rightly. I am myself not quite 15 years younger; an old man; and ought to know it, as in late times I very well do. We know not “the day nor the hour“;Matt. 25:13.—the youngest child may go before either of us:—we will wait in pious composure our appointed time; and not doubt but it will be in some way towards welcome rest; rest growing ever more welcome. And it is whither our loved ones have all gone. Enough, enough!

I am heavily enough pressed down by those sad Prussian burdens; but perhaps not quite so heavily as once: sometimes I think, “In 7 or 8 months more, why shd it not be all over; and nothing but going in grass, with the shoes off, ever after!“— This is too sanguine a computation.

The weather is sometimes quite genial. I ask myself (but only you can answer), do you punctually profit by it? Drive out in the spring sunshine, to that big Tree on the road to St. Ives,St. Ives, village, 5 mi. (8 km.) E of Huntingdon. and make my compts to it. The sight of the young spring is better than any sermon to one’s old heart!— If those BooksUnidentified. (scrap inclosed) are not in Hinchinbrk, they shd be. Give me notice, if they are not and return “Scrap.“ Yours ever faithfully T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 7 April. MS: Reed Coll., Dunedin Public Lib. Pbd: Eric Nye, “An Edition of John Sterling Uncovers New Carlyle Letters,“ Carlyle Newsletter 9 (1988): 48.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—I hope you have not fallen ill? I have been expecting you more and more for abt 10 days past.
I am now in great want of some copying,—provided it can be done immediately; not otherwise. I have had no proofs from Robson, either; have you?
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-AC, 7 Aug. [April]. MS: MUL. Pbd: Marrs 738–40. TC misdated the letter.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—If I wrote to you once for every twenty times I think of you, you would get a great many Letters! But in these overloaded times you know how it stands with me: I have not, literally for years, written any Note that I cd help; so completely occupied is every moment of my availableday,—struggle of labour during the few hours possible for that (for “the tightest old quarry-boy in the whole How-Rig,“Probably a saying of TC’s father; see 8:181TC to MAC, 19 July 1835; there was a quarry at Howrig, near Carlisle, early 19th century. you know, gets tired at last, and good for little!)—and then the resting, the &c &c; not to mention the incessant botherations from people I have no business with, whom in this roaring element I cannot in the least brush perfectly away, let me try as I will! Let me stop short in this grievous detail; let me tell you rather that, within the last few months, I have made some new arrangements (particularly, to try for a little sleep before dinner, just after my ride; to be very regular, &c &c); that I think I am perceptibly better, not tormented abt sleep, as I lately was; that I
am steadily working along, “faint tho’ pursuing“;See Judg. 8:4.—and that in 8 or 9 months more, if I can hold out at this rate (of which there is prospect), I hope to have done with the unutterable job, and to wash my hands of it forever, and belong to myself & my dear ones again! Let us hope, let us hope!—

For a good few weeks past it has been on my mind that I ought to write to you, upon one particular point (what I once said to you abt Tom & his settlement in life);TC had offered to send Alexander’s son Tom “a £200 or so,“ April 1860; see 36:95TC to AC, 13 April 1860. that I had “time“ for a practical word or two on that head (if I plucked up courage!)—and that I must and would do it. Above a month ago, I requested John to write something to that effect; but whether he ever yet did it, I have not learned;—and so, in brief, I now, after all that haggling, do it myself.

You are to understand, then, that I am, was, and shall be, practically quite in earnest abt that sum of money (£250, I think[)]—that the sum is properly yours for Tom, whenever you like to demand it. And, if anything happen to me before it be paid, I wish you to present this to those who stand for me; in proof (whh it is) of my owing you that sum, before any other affair be gone into abt what once belonged to me.— Now pray understand this, dear Brother; and be ready to act upon it, now or afterwards, at the moment you see fit:—I shall be easier in my mind knowing henceforth that you do understand it.— Something was said in yr last Letter, to Jack I think, abt setting up of Tom, as a thing you were vaguely contemplating: it was but a word; but I never forgot it,—and always meant and wished, since then, to write you what is now at last on paper! If you shd want the money at once, and cared to make a Brantford or Hamilton Banker draw on me, for your behoof, to the above amount, his Draught shd be honoured, and you wd get the money by return of post;—at any time, this will hold. And if, not being in such readiness or hurry, you warned me direct that the thing was coming ready, I wd spend a Couple of hours on it some day, and get you the due Paper ready, whh wd need only endorsing & presenting on your part. And now we will be silent abt the matter (you need not even answer till yr time come); everything, I hope, being now clear.

Jane is tolerably well; better, she too, than usual. Our march has been the wettest & warmest I can recollect. No seed-time anywhere, I doubt, till now, when the wind has stuck itself north-east. A bad harvest our last; probably a bad one coming too, after such a start. Kindred all well, by last accts, a few days ago. Jack still in Edinr; “in lodgings“;—Lodgings still, but not in bad spirits in the least.— Adieu, dear Brother; my blessing be on you all. Your affectionate T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[Duchesse d’A][DDA], 8 April. MS: Osborn Coll., Yale. Hitherto unpbd. Maria Caroline Augusta de Bourbon (1822–69), duchesse d’Aumale.
div3.head: TC TO [DUCHESSE D’AUMALE]

docBody.p: Indeed I very well remember you; and always hoped, and still hope, our first meetingFor TC’s possible first meeting with the duchesse d’Aumale in 1856, see 32:58TC to LOA, 20 Dec. 1856; he had met her husband earlier; see 29:307TC to JCA, 11 May 1855. was not to be the last by many.

To see you again, and S.A. [son altesse: his highness] The Duc d’AumaleHenri Eugène Philippe d’Orléans (1822–97), duc d’Aumale, fifth son of Louis-Philippe (1773–1850), king of the French 1830–48. Following Louis-Philippe’s abdication, they lived at Orleans House, Twickenham. The duc d’Aumale’s Lettre sur l’histoire de France. Addressée au prince Napoléon (Paris and London, 1861), a response to the Emperor Napoleon’s hostile criticism of the House of Orléans, was stirring controversy. again, and make General Malcolm’sMajor-Gen. George Alexander Malcolm (1810–88), son of Gen. Sir John Malcolm (1769–1833; ODNB) and Isabella Charlotte, b. Campbell (1790–1867); he m., 1846, Georgiana Venables Vernon Harcourt (ca. 1807–86), whom JWC met while staying with the Baring sisters at Bay House in 1858 and whom she and TC had previously met at Lady Sandwich’s; see 34:111JWC to TC, 9 Aug. 1858. acquaintance: this is a very tempting offer on your part! But, alas, I am under stern conditions, this long while past, and am still like to be for some time,—nearly killed, or buried alive under Prussian rubbish, struggling with all my poor remnant of strength to get back into daylight;—and severe hours are laid upon me. To go out at all, makes me ill; to go out to breakfast involves farther the loss of a day’s poor work, such as it is:—I must be virtuous, observe the Rules, and deny myself and my vagrant inclinations!
Accept my remembrances, my regrets,—my hopes for a better time. And believe me,

Dear Madam / Yours sincerely / T. CarlyleTC paid £10 to JWC, 8 April, the last installment of £50 that she was due from wood cut for sale at Craigenputtoch 1859; see 35:84TC to JAC, 4 May 1859 (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-RMM, [13 April]. MS: Trinity Coll., Cambridge. Quot: Southern, “The Carlyles and St. Luke’s“ 479. Dated by Ruskin’s lecture, 19 April.
div3.head: JWC TO RICHARD MONCKTON MILNES

docBody.p:
I have had to call in the God Volition to rescue me from your ‘Goddess Circumstance,’ who was dragging me into a second discourtesy, towards our
Rector,Gerald Blunt. worse than the first.At the Blunts’ recent unexpected call on her; see JWC to IEB, [3 April]. Not hearing from you, and having kept him expecting to hear from me, till the situation was become “rather exquisite,“Coterie speech; see 16:198JWC to JW, 15 June 1843, and Froude, LM 3:282. I finally wrote to ask him for the following evening;—too late! He was to start for Paris in the morning, with a sick Brother; not to return for ten days.Henry Blunt; “April 11 to 23.— G. B. went to Paris with ‘Henry and Party’“ (Reginald Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt of Chelsea [1911] 76). He called it “fatality“—the good Christian man!—another in his place would have called it culpable neglect, and been angry with me. To show he wasn’t angry, his WifeFrances Blunt. came by herself! and it would have amused you to hear the wild efforts made by Geraldine Jewsbury and me to adapt our conversation to our abstract ideas of a Rector’s Wife!

On Friday 19th we have engaged to attend Ruskin’s Lecture on Tree Twigs (!) at the Royal Institution.See TC to JAC, 23 April. If this Eastwind continues I shall have to give up the idea, but Mr C will be all the more bound to go. Besides You wouldnt come suppose we had been disengaged! not you!
I should like much to go to you tomorrow evening, if the wind would change, and if Mr C would change. But—Blessed are they who do not hope; for they shall not be disappointed!Cf. Matt. 5:3–11.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[SL][SLA], 15 April. MS: NLS 3823.255. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [SAMUEL LANGLEY]

docBody.p: I am sorry I delayed writing; but the truth is I never have one moment to myself; and have not for years written any Note except on absolute compulsion. Least of all, of course, when the terms to use are not at once apparent.

Your speculatn abt Water-Cure and Rifle-drill seemed to me, and seems entirely chimerical. None of us can help our health, except by simply working within limits, not beyond them, using good regimen every way, and taking plenty of air and exercise. To all this, Hydropathy, or Medical Science (I believe) in any form, much more rifle-drilling &c &c are quite extraneous.

I send the inclosed £5TC noted: “15 April 1861 / To Sl Langley / (Charity) / £5..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). He also noted in his memoranda of amounts given from Lady Harriet Ash--burton’s bequest (for the bequest, see 34:82–83TC to LOA, 29 July 1858): “To S. Langley (‘ill indeed’!) 5..0..0“ (MS: Bodleian Lib.). for the real requirements of yourself and parents;—condition being that no portion of it go either, to water-cure or volunteering.

For the rest you are totally mistaken abt my feelings to you; and may at once cease to distress yourself on that score. I have stated also what I dissented from;—and there is nothing of “change“ &c; in fact nothing to state farther.

Do not send me the Fredk Excerpts;Langley had written to TC, 5 Sept. 1860: “Illness both of mind and body has prevented me from completing the Excerpts— But, please God you shall have the remainder next week“ (MS: NLS 607.560). TC wrote later on MS: “An Irish reader for me; much of blarney in him, and something of mendicancy while it wd avail.“ I shall not get the least use of them in proportion. “Payment“ &c is inadmissible; you owe me nothing at this moment,—pray attend to that among other things.— In very great haste, Yours sincerely T. CarlyleOther charity recipients were noted in TC’s memoranda, Feb. and April: “1861 (febr / to Oxford man … 1..0..0 / wretched … 1..0..0 / To Irishman (of ‘Coat’) 0..10..0“; “8 April 1861: Widow of the unfortunate Painter Cross, lately dec’d 5..0..0“; “10 April, ‘help McPherson into employt (I am to administer) 6..0..0“ (MS: Bodleian Lib.). MacPherson is unidentified; Mary Cross, originally from Tiverton, Devon, widow of John Cross (1819–61; ODNB), historical genre painter, d. 27 Feb., 38 Gloucester Rd., Regent’s Park; a small civil-list pension was granted and fellow artists raised a fund for her; TC’s contribution presumably went to this fund.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WD[WDO], [ca. 15 April]. MS: NLS 1797.184. Quot: Hansons, NE 495. Dated before Ruskin’s lecture on “Tree Twigs,“ 19 April.
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p:
How are you?—And your “nice wife“?Jane Dods.—and your regard for me; what of that?— I want to know more than can be told in violets;Cf. Hamlet 4.1. so do be so good as write me a real letter; or make your wife write me one. In a correspondence between you and me, there is this advantage on your side; that whereas you, living in the old place, leading the old life, must abound in topics having either a direct or an associate interest for me; I at the other end of the kingdom, living with People whom you don’t know, occupied with things you don’t care about must write always under a discouraging uncertainty whether I am interesting you or boring you; so soon as I quit the common ground of old memories and feelings— And if I kept wholly to that, God knows if it wouldn’t become as tiresome a topic as any other! The things one likes to
preserve in Lavender (real or metaphorical) should be kept closely shut up; or the lavender fragrance will soon go out of them!
And so, let me tell you about the Sunny Bank plants.See JWC to WDWDO, [6–7? Oct.]. Surely you will care to hear their fate; that is, if you have any “sensibility“—

Well; the Fuschia and the Laburnum are dead—vanished—annihilated! And the little fir-tree can scarce be called alive. I have twice had a DrUnidentified. to it; but it seems to be one of those cases of occult malady where Science is powerless, and the only hope lies in a happy chance. But the Hawthorn has stood its ground thro’ the hard winter, and has now a little tuft of bright green leaves, and I begin to have wild hopes of its flowering someday, and bringing “airs“ from Long Ago!Coterie speech; see 27:279JWC to JRS, 10 Sept. 1852.— There is something else (which has lost its identity) still,—also in a promising way; tho’ it as yet has put forth no leaf to know it by. Before quitting this remarkably innocent “Head of method,“ I will just add, that the two little Barberries are “regular bricks“ (in the polite London dialect) and are putting out little purple leaves every day; which I take note of thro’ the large magnifying glass Mr C keeps for looking at Maps!

I wish I could say as much for myself—that I were giving any such decided sign of vitality! But alas! I don’t know whether it be the East Wind that is “making pigs and whistles of me“;Falling into wrack and ruin; see 35:57JWC to MR, 25 March 1859. or Frederick The Great that is getting into my blood; or whether I am “mopping for want of a change,“ like a parrot of my acquaintance, whom the Family Doctor ordered down to the kitchen “for a little variety“;Possibly the parrot Jacko, which JWC met in the kitchen of a Brighton lodging house July 1860 (see 36:142JWC to JN, 3 July 1860); but this parrot was moping in a “fashionable Drawingroom“ (see JWC to MO, [29 April]), so perhaps a different parrot. but it is a fact, that I never felt so dull and weary in my whole life as just at the present time! and it is the London Season too, just beginning; when dulness and weariness are out of place!— Well,—on Friday evening D.V. [Deo volente: God willing] I am going to hear Mr Ruskin lecture at the Royal Institution on Tree Twigs!— And perhaps that will do me good! and tomorrow Mrs Jackson (Catherine Cecil of Alderstone in old time)Catherine Cecil (1799–1877; see 25:41–42TC to EC, 7 March 1850), m., 1819, Henry George Jackson (1787-1849), lt.-col., Royal Artillery. Alderston, about ¾ mi. (1 km.) NW of Haddington, was the home of her stepfather, James Stewart. is to spend the day with me, to instruct me in the art of making Dresden China out of leather and paint (!); and who knows how enlivening that may prove! Certainly I know no happier looking woman, of the tranquilly happy sort, than just Mrs Jackson; since she took to making Dresden China of leather,—for Roman Catholic Bazzaars, How the China-making answers without the
Roman Catholicism; I hope to be able to tell some weeks hence. Poor Catherine! Her life must have been at a weary pass, when she let herself be converted (?) perverted (?) by William Dunlop, the Son of “Archie“ and his Wife Anne Veitch!!William Dunlop (b. 1829), son of Archibald Dunlop, former Haddington distiller, and Anne Veitch (b. 1795). for it was he who made a Roman Catholic of her some years ago—and did it effectually one must own! I saw the said Archie and Anne the other day,—went to their houseThe Dunlops lived at 5 Gloucester Terr., Bayswater. where I hadn’t been for immemorial time. But my Housemaid had broken an old saucer; and, so strangely are things connected in this world, I called in consequence at the Dunlops! You see; the old saucer had been given me when I was a girl by the then Mrs Veitch “of Hawthorn Bank“Agnes, b. Sharp, m., 1780, Robert Veitch; they lived at Hawthornbank, Haddington. Anne was one of their 11 children. and had “touching“ associations for me, which the breakage evoked, tho’ by long possession they had fallen obsolete. The effect of these was to revive a feeling of old kindliness towards the family of Veitch; and being naturally practical, and Anne Dunlop being the only Veitch accessible to me for the moment, I streamed off to see her that very day! This was the chain of Cause and Effect between the breaking of the saucer and my calling at the Dunlops!— For the rest; I found them in apparently affluent circumstances. And, if Anne is to be believed, a family so united that “The Happy Family“ in Trafalgar Square“The Happy Family“ was the name given to a collection of small animals (including cats, mice, rabbits, owls, pigeons, and hawks) kept in a cage in Trafalgar Sq., all supposedly living together in harmony. They were apparently there at least in the 1840s and 1850s; see William Jerdan, “The Happy Family,“ Bentley’s Miscellany (1844) 15:173 and Alexander Innes Shand, Days of the Past (1905) 23. is nothing to them! Protestants and Catholics they all live together in Heavenly Harmony. The only difference made, seems to be, that the Catholic members have crucifixes several feet long opposite their beds (I was taken to see them) and the Protestant members have no Crucifixes!— Nobody in that house holds the opinion of a clever German of my friends, that “it is the mixing up of things which is the Great Bad“!Count Oskar von Reichenbach (b. 1815); see 30:224JWC’s Journal, 26 Nov. 1855, and 28330:biographical note.

I send a letter which your wife will perhaps care to read—from Sunny Bank Helen.Helen Dickinson (b. ca. 1823) had been the Donaldsons’ maid at Tenterfield (Sunny Bank), Haddington; she may have left in April 1860; see 36:93JWC to EDO, 7 April 1860. How astonished I should have been, when staying at The Grange in January, if, in one of my morning drives, I had met Sunny Bank Helen taking two children a walk!!Children unidentified and Helen’s current position untraced. As might easily have happened since she has lighted down in that neighbourhood. The next time I visit the Ashburtons I will go to
see her or send for her. She was not a particular favourite with me, but she was a part of Sunny Bank, and Miss Donaldson liked her.

I have seen no more of “the English Donaldsons,“ and heard no more of them, except that the only clever one among them is dead and the vulgarest among them knighted.John William Donaldson, d. 12 Feb., and Stuart Donaldson, knighted 23 Aug. 1860. “Sich is Life! (as Mrs Gamp says)Sarah Gamp, disreputable nurse in Dickens’s Martin Chuzzlewit (1844). which also is the end of all things!“

Jackie WelshJohn Amelia Welsh, JWC’s cousin. sent me the other day a Haddington Courier containing Colonel Davidson’s Lecture on— —himself!Col. David Davidson’s lecture on “The Rifle,“ Assembly Rooms, Haddington, 29 March, was reported in the Haddingtonshire Courier (5 April). Davidson had devoted much of his life to improving rifle technology; see Davidson, Memories 291–95. I declare it made me quite poorly!

When you write, I wish you would inquire for Jackie Welsh and tell me how she is She generally answers immediately when I write to her; and my last letter has brought no answer but a newspaper. And the address on it was shaky—
Good night. I shall now go to bed; midnight having just struck. My love to your wife.
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 April. MS: NLS 525.74. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:245; Wilson, Carlyle 5:428; Ashton 417.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.dateline: Tuesday (perhaps 23d or so of April) / 1861,— Chelsea.
docBody.p:
I have many many times been longing and meditating to write you a petition for some detail of news, one brief word preferable to none. But you see I have never done it; I am in everybody’s debt;—I have not the least hook to hang a complaint upon! I got (voluntarily) one little cheerful Note from Jean, thrown off “while she was in the shop“;Jean Aitken’s husband, James, was a housepainter with premises in English St., Dumfries. I got yr James CurrieJames Currie or Corrie; see TC to JCA, 1 Feb. Letter (whh was pleasant to read) with yr two words of Postscript; I got the Saturday Review yesterday, the two strokes of whh were very welcome. Last night my hours (terribly needful otherwise!) were all stolen from me by a foolish
“Painter Lawrence,“Probably Samuel Laurence (1812–84; ODNB), who had painted TC’s portrait in 1838; see 10:115TC to JCA, 6 July 1838. to whom I can do no good, but who has a shadow of claims, and who comes very rarely. Last night I intended to write more or less;—today in force I steal the minutes, and do it.

My health is as good fully as when you heard last; feeble and baddish, one might justly call it: but it is nothing like toThus in MS, for “so.“ haggard and dispiriting as last year this time. I hover often enough on the frightful gulph of Insomnolence); but do not latterly fall much absolutely in. I prosecute my weary busss day and night, so far as strength reaches; “faint yet pursuing“;—and in general have the blessed hope of ending it yet, in a tolerable manner. Whh is a great improvet on last year, with its ‘congestions of the brain,’ and desperate forecastings and present & future miseries, If all go right, I sometimes think, why shd not next winter see me out? Alas, alas!—

At prest I am in triple & quadruple burble with an accumulated mass of Proof-slips 10 of them the most desperate ever seen (of whh only the 4th is this moment finished): till almost the end of next week (if then), I shall not get a bit of writing done. Patience; and don’t drive the old quadruped too fast. “The slower thou rides“Coterie speech; see 8:271TC to JCHA, 23 Dec. 1835. &c!

Friday last, I was persuaded (in fact had unwarily compelled myself, as it were) to a Lecture of Ruskin’s at the Institn Albemarle Street:Carlyle had attended the lecture at the Royal Institution, 19 April, with Alexander Gilchrist. Lecture on Tree-leaves (as physiological, pictorial, moral, symbolical &c objects); a crammed house;—but tolerable to me even in the gallery.James Smetham (1821–89; ODNB) reported that TC “kept inquiring the time every ten minutes, and at last said ‘I think he ought to give over now.’ Ruskin is a favourite of his, or he would not have gone at all, for he hates art in reality; but R. sent him a ticket. Gilchrist and several others we heard of thought the lecture a failure; but C. would not add the weight of his opinion to this, whatever he might think“ (Letters of James Smetham, ed. Sarah Smetham and William Davies [1891] 94). The Lecture was thot to “break down“; and indeed it quite did as a Lecture; but only did from embarras des richesses [embarassment of riches] (a rare case); Rn did blow asunder, as by gunpowder explosn, his Leaf-notions, whh were manifold, curious; genial; and in fine I do not recollect to have heard in that place any neater thing I liked so well as this chaotic one.Ruskin had been unnerved by the presence of his former wife, now Euphemia (Effie) Millais, sitting with Lady Elizabeth Eastlake (1809–93; ODNB), her confidante and one of his harshest critics. Elizabeth Gaskell wrote to Charles Eliot Norton, 24 June, that Ruskin “entirely broke down in his lecture. … [O]n looking up … he saw Lady Eastlake and Mrs Millais sitting right opposite to him, and staring at him, which finished the breaking him down“ (The Letters of Mrs. Gaskell, ed. J. A. V. Chapple and Arthur Pollard [1966] 661). William Brookfield wrote in his 1863 diary that TC mentioned Ruskin’s “breakdown,“ caused by “Mrs. M. going with a termagant of a woman called Lady E to a former lecture on purpose to disconcert him“ (17 June 1863; Brookfield, Circle 2:500).— “’Ors come, Sir!“ Adieu, dear Brother. Yrs ever T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JJR, 23 April. MS: John Rylands Univ. Lib., Univ. of Manchester. Pbd: Cate 91–92.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN JAMES RUSKIN

docBody.p: The Wife was not with me on Friday Evg last:For Ruskin’s lecture, see TC to JAC, 23 April.—but if she had been? It is a literal fact I, for my own part, found the Discourse a genial, wholesome, welcome one;—and was very well pleased. A failure as a “Lecture“ (if you will), as a Discourse tied all up into sheaves, and able to stuff itself neatly into the space of 60 minutes, filling that and no more;—failure that was; but otherwise, I can assure you, quite the reverse of “failure.“ It did contrive to tear up the big subject (by explosion if not otherwise) for one’s behoof; gave me the liveliest desire to hear that man talk for a month on “Tree-leaves“;—and to me individually (tho’ you must not mention it in Albemarle street) gave, so far I can calculate, more real satisfaction than any [of]Word omitted by TC. the neatest of the many neat Discourses I have ever heard in that place—“A failure from over-opulence (embarras des richesses):No closing quotation marks. Heaven send us many, very many, of precisely the like kind!— These are facts I can myself bear witness to. I recommend, therefore that everybody return to “the Arms of Murphy“Colloquial phrase referring to Morpheus, the god of dreams; i.e., that everyone would forget Ruskin’s temporary breakdown during the lecture. as if nothing were wrong at all or had been:—indeed it never struck me that the Chief CulpritRuskin himself rather than Effie Millais, who had probably caused it by her presence; see TC to JAC, 23 April. cared the least abt it; or I shd have been distressed for the moment, in one transient particular; whh I was not at all. This is my affidavit;—whh I wd not have written except to yourself: but I had something else to write this night for the Younger Mr R.; & will now append it here; viz:
That he, the said R. Junr is due, and over-due for weeks back in this House; and that we expect to see him within two or three nights,—any night he likes
The Glasgow Brandy was exquisite,See TC to JJR, 4 March.—perfect, so far as I cd judge.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IEB, [26 April]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:72–73.

docBody.p: I was going to you today, having been hindered yesterday; but a thought strikes me!— You are a Puseyite or, as my old scotch servantBetty Braid. writes it, a “Puisht“ and I am a presbyterian!Puseyites were followers of a doctrine of high Anglicanism named after Edward Bouverie Pusey (1800–1882; ODNB); see 12:268TC to RWE, 26 Sept. 1840. Isabella would be a member of the Church of England, Puseyite or not; JWC represents herself as a believer in Sabbatarianism, having been brought up a member of the Presbyterian Church of Scotland; she enjoyed teasing Anglican young women about Puseyite tendencies; see 35:214TC to JWC, 23 Sept. 1859. would it be proper for you to receive or for me to pay a visit on Sunday?— I dont quite know as to you—but for me it is a thing forbidden—certainly! So I write to say that if you could have gone to the GorillasAn exhibition, mounted by the Royal Geographical Society in the British Museum, of stuffed gorillas collected by the French traveler and anthropologist Paul Belloni du Chaillu (1835–1903) and purchased for the Museum by Richard Owen (1804–92; ODNB; see 33:225–26JWC to EFO, 31 May 1858), superintendent of the natural history dept.: “These wonderful examples of a race which seems to approach so closely to that of man, and yet is so different, were procured by M. du Chaillu … from forests on the western coast of Africa, near the Gaboon River. The largest of these animals would measure, when at its fullest height, about 5 feet 8 inches“ (Annual Register [1861] 224). tomorrow the Gorillas would have been “not at home“— On consulting my order of admission I find it is for all days except just the two I successively fixed upon!! Saturdays and Mondays— My order is available thro’ all the month of May—so it will still be time when you return—provided you do not indefinitely extend your programme—as you are in the habit of doing!— I shall fix with the others for Tuesday 28th—early—say to start between eleven and twelve—
Will that do?
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle
docBody.note: Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 24 April: “Mrs Carlyle is pretty well & is capable of making extensive purchases from Elise in the shape of beautiful Lace & sacs, & so forth—& when a woman is up to feeling all interest in such varieties she is not thinking of making her Will!“ (MS: Mantell). For Mme. Elise Delepine, see 36:36TC to JN, 4 Jan. 1860.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 27 April. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.

docBody.p: Thanks to you (and to Heaven first of all!) for such a cheerful little Note. We were in sad alarm all Tuesday,—tho’ that perhaps was not the chief crisis either;Presumably a heart problem rather than gout; Lord Ashburton suffered from both. but as a relapse it seemed so formidable On Wedny morning, the Wife, unable to wait for Emily’s Note, ran off to Emily’s self;Emily Baring, Lord Ashburton’s sister, lived at 23 Princes Gate. and returned radiant with the news; leaving the Postman to take his leisure.

You have had a painful crisis and peril; like that of a man fallen suddenly overboard;—and it was a blessed thing that the Hand you love best of allLady Louisa Ashburton. was the one to pull you in! Let us all be thankful.

You must take more care of yourself: my notion is, you do not yet know (as I am fast learning to do) what the meaning of “Sixty“ is. A very earnest meaning; whh will have itself attended to,—under penalties.
Adieu:—shall not we see you soon, in spite of this? I have been looking at the Bath-HouseThe Ashburtons’ London home. windows for weeks past.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MO, [29 April]. Addr: 17 Fettes Row / Edinburgh. PM: London, 29 April 1861. MS: NLS 23210.47. Pbd: Trela, “Margaret Oliphant“ 155–57. Quot: Margaret Oliphant, Life of Edward Irving (1862) 122; Trela, “Unsung Friendship“ 35; Fielding and Sorensen 261–62.
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p:
When I recognised your miniature handwriting the other morning, my heart gave a little jump for joy. For the “notion“ I took of you at our first and only meetingSummer 1860; see JWC to MO, [12 Dec. 1860]. hasn’t died out, nor got rubbed out, in all these months! I am heartily glad that you are coming to London, to stay.Oliphant moved to Ealing (then a village about 6 mi. [9.5 km.] W of London) toward the end of 1861. I thought you would! that Edinr couldn’t suit you in permanence; me it makes feel poorly—even a few days of it!— Not because of its dulness. It is “meant to be dull“ (as are the
Royal dinner parties); One goes to Edinr for repose—for “a quiet Change“—that sort of thing—as a Parrot of my acquaintance was ordered by the Family Doctor “down to the Kitchen; for a little variety“: when its precious, at least prized, existence was threatened by an attack of “mopping“ in the fashionable Drawingroom! I could stand the dulness there; but I can’t stand its narrowness, its paltriness, its prejudicedness, its self-conceit, and above all its religious cant. All that makes me excessively poorly! and I never feel so well disposed towards London, so thankful to it for the real comfort and furtherance of being well let alone,Coterie speech; see 18:231JWC to HW, 7 Oct. 1844. as after a course of Edinr Free-Churchism.JWC’s contact with Edinburgh was mainly through her aunts, Elizabeth, Ann, and Grace Welsh, who were evangelical in attitude (see 16:219JWC to JW, 26 June 1843, and 18:257–58JWC to MW, 1 Oct. 1844), although her last visit had been a success (see 35:201TC to TSS, 15 Sept. 1859). Oliphant replied, 7 May: “You are very hard upon poor old Edinburgh. Alas! Nobody meddles with me. Whether because I am a model of propriety, or because nobody is sufficiently interested to take the trouble, I don’t know.“

But it wasn’t my opinion of Edinr you asked me for, it was for “details“ about Edward Irving. And to tell the Gods Truth, I have written the above not out of any grudge against the poor old Place, but just to stave off a minute longer the business in hand. It is mildly and modestly that you ask for these “details,“ But nevertheless—the effect produced on my Imagination is that of—a loaded pistol at my breast and the words “details or your Life“!! I lose all presence of mind!Oliphant wrote: “I was greatly disturbed to think I had troubled you by my inquiries. I suspect there must be no creature so entirely devoid of feeling as an importunate litterateur in search of materials. Do forgive me.“ When trying to recollect things thus to order (as it were); the blood gets into my head; my heart falls to beating; my memory becomes blank: It is very absurd! and if this nervousness in me could have been overcome by force of Logic, it would have been long ago, but I am so made, there is no helping it! I have sometimes imputed this mental nervousness in myself to having been born prematurely thro’ a fright!— The Author of Elsie Venner would say, “not a doubt of it“!Oliver Wendell Holmes (1809–94), Elsie Venner: A Romance of Destiny, 2 vols. (Boston, 1861); untraced, but cf. “no doubt of that,“ chap. 5. If you haven’t read that Book, pray get it.—

If you were here—beside me—I dare say I might give you some of the details you want—your questions would suggest them—or they would suggest themselves in the natural course of conversation. But to write them down—to order—all in a row—with “the reciprocity all on one side“—the idea of “to be printed“ lowering over me— Oh my Dear! I can’t indeed! the thought makes me like to scream!—and makes me tingle from head to foot!

But look here! I will direct you to a person from whom I have no doubt you could elicit many details very interesting of their kind. There is an old servantBetty Braid. of my Mothers— —your own sort of old servant—to whom the name of
Edward Irving is a dear household name, and who will tell you all she recollects about him—if I bid her do so. Independently of Edward Irving this old Betty is a woman to make whose acquaintance will do you good— There is now no woman on Earth whom I love so dearly—or who so dearly loves me.
Her address is
Mrs Braid / Stenhouse / Greenend / Edinr—

If you are not a great walker, your way to go would be to get into the Dalkeith coach in Princes Street. Greenend is a village about three miles from Edinr thro’ which the Dalkeith Coach runs. StenhouseDalkeith, town about 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SE of Edinburgh; Greenend, a village in Liberton parish; the Braids lived nearby in Upper Stenhouse. is two or three cottages in a row close to Greenend—three minutes walk off—Mrs Braid—my Betty—(“Mrs Carlyle’s Betty“ she calls herself) lives there with her Husband, and a poor paralytic sufferer, her only sonAlexander and George Braid. Oliphant reported, 7 May, her visit to Betty Braid: “I found her very bright and kind, lighting up at the sound of your name, with her little house full of cottage comforts and refinements, and wonderfully still and quiet.“— Besides Her, I could introduce you to a favourite pupil of Edward Irvings—A certain William Dods—agent for the Commercial Bank at Haddington. He is often in Edinr—and if you liked to see him, you have only to write and make an appointment with him, in my name— I will warn him of the possibility—

For the rest: I send you one letter that may be printedProbably Edward Irving to JBW, 9 Feb. 1822; see Oliphant, Irving —36; Irving had enclosed the letter to TC for forwarding; see 2:39TC to JBW, 13 Feb. 1822.— It is an extremely characteristic letter, and contains nothing fatal— It was written soon after he had renewed his acquaintance with me as a grown girl—and before he had— !— I have just one other letter of his spared unburnt—and a sonnet! and I will show you these when you come but mustnt send them out of my hands—

I showed Mr Carlyle the letter inclosed, in case of his finding any objection to its publication. and he agreed with me that it is very characteristic—and that there was no reason why it might not be published—with the suppression perhaps of one passage— — I dont mean the “Lovely“ i had indeed drawn my pencil thro’ that—but Mr C said ‘no’—“the ‘Lovely’ must be let stand; for the letter wouldn’t be the least like a letter of Irvings without it“!! but “if I didnt like the epithet for myself now—I could make you omit the name—put merely my then Initial Miss W—“

What both Mr C and I think should be left out are the two lines about the “antique cast“ of his head.—which those who didnt know him might find ridiculously vain.The phrase and surrounding lines were omitted. Strangely, neither Carlyle objected to the inclusion of the sentence “Were I established in the love and obedience of Him, I should rise toweringly aloft into the regions of a very noble and sublime character, and so would my highly-gifted pupil, to retain whose friendship shall be a consolation to my life: to have her fellowship in divine ambitions would make her my dear companion through eternity“ (Oliphant, Irving 1:135). He was vain—there is no denying it!—but it was a vanity
proceeding out of what was best and most loveable in him, His childlike simplicity and desire to be loved—even to the “cast of his head“—his crystal transparency of character, letting every little weakness show thro it as frankly as his noblest qualities—and above all—out of his loyal, his divine trust in the absolute Truth and sincerity, and in the generous sympathy and good will of all who made friendly advances towards him. Still as those who only read about him now might find more of sheer vanity than of beautiful trust in those words I have marked off—it would hardly be just towards him to put them in print. Dont you think so?—

You ask about an excursion he made with me “thro’ the west country.’ Alas no! he made it not with me but after me!Possibly summer 1820; JWC and her mother were in Nithsdale (see Hansons, NE 31–32), and Irving was also in the area during mid-Aug.; see 1:269TC to JOFE, 5 Aug. 1820. It was a laughable affair at the time—very sad to think of now— I will tell you all about it when you come, or if I go north this summer as is not impossible.

I think I shouldn’t feel the same shamefacedness in having anything out of my childhood published that I feel when “brought up“ as a grown woman—one’s child-self doesnt look oneself at all somehow!—only rather a child that one has more knowledge of than of any other and takes a tenderer interest in than in any other! so you needn’t score out the little Latin outburst, since it pleased youProbably the young Jane Baillie Welsh’s outburst of “penna, pennae, pennam“ from under the table, her plea to learn Latin; see Oliphant, Irving 1:37–38 and Carlyle, Reminiscences 42; JWC had told Oliphant the story as they drove around the park at their first meeting, summer 1860: “She told me that day … the story of her childhood and of her tutor, the big young Annandale student who set her up on a table and taught her Latin, she six years old and he twenty“ (Oliphant, Autobiography 98).—

Goodby—I haven’t been well these few days—much in the case described by an old woman, a servant at Mr C’s Fathers “My heed like a Mall and my stamock like a warm bannock“!For Betty Smail of Scotsbrig, see 33:69JWC to TC, 4 Sept. 1857. a state not favourable to writing— Godspeed you—affy yours / Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WD[WDO], 29 April. MS: NLS 1797.195. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p: Now you needn’t be either flattering or frightening yourself that I am about to write you another letter “out of my head,“ just on the back of having not received a letter out of your head! Your wife’s letter I was glad at and duly grateful; and have entered it in my mental Ledger to her credit. But I have no faith in vicarious good works; so don’t feel to owe you a letter just at present, nor indeed to owe you anything in particular; For, the help with my problems and the loan of the cotton stockings I consider handsomely cleared off by my remembrance of these benefits thro’ so many mortal years!Dods helped the young Jane Baillie Welsh with her algebra problems at school and lent her his white cotton stockings; see 36:22JWC to MR, 9 Dec. 1859. No—this time I write at the instance of a sort of moral necessity—in fact, on a matter of business. (at least in the woman-sense of that word).

You have heard of Mrs Oliphant, “the celebrated novelist“? never mind if you havn’t! for it wouldn’t be any particular shame to you. “Celebrated Novelists“ are thick as blackberries at the present day. Probably you have read her last Book, anyhow, for I sent it to your Wife for newyears day?The House on the Moor (1861); see JWC to JDJAD, [ca. 27 Dec. 186030 or 31 Dec. 1860].

Well! this Mrs Oliphant has had sorrow enough, thro’ family losses;In the previous seven years, Oliphant’s parents, her husband, and two of their children had died. and finds it dreadfully irksome to cobble together Fictions, with her heart full of sad truths; and a Book of Edward Irving’sUnidentified; one of Irving’s several books, which were mostly on religious subjects. having fallen in her way, and “taken great hold of her“, (as certain Books and certain people do take hold of one, sometimes) the idea came in her head to write (since she must write something; for her own and her childrens bread) a Life of Edward Irving; of whom, be it understood, she knew absolutely nothing except the Book she had chanced to read!!

Her first steps in informing herself for the task conducted her to me; for the rest an entire stranger! and were I as fond as Major Davidson of lecturingon—“the Rifles“;See JWC to WDWDO, [ca. 15 April]. here would have been a fine opportunity! as in all my reminiscences of Edward Irving, Myself plays a distinguished part! But I have either less egotism than the dear Major, or more wit to hide it! and so those “details“ about Edward Irving, which my own memory could supply, have been either wholly refused or given on condition they shouldn’t be printed.

At the same time this Mrs Oliphant interests me; and for all reasons I wish well to the ‘Life’; and would gladly help her with it, in any way short of—
lecturing on The Rifle!— And so; I have given her introduction to such persons known to me, and still living, as could throw any light for her on Edward Irving’s character and fortune In making out my first list of these, it didnt occur to me to mention yourself. It was only two days ago that in answering a new letter of questions from the Lady, I gave her your name and address; as Edward Irvings cleverest Pupil at Haddington, and so, likely to have kept a grateful and affectionate remembrance of him. I told her, moreover, that as you went often to Edinr (where she is, for the present) I was sure a meeting might be arranged between you if she wished it; and that I would bespeak your attention for any proposal she might make you.

This then is my present business; to bespeak your polite attention and some fraction of your valuable time, for this Lady, if she should address herself to you. Which will depend I suppose on how far she has got in the Life.
And now having “done what England expected of me“Coterie speech; see 33:13JWC to TC, 7 Aug. 1857. for the moment I have only to subscribe myself affectionately yours J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[IEB], [early May?]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee identified by location of MS among other letters to Isabella Barnes; tentatively dated by Charlotte Southam still being at Cheyne Row. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 1 May 1861.]
div3.head: JWC TO [ISABELLA E. BARNES]

docBody.p: Why didn’t you come in yesterday?— A man and his wifePossibly Gerald and Frances Blunt; otherwise unidentified. The Blunts’ joint diary contained brief records of visits between the Blunts and the Carlyles May–Oct.: TC called, 17 May; the Blunts spent the evening with the Carlyles, 29 May; a dinner party with sev-eral other people attended by JWC, 22 July; JWC dined with them, 1 Oct.; and the Blunts spent the evening with the Carlyles, 2 Oct. (Reginald Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt [1911] 76–77). were here, but that was nothing—and I was looking for you. Charlotte said it was not her fault— I hope so— Goodby— Pray for me.
docBody.name: J C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 1 May. MS: NLS 517.18. Hitherto unpbd.

docBody.p: Before going out for my “midnight walk of contemplation“See Carlyle, “The Diamond Necklace“ (Works 28:372). (literally a daily or rather nightly fact here), I will write you a word,—as I have long been intending to do! You can have no idea how I am tied up and tumbled about; and have, in very fact, for long periods, no hard opportunity of even five minutes to myself. All day long it is a slaving and a puddling (such work as I never was at before), then instantly a riding till I am dead weary; then a try for sleep (often successful, in a quietish place I have contrived; a cape, a rug, and your quilt covering the body of me, an old wide-awake lightly my head, and all made perfectly dark); out of this, perhaps towards 7 p.m., I am roused to eat my bit of dinner; after whh, there is weariness, languor, and if I try the least writing headache, till tea, after whh things are to be read (now & then a blockhead stumbling in to hinder me altogether); in short, in a trice, it is 11 o’clock, and I am ordered out to the streets (very poor at walking mostly, the thing a heavy task & necessity to me); then a tumbler of hot milk, a pipe of ’bacco; and, if I am wise, off to bed again,—to sleep if I can; and recommence the same dull round next day! One day I shall get out of it; God knows I am very weary of it; weary, weary!— And, just at present, for 10 days past and perhaps 4 or 5 to come, I am in a welter of bad Proofsheets whh is like to drive me desperate! No more of it. I struggle on with my best ability, “faint yet pursuing“; and cannot hope to get free till after a good long while.

I was much gratified with yr little Note; you must soon write me another; and never mind not getting answer all at once. I like much to hear yr news & observatns, what soever is stirring, “revival“ matter, all man[ner] of matter. Write to me whenever you can. And be patient with me till I get done!

I believe yr Jim has made a good change to the Country;Apparently Jean’s son James had recently moved lodgings. there is a bed here for him, some Saturday night, when my hands are freer.— I “wish“ a new toothbrush: the excellent one you got is shedding its hair! Jane bot me another; but it does the like. Adieu, Adieu T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 6 May. MS facsimile: NLS 807.9. Pbd: Walter W. Blackie, Walter Graham Blackie (privately printed; Blackie & Son, Glasgow, 1936) 121–22. Both the NLS MS facsimile and its published form are in a collection of letters, the majority of which are to Blackie & Son, Glasgow booksellers and publishers; addressee possibly one of the Blackies: John Blackie (1782–1874; ODNB), founder of the firm; John Blackie Jr. (b. 1805), his eldest son; or Walter Graham Blackie (1816–1906), who became head of the firm after his father; otherwise unidentified. Walter W. Blackie headed TC’s letter “Thomas Carlyle, Recommending an Editor.“ The MS facsimile is on larger than usual paper for a TC letter and there is no salutation or heading; the top of the paper has been torn off. The ink is darker than TC’s usual ink of this time. Other identical versions of the letter exist at Columbia Univ., Duke Univ., Univ. of Manchester Inst. of Science and Technology, and in private hands. One is possibly the original, the others having been reproduced from it for J. M. Moir to use in various applications; other copies may also exist.

docBody.p: I have had the pleasure of meeting Mr J. M. Moir,John Macrae Moir (1827–81), journalist; b. and educ. in Scotland, he had moved to London 1846; for TC’s previous recommendations, see 28:289TC to WM, 13 Oct. 1853, and 29:23TC to TB, 17 Jan. 1854. He was ed. of the Illustrated Times, 1855–58, the Illustrated News of the World, 1858, and the People’s Magazine, 1867, and wrote extensively for provincial dailies. Moir became sec. of the Scottish Corporation, a charitable inst. for impoverished Scots in London, 1862–81. He was called to the Middle Temple bar, 1864, and later served as deputy judge in the Lord Mayor’s court (London) and various metropolitan courts. different times, in late years; and am willing to testify that I consider him a man of clear and vigorous intellect; of honest solid notions, ideas and aspirations; generally of a robust substantial and manful turn of mind. A man, I shd guess, capable of much labour, and of doing it in a faithful, energetic and efficient manner. Of his private habits, and andThus in MS. modes of working and living I have heard nothing that was not favourable. For conducting a Newspaper“The paper in question was probably The Scottish Guardian established in 1832 by John Blackie, Junr., and others. It continued until 1862, when it expired. If Carlyle’s candidate got the post, he can have enjoyed it only for the last year of the paper’s existence“ (Blackie 121). Possibly the Scottish Guardian (Glasgow, 1832–Dec. 1861), as Blackie suggests, otherwise unidentified; it was not necessarily a Scottish paper, since Moir lived in London. of solid basis and solid aims I shd consider him a man of superior likelihood.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JGC[JGCO], 7 May. MS: NLS 607.575 inc. Hitherto unpbd.

docBody.p: How provoking that you should be out of the way when your little MargaretMargaret Sullivan who came to work at Cheyne Row in early June. is hearing of “something to her advantage“Phrase from newspaper advertisements.—which needs your presence to bring it to a bearing!

I should like to take her to myself, to make a cook of her; if only I were as well satisfied on some points, as I am pleased with her bright kindly looks. and you alone whose knowledge of her I could trust, are gone nobody knows where, doing nobody knows what; the only thing stated for certain about you being, that you are not expected in Mount StreetCooke lodged at 47 Mount St. for yet two weeks.

You will infer that my “establishment“ is in a state of crisis, from this renewed idea of taking Margaret, and if I have spoken to you about Charlotte of late months (I forget whether I have) you will not be much surprised. The short and long of it is, a Devil seems to have got into that girl, and I am parting with her—This time for good. The end has been hastened by my poor white Sarah having fallen into a state of ill health that necessitates her going into the country, to her Parents, to be nursed She has been ill “for five months“ it seems! and concealed it from me—but told them of it “at home,“ and they have written to bid her return. I am excessively sorry. for a most perfect little servant, and better conducted girl in every way I never had in my house— And the only thing I ever missed in her viz: sensibility, has come out unexpectedly strong on this occasion of having to give up her place. Sarah having to be replaced then; I could not with any prospect of a good result put another young girl beside Charlotte—as it isn’t to be believed young girls as impassive to bad example as Sarah are so common that I should have two in succession! And the end of my considerings has been a final explanation with Charlotte and decision that she should go also.

The very day this came off, Geraldine happened to tell me she had “called at Mount Street,“ and that Margaret had told her she was finally determined to get “out of that,“ and wanted a place.Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 24 June: “You will be glad & Ellen will rejoice to hear that Margaret is at Cheyne Row safe & sound—tho’ it required as much trouble to get her away from 47 Mount Street as it did of old to rescue a Princess from enchantment—the old woman was very unwilling to lose her—& wailed extremely—Mrs Carlyle gives a good report of her—she likes her—& says she has not had such a cleaner since she left Scotland but of course Margaret wants training to good company manners“ (MS: Mantell). Ellen Sullivan was Margaret’s sister, currently in Mantell’s service. The “old woman“ of 47 Mount St. was Rebecca Pullen (b. ca. 1799); Margaret was the only servant according to the 1861 census; in addition to Cooke, there were three other boarders, a prof. of singing, a governess, and an actress. I remembered the agreeable impression
the girls looks made on me the day I took up the pipes. and again wondered as I had wondered then “could she cook any at all? or could she so much as learn? and I went up today to ask. She told me she could “broil chops fry fish, boil fish, and make a sort of bread puddings“— Now that aint much, especially for people who hardly ever eat fish! Still it is a point to start from, more hopeful than total ignorance—and more than Charlotte knew when I began with her— If she has a head to learn is the question. I could get her some lessons.Possibly from Ann Newnham; see 33:198JWC to MR, 29 March 1858.— now you must tell me that? if from your experience of the girl you think she has good practical intelligence? also whether you think the confusion of overwork she has so long weltered in, has given her habits of muddle which it would be impossible or very difficult to cure, even where the work was light. Does she tear about, making a noise, and breaking things, and spilling things?MS ends here.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 8 May. MS: NLS 525.75. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Two days ago I tried to write, but made little out; tonight, before anything else come, I will throw you a word off.

I am still overhead in bad Proofs; bad, tho’ not “horrible“: we are approaching the end of Vol iii; it is now 3 weeks since I have got a word written for Vol iv; and there is but little start gained there hitherto. I feel as if it wd be peremptorily necessary to call halt again at the end of Vol iii, for a couple of months, till I gathered breath. But I have not yet formally spoken of it to Robson. It will depend. I am heartily wearied to the ground; I scarcely think as difficult a job cd be set one as this 3d vol has been,—thro’ every line and fibre of it: ah me! But it is very much better (whh is not indeed saying much) than I ever thot it cd have been made. And it will not come on me again; thank Heaven! My sleeping is not very bad; yet rather baddish lately; & within a day or two I begin again to feel something of the old head;—very little of it yet (perhaps not it at all); but if it start me awake again? I will try to take care it shall not. On the whole, Vol iv will be easier;—I shall end it too (God willing), and then lie down.— ChorleyJohn Rutter Chorley. (to whom the thing is perfectly
“easy“) ardently counsels persistence witht pause! Chy is of small use on the Proofs this time; occupies himself on commas;—chiefly, of late, in protesting against the word “rendezvous“ used as a verb,—to whh I find no objection, and usually let it stand. Neuberg, who is not very well, and is interested in his own Translator work, gives me no great help either,—very swift and very slimIn the sense of “scanty.“ in anything he gets of mine:—poor soul, he has stood long true; and his fat members begin to droop at last, no wonder! After all, the whole turns, and must any way have turned, on my standing true to myself. Courage!—

We have grim N.E. weather; not wholesome, I suppose, tho’ the temperature suits me better than heat. Since last night the west wind is making a rally (won’t prevail yet, I guess), and we have stagnancy of atmosphere, with rain enough to be muddy. The Town is very full; but to me is mostly quite a stranger. One call or two in the week (on foot-day), and that is enough. Are you for Edinr, or have you planned at all, for the summer? I suppose you have done with Press-correcting (a gratuity to Widow Irving,Janet Irving (see TC to JAC, 3 Feb.), widow of David Irving; John A. Carlyle was editing Irving’s History of Scotish Poetry (see TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1860) and was presumably working on its proofsheets. as I have construed it)? That poor little Fife LadyMargaret Oliphant, who had been based in Elie, Fife, summer 1860, when she first met the Carlyles and whose mother’s family came from Fife. will do no good with her subject, I doubt. Jane has sent her one Edwd Letter.See JWC to MO, [29 April].

By all means speak to Murray,Possibly Thomas Murray (1792–1872; ODNB), author; founder of Murray & Gibb, printers, 21 George St., Edinburgh, and an old friend of TC; see 1:3–4TC to TM, 24 June 1813, and 23:135TC to JAC, 18 Oct. 1848. John A. Carlyle possibly wanted advice on publishing his edn. of Kingis Quair; see TC to JAC, 4 Dec. 1860. if you have chance; you may report my poor wishes to him, with great truth. Poor soul; old, aimed to be rich, and has not succeeded even in that!— To Erskine, if he is not yet away,Thomas Erskine, from Edinburgh back to his home, Linlathen, Dundee. my constant sincere regards. I expect to hear something from you soon.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 14 May. MS: NLS 525.76. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Last night, abt midnight, I got, at the long last, out of my Proofsheet Slough of Despond,—really better than, at one time, seemed even possible;—and am
(unless new frights arrive tonight again) once more a writing man. Vol iii is actually coming to its end: not what it shd be, by any means; but far nearer that than I could have expected. The indescribable, unfathomable and illimitable chaos whh it once was, being known only to myself, I can expect no recognition from other people of the job I have had with it: but that is no matter; if it be done, and done honestly according to my means, that is a very great blessing to me, and that needs no “recognising“ except where it will not fail of such! Vol iv, I think I said, can hardly be anything like so difficult:—but, unluckily, there is very little of it on paper in any form yet! There is no doubt I have a tough wrestle still ahead in that quarter before getting quite out!— —I have not yet laid any fixed plans: but the general intention is, to stand by the bench and toolbox, if standing can at all be. Thurso invites me cordially again, & to come off directly; but that will no do for this season, or for any that I can fix.TC had visited Sir George Sinclair at Thurso Castle, 4 Aug.–7 Sept. 1860; he did not visit Thurso again; see 36:228TC to JWC, 5 Sept. 1860. I have just ansd the good Sir George (after five weeks of waiting), that I am not to voyage this year. Annandale itself looks dreary, till I can visit it with the millstone off my neck. I think vaguely of a two months at Brighton or somewhere on the Coast (furnished house &c), with Chelsea and Books accessible: there to work in the fine solitude. Brighton sea &c were excellt last year, cd I have but secured a quiet sleeping-place.The Carlyles visited Brighton 3 to 9 July 1860; for TC’s complaints about his lack of sleep there, see 36:145JWC to CSO, 5 July 1860, and 150TC to SGS, 24 July 1860. That surely must be attainable, there or in some similar place. We are just upon a total change of servants again! The younger girl,Sarah Piggott; see JWC to JGCO, 7 May. an excellt creature, is obliged to go home for health; foolish Charlotte has been behaving very ill:—in short it is decided we are to have a clean sweep; and the new hands (a likely elderly woman for chief maid) are, I believe, nearly engaged.Margaret Sullivan (see JWC to JGCO, 7 May) and Matilda (see JWC to MR, [3 July]). I am sorry for poor Jane abt it;—drives her off sleep &c;—but in this land of “liberty“ fraternity, equality, emancipatn, “ou la mort [or else death],““On all house walls … there stand printed these words: Republic one and indivisible; Liberty, Equality, Fraternity, or Death“ (Carlyle, French Revolution, Works 4:183); TC apparently felt that the ideals of the French revolution had left employers at the mercy of their servants. there is nothing to be said. Our House has been much more comfortable for the last 4 or 6 months under the Two than it was under the One.

I got yr Saturday Review, a very high-sniffing stickish Article, but better worth reading than any rival it has. I send it to Scotsbrig today. I have been, not “annihilating rubbish,“ but smoking round the edges of it, with intent to annihilate. I am going for a ride out to Ruskin’s, this being my “holiday“
(forsooth), and the first summer day we have yet seen. Ld Mayor & Spouse invite me to a Mansion-House Sublimity (Royal Society, Royal &c for 25th next),William Cubitt (1791–1863; ODNB), builder and developer; M.P. for Andover 1847–61 and 1862–63; elected lord mayor of London 29 Sept. 1860. Since his wife, Elizabeth (1792–1854), was dead, his da. Laura (1823–98), Lady Olliffe, wife of Sir Joseph Francis Olliffe (1808–69; ODNB), was acting as lady mayoress: “she will … take up her abode and do the honours of Mansion House [official residence of the lord mayor]“ (Illustrated London News, 19 Nov. 1860). The event was described in the Times: “On Saturday evening the Lord Mayor and the Lady Mayoress entertained his Royal Highness the Duke of Cambridge, together with the President and Council of the Royal Society, the President and Council of the Royal Academy, and many other persons of rank and distinction, at a dinner at the Mansion House“ (27 May). whh I have just declined. Adieu, dear Brr
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JGC[JGCO], [16 or 23 May]. MS: NLS 607.576. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:240–41. Dated during the arrangements to employ Margaret Sullivan; see JWC to JGCO, 7 May.
div3.head: JWC TO J. GEORGE COOKE

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Thursday [9 May 186116 or 23 May 1861]
docBody.p: Goodness! No! Dont let that poor little girlMargaret Sullivan. take the long journey here again—“under difficulties“! We have said to one another all that was to be said, except just fixing the day for her coming, and she can tell me that, when she knows it—thro you—

Miss GooseburyGeraldine Jewsbury’s nickname. has been staying at Lady Cumbermere’s while LadyshipMary, b. Gibbings (1806–89), 3d wife of Stapleton Cotton (1773–1865; ODNB), 1st Viscount Combermere; they lived at 48 Belgrave Sq., London, and Combermere Abbey, nr. Whitchurch, on the Shropshire-Cheshire border. was at the racesPossibly the Chester Races, 7–10 May.—“taking care of“ Miss something!Unidentified. what an idea of a destitute girl that gives one—Geraldine called in to take care of her!

Tell Margaret to take it all quietly— I am not in any violent hurry— It is but doing for a day or two what I used to do all the days of the year and for years on years—viz: dusting about a little myself
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 19 May. MS: NLS 517.19. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:210.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Your Packet came punctually & safe; many thanks to you for yr constant readiness to oblige. The toothbrush appears one of the best that cd be got; I have little doubt it will do: if it won’t, we must just give up the speculation for this time, this being the 4th!TC deleted “third“ and wrote “4th“ above it. I have made trial of;—such beauty is in the system of “Cheap and Nasty,“Coterie speech; see 34:6TC to JWC, 2 July 1858. at present patronised by the deluded public everywhere, & followed by nearly all that work for the said public. Had there been one made right, other 3 need not have been made at all in this instance! I have not tried the socks; but they give every promise; & will be put upon their mettle, so soon as I have time to shift into summer clothing. The piece of butter, whh has been in constant requisition ever since it arrived, and is not yet finished, fairly excels any Middlesex specimen we have had; whh is a singular credit to it, considering that our grass must be 3 weeks ahead of yours. Thanks for all these bits of good things.

I am toiling along on the old terms; rather better, not rather worse: half of the job, and certainly the worst half, is as good as altogether off my hands: that is to say, Vol iii is nearly thro’ the press itself; and I am daily writing at Vol iv and last, whh I always think (fond hope springing immortal in the human breast!)Cf. Alexander Pope, An Essay on Man 1.95. will be easier to do in some measure. Clear it is, if I can hold out a certain number of months more, I shall be out of the ugliest job I have ever in my life had to do;—and be perceptibly lighter loaded for the remainder of my appointed miles in this world! The Book promises to be better, too, than I ever thot it cd have been.

Jack writes to me, sparingly, now & then Fixed in Edinr yet; he seems really to do as well there as he cd anywhere;—has always the talent of keeping himself content, and occupied with something or other, of an innocent description.— London is boiling with company; will grow madder and madder for a couple of months. The furious cold issued in plunges of rain, then in weather too hot, and has again become cold. Trade rather bad, people all say.There were widespread fears that the American Civil War would undermine world trade. The Times, 3 May, reported a “State of Trade“ summary by Manchester accountants: “The dark side of the future is the untoward progress of the unhappy disputes which have occurred in the United States. … [I]t seems very evident that much of the trade of the world will be jeopardized and thrown into confusion should the struggle degenerate into a protracted and devastating internecine war, such as at present seems too likely.“
Plentiful crops of follies, these never fail. Good night dear Sister: my kind love to the GoodmanJames Aitken. & everybody. Your affecte T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 June. MS: NLS 525.77. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I had got yr Humboldt pamphletUnidentifed pamphlet about Alexander von Humboldt (1769–1859), Prussian naturalist and explorer. and read it; I was longing much for a Letter when yr Note came on Friday. A right welcome thing to me in my almost total loneliness here. Human society does abound abt me, as nowhere else on this Planet, & at midnight this King’s-Road is a Niagara of cabs (not crossable witht difficulty, except you are bound for or from Cremorne,Pleasure gardens nr. Cheyne Row; see 19:152TC to JWC, 18 Aug. 1845. where indeed you don’t require to cross!)— But to me who am busy with my Prussian Hydra, struggling in internecine duel with that amazing monster, all these are minus quantities; and practically I have little real society, except with my poor Horse and the glimpses of fine green country he occasionally brings me to.

The change to summer is usually unfavourable, and has been as good as its wont this year. I hope I am now pretty much across the transition strip; but for the last fortnight I have rather been below par than above, and had to give up my first attempt (whh must be resumed) to get into riding in the evg, & dining betn 3 & 4.— Not that sleep ever went as it did last year (hideous to look back upon!)—but I have been very useless at work; & in fact tho with effort making frightfully little way. Contrary to expectatn too, a cargo of Slips yesternight warns me that I shall have a nice fortnight or 3 weeks of tusselling with Book XIV (last of vol. 3) before it get thro’ the needle’s eye!Cf. Matt. 19:24.— — I have nothing for it but to take time, since time must be taken: this thing is all of the nature of mosaic; witht inconceivable botheratns no mortal, in my place (nor well, in anybody’s, Chaos being hitherto King of the whole), can do any part of it. Patience, patience!

I was very glad of the news from Annandale: in general, I hear nothing; whh, as there is not time for me to write in ansr, I cannot complain of, tho’ it is always a regret to me.John A. Carlyle wrote to his nephew James Carlyle Jr., 5 June: “Do you ever write? Your uncle would be glad if you sent him some simple details from time to time … were it only to remind him of the friends at Scotsbrig; for along with his hard work comes a rather painful exclusion of society. I know your Father would be glad to see him … & it might be well to say so, though he might be unable to come“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).

I read the Humboldt witht difficulty or displeasure, tho’ the Author seems a rather albuminous young man; and the rugged old Heathen is never very much to my mind.TC had found Humboldt’s view of nature as expressed in his book Kosmos (Stuttgart, 1845–47) “altogether unworshipping“; see 21:165TC to TCH, 20 Feb. 1847. What am I to do with the Pampht? Send it back to you?— I doubt you have not yr two Histories of Rebelln 1745 (Henderson’s & Wray’s)Andrew Henderson, The History of the Rebellion, 1745 and 1746 (Edinburgh, 1748); James Ray, A Compleat History of the Rebellion (York, 1755). TC had acquired Andrew Henderson, Life of William Augustus Duke of Cumberland (1766) in 1857; see 33:95TC to HL, 2 Oct. 1857, and Works 15:434. about you just now,—both at Scotsbrig? I have, unluckily given both mine away, when perhaps I might have picked a something out of them for what I am now at.— Tom Wilson has brot a Wife from Weimar;Thomas Wilson, living in Weimar since 1853, had recently m. a German woman, connected to the ladies’ college where he was teaching but not further identified. and settled himself on Black Heath (place called Paragon there), in hope of getting Boarders. He has one, but wants still other two.The Paragon was a crescent of 14 large houses, built (1794–1805) in seven blocks linked by colonnades, designed by Michael Searles (1750–1813); Wilson was in no. 4. Tait, whose wife I never saw, has produced a dr from her;Mildred Tait was now over a year old. he comes down once in 3 or 4 months, sententious sawdustish as formerly. Neuberg is in weak health, wholly given to translating. Jane has got a pain in the back of her right side, for the last few days. Not very bad. Adieu dear Brr
docBody.name: T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 4 June. MS: MUL. Pbd: Marrs 737–38.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Your Note with Alick’s Letter in it was waiting for me when I got back from riding this afternoon. I remain ignorant of the particulars of Alick’s Proposal; but the practical outline, as I suppose, of what is immediately to be done is very clear to me.

Seven or eight weeks ago, not knowing what you had written to Alick, nor whether you had written at all, I wrote to him myself, a little Note prompted by my dread of accidents, reiterating, & confirming as serious and practical, what I had said in a former Letter,TC wrote first to Alexander Carlyle in April 1860, then again in April 1861; see 36:95TC to AC, 13 April 1860, and TC to AC, 7 Aug. [April] (TC misdated the letter). That by way of helping TomAlick’s eldest son. to an outfit
there was money here, any sum not above £250, whh was intentionally set apart for that object, and whh he Alick might himself draw a bill for at any time, in case my great hurries did not permit me to settle all about it, and to send it, before it shd be needed. This was, and is, the state of matters; as perhaps I explained to yourself also in writing abt it long ago.

There seems to me no trade in the world so little eligible as that of Schoolmaster for poor Tom; nor any so likely as something of the kind whh appears now to have offered itself,—namely, starting as a Farmer, or Tiller of the soil, with a fair chance of becoming Full owner of it by paying in gradual instalments. If the thing therefore is sound, whh on Alick’s judgt we must take it to be,—I can only desire you, for my own share, to act for me, with all despatch, on the above principle,—viz. of £250 in whole, or in part, being ready for the object: to you, with yr better information on particulars, coupled with knowledge of yr own intentions, I must leave wholly to choose what sum of mine (the whole or the part of that £250); but send at once what you judge right; and whatever you send I will be good for. Tantum sufficuit [enough is enough].— I am worried worse than usual with Proof-slips with &c &c; and must so leave it.

I write at some length sunday last; & put it into “the Pillar“;Pillar boxes had been introduced, 1852, by Anthony Trollope (1815–82; ODNB) when he worked as a post office surveyor in the Channel Islands. you do not seem to have got the poor dud nevertheless;TC to JAC, 2 June, arrived 3 June.—I will beware of Pillars again! Good night, dear Brother. Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, [6 June]. MS: NLS 553.233. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 6 June 1861. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:431.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I bethink me that in charity to Tauchnitz you shd mention (in amendment of what I said yesterday) That the “Squire PapersThe “Squire Papers“ were a collection of 35 letters purported to have been written by Oliver Cromwell, sent to TC by William Squire in 1847 (see 21:156–57TC to EF, 6 Feb. 1847, and Clyde de L. Ryals, “Thomas Carlyle and the Squire Forgeries,“ Victorian Studies 30 [1987]: 495–518). TC was convinced that they were authentic; he included them as an appendix in the third edn. of Cromwell (1850) and in subsequent edns. Christian Bernhard Tauchnitz, Leipzig publisher who pbd. many of TC’s works in Germany, was preparing to publish Oliver Cromwell’s Letters and Speeches, 4 vols. (Leipzig, 1861) as part of his Collection of British Authors series. are an exceptional kind of Appendix, not to be called “Appendix“ at all; but to be put down with their present Title, and “adjoined“ to the Events they treat of (wherever the end of these may be). That is all, of amendt.

You might mention also my astonisht at the sublime sum of money he pays me for this Cromwell,—no less than £15 per large 8vo vol! A thing for a man to grow rich upon;—and practically that if he, Tauchtz, cares to send me a Couple of Copies of his precious Cromwell, I will put them by here in memoriam. But that also is of next to no moment. Only I do feel the price to be scandalous; and wd have the fat blockhead apprised that I do,—in case of future applicatns on his part.

I have spent 1½ hour in search of the poules mouillées [wet hens],Frederick the Great’s description of the French forces at the siege of Prague, 9–16 Sept. 1744, as recorded in Campagne de monsieur le maréchal de Coigny en Allemagne l’an M.DCC.XLIII—M.DCC.XLIV 4:185–87 (vols. 19–26 of Pierre Francois du Moulin, Recueil des campagnes de divers maréchaux de France, 27 vols. [Amsterdam, 1760–73]; see 36:135–36TC to JN, 7 June 1860). Neuberg had sent his notes from Campagne to TC, 4 [3] April: “I send you my achievements amongst the ‘5 Maréchaux’: very insignificant. … Adelung’s ‘old women’ can only be his rendering of the Poulles-mouillées.“ See Works 16:32; see also CL 36:136TC to JN, 7 June 1860. Johann Christoph Adelung, Pragmatische Staatsgeschichte Europens von dem Ableben Kaiser Carls 6 an bis auf die gegenwärtigen Zeiten, 9 vols. (Gotha, 1762–67); TC’s copy: HCC.—witht result of any kind. We will now honestly let it go to the —, being able to get thro’ witht it.
No more; I am like to be driven mad with these beggarly botherations;—but hope to see you, Sunday Evg, a good deal better.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 June. MS: NLS 517.20. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—Thanks to you for doing that piece of business in the way you have, and especially for cooperating with me in it. A duty clearly; a thing we had to do, and whh is now done, and secured agt chances. It appears to me, if they get either that piece of land adjoining BieldAlexander Carlyle’s farm, nr. Brantford, Ontario; see 18:72TC to JCA, 17 June 1844, and 20:171TC to AC, 18 April 1846. His son Tom wrote in his journal: “Uncle[s] Thomas and John were endlessly generous and kind to us in every way. Carlyle, whom so many people, in their ignorance, characterize as harsh, and gloomy and gruff, was nothing short of an inspiration to us, arousing hope, courage, energy and steadfastness.
