The ‘good’ Doctor too was one of a million for disinterested kindness, In fact, two such uncles would be hard to find in any age or country for high, noble, loveable qualities“ (Marrs 597). or some other similarly eligible, Tom will have a fair start in life, and may be looked hopefully upon till we hear to the contrary. You did well to advise Alick to get “a careful Lawyer“; he himself was never over-safe for having loose strings, whh bred burbles in the end.— Before taking to any other kind of work, I repay
you, in the way directed, what money I owed: Draught inclosed, of £250, with “Order on it;TC noted: “7 june 1861 / to Br John (for Br /Alick’s Tom). / £250..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). the two strokes, I conclude, you wished to be forborne, in tenderness to Scotch Bankers.

The Wray came duly; I have a Henderson “lent“ too,See TC to JAC, 2 June. and unattainable now when I want it. Abt a year ago the new Lady Ashburton got it from me, has I dare say never read a page of it; and is now out of the way (in the Highlands, Husband & she, very suddenly, her Mother thot to be dying),Mary Elizabeth Frederica Stewart-Mackenzie lived at Brahan Castle, 4 mi. (6.5 km.) SW of Dingwall; she d. 1862. when I might redemand it, in the absence of other resource that way. For two or perhaps 3 weeks yet, yours, if you do fall in with it, will still be in time.

Contrary far to my fond hopes, I have fallen in with a new Gordian burble, or rather with a pair together, one in my proofs, one in my ms.; and know not what way to turn with it. “Impossible!“ seems the word again. The like will occur, I suppose, always till I see myself out of this—a consumatn whh is the sum of all my prayersCf. Hamlet 3.1. for a long while past!— To add to the concern, I mostly missed sleep last night; owing to high east-winds, certain bankrupt joiner peopleGeorge Todd Jr., Ranelagh Works, Cheyne Walk; see also TC to JAC, 20 July. (tumbling logs) nearby, and first of all to new uninstructed maids we are are getting.“Are“ repeated on turn of page. Matilda and Margaret began work about the beginning of June. “Three cheers for Freedom!“See TC to JAC, 14 May. I exclaim on the last item.— But it is fit I were at other work. Yours Ever Affecte T. CarlyleCharles Dickens reported TC’s comments about Jews making money from usury rather than from real work to William Macready, 11 June; see Introduction xix37:introduction and DL 9:425–26.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 13 June. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 13 June 1861. MS: NLS 553.234. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Would you despatch that Humboldt PamphtSee TC to JAC, 2 June. (if, as is likely, you have quite done with it) to my Brother’s Address (67. Hanover street, Edinburgh);—the 2 stamps will carry it.

Item tell me how you are;Neuberg had heart trouble; see TC to JAC, 24 June. since by one impediment and another I have
not got up to you. We trusted, last sunday night, it was only the bad weather; but have our doubts, whh remove if you can.

The “wet-hens“See TC to JN, [6 June]. (date at least) was still in time to be useful. I have just (after 3 weeks of muddy despair!) got out of that preliminary Chapter (Chapter iii, I think),—and must undertake tomorrow such a lot of Proofslips as I had hoped never to see again.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JC], 14 June. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO [JAMES CARLYLE]

docBody.p: I got the Junior’s kind Note, your kind invitation.James’s son James had apparently written inviting TC to Scotsbrig, as John A. Carlyle suggested, 5 June; see TC to JAC, 2 June. How happy shd I be to come and idle for a while in Scotsbrig, running abt in the fine breezes! But I doubt much it cannot be this year; scarcely, if avoidable at all, must I permit myself the thought of Scotland at all again with this horrible job still unfinished. Alas, alas, you never saw anything go on so slow; such are its difficulties,—such is the poor remnant of strength for it now left in me. But Courage, Courage: I do hope, by the toil of many months yet, to get it done; and then—!—

I am very glad to hear of Burnswark,Farm in Hoddam parish, Dumfriesshire, previously rented by TC’s old friend William Graham. His sister Elizabeth Graham d. 21 May, and the tenancy was to be sublet by her nephew George Graham (b. ca. 1834). The Dumfries and Galloway Courier, 11 June, advertised the farm to be leased “with entry at the present term of Whitsunday. … Mr. Graham, the present tenant, will give directions for showing the boundaries of the Lands. … [O]ffers will be received … till Monday 17 June next.“ John A. Carlyle wrote to his nephew James, 12 June, “I hope you may succeed, but [would] be sorry if you got the place at too high a rent. The house is a very good one. … Perhaps also you might arrange with Mr Graham to take the furniture at a valuation. It might probably be got cheap in that way, & would be worth more to you than to any one else“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). John wrote again to James, 14 June: “I, for one, would not venture so large a sum on any land belonging to such people as the Jardines—who seem to be guided in letting, as well as in buying their land, by mere commercial views“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). The owner of the land was Andrew Jardine (1810–81). James did not get the farm, and John wrote to him, 25 June: “I am sorry to hear that the Farm of Burnswark is let to the Ayrshire man“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). Burnswark was let to an Ayrshire widow, Barbara McKerrow (b. 1816), with 12 children. and that there are good outlooks of succeeding in yr offer there. It seems a very feasible kind of adventure too,
were you once in it; a fair hope of Jamie’s doing well there. No other spot cd be so handy.Burnswark is about 2 mi. (3 km.) NW of Scotsbrig.
Don’t fret abt the £600; Jack says he will not see you beaten with it;—and there is another of us that now says the like!—

Alas, it is striking 3: I have not one other moment. Believe always in my unalterable affectn, as I do in yours; and continueThus in MS; presumably for “construe.“ my silence as meaning at all times many thots abt you.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[IEB], [ca. mid-June]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Quot: Blunt, Forum 399; Blunt, CR 153. Addressee identified by location of MS among other letters to Isabella Barnes; conjecturally dated by the recent illness of Sarah and dismissal of Charlotte. [To maintain the order established by the editors of the CL, this letter has been assigned a document date of 15 June 1861.]
div3.head: JWC TO [ISABELLA E. BARNES]

docBody.p: This is to tell you that should my discharged CharlotteCharlotte Southam had been dismissed in May. come after your place of Housemaid, and say she heard of it thro me, you are not to believe that I sent her. I advised Sarah—my housemaid who had to go into the Country for her health, and who to my astonishment arrived at my house last night, quite recovered—I advised her to go after your place as I could have given her an excellent character in every point except bodily strength and in that your FatherAlfred Barnes. might have improved her. She, aiming rather at something in the Lady’s maid line, told Charlotte about my wishing her to apply for your place and Charlotte said she “had a good mind to go after that“— I warn you before hand that I would rather not be responsible for placing Charlotte in ‘the bosom of any quiet family’ I am interested in; because were you to come to me officially for her character, I should officially give her and “feel it my duty“ to give her a character for the usual servant virtues honesty sobriety and activity— But outside of that broad moral line there is much to be said which would not be to her advantage—
What pens you do keepPresumably JWC wrote the note in Isabella’s house.— Mercy of Heaven
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 24 June. MS: NLS 517.21. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got all yr Notes, and duly both the Books; Probably John A. Carlyle’s copies of Ray’s Compleat History and Henderson’s History of the Rebellion (see TC to JAC, 2 June , and 7 June) and another unidentified book. TC cited Henderson in Frederick; see Works 16:80. for which many thanks. I am not fallen worse than usual, nor has anything sinister occurred to cause my silence,—except that (unexpectedly altogether, for I thot the vile thing was done) I have got into such a mess of incurable Proofsheets as beats all example hitherto; and am weltering over head and ears for two weeks past, the most disgusted, bedarkened and uncomfortable of men! I expected to get the essential heart of the ugly thing finished today,—and, alas, I merely puddled deeper and deeper into it, and cd do nothing at all! I at least write this Note to tell you so before going to bed.

I think it is very certain there has not for hundreds of years an English Literary man got into so insoluble, unfortunate, and in fact heart-breaking subject:—nevertheless I count on still doing it;—and even that it will prove worth the doing (by and by when better knowledge comes), if I can do it well. In the meanwhile, “genius” (if poor I have any genius) “means transcendt capacity of taking trouble,”TC’s own phrase, used in vol. 1, bk. 4 of Frederick; see Works 12:339.—that, alas, and almost that only! I find it so, to my sorrow.

We have a charming climate here just now; sun of the brightest, wind of the clearest, with due cooling admixture of rain (thundery wet, till 5 p.m. this day, for example). I dine now at 3; sleep an hour; ride then till 7½, before tea. I am certainly not worse than last year; I am rather better certainly. I have mounted an awning (stretched between the walls, where the water-barrel stands),For TC working near the water barrel, see 32:187 TC to JWC, 15 July 1857
. whh does better than th[e te]ntLetters obscured by a small tear on the surface of the paper. of former years;For TC’s awning in 1857, see 32:176 TC to JWC, 9 July 1857
, and 182 TC to JWC, 13 July 1857
I sit there all day, if there is sun in the sky,—and take well with it, or fancy I do.

Poor Neuberg has got spasms in the breast,—means weakness, not yet derangt, in the heart, say the Doctors; and give him iron &c. He is somewhat better;—means for Langen Schwalbach next week; whh, I too expect, may do him more good than the iron.German spa village (now Bad Schwalbach), about 28 mi. (45 km.) W of Frankfurt. Langen Schwalbach was known both for its chalybeate springs and for its bracing air; see Edwin Lee, The Principal Baths of Germany, France, and Switzerland (1863) 32–46.

figure.p: “The Great Fire in Southwark: Scene at Cotton’s Wharf on Sunday Morning at Two o’Clock ”
Illustrated London News, 29 June 1861

ps.p:
(poor Mrs Johnston of Grange:Mary Johnston (1785–1861) d. 22 May; her husband, William Johnston, d. 1835; see 3:379 JBW to TC, 2 Sept. 1825
, 8:214 TC to WG, 25 Sept. 1835
, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 257. alas, alas, she too is gone from us!Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Mantell, 24 June: “Mrs Carlyle is much as usual—thrown into a state of mind by the authentic revelation that her drawing room paper wh you may re-collect is green contains no end of ARSENIC. The doctor analysed it when he was here—so it is to be stripped off at once—” (MS: Mantell). For the wallpaper, see 33:17 TC to JAC, 11 Aug. 1857
, 174 TC to JN, 2 Feb. 1858
, and 235 TC to EC, 9 Aug. 1858

div3.sourceNote:
TC-Editor of the Times,
[EOT] 30 June . Pbd: Times, 2 July 1861 ; Spectator, 6 July 1861 ; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:177–78.
div3.head:
TC
TO THE EDITOR OF THE TIMES

docBody.p: Sir,— There is a great deal of public sympathy, and of deeper sort than usual, awake at present on the subject of Inspector Braidwood.James Braidwood’s funeral, 29 June, was reported in the Times, 1 July : “The hour fixed for the departure of the cortège was 3 o’clock, but long before that time every avenue leading to Watling-street was blocked by a dense and almost impenetrable crowd, while, the entire length of the route along which it was to pass, every path was thronged, and the windows and even the roofs of the houses crowded. Before 3 nearly all the shops were shut up and at some houses … the shutters were closed and the blinds drawn. Every bell from the city churches rang out a funeral peal.” The Illustrated London News, 29 June , pbd. a long description of the fire and details of Braidwood’s death, recovery of his body, and the inquest; for the accompanying portrait of Braidwood, see opp above . It is a beautiful emotion, and apparently a perfectly just one, and well bestowed. Judging by whatever light one gets, Braidwood seems to have been a man of singular worth in his department, and otherwise; such a servant as the public seldom has. Thoroughly skilled in his function, nobly valiant in it, and faithful to it—faithful to the death. In rude, modest form, actually a kind of hero, who has perished in serving us!

figure.p: “The Late Mr. Braidwood, Superintendant of the London Fire Engine Establishment”
Illustrated London News, 29 June 1861

docBody.p: Probably his sorrowing family is not left in wealthy circumstances.Mary Ann Jane (1807–71), widow of J. B. Jackson, m. Braidwood 1838; they had six children: Ellen (b. ca. 1840), Fanny (b. ca. 1841), Janet (b. ca. 1843), James (b. ca. 1845), Lithgow (b. ca. 1848), and Francis (b. ca. 1850); Braidwood also supported his four stepchildren and his two unmarried sisters. Most certainly it is pity when a generous emotion, in many men, or in any man, has to die out futile, and leave no action behind it. The question, therefore, suggests itself,—Should not there be a “Braidwood Testimonial,”Lord Mayor William Cubitt led a committee to organize a subscription on behalf of Braidwood’s family. The Times, 15 July , reported the resolution taken at a meeting held at Mansion House, 4 July: “that in consideration of the high character of the late James Braidwood … it is expedient and proper that the regret manifested by all classes should find expression by means of a public subscription, to be applied to the benefit of his six children and two sisters, who have thus been deprived of his protection and support.” But the Times reported, 10 Aug.: “It was admitted by the committee generally that the endeavour to raise a fund for the object in question had been rendered comparatively abortive, and indeed unnecessary, in consequence of the public announcement that the fire-offices had voted 7000l. to the widow and family of the deceased, and that his personal property had been sworn by the executors in proving the will as under 5000l. It has, therefore, become desirable to proceed no further in the business.” the proper parties undertaking it, in a modest, serious manner, the public silently testifying (to such extent, at least) what worth its emotion has?

I venture to throw out this hint, and, if it be acted on, will, with great
satisfaction, give my mite among other people; but must, for good reasons, say further, that this [is]Word omitted. all I can do in the matter (of which, indeed, I know nothing but what everybody knows, and a great deal less than every reader of the newspapers knows); and that, in particular, I cannot answer any letters on the subject, should such happen to be sent me.

closer.salute: In haste, I remain, Sir, your obedient servant,

docBody.name: T. CARLYLE.
docBody.note: The Illustrated London News reported, 6 July: “It is something to hear the voice of Thomas Carlyle. His utterances are few and far between, but when speech comes from him it has a trumpet sound. Great Tom of Chelsea has just boomed forth a short, powerful letter to the Times advocating a testimonial to the lamented Braidwood. The Lord Mayor has kindly bestirred himself in the matter, and we may anticipate a noble subscription and a worthy monument to the gallant man who fell in the discharge of his duty. ‘True Thomas of Cheyne Walk’ was, doubtless, ignorant of the fact that the original suggestion for a ‘Braidwood memorial’ appeared two days after the great fire in a leading article of the Daily Telegraph newspaper; but Mr. Carlyle’s advocacy of a worthy object is not the less valuable for having been anticipated.”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [3 July]. MS: NLS 607.577A. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: 3 July 1861. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:73–76. Though dated “Tueday,“ this letter was written and posted Wed., 3 July, after Matilda had left for St. George’s Hospital. JWC spent Tues., 2 July, “rushing about“ arranging Matilda’s admission to the hospital; see JWC to MCA, [18 July].
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Decidedly, dearest Mary I am in a run of bad luck. and entertaining for a moment any idea of a pleasure seems to be the signal with me for some misfortune to plunge down!—

The longer I thought of it, the more it seemed to me fair and feasible that since Mr C was minded to go nowhere this summer; I should go for two or three weeks by myself where I had been so unreasonably disappointed of going last August.JWC intended visiting Mary Russell and others in Scotland in Aug. 1860, but canceled her plans after misunderstanding TC’s intentions about returning home from Thurso; see 36:200JWC to MR, 25 Aug. 1860. Mr C himself had said I might; “if I thought it would be useful to me;“ and there could be no question about its being useful to me, to have a breath of Scotch air and a glimpse of dear scotch faces! So, when I had read your cordial letter I felt my purpose strong to carry itself out; and only delayed answering till I had seen the baking-difficulty overcome and could say positively that I would come as soon as you pleased after your visitor had departed— Two visitors at one time is too much happiness (I think) for any not overstrong mistress of a house, who gives herself so much trouble as you do to make every thing comfortable and pleasant about one!

And in the meantime here is what has befallen—. My nice trustworthy cook,Matilda, who had begun work early in June. who inspired me with the confidence to leave Mr C; being certain, I thought, to keep him all right, and the house all right, and the young girlMargaret Sullivan. all right in my absence, this treasure of a cook, my Dear, who was to be the comfort of my remaining years, and nurse me in my last illness, (to such
wild flights had my imagination gone!) turns out to have come into my service with a frightful neglected rupture! what the Drs call ‘strangulated Hernia’—making her life (My DrAlfred Barnes. says) “not safe for a day“!! He could do nothing with it, he said—she must go to St George’s HospitalSt. George’s Hospital, Hyde Park Corner; Matilda was admitted immediately to the hospital; see JWC to MCA, [18 July]. and what was possible to do for her would be done there. But I have no hope that the woman will ever be fit for service again. And what she could mean in going into a new service with such a complaint I am at a loss to conceive. And I am also dreadfully at a loss what I am to do with her! She is such a good creature and hasn’t a relation in the world to depend upon. If the Drs take her as an in-patient of course it would settle the question of her leaving here—but if they don’t—! Oh my gracious! how unlucky it is!— In any case I see no chance for me now of getting to you! Unless indeed she could be cured sufficiently to go on at service— I shall know more about it when she comes back from the Hospital —or when I have spoken with one of the Surgeons there. whom I knowPossibly Henry Bence Jones (1813–73; ODNB), physician, who had been doctor to JWC’s cousin John Welsh 1858–59; see 33:254JWC to TC, 27 June 1858. He worked at St. George’s Hospital 1846–62.—

But unless the case is much less grave than Mr Barnes seemed to consider it—we shall be all at sea again—and the best arrangement I can think of for the moment would be to put my new housemaid into the kitchen, for which she is better suited than for her present place only that she would have the cooking all to learn!!! and to take another nice girl I know of, for housemaid.Possibly Maria Chamberlayne; see TC to JAC, 20 July. But fancy the weeks and months it will take to get even that most feasible scheme to work right—and all the while I must be standing between Mr C and new bother—and looking after these girls that they may be kept in good ways! I declare I could take a good cry. or do a little good swearing! I will stop now till the poor woman comes back from the Hospital—and then tell you the news she brings—
no Matilda come yet, and I must take the letters myself now to the post office having nobody to send later
I will write soon

closer.salute: Your much bedeviled but always loving

docBody.name: J Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 [8] July. Addr: 67. Hanover Street / Edinburgh. PM: London, 8 July 1861. MS: NLS 525.78. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have got out of my Proofsheets again,—one always gets out by struggling diligently!—and write you a rapid word to say so. There has been, and it came quite unexpectedly, four ofThus in MS. five weeks of it; the sorrowfullest of all the quagmires (or almost the sorrowfullest) I had yet plumped into,—oh me, oh me, there is no end of them, till the work itself end! But I am out for this bout; and take to writing at Vol IV tomorrow; Vol III now entirely off my hands, nothing but 2 hours or so (more of sport than of labour, on the final revises) now likely to be required of me there. It is abt 740 pages long,—too many by 80 or 100;—but it is far better than iThus in MS. once hoped it could ever be made: adieu to it, forever and a day. Before this time twelvemonth,—surely before, if I be spared in prest health, I shall have the unutterable burden tumbled clear off me; and be once more a man like other men!—

We have excellt weather here; I do not remember a finer summer than this hitherto. My place is (as at present) sub divo [in the open air];For TC’s arrangement in the garden, see TC to JAC, 24 June. far wholesomer, far pleasanter:—but you shd have seen me yesterday, when the thunder-deluge came on me; and the Water-Butt began spewing and overflowing, upon my paper-clippings, portable library, &c &c, in the very heat of the game!— — I am somehow sorry you did not get a longer spell of Annandale in the fine Summer. But Edinr too, I suppose, is pleasant under such skies.

Poor Neuberg came yesterday; drove me about in his poney-vehicle, the rain & the hurlyburly being both done.Cf. Macbeth 1.1. He is still weak and poorly; biliously, this week: “poverty of blood“Meaning anemia. the Doctors call it;—on Thursday he goes off to the Taunus Country,Hills N and W of Frankfurt: “No part of the world contains—within so small a space—so many valuable medicinal springs, differing in their nature. … They rise … at or near the foot of the Taunus range, and are consequently but a short distance from each other“ (Edwin Lee, The Principal Baths of Germany, France, and Switzerland [1863] 2). to Frankfurt first of all, to try the waters there. He has been of no or of little help to me this long time; and indeed has now plenty of Translatn work ahead of his own.— — Jane had got a pair of ofRepeated in MS. really promising
servants; and we hoped all wd do well,—when, behold, the Cook (so-called, a highly useful respectable elderly woman) owns to a “tumour“ whh she has had for some months, whh is growing worse; and, in fine, whh turns out to be “strangulated hernia“ in a very bad form, when Barnes examines it: so that she is now, for some days back, in St George’s Hospital, we know not yet with what outlook! The younger lass is, luckily, a very serviceable honest creature. But all this postpones Jane’s Scotch expeditn, or pushes it altogether into the vague. We are rather agreeing with the summer, both of us; I sometimes (but hardly dare, since it may be only bile) think myself sensibly better than last year this time. But I need not continue in such strain. Write you, whenr you can. Your affecte Brr T. CarlyleGeorge Henry Lewes brought the novelist Anthony Trollope to Cheyne Row for tea, 4 July; Trollope wrote to Lewes, 3 July: “I cannot resist the triple temptation you offer me, & will be with you tomorrow. … I confess I should very much like to meet Carlyle, but imagine he is a man who does not like being entered in upon by every body … on you however be the responsibility if in such a matter you do what you should not“ (The Letters of Anthony Trollope, ed. N. John Hall [Stanford, 1983] 1:154). Lewes reported in a letter, 5 July, to Trollope’s brother, Thomas Adolphus Trollope: “Carlyle had read, and agreed with the West Indian book, and the two got on very well together; both Carlyle and Mrs. Carlyle liking Anthony“ (Eliot, Letters 8:287). In The West Indies and the Spanish Main (1859), Trollope criticized the misguided attitudes of Victorian philanthropy toward W. Indian Negroes. Without supporting slavery, he argued that the Negroes were lazy and that they should be compelled to work with the same discipline as the British laboring classes.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, [8 July]. Addr: Elm Cottage, Old-Brompton Road / Brompton. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. The date of 8 July, written in another hand on the envelope, is confirmed by the heavy rain of 7 July; “[1860],“ also written on the envelope, is incorrect; 8 July was a Mon. in 1861.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—I was very sorry the rain caught you, and that I had not even given you an umbrella!

Pick that Book up for me (No 475, 1/6)Possibly a book from Williams and Norgate’s catalog (see 32:166TC to HL, 11 June 1857) or from John Stenson, secondhand-book seller (see 33:95TC to HL, 2 Oct. 1857); otherwise unidentified. tomorrow; & please call at Robson’s, same day, & ask him, if he wishes you to copy a certain little Piece,—with speed. Yrs always T.C. (Monday, in haste)!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 9 July. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 9 July 1861. MS: Univ. of Texas. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I am sorry to interfere in the hurries of yr preparatn. But the pages (where I have marked in pencil) to two or three pi[e]ces in that excellt illuminative AbstractNeuberg replied, 10 July: “My notes, I am sorry to say, yield but one of these page-references you require; and I am much afraid I shall not be able to get to the Museum to-day, to find them for you. / However, you have (or had) a list of the Carteret Papers, with the Press-numbers of the MSS.; so that Mr Larkin could easily do this job for you.“ Neuberg had sent TC abstracts from the Carteret Papers, 9 June 1860; see 36:152TC to JN, 25 July 1860. will be useful at this moment.TC was beginning work on bk. 1 of vol. 4 of Frederick (see TC to JAC, 20 July); it contained many references to John Carteret (1690–1763; ODNB), 2d Earl Granville, politician and diplomat.— Yrs with hearty Gluck auf dem Weg [good fortune to your journey]
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [16 July]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 16 July 1861. MS: NLS 607.577B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:76–78.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Mr Dunbar’s bookProbably William Burnside Dunbar, From London to Nice: A Journey through France and Winter in the Sunny South (Edinburgh, 1861). was from you; was it not? I used to be able to swear to your handwriting; but latterly one or two people have taken to writing exactly like you. and I need the postmark to verify the handwriting; and the postmark was illegible on that book-parcel. Whether from you or not I am glad of the little book which I am sure I shall read with pleasure. I liked that mild gentlemanly man so much!William Burnside Dunbar (1815–68), minister at Glencairn 1855–64; Glencairn Church, 2 mi. (3 km.) SE of Moniaive which is about 7 mi. (11 km.) SW of Thornhill. JWC had probably met him on her visit to Thornhill, 15–27 Sept. 1858, or possibly at Lann Hall, Tynron (3½ mi. [5.5 km.] NE of Moniaive), 28 Aug.–15 Sept. 1858 (see vol. 34). But I am still as far off as when I last wrote from sitting down quietly to read a pleasant book! Every thing is at sixes and sevens still! My Treasure of a servant who was to “sooth my declining years,“Cf. Marianne Breton, The Wife of Fitzalice, and the Caledonian Siren (1817) 122, and Ellen Pickering, The Quiet Husband (1840) 279. and enable me to go to Scotland this year, is still lying in St Georges Hospital
certain to lie there “for some months“ and not certain to be fit for service even of the mildest form, when the months are over! Mr TaitumThomas Tatum (1802–79), surgeon and lecturer on surgery at St. George’s Hospital; his “A Case of Hernia, Strangulated within the Abdomen, Successfully Operated On“ was pbd. in the Lancet (1858). the Head Surgeon found immediately that she had got ulceration of the spine, and the rupture proceeded from that— He says she “may get over it; but it will be a tedious affair“— I dont think that even if she were cured nominally I should like to have her for kitchen servant again, I should live in perpetual terror of her hurting herself at every turn! Meanwhile I have been puddling on with my old going-out-to-cook-womanMrs. Newnham. coming in daily, to cook the dinner, and teach the Welch Housemaid;Margaret Sullivan; “Irish in reality; a little, black, busy creature, who did very well for some time; but, &c. &c. (some mysterious love-affair, I think)—and went to New Zealand out of sight“ (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:77). She presumably joined her sister Ellen in New Zealand; see JWC to JGCO, 7 May. There were some problems by late July, as Geraldine Jewsbury wrote to Walter Mantell, 25 July: “I am sorry to say that Margaret is not so satisfactory“; she had begun to tell lies, and Jewsbury continued: “tho poor child how shd she have behaved better at that horrid old woman’s [Rebecca Pullen]!. . . but the fact is Margaret is deceitful I fear—with all her apparent innocence. Still she is honest & a good thoroughly clean & industrious servant“ (MS: Mantell). whom I have decided to make kitchen woman; getting another girl for housemaid: a Safe housemaid is so much easier to get here, than a Cook who doesn’t drink, nor steal nor take the house to herself! This Welch girl has, I think, more the shaping of a good cook than of a housemaid. Not being good at needlework and utterly incapable of reading the titles on Mr C’s Books—so that she cant bring him a book when he wants it— The girl I am gettingProbably Maria Chamberlayne; see TC to JAC, 20 July. is more accomplished! whatever else!

The present state of affairs however is wretched; for Mr C, being a man, cannot understand to exact the least bit less attendance, when we are reduced to one servant again, that he had accustomed himself to exact from the two. so I have all the valeting and needle-womaning, and running up and down to the study for books &c &c &c to do myself—besides having to superintend the Welch girl and to go to St Georges (two miles off) almost every day in my life.“The Friends of the Patients are allowed to visit them between the hours of Three and Four in the afternoon, Sundays and Wednesdays excepted.“ Rev. Albert Alston, How Shall I Get into an Hospital? A Guide for Patients (1861) 35. to keep up the heart of poor Matilda who lying there with two issuesTwo incisions made to drain blood or other matter from her body. in her back, and nobody but myself coming after her, and her outlooks of the darkest; naturally needs any cheering that I can take her!

Mercifully the plentiful rain keeps things cooler and fresher here than is usual in summer—and I am nothing like so sick and nervous as I was last year
at this time. So I am more able to bear what is laid on me—to bear amongst the rest the heavy disappointment of having to give up my visit to you—and stay here at my post which is a rather bothering one—
God bless you— It does me good anyhow to think that if I could have gone the kind Dr and you would have been so kind to me!
docBody.name: J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [18 July]. Longhand copy: NLS Acc. 7864; MS: NLS Acc. 7864 inc. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by events described in JWC to MR, [16 July]. Where MS is incomplete, text is from longhand copy.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p: Every day since I received your kind little note I have been aiming at writing to you; nay, I was aiming at writing to you before receiving it. But what I had to say was very different before and after. ‘Before’; I had to tell you the hopes and purposes I was entertaining of making a short flight to Dumfriesshire, to which the prospect of fulfilling my engagement of last year, and having a long hearty talk with you at the Gill was no inconsiderable part of the attraction. While ‘after’—alas! ‘the spirit of my dream’Cf. Byron, “The Dream.“ had undergone a dismal change, and there only remained to tell you of the hopes and purposes I had entertained, and how there had been an extinguisher clapt on them in the most “promiscuous“ manner!

The same misluck however, which had so transformed my prospects, has given me so much more than usual to do and think of, that this is literally the first leisure hour I have had for answering your letter since I received it! Mr C told me [he]Word omitted. had written to you that I might perhaps go to Scotland by myself this summer; I don’t know whether he told you the circumstances which had made the idea feasible, viz: that in room of Charlotte, who had again gone away in disgrace, and whom I could not have trusted him to the cares of—seeing that she was become much more thoughtless and needed looking after much more than when I first took her, a child of sixteen, four years ago. In room of Charlotte, we had got an elderly [cook?]Word omitted. who was so up to the management of a house and gave one such a delightful impression of trustworthiness, and kindliness, that both he and I felt every thing would go on the same behind my back as when I was here. She had not strength for hard work
this woman; but with an active willing Welsh Papist (!) to help her, (age nineteen) it was trustworthiness, and management more than hard work, that were required of her.

I thought at last we hadMS starts here. a prospect of a comfortable establishment, for years to come! the two new servants expressed themselves so pleased with their place, and got on so nicely together! And this had lasted just one month; and I had just written to Mrs Russell that I would fix a time for being at Thornhill, so soon as the new cook had learnt under my superintendence to make the bread to Mr C’s mind; when the Welch housemaid said to me one day: “If you please Mam Matilda has got such a lump on her side!— She showed it me but said I was on no account to tell you about it, for fear of its worritting you; but I think Mam you should know.“— “Of course I should!“— The next time Matilda came up, I asked what was this about a lump on her side?— “Not on her side—if she might use the liberty to name it, the lump was on her groin.“ She showed it me—as large as your two hands—thro’ all her clothes! and as hard as stone!— Frightened to death, I sent off immediately for my own Dr, He came, and examined her, and told me she had got a rupture which had become thro’ long neglect a most alarming affair—that I must get her into St George’s Hospital the following Wednesday (Wednesday is the one admission day in the week)“A Letter of recommendation is necessary for In-Patients, and must be delivered on Wednesday morning by half-past eleven o’clock, and none will be received after twelve“ (Rev. Albert Alston, How Shall I Get into an Hospital? [1861] 34). and by no means miss that Wednesday, for her life wasn’t safe for a day!!—all next day (Tuesday) I was rushing about, like a Maniac trying to get an order for St George’s—at last Lady Ashburton, in the absence of her Husband, who is a governor, but had his orders nobody knew where—wrote a line to the Hospital to admit the woman;“Before the Patient can be admitted to the Hospital, he or she must attend with a Paper, duly signed by a Governor, and a House-holder“ (Alston 30). and I was in agony till the last moment lest she should be refused on account of the informality. But it was all right. she was at once consigned to a bed, and if she is ever able to leave it poor soul, it will not they tell me be “for months“! Every day since but one, I have been back and forward to the Hospital which is two miles off, And then her place here to be supplied by myself in the mean time, and then Mr C to be kept from feeling any difference—menMS ends here. never understanding that any difference for the worse in their comforts is excusable under any circumstances! All that complicated with a great dinner party at Bath house last night has kept me in a turmoil. And now there is not the least chance of my getting away—unless Mr C changes his purpose to spend the whole summer and autumn under a sheet, at the side of the water barrel!
The surgeons at the Hospital find that Matildas malady is ulceration of the Spine—the rupture being merely part of the spinal complaint. They have put two issues in her back, and “if she do get over it, it will be a very tedious affair“— To wait for her in this state of things is out of the question. And the best I can see to do is to have my Welch girl trained to be Cook and get a fresh housemaid—a thing much easier to get tolerably good than a cook is. I might have a hundred Cooks before I lighted on one to be trusted!
With a girl under process of training, and a stranger girl coming, who may also perhaps, need training (God knows) you may judge what power I shall have to get away after my own pleasure!

I could sit down and take a good cry about it! I mean about the whole thing! the poor woman so good! and promising to be such a comfort! laid down so suddenly on that hospital bed! a new face and new ways to be made acquaintance with!

New Jeremiads from Mr C over the “a-bo-minable condition servants“ to be listened to! And no dear old Dumfriesshire, nor dear old Dumfriesshire faces to be seen this year either! Oh yes I could cry, if it would make me the least bit happier—but it wouldn’t! The best thing to do for the moment is to go to bed and try and get a better sleep than I have had for some nights back. Good night dear; I send the kiss, I had ready for you, by post since no better may be. Kind regards to your husband and all of them.
docBody.name: Jane W. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 July. MS: NLS 525.79. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:246.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I got yr Letter, and preceding it the Spectator, the Dr Irving Pieces (whh are very well worth reading, Laing’s part intelligently done, and yours):Presumably John A. Carlyle had sent TC his edition of David Irving’s The History of Scotish Poetry (see TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1860), pbd. June. thanks to you for all those kind bits of remembrance. I am sitting here under my Awning; and will use a few minutes that I have of interval to answer with a word. This Letter of Jenny’sJanet Hanning. came this morning; and is a new incitement.

I wish you wd write to Jenny poor little soul; and send her some sufficient news of the Annandale affairs she is interested in. She turns the best face out in regard to Canada & her little Household; and appears really to be struggling on, like the rest of us, on fairly reasonable terms. I will send the Hoddam
AntiquityUnexplained but probably connected to John A. Carlyle’s query, 16 July: “Did you keep the receipt of the old Hoddam schoolmaster?“ Probably John Orr, their father’s schoolmaster; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 23–24. too; I well remembered it last time I wrote; but had laid it so securely up, there was then no finding of it; but it has now come to light again, & I know its whereabout.— Another little bit of business, let me not forget in my hurry: concerning Edinr biscuits! It strikes me sometimes there were excellt biscuits procurable somewhere near Hanover Street:John A. Carlyle lived in Hanover St. is that so, and do I only dream it? If that is so, then pray get me a little bag of them, so many as Aitken can convenient stow into his luggages;Their nephew James Aitken was on holiday in Scotland; John A. Carlyle wrote, 16 July: “I expect young James Aitken to come here next Saturday & stay with me till the monday evening—on his way back to London“ and then, 23 July: “James Aitken … started last night for London. Biscuits & a book for you he took with him & will probably deliver them himself tomorrow or following night.“ let him come over hither with them; and they will be a real something to me. My supper is a tumbler of hot milk abt midnight (stands simmering on a very old Craigenputtock or even Haddington lamp, till I am ready for it);—and for biscuit to it, there is nothing but sandy rubbish, whh a horse wd reject. I have had in fact to give it up altogether, and take a crumb of bread if anything. Verb. sap. sat. [Verbum sapienti satis est: a word is sufficient for a wise person].

Robson gets on very slowly; has still above 40 pages of vol III in revise. Vol IV is an awful gachis [mess]; Book I of it just now on hand, and will take a great deal of work. Indeed the whole thing will be one of the toughest in the world; such barking and hammering, and splitting & sorting, till the slag is, in some measure, clear knocked out of it, and a presentable bit of metal (if possible) results! Alas, and my poor old limbs are nothing like so equal to that work as they once were. A fact that; but an irremediable one. Seldom was a poor man’s heart so near broken by utter weariness, disgust and long-continued despair over an undoable job;—the only point is, said heart must not break altogether, but finish if it can! I consider myself to be perceptibly better in health than this time twelvemonth; sleep in particr is nothing like such a “horror“ of a business (really the only thing that quite cows me down) as it then was. I sit under my Canvas here, all days not rainy; a certain Builder too has fallen bankrupt over in Oakley StreetGeorge Todd; see TC to JAC, 7 June. (one can hardly help thanking Heaven), and there is a quiet as of Elysium in the mornings for a poor wretch seeking rest! I design to stay here; I know not where I cd be so well. Servants are reinstated again; a new one got from Hampshire (likely yg lassMaria Chamberlayne.) instead of the old one in inWord repeated on turn of page. Hospital, is just come. The “season“ seems to be nearly
ending;—meinetwegen [on my account]; the nice weather will continue, and the tumults will in good part go. I have only dined twice;TC had dined with the Ashburtons 17 July. Walter White, another guest, recorded in his journal, 19 July: “To Lord Ashburton’s soirée at 9:30. The house and paintings more interesting than the curiosities collected. The presence of ladies imparts a charm. … Had a long talk with Thomas Carlyle, concerning his travels in Bohemia, his dislike of the Czechs, and the way in which a Czechist landlord cheated him, because the bargain for a wagon had not been put into writing. … He said a good walk and book might be made out of Luther’s land and special haunts; that the Wartburg is one of the most curious old castles he ever saw. I said I had often wished that he had taken up Luther to write about instead of the Great Frederick. He thought that enough had been written about Dr. Martin Luther“ (Walter White, The Journals of Walter White [1898] 172–73). and won’t again. Jane too is tolerably well. Adieu dear Brother. Yrs ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-RCT, 24 July. Pbd: Richard Chenevix Trench, Archbishop. Letters and Memorials, ed. [Maria Trench] (1888) 1:333–34. Richard Chenevix Trench (1807–86; ODNB), clergyman and writer, dean of Westminster from 1856, known to TC since the 1840s; see TC to JWC, 17 July 1844.
div3.head: TC TO RICHARD CHENEVIX TRENCH

docBody.p: Permit me to thank you very much for that charming bit of “Diary,“Melesina Trench, Journal Kept During a Visit to Germany in 1799, 1800, ed. [Richard C. Trench] (privately printed, 1861). which you have been so kind as to distinguish me by sending. I would not answer till I had read it faithfully; and now I can only say, “Would there were much more of it to read!“ It is seldom I have had two such hours as those spent upon it, in rather careful study of it, the other night. It is lucidly transparent as spring-water, faithful as a picture by the sun; a clear, pure, lucid English lady-soul,Melesina, b. ChevenixChenevix (1768–1827; ODNB), Irish diarist and letter writer; m., first, 1786, Col. Richard St. George (d. 1788), and m., second, 1803, Richard Trench (1774–1860). Richard Chenevix Trench, their 3d son, wrote in the preface to the Journal: “When last year the letters journals and other papers of my Mother came into my hands, I found among these a journal somewhat irregularly kept during a visit to Germany in 1799, 1800. This was not intended for publication, and only parts of it have received even that limited publicity which I am giving to them here. … The chief interest of the journal lies in the notices of persons with whom the writer was brought into more or less familiar contact“ (Trench, Journal v–vi). photographing for us in that manner. Perfectly credible in every part; all true,—as done on that kind of cardboard, with that kind of cullodium,Collodion or collodium, an early photographic process. etc., which can be allowed for, whenever necessary, as indeed it very seldom is, and very slightly anywhere.

The old Duchess of BrunswickPhilippina Charlotte (1716–1801), dowager duchess of Brunswick-Lüneburg, sister of Frederick the Great. Melesina Trench recorded, 31 Dec. 1799: “In the course of the evening I was presented to the Dowager Duchess, a wonderful woman of eighty-five. … She is sister to the great Frederick, whose pictures she resembles, has great sharpness in her eyes, and peculiar animation in her remarkably small features. Her address is pleasing, and there is a neatness, a purity, if I may so express myself, in her whole appearance, that one contemplates with satisfaction“ (Trench, Journal 16–17). (a stranger to me since 1786)Philippina Charlotte was mentioned only a few times in Frederick; presumably TC meant he was aware of her history preceding Frederick’s death in 1786. is beautiful like the vision of a spirit; Prince HenriHenry Frederick Louis (Heinrich Friedrich Ludwig) (1726–1802), prince of Prussia, brother of Frederick the Great, and one of his most able generals. (who did indeed glare strangely with the eyes of him, and croak with his voice, and was a very morbid, keen-edged, unhappy creature) amused me by turning up as “a minor fiend“Melesina Trench wrote, 30 Oct. 1800: “Prince Henry … looks like a little fiend of the minor class, not Belial, or any of the noblesse of hell. We conversed so little, I can speak but of his exterior. He appears as if he had just crept out of the embers, and was half-singed. … They say Rheinsberg, his country house, is a scene of extraordinary wickedness and depravity“ (Trench, Journal 86). (due to the cullodium in part):—indeed, I read throughout with a particular interest; and the Nelsons,Admiral Horatio Nelson (1758–1805; ODNB) and Lady Emma Hamilton (ca. 1765–1815; ODNB); Melesina Trench met them in Dresden and was unimpressed; she wrote, 3 Oct. 1800: “It is plain that Lord Nelson thinks of nothing but Lady Hamilton, who is totally occupied by the same object. … Lord Nelson is a little man, without any dignity. … Lady Hamilton takes possession of him, and he is a willing captive, the most submissive and devoted I have seen“ (Trench, Journal 75–76). the Elliot,Hugh Elliot (1752–1830; ODNB; see 36:100TC to LS, 19 April 1860, and 115TC to JN, 16 May 1860), diplomat and adventurer, British minister at Dresden. Melesina Trench wrote, 1 Sept. 1800: “Mr. Elliot remarkably amusing; no one has so much small talk, or parries better by a jest an opinion he disapproves, but does not choose to refute. He has so much wit, originality, and knowledge of the world, his caprice rather increases than diminishes his powers of pleasing“ (Trench, Journal 68). etc., etc., were not the only portions that I found extremely curious. Rivarol versus Gentz,Antoine de Rivarol (1753–1801), French writer, royalist journalist who fled to Berlin during the French Revolution, and Frederick von Gentz (1764–1832), German writer and diplomat. Melesina Trench wrote, 14 Dec. 1800: “Rivarol and [Gentz] are the two men of greatest talent I have seen in Berlin. I perceive this difference in their conversation, that Rivarol is perpetually on the watch to display himself, and catch the approbation of the circle, while Gentz is only anxious to do justice to his topic, and to lead their opinion. Rivarol labours, and sometimes successfully, to produce wit; Gentz lets fall from the plenitude of his ideas such superfluities as he cannot even miss“ (Trench, Journal 93). for example; a pair of eminent pamphleteers; windy, ambitious, barren fellows both;—who make so different an impression on the writer.
You have managed your filial part (allow me to say) in a pious and ingenuously modest manner. If you find any more such manuscripts, be strongly tempted to print more,—and let me share!

closer.salute: With many thanks and regards (kindest remembrances to Mrs. TrenchFrances Mary Trench (1809–90). included), I remain, your sincerely always,

docBody.name: T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LS], 24 July. MS: NLS 19.3.52.18. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:431–32.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: I was very sorry for myself I could not get out yesterday to lunch with the Infants & you:Lady Sandwich rented Harewood Lodge, on the edge of Windsor Forest, 24 mi. (38.5 km.) WSW of London, for later in the summer; see JWC to JC, [26 July]; she usually lived in London at 40 Grosvenor Sq., but was apparently staying elsewhere at the top of a hill, presumably with her younger grandchildren.—indeed, as was too evident, had I thought of it, there is no lunching possible for me at all; the rule being that I dine (what is called dining) here at 3 p.m; then go to sleep (deliberately); and am roused at 5 by the Horse stamping at the door, “Come & ride me, you lazy fellow, till half past 7, when you shall have tea!“ That is the fixed regulation, at this season; Water-Butt and Horse alike inflexible to their times. Nevertheless I hope to get out some evening, and see a glimpse of you before yr dinner.

Here is a little DiaryMelesina Trench’s Journal; see TC to RCT, 24 July. TC also sent the book to Sir George Sinclair, who thanked him, 3 Sept.; Sinclair had met many of the people described in the book: “The authoress seems to have been a very accomplished, amiable, witty & discerning person.“ whh, if you have not seen it, will amuse you for a Couple of Hours; at least I have found it very entertaining. It is by an Irish woman withal; and a very nice clear-eyed creature. I dare say you have seen Trench her Son. If you have seen the Diary too, or be bored by it, forgive me,—at least till you come back!

In spite of St. Swithin,Proverbially, if it rained on St. Swithin’s day (15 July), it was supposed to rain for the next forty days; John A. Carlyle wrote from Edinburgh, 16 July: “St Swithin passed without any rain.“ I hope this fine balmy air will be good to you at the top of your Hill. Don’t let me bother you to write; but, unless I appear in a day or two, rain permitting, a couple of words wd be very welcome. I passed yr door this evening; castle all standing, no Enemy in view.Untraced. TC meant that he rode past her London home and that all was well.
Good be with you, dear Lady. / Yours ever truly / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JC[JACA], [26 July]. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Dated by Matilda having been in hospital for three weeks; see JWC to MR, [3 July].
div3.head: JWC TO JAMES CARLYLE THE YOUNGER

docBody.p: “All right,“ my dear Cousin—that is to say all right as to the cousinship and the portrait; but, for the rest, all as wrong as can be—as to my outward and inward woman!

There is constant thunder in the air, to begin with; and that keeps me languid and sick. Then Mr C is in a crisis of proofsheets, such crisises occurring every two or three weeks and lasting two or three days; during which he tears about, wildly seeking scraps of paper, books, letters &c, which we are all accused of having “swept out of existence,“ and which are finally, after hours lost found under his eyes! Besides which, everything presented to him to eat at these times is “cold,“ or bad, or wrong somehow—and in the whole universe there is nothing that is not “rapidly going down to perdition“!Cf. Milton, Paradise Lost 1:47. awful times! and complicated just now by such a series of household mischances that I begin to turn my eyes towards suicide as the only possible outlet!

The girl who had cooked for Mr C these three years back, and “knew all his ways“—took to knowing another person’s ways equally well—viz: the Devils!— —and had to be put away. In her place I engaged an elderly widow, of the highest respectability, and experienced not only in cookery but in Life So capable indeed, and trustworthy, and sympathetic, that I felt Mr C could be safely intrusted to her cares, and was going myself to Dumfrieshire for two or three weeks, for “a change“Coterie speech; see 16:305JWC to TC, 22 July 1843.—which I am greatly in need of—when something came to light about this womans bodily State, which induced me to fetch my Dr to her—and he told me she must be sent immediately into St Georges Hospital as “her life was not safe for twelve hours“! There she has been these three weeks, in the hands of Surgeons, and is not likely to be off her back, for months to come— Meanwhile, till her fate was decided, I had in an elderly married women of the neighbourhood, to do the cooking, and teach the housemaid to do it, in case Matilda could never return. This woman has come about the house helping and teaching on occasion for these 14 years back. And Mr C was always pleased with whatever “Mrs Newman“ had cooked. Well! If this infatuated woman hasn’t gone and chosen the present moment, when I was so in need of her—to elope from her Husband and family!Her husband was Samuel Newnham; they had four children, the eldest (who m. 31 Aug.) was 18, the youngest seven years old. and go to service—where her Husband cannot find her!! Served
him right for having a diabolic temper, that was wearing the poor woman’s life out—but a very great calamity for me!

In these circumstances of course my project of going to Scotland on my own basis is clean snuffed out—and I must struggle on thro the warm weather here where I am, with what strength and spirits I have left which are little enough!— For here Mr C is resolved to remain under an awning in the back court, at least till September when we have an invitation to stay a while with old Lady Sandwich at a villa she has taken for two months in Windsor ForrestHarewood Lodge; see JWC to Lady SLS, 11 Sept.—

Keep the portrait for me safely till there is some opportunity of sending it safely— Mr C says Mr Grahame promised that pictureWilliam Graham d. Sept. 1860 and his belongings had been dispersed. repeatedly to him—and I am sure he promised it to me every time I was at Burnswark—
Kindest love to your Father and John and Jenny
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 29 [April or July 1861]. Addr: Steamboat Pier, Battersea-Bridge. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Dated 29 April or 29 July 1861 as these are the only dates applying to “Monday” within the timeframe of Larkin being next door to TC. [This letter, originally pbd. at CL 45:218, has been assigned a document date of 19 July 1861 and moved to its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Dear Larkin,—Be so good as call on Wedy: I shall perhaps have something for you to do.
The ferules,Ferrules: metal collars used on walking sticks (see 9:66TC to JOST, 3 Oct. 1836) or on pen nibs. I suppose, are ready? Don’t mind them any farther, if not.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG[AGI], 31 July. Pbd: Gilchrist 85–86.
div3.head: JWC TO ALEXANDER GILCHRIST

docBody.p: My dear Mr. Gilchrist: A thousand thanks for your kind thought about us!—tho’ fated to remain ‘a devout imagination’One source for “devout imagination“ is the response of Scots nobles to John Knox and other reformers’ plans to have the ministry, education, and the poor supported by proceeds from church funds, as set out in their Aug. 1650 “Book of Discipline“: “being resolved to keep what they had gotten, they voted his plan of partition to be ‘a devout imagination’—a well-meant, but visionary system, which could not possibly be carried into execution“ (George Lillie Craik, Pictorial History of England [1841] 567). TC used the phrase in “Hero as Priest“ and “Hero as King“; see Works 5:153 and 226. Both Carlyles used the phrase in letters, sometimes in quotation marks; see, for example, 28:248JWC to KS, 13 Aug. 1853. on your part! We are no longer on the Farm-House quest,—‘anything But!’ (as my maid says.) In fact Mr. Carlyle is become so enamoured of the retirement he enjoys—beside the water-barrel, under that ten shillingsworth of calico—that I don’t think a farm-house even within a stone cast of the sea, warranted free from cocks, dogs, and donkies, would tempt his imagination! And certainly on the principle of “letting well be’—‘letting sleeping Dogs lie’—and that sort of thing, for nothing in the world would I unsettle him, when he is so peaceable!— Just come and see; the next time you are up! For myself the back-court is by no means country. … I am speculating about going with Geraldine Jewsbury for three days to Ramsgate! I do so need a change?

Your house seems to be taken most perfect care of—but! Oh the noise of that stumping wooden leg!—it gets up so early too!“An old soldier acting as caretaker at number six“ (H. H. Gilchrist’s note in Gilchrist 86); otherwise unidentified.
My kind love to your wife when you see her or write to her I miss her dreadfully.

I went to see FechterCharles Albert Fechter (1822–79; ODNB), actor and playwright; b. in London to French émigré parents, Fechter lived in London and Paris as a child; his stage career had been mainly in Paris since 1840, but he moved to England, June 1860, to establish an acting career in English. He played the role of Hamlet (March to end Aug.) to great acclaim at the Princess’s Theatre in London; the Times reported, 22 March: “M. Fechter’s performance of Hamlet should unquestionably be seen by every one who takes interest in the higher departments of histrionic art. … Probably ‘Shakespeare’ never has been, or will be, played so well by a foreign artist as M. Fechter has played Hamlet, and it would be wholly incorrect to measure him by an English standard.“ the other night and found myself between Lewes and Miss Evans!George Henry Lewes and Marian Evans (George Eliot) lived together from 1855. Eliot wrote to Sara Sophia Hennell (1812–99; ODNB), 30 July: “We had a treat the other night [26 July] … we saw Fechter in Hamlet. His conception of the part is very nearly that indicated by the critical observations in Wilhelm Meister, and the result is deeply interesting—the naturalness and sensibility of the Wesen overcoming in most cases the defective intonation“ (Eliot, Letters 3:442).—by Destiny and not by my own Deserving. At least Destiny in the shape of Frederick Chapman who arranged the thing. Poor soul! there never was a more absurd miscalculation than her constituting herself an improper woman. She looks Propriety personified!Margaret Oliphant wrote to JWC, 7 May: “Speaking about propriety, will you tell me whether there is any possible way of excusing that poor Miss Evans for being as she is, and yet being the author of those wonderful books? … Was it temporary insanity or actual felo de se [self-destruction]?“ Oh so slow!
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 3 Aug. MS: NLS 517.22. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
I was very glad of your Letter this morning. The Dr sent me a flying word some good time ago,—I think, along with some excellt Biscuits whh yr James conveyed;See TC to JAC, 23 July.—and that is all I have had lately; or am likely to have from the Edinburgh fountain till I prime it again. One of the loneliest lives under
the sky’s compass is isRepeated in MS. mine at present. God send I were out of this prest section of it!

Jane went off this morning to Ramsgate (on the western Kent Coast abt 50 miles off); along with Miss Jewsbury; for a little breath of sea air,—of whh certainly my poor little woman had ample need. She was to have gone yesterday; but “had not slept a wink,“ and absolutely could not take the road. I dissuaded rather this morning still, weather being grey and showery, sleep still but a beggarly account: however, I was not listened to; nor indeed did I much wish it, thinking there might lie hope in the locomotion, in the &c &c. Miss J. is herself well; & serves as an assiduous companion. The place is said to be recommendable for quiet (if you avoid the very margin of the sea, and keep back upon the heights); the air must be of the freshest, and I know the sea for very good. I hope there will be some benefit; I have seen few more feckless looking adventures, nor more saddening to one’s spirits, than the driving off of that hackney-cab this morning. I will encourage her to go to Scotland, if this answer at all: but I hardly think she will go,—leaving her two maids here still in the half trained conditn,—tho’ they are good hopeful creatures too.

I did not hear definitely of John’s “going Southward“: if he can stay with you a while at Dumfries, it will be pleasant to think of in his wandering pilgrimage, whh often looks sad to me, it too, from this grim point of vision I now occupy.— My 3d volume (about 100 pages too long, but not ill otherwise) is off my hands: and now I stand face to face with vol 4th & last;—a sufficiently hideous and impossible object now that I am close to it. But that has all along been the way. Courage: it shall be possible.— I am not in worse but better health than last year. Adieu, dear Sister.— Nasty “revival“ puddles: faugh!Possibly referring to the religious revival in Dumfries, although it was at its height in Feb.: “It was chiefly brought about by the instrumentality of Mr. (now Rev.) Edward Payson Hammond, graduate of Williams College, Massachusetts, America. After holding a series of remarkable meetings at Annan, he visited Dumfries; and there, day and night, laboured as an evangelist from the 27th of January till the 15th of the following month, drawing such continuous crowds to hear him, and making such an impression upon them, as were truly marvellous. Though much of the effect produced seems to have been transient as ‘the morning cloud and the early dew,’ the religious public of the Burgh and vicinity cherish a grateful recollection of Mr. Hammond’s devoted services, and there is reason to believe that they have been of lasting benefit to many“ (William McDowell, History of the Burgh of Dumfries [Edinburgh, 1867] 878). Edward Payson Hammond (1831–1910), American evangelist; he completed his studies at the Free Church of Scotland Theological Seminary, Edinburgh, 1860–61, and was ordained as an evangelist, New York, 1863. He later conducted revival meetings at C. H. Spurgeon’s Metropolitan Tabernacle, Nov. 1868. Poor old Mary.Mary Grierson, b. Tait; TC sent Jean Aitken a check, 9 July: “Jean (for poor old Mary Tait) / £5..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). Jean wrote, 6 Aug.: “I went as usual tosee poor Old Mary Greer last night our own little Mary had been there several hours before me & had done good service in the way of holding the old woman up in bed (by sitting behind her) filling her foot jar with hot water &c &c. She seemed to have managed pretty well for Old Mary told me she was ‘a fell, wulling wean; & kent sense [capable, willing child; and knew sense].’ She was in as good case as I have seen her for some time past; but seems at best poor old soul to be heavy laden with pain & general weakness. … The greatest want last night was ‘some yen to pit up a petition.’ I tried to convince her that we did not need to speak loud—as God knew all our thoughts— ‘Nae but I like aye to hear a petition & nobody’s put yen up for twa days now.— An He’s promised to hear the prayer of the destitute.’“ God be with us all.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [4 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Gt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ramsgate, 4 Aug. 1861. MS: NLS 607.578. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:78–80.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.dateline: Mrs Stokes’s 21 Wellington Crescent East Cliff / Ramsgate Sunday [4 August 1861]
docBody.p: That is the address;—if there be anything to be addressed!! ‘Fortune favours the brave!’See Terence, Phormio line 203. Had we talked and thought and corresponded and investigated about Lodgings for a month before starting, I doubt if we could have made a better of it, than we have done! Certainly in point of situation there is no better in Ramsgate or in the world! Looking out over a pretty stripe of lawn and gravel walk on to the great boundless ocean! You could throw a stone from the sitting room window into the sea when the tide is up! Then there is not the vestiveThus in MS, for “vestige.“ of a Bug in our white dimity beds! For the rest, I cannot say it is noiseless!— Geraldine says her room looking on the sea is perfectly so; but I consider her no judge as she sleeps like a top! However the rooms looking on the sea cannot but be freer from noises than those to the back, looking on roofs of houses, stables streets &c—but the bedrooms to the back are much larger, and better aired. With no sensibilities except my own to listen to them with, I can get used, (I think) to the not extravagant amount of crowing, and barking, and slamming with the wind, and even to occasional cat-explosions on the opposite roofs! If I cant; I can exchange beds with Geraldine and there I can only have the noise of the sea (considerable!)—and the possibilities of occasional carriages passing. (I have heard NONE today—but it is Sunday) and “riffle tippling“Probably meaning people riffling their Venetian blinds in order to peek through. of Venetian Blinds!— With a great diminution of room however—and andRepeated on MS. alarming increase of glare.

The people of the house are civil and honest looking and slow—oh my!— But we are not come here Geraldine and I, to be in a hurry!— For us the place will answersJWC added “will“ but did not delete the “s“ in “answers.“ extremely well for a week that we had to engage it for, and the sea air and the ‘change’ will overbalance all the little disagreeables, as well as the “Chaarge“Coterie speech; see 27:206–7JWC to TC, 5 Aug. 1852. which is considerable!

If my advice were of any moment, I would strongly advise you to come one day during the week, and see the place under our auspices, and stay one night— I could sleep on the sofa in the Drawingroom. and you would not mind any trifling noises with the knowledge that it was only for one night. the mere journey and a sight of the sea and a bathe would do you good—
I am going to seek out the BainsAlexander and Frances Ann Bain. after church—

I feel much less tired today than I have done for weeks—months back!—tho’ I was awake half the night, first feeling for bugs which didn’t come! and then taking note of all the different sounds far and near—which DID come!
Margaret will do everything very well for you, if you will only tell her distinctly what you want— I mean not elaborately but in few plain words.
docBody.name: Jane W C

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 5 Aug. Addr: Mrs Stokes’s / 21. Wellington Crescent / East-Cliff / Ramsgate. PM: London, 5 Aug. 1861. MS: NLS 615.544. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My dear little Jeannie,—All is well, since you are doing well in yr new quarters yonder; I am right glad the bad beginning turned so well out as it has done hitherto. Seldom have I been part of a sadder-looking busss:—but I saw it to be necessary too; and expected the ride & the new objects, not to speak of the sea air, wd certainly (unless you were drowned by wet) have a good effect.

I have been the quietest of mortals since you went away; nothing but my own unpleasant thots, glooms, and Historical and other impossibilities to talk with. Nobody whatever has called,—except yesterday (near 3 p. m) Madame Venturi (is it? I mean Hawkes that was),Emilie Hawkes m. Carlo Venturi, 6 June; their travel is untraced. who summoned me in, not finding you, to bid her farewell. She was looking cheerful, handsome; talked pleasantly for a quarter of an hour, and then affectionately took her leave,—attended by my hearty wishes, poor little soul, if they cd do her any good!
“The TaylorsHenry and Theodosia Taylor lived during the summer in Bournemouth at The Roost, a house they had had built in 1860. had not brot them across,—because they went from Taylordomalmost next day: whh Taylor had not been aware of.“—— I had been writing all morning (in a kind of despair, whh came to little or nothing); I then dined, slept; rode round by the Regent’s Park (where braying of distant Opera “Music“ saluted me;Musical concerts were performed regularly on Sun. evenings in Regent’s Park; see 32:204TC to JWC, 26 July 1857. great crowds listening well in the distance from me): at night I read proofs, walked diligently; was in bed before 1 a. m;—nearly lost sleep (owing to a semi-pill, alas!) but did not; only awoke boiled, confused; and in such state have sat haggling over impossibilities (Historical in kind) all day till it is now close on 3.

The maids do perfectly well hitherto; ButtonMargaret Sullivan’s nickname. takes charge as if she had now become Lieutent-General; makes everything hot (to a degree) &c &c. Do not bother your little heart abt me; enjoy the sea-air or whatever is enjoyable, & get a little better, if it be in the power of Nature or Art to help you to that result. In particular I wd recommend plenty of Neat-Flys; never be sparing of them, nor inquire abt “chaawch“A variant of the more usual “chaarge“; see JWC to TC, [4 Aug.]. at all at all! a word daily wd be welcome. God bless you Dearest. T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [6 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ramsgate, 6 Aug. 1861. MS: NLS 607.579. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:81–3 inc. Quot: Ireland, JWC 268; Ashton 418.
div3.head:
TC
TO JWC

docBody.p: Very charming, doesn’t that look with sea in front as far as eye can reach?—And that seen (the East Cliff)JWC’s notepaper was headed with an engraving of Wellington Crescent, bordering the East Cliff promenade; see 200 above . you needn’t wish to ever see more of Ramsgate! It is made up of narrow, steep confused streets, like the worst parts of Brighton. The shops look nasty, the people nasty, the smells are nasty! (spoiled shrimps complicated with cess-pool!)— Only the East Cliff is clean, and genteel, and airy, and would be perfect as sea-quarters, if it weren’t for the noise! which is so extraordinary as to be almost laughable!

figure.p: “Wellington Crescent Ramsgate “ and JWC to TC, [6 August 1861] (detail)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
Along that still looking road or street between the Houses and the Gardens, are passing and repassing from early morning to late night Criers of Prawns, Shrimps Lollipops, things one never wanted, and will never want, of the most miscellaneous sort, and if that were all! But a Brass Band plays all thro our Breakfast, and repeats the performance often during the day, and
the Brass Band is succeeded by a Band of Ethiopians,“Ethiopians” were street musicians in black-face who sang American popular songs; see Henry Mayhew, London Labour and the London Poor (1861) 3:190–94. The first singer interviewed implied that many of the singers were local (i.e. Londoners), but noted that some were Irish or Scottish, and one was “a real black—an African” (Mayhew 3:191). Another interviewee said: “I’ve been to Brighton with them, and we did pretty well there in the fine season, making sure of 30s. a-week a man” (Mayhew 3:194). For Mayhew’s illustration of “Ethiopian Serenaders / [From a Photograph],” see above. and that again by a Band of female fiddlers!, and interspersed with these are individual Barrel organs individual Scotch Bagpipes, individual French Horns!—

figure.p: “Ethiopian Serenaders, [From a Photograph] ”
Henry Mayhew, London Labour and the London Poor (1861)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
Oh Lord it is—“most expensive!”—and the night noises were not to be estimated by the first night!— These are so many and frequent as to form a sort of mass of noise—perhaps easier to get some sleep thro’ than an individual nuisance of cock or dog— There are hundreds of cocks! and they get waked up at, say, one in the morning! by some outburst of drunken song or of cat-wailing! and never go to sleep again (these cocks) but for minutes!—and there are three Steeples clocks, that strike in succession—and there are doors and gates that slam—and dogs that bark occasionally—and a saw-mill—and a Mews and—and—in short, everything you could wish not to hear!—and I hear it all, and
am getting to sleep in hearing it!! the bed is so soft and clean! and the room so airy!—and then I think under every shock, so triumphantly; ‘crow away’—‘roar away’—‘bark away’—‘slam away’—you ‘cant disturb Mr C at Cheyne-Row’—that can’t you!—and the thought is so soothing I go off asleep—till next thing! I might try geraldines room but she has now got an adjoining Baby!— Yesterday we drove to BroadstairsBroadstairs, seaside resort, 2 mi. (3 km.) N of Ramsgate.—a quieter place but I saw no lodgings that were likely to be quiet—except one villa at six guineas a-week—already occupied!

I sleep about—in intervals of the Bands—on sofas—during the day—and am less sick than when I left home, and we get good enough food very well cooked—and I dont repent coming on the whole— Tho’ I hate being in Lodgings,—in strange places I saw the Bains, and saw Mrs GeorgeProbably Margaret Welsh, widow of JWC’s uncle George. before she left—The last lines were written in small characters and it was probably the end of the letter; no signature. Froude printed JWC to TC, [7 Aug.], as part of this letter, but two separate envelopes survive, confirming they were separate letters.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 6 Aug. Addr: Mrs Stokes’s / 21. Wellington Crescent, East Cliff, / Ramsgate. PM: London, 6 Aug. 1861. MS: NLS 615.545. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Three is actually struck; “dinner on the table, sir!“ Nothing but my salutation to poor Goody had I to say, at any rate. Salutatn, and request for news.— I continue, as in La Trappe;Site of the first Trappist monastery; see 6:432TC to JWC, 7 Sept. 1833. actually speaking no word to any being (except my Horse) since you went! Get on very ill too, my Enterprize more hideous if anything than it ever was. Stick to it; no other hope whatever.

Except this LetterUntraced. nothing for you; for me one begging Letter (from a blockhead of a CochraneJames Cochrane, John George Cochrane’s cousin; see 35:19TC to JCOC, 31 Jan. 1859. TC sent him a check: “12 Augt 1861 / To our Cochrane (Charity) / £5..0..0“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). unfit for helping again), and no other melody of sympathy from surrounding universe.

You are getting the best of weather. A Fly, a neat Fly, I recommend again aand again. “The chaawch“ is nothing; I will thrice-cheerfully liquidate the chāwchTC commonly used a line over a consonant or vowel to indicate that it was doubled.
Good be with you Dearest. Dinner need not cool. Yours ever / T. C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 7 Aug. Addr: Mrs Stokes’s / 21. Wellington Crescent, East Cliff / Ramsgate. PM: London, 7 Aug. 1861. MS: NLS 615.546. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks for yr pretty little sheet, as winding up to Breakfast in the bright morning. What picture you give me of the melodies of East-Cliff: I shd go altogether mad in the middle of them; I cannot enough praise you for enduring them, for dodging and ducking thro’;—and congratulate myself on my own almost miraculous state of silence here: thanks to Goody & the gods! It is really wonderful; and after dinner, when I enter my darkened cell, I feel (if I say nothing) what Drawingroom in WindsorWindsor Castle, a royal residence. is 1000th part such a room!

(N.b. Yesterday, however, a yellow messenger with OrganOrgan-grinders usually came from Italy and were seen as having light brown or yellow skin; see 28:38TC to JCA, 8 Feb. 1853, and 185TC to JWC, 8 July 1853. did burst out on me,—the first these 3 months,—and I had to go myself, and deal with people in the Upper Row, who were comforting the wretched caitiff & his Box of Woe. Fear not: I managed well enough; and got no damage at all,—except the total loss of my siesta, whh was, and is still rather sensible to me.)

In the evg just as Tea was ready, in came Woolner;Thomas Woolner. kept me noisily two hours from a big mass of Proofs there were, not far from done:—it was thus near 1 a. m. before I got quite finished; and near 2 before I was in bed; very sleepy, but very shivery too, and ticklish for missing. This night I will read the Fire worshippers (really a kind of Aurora-Borealis of almost genius in that poor Book; whh I think must be done by a Swedish Woman);Charles de H——, Life in the Land of the Fire Worshipper, ed. Fredrika Bremer, 2 vols. (1861). Although attrib. to various people, the author was most probably Carl Peter von Heidenstam (1792–1878), Swedish soldier and diplomat. Fredrika Bremer (1801–65), Swedish author and feminist; see 16:65JWC to HW, 27 Feb. 1843. In a letter (dated Athens, Nov. 1860) reproduced at the beginning of the book and addressed to Charles de H——, Bremer called the author “countryman“ twice. The author’s preface noted: “It was at the instigation of this distinguished lady that the following work was prepared for publication in England, and she has expressed so much more beautifully than the author could have done, the most noble objects which she believes may be advanced by all such truthful descriptions of Asiatic life.“ The book was reviewed by Jewsbury in the Athenaeum, 10 Aug.: “Persia is a region where persons might go from a love of adventure, but never from a mild desire to take a pleasant excursion. The odds against coming safely back again seem ominously heavy.“ She concluded: “It is not often we have read a more entertaining book; the story is as unlikely as possible, but the reader would be worse than ungrateful to complain of such a trifle.“—Fire-worshippers, I say; and will take my walk in good time. Vol iii is now, to last cobweb of it, gone, gone to all Eternity;—and 2 sheets of vol iv are done.

Sydney Herbert is dead;Sidney Herbert (1810–61; ODNB), 1st baron of Lea, politician; d. Wilton House, Wiltshire, 2 Aug. TC was acquainted with him for some years; see 23:66–67TC to JWC, 7 July 1848. did you hear? I was heartily sorry at the news, as Woolner gave it me. Oh dear, Oh dear!

Woolner wanted me to ride in by his bust of Julius HareWoolner’s marble bust of Julius Charles Hare (1795–1855; ODNB), author and clergyman, was commissioned by Trinity Coll., Cambridge, in 1860 but was not finished until 1863.
