Woolner’s studio was at Tudor Lodge, Albert St., Mornington Crescent, N London. some evg soon; whh I promised.— “Dinner!“ (consisting of brown soup, whh I must not let cool.
Dinner very good (brown soup & mutton collop):—all going on, indeed, perfectly well; be secure on that side; and ride comfortably along the shore on ass-back or in neat Fly.

Woolner is abt taking a big HouseWoolner wrote to Emily Tennyson, 5 Oct.: “You know that one of the dearest wishes of my soul was to get a house in town where I could also have my studios; this has at last been accomplished: I have paid the whole of the money £1200 and now you may regard me as a Nabob swelling with importance. … I think it will be a most beautiful place, with five rooms for workshops besides a large kitchen below in which I can stow away things not in immediate use, and this advantage is equal to another shop“ (Woolner 205). in Welbeck Street (near Darwin’s).Erasmus Darwin lived at 6 (renumbered from 57) Queen Anne St., which intersects with Welbeck St. The Silvester WifePhoebe, wife of John Silvester, livery stable owner. has been at the Hospital; “shd have applied sooner,“ said they; “but“—&c She is to come again in 10 days.

closer.salute: Adieu, dearest; I am sure you grudge me every word.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [7 Aug.]. Addr: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ramsgate, 7 Aug. 1861. MS: NLS 607.581. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:83–84. JWC’s notepaper was headed with an engraving of Ramsgate harbor and East Cliff; see above.
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.p:
Oh Lord! —I had just cleared my toilet table, and carried my writing things from the sitting room to my bedroom window—where there was no worse noise for the moment than—carpets-beating; and the grinding of passing carts—whereas the sitting room had become perfectly maddening with Bagpipes under the windows, and piano-practice under the floor—(a Piano hired in by “the First Floor” yesterday!) all which received an irritating finishing touch from the rapid, continuous scrape-scrapery of Geraldine’s pen! (nothing more irritating as you know than to see “others” perfectly indifferent
to what is driving oneself wild!)Had just dipped the pen in the ink when—a “yellow scoundrel”Organ-grinder.—the loudest, harshest of yellow scoundrels,—struck up under my bedroom window!—and here the Martyr power of BabbageCharles Babbage ( 1792
1791
–1871; ODNB ; see 11:19 TC to JAC, 4 Feb. 1839
), mathematician and computer pioneer, also campaigned tirelessly against street performers, through direct action and in the press. In his memoir, Passages from the Life of a Philosopher (1864), he included a chapter (also pbd. as a separate pamphlet) on “Street Nuisances” which began: “During the last ten years, the amount of street music has so greatly increased that it has now become a positive nuisance to a considerable portion of the inhabitants of London. It robs the industrious man of his time; it annoys the musical man by its intolerable badness; it irritates the invalid; deprives the patient … of that repose which … is essential for his recovery, and it destroys the time and the energies of all the intellectual classes of society by its continual interruptions of their pursuits” (337; pamphlet 3). He described some of the persecution he had suffered: “At an early period when I was putting the law in force, as far as I could … I received constantly anonymous letters, advising, and even threatening me with all sorts of evils, such as destruction of my property, burning my house, injury to myself. … I will not describe the smaller evils of dead cats, and other offensive materials, thrown down my area; of windows from time to time purposely broken, or from occasional blows from stones projected by unseen hands” (351–52; pamphlet 17–18). has not reached! Indeed noise seems to be the grand joy of Life at Ramsgate—

figure.p: “Ramsgate, East Cliff ” and JWC to TC, [7 August 1861] (detail)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p: If I had come to Ramsgate with the least idea of writing letters—or doing any thing whatever with my head—I might go back at once— But I came to swallow down as much sea air as possible, and that end is attained—without fatigue;—for lying on the sofa with our three windows wide open on the sea we are as well-aired as if we were sailing on it. And the bedroom is full of sea air all night too— It is certainly doing me good tho’ I cant ever get slept many minutes together for the noises— I get up hungry for breakfast, and am hungry again for dinner—and a fowl does not serve Geraldine and me two days!! I do hope you are getting decently fed— It won’t be for want of assiduous will on Margarets part if things are not as you like them We called for the Bains last night and invited them to tea tonight which they thankfully accepted— They seem entirely occupied in studying their mutual health— Indeed what else would any mortal stay here for! Mrs Bain is quite the female of that male, clear and clever and cold and dry as tinder!

They have “the only quiet house in Ramsgate”— Mrs Bain is troubled with nothing but the bleating of sheep to the back!— After today however there will be crying Babies in the house; and it is nothing like so airy a situation as ours— What a mercy you did not try Ramsgate.

My compliments to the Maids and say I hope to find them models of virtue and activity when I come on Saturday— Geraldine is clear for staying another week—but I had better ofThus in MS. gone to Scotland than that—
docBody.name: JWC

bibl.person: THE OFFICERS OF THE CUSTOMHOUSE AT THE LONDON DOCKS

div3.sourceNote: TC-OCLD, 8 Aug. MS: Shakespeare Birthplace Trust. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO THE OFFICERS OF THE CUSTOMHOUSE AT THE LONDON DOCKS

docBody.p: To the Officers of the Customhouse at the London Docks.

A Copy of Carlyle’s French Revolution (Tauchnitz’s Leipzig Edition),The French Revolution: A History, 3 vols. (Leipzig, 1851), pbd. by Tauchnitz in his Collection of British and American Authors series. The book was possibly confiscated in the belief that it contravened the International Copyright Act of 1852. belonging to Mr Brown of Antigua,Possibly Crowther Brown (1798–1863), Quaker and colonial agent, mentioned by Sir Evan John Murray MacGregor (1785–1841), governor of the Windward Islands 1836–41, in a letter, 11 June 1838, to Charles Grant, 1st Baron Glenelg (1778–1866; ODNB), minister for the colonies. Brown had accused MacGregor of misappropriating funds and of not following proper procedures in the dissolution of the House of Assembly in Antigua. has been detained, as was altogether proper:—I now beg to say that it will give me pleasure if the said Book be liberated, and given up to Mr Brown as a mark of my regard for him.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [8 Aug.] MS: NLS 607.581. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:241–42.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Just returned from Margate,Resort on the N coast of Kent, about 4 mi. (6.5 km.) N of Ramsgate. tired, damp, cross!—weak brandy and water “thrown into the system“!Coterie speech; see 2:479TC to JAC, 31 Aug. 1823. and dinner in prospect—nothing else in prospect! for today it rains by fits and starts, and having no change of clothes with us, we may not risk being wet thro’. So we got down out of the Ramsgate Omnibus at Margate, only to [get]Word omitted. into another Omnibus going straight back.
But I liked the appearance of Margate, as seen from the Omnibus, better than this place, and will go again tomorrow to view it in detail if the weather take up—

I am solemnly invited to take “dinner-tea“ with the Hepworth DixonsWilliam Hepworth Dixon (1821–79; ODNB; see 36:104TC to JCHA, 30 April 1860), writer and journalist, ed. of the Athenaeum 1853–69; and his wife, m., 1844, Mary Ann, b. McMahon (b. 1819). at Margate on Saturday: but have held stiffly to my purpose of taking tea at
Cheyne Row on that evening, To Geraldine’s marked displeasure who delights in persuading people to alter their plans for the mere pleasure and pride of overpersuading them.

Good Heaven! Who, think you, passed our windows this instant,—with a profligate little pipe in his mouth—? your hump-back hairdresser the Beetle-Destroyer!Unidentified. That is the sort of gentry that congregate here! I never saw so vulgar a place!Jewsbury wrote to Mantell, mid-Aug.: “I & Mrs Carlyle have had an expedition together to Ramsgate … the sea & the air are celestial but the people seem as tho’ they had been sent to show how ugly human nature can be made—all the Jews & Jewesses & the people from beyond the Monument were there upon my honour they wd have excused a fit of misanthropy“ (MS: Mantell). The Monument to the great fire of London, 1666, is in the City of London, nr. St. Paul’s Cathedral; “beyond the Monument“ indicated the overcrowded East End, populated by dock workers, laborers, immigrants, and many others. neither did I ever hear so noisy a place—! But there need be no reflections for want of sea air— The air is heavenly

Our tea-party was of the dullest—when the eating part of it was over!— I was forcibly reminded of poor Plattnauers Temptation of long ago—to “take up the poker and knock out the brains of that man“Richard Plattnauer; for his reaction to Bain, see 18:199JWC to TC, 11 Sept. 1844.

However my mouthful of “change“ has answered the end— That horrid sickness has kept quite off since I have been here. Like the Parrot sent down into the kitchen “because it moped and wanted a change“ I have “come round finely“— For how long?— I see you are going all wrong—proof sheets till one!—to bed ‘shivery’—that is the way you bring yourself to ruin!—

Have you perhaps heard of the Americain Battle?The first battle of Bull Run, fought 21 July near Manassas Junction, about 30 mi. (48 km.) SW of Washington, D.C. The Union Army had early success, but a fierce afternoon counter-attack by the Confederates led to the panicked retreat of the Union Army back to Washington, D.C. Nearly 900 men were killed and 2,700 wounded. No?
Dont expect me to dinner on Saturday and dont wait tea
docBody.name: JWC

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 9 [8] Aug. Addr: Mrs Stokes’s / 21. Wellington Cresct, East Cliff / Ramsgate. PM: 8 Aug. 1861. MS: NLS 615.547. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; he was writing on Thurs., 8 Aug.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Alas, Dearest, dinner is done today; and I must not write a word but the Address: I thot there had been 30 minutes good, when Maria entered with the fatal announcet.— — I am upstairs today, owing to the rain: you never
saw such a Table in your life; 12 or 10 open books upon it, with clipping, implements, &c &c
What a chosen place for noise; what a blessing you have gone without me! Your Note is full of amusement to me here; but there it wd not have been amuset at all.

One Letter more, tomorrow, to tell me what yr hour on Saturday will be: won’t you? You have been very good in Letter writing this time:—I hope to find you in other still more importt respects an improved Goody.
Everything goes on right enough here: the two maids as punctual as can be; & Button with a weighty air as if she had got the seals of a Secy of State. A very excellt artist in plain cookery too.
My compts to that male and that femaleAlexander and Frances Bain. (no, I don’t know the latter!):—sawThus in MS. when the dinner on Saturday shall be!—
docBody.name: T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 Aug. MS: NLS 517.23. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am very glad to hear of you again,—tho’ I have been very remiss in writing. I am so chained and hobbled amid footropes and handropes, and thrums of innumerable kinds! Not in bad health, however; not at all to call in bad comparatively. There is a marked difference, for instance, from our pluisterings and voyagings in quest of sleep, last year this time. And I am sitting here as quiet as if I were in my bed, all day as well as night. By degrees I will get fairly into vol IV (not quite 3 sheets of it yet off my hand!),—and perhaps shall do better than I expect.

Jane reports good progress of herself at Ramsgate; in spite of such noises, brass-bands, bagpipes, ballad-singers, organ boys, cocks, donkeys as never were. She is to return tomorrow; her sickly nausea quite gone for the moment &c: a very fair week’s work. We have, and have had, in respect of weather all along, such a summer as I hardly recollect, for salubrity and not tolerability only but agreeableness & geniality to the human tabernacle:—certainly there was nothing equal to it in my London experience And so solitary it now is; quiet as in Elysium; free room for work (if one had any strength left). I am worst off with unripe vegetables: nothing but a sop of bread by way of dinner vegetable.

Browning is said to be here; I expect him in an eveng or two. Poor fellow, I
believe he is very sad abt his loss of such a Wife:Elizabeth Barrett Browning had d. 29 June in Florence. but I believe it may ultimately prove a great gain to him.TC had always liked Elizabeth Barrett Browning (see 21:57TC to JAC, 25 Sept. 1846), but he believed that Robert Browning, no longer having a sick wife to care for, could now return to England and devote himself to his own work; see TC to JF, 17 Aug. If he come to England, and look after his own Tasks while it is yet time!—

I am not sorry you gave up the Killarney Adventure. The place is very wild and pretty; something touching in its intrinsic beauty, sublimity even, streaked with a kind of Irish squalor.Killarney, town in County Kerry, SW Ireland; presumably John A. Carlyle had been thinking of visiting there. TC had traveled there July 1849; see 24:133–34TC to JWC, 18 July 1849, and 139TC to JWC, 21 July 1849. He described the countryside in his Reminiscences of My Irish Journey in 1849 (1882): “mountain-country, handsomely fringed … with some wood … the moor changes itself into drained cultivated land … decidedly rather beautiful, by contrast especially“ (129). Of the town he wrote: “chaos of hungry porters, inn agents, lodging-agents,—beggars, storming round you, like ravenous dogs round carrion; this is Killarney“ (130). But you wd have had wet weather; endless fatigue; you are better nearer home. I hope you will take a little “Country-air,“ however; the very change (whh indeed, I think, is the chief point) does one good. Write to me what you find at North Berwick,North Berwick, town on the coast, 22 mi. (35.5 km.) ENE of Edinburgh. what you do and are going to do. The Yankee FightTC still used the term “Yankee“ to signify “American“; in the U.S. by this time it was used by Southerners to signify their Union opponents. sung by Homeric Russell is superb in the Annals of War!William Howard Russell (1820–1907; ODNB), special correspondent for the Times in the U.S., already famous for his reports on the Crimean War, 1854–56, and the Indian Mutiny, 1858–59. Russell had been sending reports from America regularly since April, producing an epic account of the build-up of war. His detailed and vivid account of the battle of Bull Run, 21 July, included lists of the Union regiments and officers involved, the movement of troops and the course of the battle, and Russell’s opinions on the battle: “the repulse of the Federalists, decided as it was, might have had no serious effects whatever beyond the mere failure—which politically was of greater consequence than it was in a military sense—but for the disgraceful conduct of the troops. The retreat … seems to have ended in a cowardly route—a miserable, causeless panic. Such scandalous behaviour on the part of soldiers I should have considered impossible, as with some experience of camps and armies I have never even in alarms among camp followers seen the like of it. … Washington this morning is crowded with soldiers without officers … and with ‘three months’ men,’ who are going home from the face of the enemy on the expiration of their term of enlistment. … If in the present state of the troops the Confederates were to make a march across the Potomac above Washington … the Capitol might fall into their hands“ (Times, 6 Aug.). I send today a Yankee Acct (I suppose) of the same thing; the Newspaper itself you may find to be a curious fact.TC had presumably been sent an American newspaper (possibly by Butler) containing an account of the battle. Adieu dear Brother; write soon agn. T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 9 Aug. Addr: Mrs Stokes’s / 21.Wellington Cresct, East Cliff / Ramsgate. PM: 9 Aug. 1861. MS: NLS 615.548. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JWC

docBody.p: Thanks again Dearest; you are very good in the matter of writing. I believe dinner here is just on the point of coming up,—woe’s me!—but I will add a word after. Yes, there it is— — —“on the table, Sir” well, dinner was very good again;—tho’ I cd give Button no idea at breakfast time, except—“The same as yesterday: brown soup, one chop, one small pudding!” Button has done it; and so have I.

You are very lucky (for me), were there no other wisdom in it, to have missed the Margate Dinner. With the Dixons; see JWC to TC, [8 Aug.]. There is not (to whom I can wish no ill) a more perfect snob & more or less distressing contemptibility than that gentn: William Hepworth Dixon. may he be happy always, on his own side of the hedge!

Yesterday I missed my Siesta again;—I was on the edge of elysium twice (Old man’s Elysium, that is perfect rest) when a neighbouring joinerPossibly Dominick Ronca, who lived next door at 4 Cheyne Row. tip-tipped: and, the second time, I cd stand it no longer. I hear him still today; but perhaps I shall be more patient. How one’s Life (very life) lies under the feet of all the world,—if one is too thin of skin!

Adieu, Dearest; I have really nothing but clatter as you see; and you wd not wish me to sit vigilant on no better terms than in writing that.— —Jack sent me a Narration of the Yankee passage of arms; a thing beyond wonder & admiratn. For the Times article, 6 Aug., on the battle of Bull Run sent by John A. Carlyle, see TC to JAC, 9 Aug. For an illustration of the “Stampede from Bull Run.— From a Sketch by our Special Artist,” see 212 above . The “special artist” of the Illustrated London News was Frank Vizetelly (1830–83?; ODNB ). Come to tea then! Ever my Goody’s /
T.C.

figure.p: “The Civil War in America: The Stampede from Bull Run.—From a Sketch by our Special Artist”
Illustrated London News, 17 August 1861

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 17 Aug. MS: FC. Quot: Davies, John Forster 191. Some punctuation is obscured by the binding of MS.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
I return Browning’s Letter;Forster wrote, 11 Aug., enclosing Browning’s letter of early July: “I wished to send you this letter of Browning’s about his wife’s death and his own future plans—the substance of which he permits me to tell to any friends interested in him, and I know your interest, as well as his reverence & regard for you. Dear Mrs Carlyle, too, might care to see what he says. It is a very manly, true, & honest letter—I think: increasing one’s love for Browning.“ whh we have read, naturally, with very great interest[.] The poor Lady seems to have passed away in a state of perfect peace, unconscious altogether of what was coming; the mildest end that cd have been provided to a gentle Human Life.Part of Browning’s letter is missing; the remainder contains a description of Elizabeth Barrett Browning’s last days. Browning wrote of her death: “There was no struggle, no sigh even, only a dreadful suspense for a minute or two—then a silence. I thought she had only fainted as her head lay on my arm—then there was one least contraction of the brow and Annunziata cried, ‘The blessed Soul has passed away!’ Why should I not have tried to tell you so much of this as will give you my own one comfort in some degree and not leave you to fancy there was pain, struggling, or the consciousness of departure and separation?—She went, like God’s child, into his presence with no more apprehension or difficulty than that!“ (New Letters of Robert Browning, ed. William Clyde DeVane and Kenneth Leslie Knickerbocker [1951] 139). Whh is a great consolation to
survivors in their sorrow.— I know not whether Browning has yet come to you; I partly expected or hoped to have seen him here; but had no right either,—not having written, tho’ I did not want for matter, or even for intention, but only for a few minutes of composure; whh you know are seldom if ever mine, in these sad months and years. Tell him from me to gird himself together out of these sore wrecks of the Past (as indeed I see he is manfully doing);—and that I expect a new epoch for him, in regard to his own work in this world, now that he is coming back to England at last; and that, in my poor opinion, whh I have never changed, a noble victory lies ahead for him, if he stand to it while time yet is. This is my fixed thought; and often my greatest sorrow over the “woes of Italy“ has been that a soul like R. B.’s was kept weltering, in a hobbled condition, amid such a mass of thrums and hopeless cobwebs! Assure him of my deep sympathy and true regard, at any rate. And come to me, you at least, when you return[.]

You need not fear my doing Friedh the way that is easiest for me!Forster advised TC: “Don’t think of completing ‘Frederick’ in two more volumes! You cannot do it in a manner fully worthy of what is already done—how, possibly, can you in the space you have left yourself! I am convinced that you cannot—and I woke the other morning in the midst of a violent argument of which the drift was to show that by attempting it you’d not only do wrong to a magnificent piece of work by huddling it up at the close, but would inflict upon yourself all kinds of harassments and worries and troubles still more to be regretted by those to whom nothing that even you can write is so valuable as You.“ No man, not the weariest of the Greeks before Troy, ever was so weary of a Task whh has fairly broken my heart,—and far excels, in disgusting bother, and difficulty and discouragement of every kind, all the work I hitherto had to do in the world. “I will gar myself do it,“ nevertheless, if I live! Do you know “gar“ (French, guerre), Scotch verb for “compel“? The above phrase I remember out of early years,—from oneCoterie speech; saying of TC’s father, James; see 2:430TC to JAC, 17 Sept. 1823, and 17:292TC to AC, 3 March 1844. who always made it good, and left a brave example to me!—

We are for Windsor region,TC and JWC had accepted an invitation to visit Lady Sandwich at her rented villa, Harewood Lodge, nr. the village of Sunninghill (a very popular spa town in the 18th century), on the edge of Windsor Forest; see JWC to JC, [26 July]. a week or two, abt the beginning of Septr. Come and report yourself, on getting out of the litter of Welsh Villages and ruinous Cockroosts of an extinct time.Forster became a commissioner of lunacy in Feb. and traveled extensively in England and Wales visiting hospitals for the insane. His letter, 11 Aug., was from Abergavenny, S. Wales: “What most pleases one, is to see the history of the inflammable little fiery and angry Province still written in the ruins of the innumerable old ivy-grown towers & castles to be seen in every town or village that one passes—none so insignificant but has its unpronounceable fragment of an abode where an old Celtic chief once perched himself—now riddled by mines and railways, and darkened by English smoke more incessantly than by Welsh mists.“ Yours ever, dear F. / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 17 Aug. MS: NLS 553.236. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: We are very glad to hear of you again, definitely at first hand, tho’ the news is none of the best.Neuberg wrote, 9 Aug., from Switzerland, where he was trying to recover his health: “The last 5 or 6 months of my life were very sad; the bodily suffering was the least part.“ I had been continually whipping myself up to the evident duty of inquiring for what I was anxious abt; and probably I shd have been writing this Sunday at any rate,—but it is better on the present terms.

The goat-milk, whh about 100 years ago was the constant Autumn Panacea for mankind in Engld too, is a thing I have often thot of trying for my own behoof, some time or other;TC was given goat milk in 1849 in Ireland; see 24:140TC to JWC, 21 July 1849. honest cow-whey, whh I drink largely in the Country, always does me good within limits. Perhaps your Gais [Geiss, goat] experiences, tho’ not joyous for the moment, may yield good fruit in a little while.Neuberg wrote that he was “drinking the whey of goats’ milk, warm, almost hot, as it is brought down every morning from the Alp where the goats feed on sweet herbs … and where the cheese-making process is carried on in the night, leaving as residue said whey, very disagreable insipid stuff. What it will do for me, time must shew; for the present it plagues me considerably.“ And, one way and another, were it only from change of scene, and influx of new sensations instead of the dreary old, we calculate on getting you back a considerably improved man.Neuberg wrote: “tho’ I am certainly much stronger than I was when I left home, I am not nearly as fresh and elastic as I was on the journey hither, when the mere moving about and change of air seemed to operate like a charm.“ It will never do for us to break down now! Here and there, you tell me, are inquiries for Frh: alas, in one’s own poor overwearied soul there is most passionate nigh desperate inquiry for it;—and we must get it done!

I have sat out of doors here, under my awning, ever since you left; pulling along at the ropes, but hardly able to stretch them straight, much less to make any perceptible way! The weather has been bright, but occasionally sultry, always heavy and enervating. To me the want of ripe vegetables to my meat (unripe being poisonous to me) is always a great drawback at this season. Madam went off, for a week, with Miss Jewsbury, to Ramsgate: never was
such air, such sea;—but also never were such “noises“ day and night, such unsightly cockneyhoods fallen opulent, such— In short there was not, for me, the faintest likelihood there; nor elsewhere on the English coasts My friend the sea must therefore remain a stranger, at present. In France next year, if one had done,—alas, alas! We are going out to AscotAscot Racecourse, founded 1711, about 11½ mi. (2.5 km.) from Harewood Lodge. (in the Windsor-Forest region) abt the beginning of Septr,—to visit Lady Sandwich in a place she is getting ready there,—Horse Fritz being also invited, I hope to have comfortable riding in the silent woods; and Jane will wisely guide the Dietetics. For a week or two weeks:—this is all the rusticatn we are to have.

I have hardly got 4 sheets of vol IV yet off my hands. Vol iii is fully 100 pages longer than I wished;—Vol IV threatens to be more “impossible“ than any part I have yet done: but indeed the whole has been a work of sheer force; spasm after spasm,—and I am sick of dead-lifts any farther.

Nothing in military annals equals that of Bull’s Run,—except indeed it were the Taking of Fort Sumter,Fort Sumter, at the entrance to Charleston harbor, South Carolina. Following their secession from the U.S., the Confederate States claimed possession of all U.S. forts and arsenals within their territory. President Abraham Lincoln determined to hold on to them, but the Confederate authorities refused to allow supplies in. When the commander of the garrison, Maj. Robert Anderson (1805–71) refused to surrender, Confederate forces attacked; Anderson surrendered 14 April. whh ought to be memorable as that of Troy!By the time of the battle of Bull Run, the significance of the fall of Fort Sumter had become much more apparent. On the whole, I believe many persons are abt opening their eyes to the real Beschaffenheit [condition] not of Yankeeland alone, but of England & all lands; and we shall see alterations. Prosper, write!— T.C.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JG]M[JGM], 19 Aug. MS: London Lib. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee conjecturally identified as James Garth Marshall (1802–73), Leeds flax manufacturer, known to TC since the late 1830s; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 142–44; see also TC to JGM, 11 Jan. 1854, and TC to JGM, 20 April 1857. Although Marshall no longer had a London house, several members of his family lived there.
div3.head: TC TO [JAMES GARTH] MARSHALL

docBody.p: I have not gone out to dinner for months and years past:—there is no subject of her Majesty so ill off for want of time, and for want of strength according to his demands, as poor I have been and am like to be, in this the concluding stage of my activities! I have got a quite hideous job of work, whh no man can do;—whh I must contrive to do, or else—!

It wd give me great pleasure to have a talk with you again. Cannot you
come and ride, some day? I ride daily two hours good; 3p.m. from this door,—or any hour you wd appoint. There seems to be no other chance for me.
With best regards to the Lady,Marshall’s wife, Mary Alicia, b. Spring-Rice (1812–75; see 10:28TC to MAC, 15 Feb. 1838), m. 1841; see 13:90TC to JWC, 9 April 1841, and 105TC to JWC, 18 April 1841.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD[JAD], 23 Aug. MS: NLS 1797.152. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO JANE DODS

docBody.p:
You have no idea, I am pretty sure, of the numbers of times you have been in my head since you heard any word to that effect! Just the more I don’t write to the people I care about, the more I think about them! Latterly, that is for weeks back, a day hasn’t passed without my meaning—vaguely—to write, and ask if there was any chance of my seeing you here, since there was clearly no chance of it elsewhere— But I would wait always—just another day—to see if the question would not be anticipated by a letter from you or a visit! And this half-expectation was not so fantastic as you may think. There had been more than one person from Haddington here,Helena Shortess Ferme and Agnes Catherine Howden, das. of JWC’s father’s partner, Thomas Howden; see below. at whom I had inquired about you and “William Dods,“ and who had given me an impression that I should soon see at least him if not both of you in London— I say an impression, because, to get anything like cordial, detailed, satisfactory information, about anybody or anything in old Haddington, that interests me, by any pressure of questioning a Howden is frankly impossible!— It is like squeezing an unripe orange, or a dry sponge. The very tone of voice in which my questions are answered is discouraging and makes me wish I hadn’t asked any! What is that dryness (dreechness) that repells me so in the Howdens?— I feel so glad to see any of them always—for the sake of old times—I strive to be agreeable to them and to not take offence at their ungracious ways; and the result is always the same; that they leave me “heavy and displeased.“1 Kings 20:43. Helen is the only one that I feel to be welldisposed towards me, in spite of her uncouth manners— —and yet Agnes seems a good brave girl. The way she was bearing that spoiling of her good looks filled me with admiration. Do tell me when you write (you will write?) if the London surgeon’s remedies have
been of any benefit to her face. It would give me real satisfaction to hear that she had been cured.Agnes had possibly been disfigured by cholera; they may have been consulting James Startin (1806–72), senior surgeon at the Hospital for Diseases of the Skin, Blackfriars, who had a practice at 3 Saville Row, Piccadilly; otherwise unexplained.

I never was more astonished in my life than when on opening a large letter some weeks ago there fell out of it on the table a lot of the most atrociously ugly likenesses of—myself (!) A letter from Mrs Campbell (“who Nurse’t Miss Ds at Tenterfield“)The Donaldson sisters’ nurse; see 36:93JWC to EDO, 7 April 1860. explained the mystery— —or, rather didn’t explain it! for the wonder remained, how came the horrid things into “her box“?—

I hear never a whisper of the London Donaldsons; which is a comfort!— so far as it goes! It is curious how people may live in this London, as separated by their several “circles“ as tho’ the whole Atlantic lay between them!

I was very near going to Scotland this month,—to Dumfrieshire; that is, I had taken a wild longing to go, and made up my mind to leave Mr C, (since he would live on here, all thro’ the hot weather, writing away under an awning in the back court) to be cared for by a new Cook I had got, who inspired me with a most comfortable trust in her good sense, and kindliness, and delicate management; but the very day after I had written to my friend at Thornhill that I would come; this Woman who I was hoping to retire upon as “a Treasure“ for the remaining term of my earthly housekeeping was discovered to be privately at death’s door with an abcess in her back! had to be removed to St Georg’es Hospital, where she is still, after about two months; and, instead of getting to Scotland, I had to spend my life in teaching the housemaid to cook, and running backwards and forwards to the Hospital; till I fell so ill with it that I had to take a week of rest from my household worries, at all costs and risks, and a breath of sea air—which saved me I think from a nervous fever

I spent this sacred week at Ramsgate, the nois[i]estLetter omitted. most odious place!, but such air!— I was terrified that I should find on my return your cards or your Husbands card on my table but there was no such thing Do please put me out of this suspense. The more, that I am going soon with Mr C on a visit, which may last two or three weeks, if he finds he can work there— It is no further than Ascot— So I could come up home any day, for the sight of an old friend if any was forthcoming
All good be with you and yours affly / J W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 Aug., MS: NLS 525.80. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I suppose, having heard nothing from you, that you are still in Edinr, and that you did not go to No[r]thLetter omitted. Berwick or anywhither. One is quietest of all in a Capital City during, these autumn times, really; and the vis inertiae [slothful life] tempts one more and more. London is emptier than I almost ever saw it; the weather, tho’ it has been generally dry and even bright, & occasionally for a couple of days very hot,The Times noted, 14 Aug., “The greatest heat in the sun was 135 deg. on Monday [12]“ and the Illustrated London News reported, 17 Aug., “110 deg. F. in the sun and 95–97 in the shade, a heat almost unprecedented in this century.“ has not agreed with me quite as the summer did; and I am getting on with my Fourth Vol. even worse than I cd have expected. Oh what a deliverance if I can really hold out till next year, and be rid of it forever and a day! I do struggle; but with years got to the height of mine (and perhaps the want of ripe vegetables to boot!) it is uphill work. Courage; silence!—

I have often been thinking whether you cd not be tempted to a sail up to London, while there is still sun in the sky. It wd blow the dust out of you better than most things; and might be a useful interlude between this and winter? If you could resolve on it, there is always a vacant room here; and there are now two handy maids, no difficulty about waiterage;—also Jane has been spoken to;—and in short for a couple of weeks, or till you tired, there is nothing to hinder but yourself; and vis inertiae, whh I hope is not too strong. There ought not at this point of time to be years of interval between our meetings, so few years now by nature remaining. I bid you seriously think of this;—and have delayed writing specially abt it too long.

Some time “early in Septr“ we are to go out for a week or an indefinite time to Windsor or Ascot quarter: the good old Lady Sandwich (above 80 now, tho’ full of spirit) has taken some villa out there,—very pretty little House she says;—and insists that we shall go, “Horse Fritz and all,“ “dine when you like“ &c &c. Principally with a view of breaking up the stagnancy here, we have consented.— It need not interrup[t]Letter omitted. you, were you even here: it is so near hand for coming & going; and the two maids wd take good care of you. Jane thot she got real good of Ramsgate, “air so elastic, sea so &c“: but the noises, and vile opulent vulgarities, fat Jewhoods, Cockneyhoods &c were such, that she cd not propose it to me at all. She has given up Scotland, restricts herself to this bit of Ascot & Windsor Forest.

Three O’clock is striking! You may read the Neuberg Letter, and light yr pipe with it. But here is another special thing. Did not I once give a little Pamphlet by Varnhagen von Ense abt Voltaire’s Detention at Frankfurt in 1753?Karl August Varnhagen von Ense, Voltaire in Frankfurt am Main, 1753 [Leipzig, 1846]; see 29:335TC to JN, 19 June 1855, and Works 16:370. TC’s copy with Varnhagen’s autograph and TC’s marginal notes: HCC. I have possessed a Copy of it myself for 10 years back; I think I gave you that 2d Copy as superfluous;—and lucky it will be if you still have it: for now, when I want my own, I cannot find it, high or low! Woe’s me. If you have it not, I must write to Neubg witht delay to bring a Copy with him.— We have still some company; especially Jane has. Froude was here, with Ruskin, the other night. Adieu dear Brother T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 25 Aug. MS: NLS 517.24. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:21–12 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
I have barely a minute; but will send you the indications necessary. Poor T.C.’s recovery of himselfTC’s paternal cousin Thomas Carlyle (b. 1815). at Birmingham is an interesting fact; and I am truly glad to hear of it: “Uncle Frank“TC’s uncle Francis Carlyle (1761–1819); TC described him as “a quaint, social, cheerful man … fond of genealogies, old histories, poems, queer sayings and all curious and humane things he could come at“ (Carlyle, Reminiscences 26). He and his wife, Elizabeth, b. Bell (1783–1842; see 15:212TC to MAC, 30 Nov. 1842), had two sons, Thomas (b. 1815) and John (b. 1818): “Frank left two sons, as yet young; one of whom (my namesake), gone to be a Lawyer, is rather clever, how clever I have not fully seen“ (Carlyle, Reminiscences 26). is to me also a very lively reminiscence. I recollect as if yesternight, the last time he ever came to Mainhill,Mainhill, small farm nr. Ecclefechan, rented by TC’s father 1815–26. or that I ever saw him;—I suppose he himself thot it wd perhaps be his last visit; for he had just risen from a dangerous illness;—however, he had dressed himself, in the pale autumn afternoon, and came up with the Two Boys, winding pensively along. He fell mainly to me, all hands being on the corn-rig; and was very amiable: “The German language!“ he said, with goodnatured wonder, when I shewed him the Book I was then intent upon. My first German Book;—and, as it happened, the History of Fredc’s Seven-Years War;Johann Wilhelm von Archenholz, Geschichte des siebenjährigen Krieges in Deutschland (Berlin, 1788), given TC by Irving, spring 1819 (see 1:173TC to AC, 29 March 1819), to read at home that summer; see 1:193TC to JOFE, 25 Aug. 1819. John A. Carlyle sent him a copy (Berlin, 1793) from Germany, 1856 (see 31:69TC to JAC, 22 April 1856); TC’s copy: HCC. whh now again so much concerns me, when I too am grown old! At
crossing the burn (edge of “Calf-park“),Presumably a field nearby where calves were kept. he took one of the little Boys on his back, I helping with the other; and muttered something, “Poor things, I kenna what’ll come of them, an I were gane!“—with a tone, I think altogether of tears (this was in returning in the dusk) whh is deeply memorable to me.—— —— I could do nothing at all for Tom in 1834,TC wrote to Henry Inglis (1806–85, Edinburgh lawyer; see 29:35529:biographical note) and JWC’s uncle Robert Welsh, 1835, trying to get his cousin a job as a lawyer’s clerk in Edinburgh; see 8:235TC to HI, 21 Oct. 1835, 242TC to JAC, 24 Oct. 1835, and 254TC to JWC, 2 Nov. 1835. It is unclear what happened, but in 1844 TC described Thomas as a “disgraceful slut“ who had left the country; see 18:70TC to AC, 17 June 1844. tho’ I did try this and that; and he owes me absolutely nothing. Nor can I now do anything for him; nobody can, except himself, by being wiser than he was. It is still time; now is the time, now and henceforth; the past is irrecoverable inalterable, not good to dwell on; the present and the future one still has.—— —— I would not insult the poor fellow’s grateful feelings by refusing what he offers;—if you think that wd be the effect, here is a snip of measurement inclosed.His cousin had apparently offered an item of clothing. Do what you find good (do not fash him at all, if you think it will not insult or hurt,—for really I do not need the article);—and send him, at any rate, my best wishes, as you truly may.— The Dr. I conjecture is with you since yesternight. Your James has sent us a “brace of grouse“ (think of that!) & is coming on Wedny, we hope.— Adieu, dear Jean. Good be with one & all of you.Signature cut away.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 26 Aug. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Many thanks for the bright little Note you flung me from Blair Athol;Lord Ashburton wrote, 15 Aug., from Blair Athole (now Atholl), Perthshire (about 35 mi. [56.5 km.] NNW of Perth): “We have arrived here safely, & are posting up the Highland road most happily with babe in romping spirits, growing brighter & stronger & heavier & taller every hour.“ whh was abundantly welcome here. We guessed well enough why you had not seen us; and what a miserable confusion that of poor Mason must have been.James Mason (ca. 1817–61), Lord Ashburton’s valet, had killed himself. Lord Ashburton wrote: “We grieved much to miss seeing you in London during our 36 hours there spent but the disaster of Mason’s death had so embroiled the accounts, & had such a remodelling of household arrangements to provide against the recurrence of past disorders then for the first time revealed to me in all their extent, that we had no time.“ I have not been so shocked with anything for a long time. Jane, last time we were at Bath House, had been remarking to me what a desperate and gloomily deadly look the poor fellow wore;—and the next news had of him was this
of the finale! In spite of his bitter temper, I had always found poor Mason, in my outside experience of him, one of the most respectable men I had ever met of his station;—a man now who has become permanently tragical to me. My guess is, the first bend sinister in his character and course had been at that point, long since, when he found that (for valid reasons) he was never to reach Butlership;The Ashburtons’ butler was George Maynard (b. ca. 1819).—“ambition thwarted“ is sore in a violent heart;—like Dean Swift,Jonathan Swift (1667–1745; ODNB), writer; dean of St. Patrick’s Cathedral, Dublin. whom Fate and the Duchess of Somerset had forever forbidden to be a Bishop!Elizabeth Seymour (1667–1772; ODNB), duchess of Somerset; courtier and politician. John Hawkesworth in his “Account“ of Swift’s life, prefixed to Swift’s Works (1755), wrote: “a bishopric was intended for him by the queen, but, archbishop Sharpe and a certain great lady having misrepresented his principles and character, her majesty gave it to another“ (1:18). Samuel Johnson in Lives of the Poets (1779–81) said that this referred to Swift’s A Tale of a Tub (1704). In the “Apology“ for A Tale of a Tub (5th edn.; 1709), Swift made reference to high churchmen disapproving of the work. But the cause may have been Swift’s personal attack on the duchess of Somerset in the lampoon entitled “The Windsor Prophecy“ (1711). John Sharp (1645–1714; ODNB), archbishop of York; Anne (1665–1714; ODNB), queen of Great Britain. All your kindnesses and forgivennesses, after that, only added fuel to the fire. Be thankful, let us all be thankful, he wreaked his furious vengeances where he did, and left us able to pity him & them, instead of otherwise as it might frightfully have been!Lord Ashburton wrote: “I think he must have been shaken by constant drink, for there was at times a wildness in his eye that made me fear some desperate attack either upon Lou or upon the child. This was confirmed by an expression that fell from his brother (whom he had stripped of £140). The brother sd he almost felt relieved when he heard that he was dead. He had always been haunted by the fear of some more awful catastrophe. / The last act was brought on by the pursuit of creditors who dogged his steps, by his inability to make up the £200 which proved afterwards to be owing on his book to me; and the receipt of a note of wh no trace was ever found as he returned at 11 pm on the fatal night. I feel myself guilty. I trusted him with too much money, I humoured his madness; I allowed him to set all other authority but mine at defiance in the house to do no work in short of any kind but for my personal service.“—

We flatter ourselves you are all safe in Brahan Castle; and that Rous’s reports are still equally flourishing (from Baby upwards, everybody somewhat well);Lord Ashburton wrote: “Rouse daily dogmatically examines & reports on each. We are all pronounced the better for our journey, wh is to be brought to its conclusion at Brahan on Friday.“—and that we shall see you again, safe out of these Highland journeyings and adventures, before very long. Our weather by report is superior to yours; nothing of rain here, tho sometimes grey and tempestuous; latterly rather cold, with a smell almost of October in it, and a suggestion of looking out for winter hosiery again. I never saw London emptier; not a carriage except busses & hack-cabs on the streets: from end to end of Piccadilly you will not meet two figures of gentlemen;—perhaps half a dozen of
the gent species, not in fortunate circumstances.— — Jane ran down to Ramsgate for a week: sea-air quite celestial; but noises,—such noises, such efflorescences of opulent vulgarism,—to me a forbidden place! We are to go for a week to good Lady Sandwich, to a villa she has hired in the Ascot or Windsor-Forest region; no other rusticatn: instead of amusement, work for life.— I have cut from the Newspaper this invaluable Druidism in Lewis for my lady;Possibly an article on the Callernish (now Callanish) standing stones circle, 16 mi. (25.5 km.) W of Stornoway, Isle of Lewis; Lady Louisa Ashburton was b. at Seaforth Lodge, Stornoway. to whom offer it for me with bended knee. Yours ever T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [27 and 29 Aug.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries NB. PM: London, 30 Aug. 1861; Thornhill, 31 Aug. 1861. MS: NLS 607.582. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:85–87 inc; Simpsons 210–11 inc. Quot: Ireland, JWC 268–69; Hansons, NE 496.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I want to hear about you; and that is lucky for you, if you be at all wanting to hear about me! For I’ll be hanged if mere unassisted sense of duty and that sort of thing could nerve me to sit down and write a letter in these days—when it takes pretty well all the sense and strength I have left, to keep myself soul and body together, doing the things forced into my hands to do, and answering when I am spoken to!

A nice woman I am! But I know you have been in such depths yourself occasionally, and will have sympathy with me,—instead of being contemptuous or angry, as your strong-minded able-bodied women would be—and accordingly strong-minded able-bodied women are my aversion, and I run out of the road of one as I would from a mad cow!— The fact is, had there been nobody in the world to consider except myself, I ought to have “carried out“ that project I had set my heart on of streaming off by myself to Holme Hill—and taking a life-bath, as it were, in my quasi native air, in the scene of old affections, not all past and gone, but some still there as alive and warm, thank god, as ever! and only the dearer for being mixed up with those that are dead and gone.————
Thursday [29 August 1861]

I was interrupted at this point, and could not find a quiet hour on Tuesday to resume my letter—and yesterday morning brought your letter—making what I had written out of place—but I send it to show you that I was writing voluntarily—tho’ a second letter from you puts more go into the voluntariness.
Ah my Dear, your kindness goes to my heart, and makes me like to cry—because I cannot do as you bid me!

My Servants are pretty well got into the routine of the house now, and if Mr C were like other men he might be left to their care for two or three weeks without fear of consequences! But he is much more like a spoiled Baby than like other men! I tried him alone, for a few days, when I was afraid of falling seriously ill unless I had change of air. Three weeks ago I went with Geraldine Jewsbury to Ramsgate one of the most accessible sea-side places, where I was within call, as it were, if anything went wrong at home; but the letter that came from him every morning was like the letter of a Babe in The Wood! who would be found buried with dead leaves by the Robins if I didn’t look to it! So even if Ramsgate hadn’t been the horridest, nois[i]estLetter omitted. place where I knew nobody, and had nothing to do, except swallow sea air—(the best of sea air indeed)—I couldn’t have got staid there long enough to make it worth the bother of going.

I had thought in going there, that if he got on well enough by himself, for the few days, I might take two or three weeks later and realize my hearts wish after all. But I found him so out of sorts on my return that I gave it up—with inward protest and appeal to posterity! Again a glimmer of hope arose. Lady Sandwich had taken a Villa on the edge of Windsor Forrest, for a month and invited us to go with her there. Mr C is very fond of that old Lady, partly for her own sake and partly for the late Lady Ashburton’s (her daughter)— He can take his horse with him there, and his books, and if he miss his sleep one night, he can come straight home the next! So on the whole, after much pressing, he consented to go, And the idea came to me, if he were all right there, mightn’t I slip away meanwhile to you! Before however it had been communicated, he said to me one day; “What a poor shivering nervous wretch I am grown! I declare if you weren’t to be there to take care of me, and keep all disturbance off me, nothing would induce me to go to that place of Lady Sandwich’s, tho’ I dare say it is very necessary for me to go somewhere.“
Humph! very flattering! but very inconvenient!— And one can’t console oneself at my age for a present disappointment, with looking forward to next year—one is no longer so sure of one’s next year!

One thing I can do and you can do—we can write oftener. It is a deal nicer to speak face to face from heart to heart— But we might make our correspondence a better thing than it is if we prevented the need of beginning our letters so often with an apology for silence.

Thanks for all your news. Every little detail about Thornhill people and things is interesting to me— And oh many many thanks for your kind messages to us all— God bless you Dear—and love to the Doctor. / affectionately Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CC[CCU], [6 Sept.] MS: Charlotte Cushman Papers, Lib. of Congress. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 263–65. Quot: Julia Markus, Across an Untried Sea (New York, 2000) 157–59. Dated by the biting of Fritz’s neck; see TC to JAC, 9 Sept.
div3.head: JWC TO CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN

docBody.p: If I believe in one human will having power over another even thro’ some miles of other human beings?—if I believe in Spiritual Mag[n]etism?— Most assuredly! I believe in it absolutely and entirely! It is the Great Central Fact of the Universe for me!— The concentrated Essence of Life!— I wouldn’t say as much in ‘mixed company’; knaves and idiots have so taken the name of Magnetism in vain—so disgraced and disecrated it with their Clairvoyant Champaign Breakfasts—their after-dinner table-turnings—all their brutal nonsenses, that to declare oneself a firm believer in MagnetismBy “spiritual magnetism,“ JWC apparently meant a kind of telepathy. She did not approve of the idea that animal magnetism or mesmerism (promulgated by Franz Anton Mesmer [1734–1815] and his followers) could be used for medical purposes; see 18:282–85JWC to JWE, 13 Dec. 1844; see also 18:308JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1844. The use of mesmerism, along with table-turning and clairvoyance, as entertainment, was very popular in the 19th century, with some people taking it very seriously, and others viewing it merely as a parlor-game.—and in little else—were to expose oneself uselessly to the misconception of the greater number; but it suits my humour to begin my correspondence with you by a confidence!

For the rest; I do wish to see you; do wish to hear from you; do love you; (you know that; why make me say it?) And, further I mean, deliberately and imperatively, that we Two should be friends for the rest of our lives,—and good ones! to make up for lost time.Cushman first came to Britain 1844, when she met Geraldine Jewsbury; Cushman wrote to Emma Crow Cushman, 7 Sept.: “a Miss Jewsbury was then so injudicious in her praise of me, that Mrs Carlyle took a true womanly antagonism to me & would not know me“ (Cushman’s draft letters, Charlotte Cushman Papers, Lib. of Congress); see 20:109–10JWC to JW, 19 Jan. 1846. That is my modest meaning; understand!— Set yourself against it if you can!

In reading your programme I thought for a few moments of asking Mrs DilberoglueCushman and JWC met at the Dilberoglues’ home, 25 Aug. Cushman wrote to an unidentified correspondent: “On Sunday, who should come self-invited to meet me but Mrs. Carlyle? She came at one o’clock and stayed until eight. … Clever, witty, calm, cool, unsmiling, unsparing, a raconteur unparalleled, a manner unimitable, a behavior scrupulous, and a power invincible,—a combination rare and strange exists in that plain, keen, unattractive yet unescapable woman! … After she left, of course we talked her until the small hours of the morning“ (Charlotte Cushman: Her Letters and Memories of Her Life, ed. Emma Stebbins [Boston, 1879] 84). Cushman also wrote to Emma Crow Cushman, 7 Sept.: “I met a person whom I have longed for 12 years to know. Mrs. Carlyle—wife of Thomas Carlyle. … Well dear, she came—she saw & I conquered! & now she ‘admires me very very much’ she says! … I wish you my darling could have seen this unhandsome, clever, keen, witty, scathing Scotch woman—come entirely down from her proud Eminence to sit at your Aunties side—with her hand seeking hers & occasionally giving it a nervous clutch—as though she had found some warmth and nature there—which she failed to find among the proud intellectualities which surround Carlyle to gather up his crumbs—but who invariably come away glamoured by her! I confess darling to being greatly flattered!“ (Cushman’s draft letters). to let me meet you once more in her dear little Temple of
Concord,Originally a temple near the forum in Rome, built sixth century B.C. to foster harmony between discordant factions; possibly the Dilberoglues had a summer house in their garden. Cushman described them to her niece as living in “a quiet nook in Islington“ (Cushman’s draft letters). Sarah Dilberoglue, as the actor Sarah Anderton, had previously been a protégée of Cushman. on Sunday evening; or asking yourself to make Time to come here again one morning before our departureThe Carlyles left for Harewood Lodge 12 Sept.— But the idea was quickly rejected. The impression left on my mind by our Parting the other evening was so good! so exactly the sort of impression of you I wished to keep till your return next June;Cushman left for Paris, then Rome, 12 Sept.; she planned to return to England the following summer. and suppose I managed to arrange another—parting; how easily, in the prosaic unsettledness and bustle of the next days, might there arise something from without or from within to make the second parting less satisfactory to think of than that other! and to disturb or mar the impression of that other, which I wished to keep intact!

A cowardly apprehension you may think! at least a nervous one! But, anyhow, it came to me with the impressiveness of a Monition of Nature; and having no “principles of conduct“ “to speak of,“Coterie speech; see 17:63JWC to TC, 18 Aug. 1843. the more need I should give heed to my Instincts!!

You will write to me when you are settled?Cushman replied from Rome, 16 Nov.: “The note which came to me on the 8th Sepr from you has made a part of my every day since then.“ She continued that if she waited to write until free from “worry of things“ she would never write: “I think of you ever—and of all that you said & did on that first & only day I saw you when a new heaven & a new earth was revealed to me“ (MS: NLS 1774.216). I mean when you have leisure of mind and body— I dont want a letter written, as I am writing this one, in a worry of Things!

I have the strangest thing to tell you about your flowers! The moment I set my eyes on them, and before setting my eyes on the note, and in face of the glaring improbability that grapes and flowers should be sent from the same person, on the same day by two different messengers (!) I knew somehow—knew as assuredly as if I had taken them out of your hand—that those flowers
were from you! My maid, in entering the room with them said—“not from Mr Ruskin I think mam!—at least it isn’t his man that brought them.“ “No“ I said as if I had known of their coming “they are from Miss Cushman.“ And I knew the note was from you, before I had looked at the signature or read a word of it! I did not know the handwriting yet I knew it was yours!

I must stop— I have to go up to Piccadilly to arrange about—about—Oh Heavens about something much above my capacity! viz placing Mr C’s horse out at grass for a few weeks!! He has gone and got himself bitten (the horse not Mr C) on the neck by another horse, and Mr C who calls himself or is called a Philosopher is so ashamed of the trifling disfigurement to his Horse’s beauty, that he declines taking him on a visit to an Aristocratic Stable!—and i (!) must find him a month’s grazing somewhere!— My Dear! Men are—what shall I say?—strange upon my honour!Coterie speech; expressions of Mazzini; see 36:216JWC to TC, 2 Sept. 1860.
God Bless you—kind regards to Miss StebbingEmma Stebbins was also staying with the Dilberoglues. with the clear fine eyes and gentle smile—your

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 Sept. MS: NLS 525.81. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: The VarnhagenSee TC to JAC, 23 Aug. came punctually on Saturday,—thanks. I have read it critically thro’ (loosish at some of the joints, but complete on that subject); and cannot but praise my luck in having it there in reserve, when the want of it wd have occasioned so much bother!—

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle to John A. Carlyle, 9 September 1861 (detail)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p: I have had to stop the Press: at p.64 vol iv, I decide to wait “for two months,“ that is, till Novr come. Of the next 300 pages, above 100 more are in type but will require (and are daily getting) a painful manipulatn; 200 more are still a good way off “type,“ or perfection of any degree; lying rather like a tumbled mass of clay,—bricks enough, if they were burnt (or even wholly baked) and put into the form of Wall:—agt Novr I hope to be far on with both operatns. After whh there is again a piece in partial readiness. Surely to Heaven, “next year“ will now see me free!

We are for the Windsor Country, Thursday coming (3 days hence). I think it is hardly above 20 miles, going by Staines Bridge,The main SW road out of London went through Staines, 18 mi. (29 km.) from London; the bridge, opened by William IV in 1832, was designed by George Rennie (1791–1866; ODNB), mechanical and structural engineer, cousin of JWC’s friend George Rennie. having Windsor itself to
right some good distance. Lady Sandwich, who is our Hostess, writes today that the place is airy, pretty, all very good, but afflicted “with bats, gnats and wasps.“ Let me give you the Address:
“Harewood Lodge / Sunning Dale / Staines“ (Countess Dowagr of Sandwich“ may go on the first Letter, if you write soon).

I calculated on riding out (Railway from Waterloo takes only an hour, but there are 2 miles driving at each end); and had a great notion of my “fine rides in Windsor Forest“: but, alas, the other night, Horse Fritz fell into an absurd accident with his neighbour in the next stall; they broke their halters, got both into one stall, and were found fighting in the morning, with neck and shoulders all bitten! My poor Fritz, I have little doubt, must have been passive, or if he invaded, it cd only be with friendly intentions (poor quadruped): but, his neck all blue and lumpy, he was a shocking fellow on the sudden, and went very ill withal, every step hurting the bitten parts: in short he was such a fright, I had him turned out to grass (a field here, where they give him corn too), and since Thursday I have no Horse! Whh is going to be a considerable disappointt. If I find the neck quite whole again, even with defect of hair, I may be tempted to take him after all. We shall see on Thursday.— The weather here is, and genlly has been, admirable for Harvest work. Bid them all good speed (the excellent kind souls!) at Scotsbrig. My blessing on the Place & all that it holds.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S[LS], [9 Sept.]. MS: NLS 19.3.52.19. Pbd: Henry W. Meikle, “Two Letters of Jane Welsh Carlyle,“ Scottish Historical Review 28 (1949): 57–58 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 496. Dated by Fritz’s injuries.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: I was so frightened in opening your letter! Lest it should be to say we weren’t to come!

“Fancies“? Curtains? “Ah Yes!“ (as one of the Turnkeys at Pentonville said to me, apropos of a blue-and-silver tassel on the wall of a cell) “That (the tassel) is a little fancy of this Number’s! We allow them their little fancies here!!!“JWC and TC had visited Pentonville Prison, 2 Jan. 1851; see 26:8JWC to JWE, 7 Jan. 1851.

Mr C is particular as to curtains, “but now, you aren’t to worrit yourself Mam“ (as my new housemaid is always urging on me) for if particular as to curtains,—he isnt at all particular as to the sort of curtains; and when I read your question to him the answer was, “Pooh! I can make myself curtains in
two minutes! tell Lady Sandwich!“ “How,“ I asked, thinking the secret worth any housewife’s knowing! “Why,—easily,—with a clothes horse and my plaid! It was an expedient that suggested itself to me on my first visit to Germany,For TC’s complaints about curtainless windows in Germany in 1852, see 27:274TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1852. and I went all over Germany on the strength of it!“— Whoever has it in his head to write Mr C’s Biography might gather many curious and valuable ‘particulars,’ I am sure, from German Chambermaids!
So the curtains need be no “worritting“ thought.

But he hasn’t told you about the Horse, he says. He was “meaning to write this very day.“ I dont wonder he ‘thought shame’ to tell you what a sacrifice to appearances he, a Philosopher, had gone and made!

Some excitement arose in the Stable the other night, and the horses broke loose, and (“whether in ill humour or in in play the groom couldn’t take on himself to affirm“) they fell on one another’s necks—with their teeth! And when poor Friz next presented himself to carry his master, his Master was so disgusted with the disfigurement to his personal beauty of all these scratches on the neck, that he ordered him into outer darkness, that is—“out to grass,“ till the hair grew!—answering to all my remonstrances and entreaties; that he (Friz) “wasn’t fit to appear in Lady Sandwich’s stable nor indeed to appear at all!“— Imagine the disappointment to the Horse! Ascot! such an interesting locality for Horses!—on a visit to you! for whom he shows the most passionate preference, in always refusing to pass your door, and in pushing towards Grosvenor Street, wherever he may be wanted [to]Word omitted. JWC repeated “in“ above (l.2 of this para.). go, within half a mile of it!— He would have felt himself in Heaven, that horse would! and now; exiled to a despicable paddock at Fulham!Possibly to Mrs. Sarah Filby, livery stables, 2 Unity Pl., Fulham Rd., about 2 mi. (3 km.) W of Chelsea.—where he can have no interests, no associations, and very little grass!—all because he dont look quite so sleek as usual!— I am so sorry for him and rather indignant!

I suppose if the Cat were to fall upon, and scratch my face—as might easily happen just now when she has kittens—I shouldn’t be taken either! but be—sent out to grass; figuratively speaking!— But he will be punished, for his “cruelty to animals“The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals was founded in London in 1824 and given royal patronage in 1840. by the loss of his daily ride. And “serve him right“ if he walk himself into a soft corn or two—
I suppose Mr C knows all about the train he went to consult with Mr DawsonPresumably a servant of Lady Sandwich; see TC to Lady SLS, 11 Sept. the other day.
God send us safe there.
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LS], 11 Sept. MS: NLS 19.3.52.20. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: We are coming tomorrow as per contract; and intend to be, at least Jane does with both the luggages, at the Sunning Dale Station,Sunningdale, small town about 1½ mi. (2.5 km.) SE of Harewood Lodge on the Staines and Reading branch of the London and South Western Railway. by the Train whh leaves WaterlooWaterloo Bridge Station, opened 1848. (down the River here) at 2 p.m.; & gets to Sunning Dale (if your Dawson be correct) abt 3 p.m.

As for me, I am, after all, thinking to come on horseback! My unfortunate Fritz, who gratefully salutes yr Ladyship, has to the eye become a perfect fright,—Jane wd explain to you by what accident. He has been shoe-less, out at grass, for a week; I had him brought in today, for a look at him: he is ten times uglier than ever (has been rubbing himself on posts &c), and in fact I have never seen a handsome fellow fallen so out at elbows on the sudden,—more like a costermonger’s horse, than a respectable Philosophical Historian’s!— — However, as the poor creature has intrinsically all his old speed, strength and willingness, and may be of immense convenience to me in your woody solitudes & interesting localities, I almost (or altogether?) decide to bring him, all the same;—and shall arrive most probably by Staines Bridge (a pretty ride of 20 miles or so, if all go well); and (I should think) most probably too after the Better Half’s arrival.— — I do not design to be heavy on work while we are with you: fresh air, riding, walking, driving abt under the fresh sky, will be perhaps a better investment of my industries and your kindnesses,—tho’ I will bring something, too, for odd hours, and to keep my hand in use. At present (Proofsheets &c up to the chin, and time nr done) I am in vast hurry, and need not keep you by the Apron-string any longer.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WD[WDO], 16 Sept. MS: NLS 1797.50. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.dateline: The Dowager Countess of Sandwich / Harewood Lodge Sunningdale / Staines 16th Sept. /61
docBody.p:
I hope you are well!— And happy in your mind; which is indeed nine tenths of everything!— And I hope you are still intending to come to London in
october; and that I shall have the joy of seeing you there again—you and Her!Jane Dods.— Bless you!, there are so few joys in the world now (don’t you remark that?) and so little power of enjoying joy when one has a chance at it! no wonder if I hold much to the prospect of seeing any one, that can still make my heart beat with a certain enthusiasm!

I shall be at Home in another week or ten days I expect;— If anything should send you South sooner than the time your Wife mentioned; send me word to this address. The distance is not so great but that I could go up to Chelsea for a day, on purpose to not miss you.— Do you ever dream? I do, indefatigably! and I have got into the way of regarding dreams as—not prophetic, I am not quite credulous enough for that—but as to a certain extent, suggestive and monitory! I think that good sleep calms down and clears ones ideas, so that one’s dreams, in spite of their insane incoherency are sometimes worth minding, as being further sighted than one’s waking thoughts—

Now I dreamt last night, without the slightest apparent connection with anything that had been occupying me the preceding day,—without, to say the truth, my having, to the best of my remembrance, so much as once thought of you that day!—that I was standing with you at the stile in B’abbies Butts, and saw you drawing a mathematical figure on one of my (present) visiting cards—And while standing there the Babbies Butts stile changed itself, more insensibly than any “Dissolving View“Pictures produced on a screen by a magic lantern, one gradually disappearing while another appears. ever did, into a gate in Battersea FieldsBattersea Fields, common land on the S side of the Thames, opp. Chelsea; in their early years in Cheyne Row the Carlyles often walked there (see 12:229TC to JAC, 23 Aug. 1840, and 16:240JWC to JW, 7 July 1843); by the mid-1850s it had become notorious as a site for illegal racing, gambling, and drinking; see also 30:242JWC’s Journal, 13 April 1856. on which, when I first lived in London, I used to swing (!!) when nobody was in sight!— And I looked up at your face in a perplexed frame of mind; and was still further perplexed by finding it your young face!—the face that owned the white cotton stockings!See JWC to WDWDO, 29 April. But I was perfectly well aware that my face wasn’t the same that borrowed the stockings, and while I was making a great mental effort to understand and reconcile things; a Railway train swept past, and I knew, without having seen how, that you had gone in one of the carriages! And we hadn’t exchanged words, and that was all; and I awoke in a state of vexation. And therefore it is that I write today to tell you where I am and for how long. So guard against the disappointment which my dream put into my head as not unlikely if I didn’t take care. Love to your wife—
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 19 Sept. MS: NLS 517.25 and 518.74. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I had a short Note from the Doctor two days ago, and some hopes of another, or two others one from you & another from him, neither of whh latter have come. I suppose probably you have lost my exact address: I learned from the little that already came, what was important, that you are all in your usual way of welfare,—nothing worse among you than wet weather, and hagglings with the tail of Harvest.

We came out here exactly this day (Thursday) gone a week: Jane went by railway, taking all the luggage; it is about an hour and ten minutes by a good train till you land within two miles of this. I rode out, took my horse after all in spite of the accident whh he had met with to his skin; I had a good day, and a pleasant Country, the last twelve miles of whh were new to me; on the whole both horse and I did very fairly, tho’ it took us 4 or 5 hours, and I had a great difficulty spiering my way after I got into the Forest. It is such a country for roads, for multiplicity of roads, as I think is not elsewhere in the world; scattered everywhere with House of Gentry; and this Harewood is a place of no distinctn, except for the common Owner’s name, whh I did not know. At last a fat good man, a watchmaker at EghamEgham, village about 6 mi. (9.5 km.) ENE of Harewood Lodge; watchmaker un-identified. asked me if “the Lady I was going to did not keep a French Cook?“Probably William; see below, n. 4. By guess I considered I might safely answer “Yes.“ Upon whh the good man joyfully directed me, with perfect accuracy as it proved! A “Lord Wm Paulett“Maj. Gen. Lord William Paulet (1804–93; ODNB), army officer. usually occupies the house; him everybody in the neighbourhood knew; & my watchmaker had heard that there was to be a Lady very grand indeed “with a French Cook“ and all the other trimmings resident in the place for a couple of months. Thanks to the French CookApparently called William; see JWC to Lady SLS, [24 Sept.]. for that at any rate; tho’, except it be good hot coffee that he makes in the morning I owe him nothing but mischief on other grounds.

Jane does very well here; I not so well,—owing to French Cookeries (whh do honest mutton and beef very ill), and still more to a French Bed (sorrow on it), whh I sometimes liken to “big potatoe-scull“A shallow wicker or wood-lath basket shaped like a scoop and used for carrying potatoes, peats, turnips; for TC’s experience of scull-shaped beds in Germany, see 27:277TC to JAC, 9 Sept. 1852. given one to sleepMS 517.25 ends here. in,—
curtainless, crooked, hard, strait and in every way rather detestable than otherwise.

For the rest we are quiet as mice; there have been only one or two people here,Miss Raikes and Lady Elizabeth Emily Bertie; see JWC to IEB, [22 Sept.]. and the last of them went to-day. Our good old Lady (age 82, but full of spirit, tho’ weak in body, and often sickly) never comes down [till]Inserted by another hand. 2 or 3 p. m.: all forenoon the House with lawns and gardens are silent as the valley of Jehosaphat;Probably the valley where Jehosaphat overcame the Moabites and Ammonites (2 Chron. 20), after which “the realm of Jehosaphat was quiet: for his God gave him rest round about“ (2 Chron. 20:30). one has liberty to smoke, to lounge abt, to walk, ride and rove at perfect discretion. I have even a little room called the “study“ for my sake: but alas, alas! this is actually the first time I have put pen to paper since my appearance here! An exact fact, tho’ a strange one. The French Cook and the Potatoe Scull are sore agt me. I have had express lumbago from the second day (rather gone now); and have felt nothing but feverish discomfort and inability to do anything but read a little, and ride considerably. The weather has once or twice been damp; but generally is the best that can be in Septr; burning bright in the noon period, sinking into chill at night. I might have staid here for a month, with advantage, and done regular work, had it not been for my perverse Cook and Bed! As it is, I think of being home on Saturday; my longing to be again in a Christian Bed is very considerable.

This is one of the prettiest Countries for riding that one cd find in the world. Fifty or a Hundred Square miles (10 miles each way) of country mostly in wood and park; the finest wood and the finest green, all broken into knolls and vales, that cd be desired. Windsor Park (Queen’s special part of it) is by far the finest I have ever seen: gigantic old oaks, endless shady lanes (to whh you need a key), avenues with Windsor Castle (whh is like a little Edinburgh)He means Edinburgh Castle, not the city. far off at the end of them;—and in particular such expanses of perfect turf for galloping upon as cd not be matched. I have been there once (after long mistake and delay abt the “key“); yesterday, being somewhat bankrupt in the sleep way, I did not ride at all; but today I am off again, preferring much a solitary canter to a drive on wheels.

I had something to write to you about trowsers that I want (if you can get any “Orleans Stripe“);See 34:5TC to JCA, 2 July 1858. item abt a pair of Sponges!See 29:265TC to JCA, 16 Feb. 1855. But I will put it all off till next week and composure again at home. Love to everybody. I am ever Yr Affectionate
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 20 Sept. MS: NLS 525.82. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Yesterday I wrote to Dumfries (to Jean for surety) in answer to yr word from The Gill; and gave a long account of my zero of an existence as carried on here. This morning, lying on the table for me there was the inclosed,Presumably a letter for John A. Carlyle sent to Cheyne Row. successively inclosed in the covers as now sent. Not knowing, when I got to the second cover, but it might actually be for myself, I opened the second cover; but at the first word, stopped short, and now forward to Scotsbrig as the surer place for getting done with it at once. I have no doubt I might have read to the last syllable without harm to you or any of my fellow-creatures; but there was where I stopped short, as evidently steering nowhither.

Having given Jean so much talk about nothing at all, I need not add to it today on the same subject. We have still sunshine along with silence; I am in a haggly rheumatic totally useless posture; sauntering about with paltry printed bubble called “Books“ in one hand, and a long white ’bacco-pipe in the other;—determined to have my ride earlier today, and superadd to it the drive in the afternoon. I am sorry only to say that it will not be tomorrow I get home; it has had to be put off till Monday,—whh gives me still 3 nights of my “Potatoe-Basket“ Dormitory and my too elaborate Form of Cookery. Perhaps the very change will be of a little use. Yesterday I had a fine Canter of Windsor & back, whh must be abt a dozen miles, mostly over turf. Blessed is he that is getting forward with work!Cf. Matt. 5:3–11.— With love to all, Your affecte T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Mr. B[JBUL], [22 Sept.]. MS: NLS 1797.238. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MR. BULLOCK

docBody.p: Harewood Lodge / Staines Sunday [22 September 1861] ;Thanks! Mr Bulock And no more letters please!
We intend being home tomorrow (Monday)
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-IEB, [22 Sept.]. Addr: care of A. Barnes Esq / Surgeon / Kings Road / Chelsea / London. MS: letter NLS Acc. 9086; envelope Carlyle House. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:89–91; Bliss, JWC 289–90. Quot: Hansons, NE 496–97; Simpsons 102.
div3.head: JWC TO ISABELLA E. BARNES

docBody.p: Carina [darling]! Oh Carina! “Did you ever?!“ “No! you never—!“ It has been an enchantment! a bad spell! the “quelque chose plus forte que moi [something stronger than I]“ of French criminals!See JWC to JDJAD, [30 or 31 Dec. 1860].— I don’t think a day has passed since I got your letter—certainly not a day has passed since I came here—that I haven’t thought of you, and meant to write to you; only—I never did it!

And why?— Were I to assign the only reason which occurs to me, for the moment; it would seem incredible to your wellregulated mind! You could never conceive how a woman “born of respectable parents, and having enjoyed the advantages of a liberal education“ (like Judge Somebody’s malefactor who “instead of which, had gone about the country stealing Turkies!“)Untraced. should be withheld from doing a thing, by just the feeling that she ought to! altho’ if she had ought to not to she would have done it at the first opportunity! No!— You have no belief in such a make of a woman,—you!—you are too good for believing in her! And—one can’t do better than believe all women born to a sense of duty ‘as the sparks fly upwards’See Job 5:7.—as long as one can!
