For the rest; I should have enjoyed this beautiful place excessively: if Eve hadn’t eaten that unfortunate apple a great many years ago! in result of which there has, ever since, been always a something to prevent one’s feeling oneself in Paradise! The “something,“ of the present occasion, came in the form of Lumbago! not into my own back but into Mr C’s; which made no difference, so far as the whole comfort of my life was concerned! For it was the very first day of being here that Mr C saw fit to spread his pocket handkerchief on the grass—just after a heavy shower—and sit down on it!—for an hour and more!—in spite of all my remonstrances!! The Lumbago following in the course of nature; there hasn’t been a day that I felt sure of staying over the next, and of not being snatched away—like Proserpine—as I was from the Grange last winter!The Carlyles visited The Grange 15–19 Jan.; see JWC to MR, [early Feb.]. In Roman mythology, Proserpine, the da. of Ceres, was snatched away to the underworld by Pluto. For what avail the “beauties of Nature,“Coterie speech; see 35:139JWC to JGCO, 9 July 1859. the “Ease with
dignity“Cf. Cicero, Oratio pro Publio Sextio 15.98. of a great House, even the Hero worship accorded one, against Lumbago? Nothing, it would seem!—less than nothing!— Lumbago my Dear; it is good that you should know in time, admits of but one consolation—of but one happiness!—viz “perfect liberty to be as ugly and stupid and disagreeable as ever one likes“!Coterie speech; see 13:196JWC JF, 24 July 1841.—and that consolation, that happiness, that liberty reserves itself for the domestic hearth! as you will find when you are married, I dare say.

And so, all the ten days we have been here, it has been a straining on Mr C’s part to tear his way thro’ the social amenities back to Chelsea!—while I have spent all the time I might have been enjoying myself, in expecting to be snatched way!—
Tomorrow we to go finally and positively—tho’ the Lumbago is almost disappeared and we were to have staid at least a fortnight

Where are you then? If you are returned to “the Paternal roof,“ no need almost of this letter— But I dare say you are gadding about on the face of the earth “Too happy in not knowing your happiness“Cf. Virgil, Georgics 2:458–59. Isabella Barnes was possibly visiting Ashby-de-la-Zouche, Leics., and her future husband’s family; see JWC to IEB, [3 April]. of having a Paternal roof to stay under! If your Father would take me home for his daughter; and pet me, as he does you; would I go dancing off to all points of the compass as you do? No indeed!
God bless you anyhow, If you are returned, this letter will still be worth while, as enabling me to look you in the face more or less!
docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle
docBody.note: “[The good old dowager Lady Sandwich had this autumn engaged us to go out with her to a pretty little lodge she had hired for a while in Windsor Forest, to rusticate there. It struck us afterwards, she had felt that this was likely to be her last autumn in this world, and that we, now among the dearest left to her, ought to be there. She was a brave, airy, affectionate, and bright kind of creature; and under her Irish gaieties and fantasticalities concealed an] honest even noble generosity of heart, and withal a clear enough discernt, and a very firm determinatn, in regard to all practical or essential matters. We willingly en[g]aged; went punctually;—staid, I think, some 12 or more days,—whh, except for my own continual state of worn-out nerves &c, were altogr graceful touching and even pleast. I rode out and rode back (my Jeannie by railway both times); ‘Windsor Forest’ sounded something Arcadn when I started; but, alas, I found all that a completely changed matter (since the days of Pope and his sylvan Eclogues [Alexander Pope, Windsor Forest (1713)]), and the real name of it now to be Windsor ‘Cockneydom-Unchained.’ The ride out was nowhere pleast, in parts disgusting: the ride back I undertook merely because obliged. During my stay I rode daily a great deal; but except within the Park, where [was] a gloomy kind of solitude, very gloomy always to me, I had nowhere any satisfactn in the exercise, nor did ‘Fritz’ seem to have. Alas, both he and I were getting very sick of riding;—and one of us was laden for a long while past & to come, far beyond his strength and years!— It seems by this Letter, too, I was at times a very bad boy;—and alas, my repentt memory ansrs too clearly, Yes! The ‘lumbago’, indeed, I have entirely forgotten; but I remember nights sleepless; and long walks the morning aftr whh were courageous rather than victorious! I remember the old Lady’s stately ever-courteous appearances at dinner; affecting to me, and strange, almost painful. We had little or no other company: Miss Raikes (elderly), then appd a lady Elizth Bertie (young & in revolt agt Parties); finally for a couple couple [sic] of days Ld Sandwich who alone had any interest for me.— Th[e] little scene even to the very name had vanished from me; and ‘Harewood Lodge’ when I read it here re[v]eals a whole series of things to me,—things sad, now sad as death itself, but good too, perhaps almost great.— ‘Miss Barnes’ a very pretty amiable modest and clever yg Lady was the Dr’s one Daughter; is now Mrs Simmonds of this neighbd (wife of a rising Barrister);—and was always a great favte with my Darling“ (TC’s headnote; MS: NLS 7197.109 inc; Froude, LM 3:88–89 inc); the first two and a half sentences (in sq. br.) are in Froude only; the rest is taken from MS.

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JAC], 24 Sept. MS: Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Never having heard of that strange Isle-of-Lewis AdventureJames Carlyle Jr. was interested in renting a farm at Galson, Isle of Lewis, and had been consulting John A. Carlyle. The farm was widely advertised over the summer; for example, “Farm to be Let In the Island of Lews [Lewis], on Lease, with Entry at Martinmas 1861 / The Valuable Sheep and Arable Farm of Galson … consisting of 15,000 Acres of Moor Pasture … and 500 Acres … of Arable, partly superior pasture and partly under crop. … The Dwelling-House and Steadings are ample and in good repair, accessible by a good road from Stornoway, and there is a regular post. … Steamers ply Twice a Week between Stornoway and Glasgow“ (Dumfries and Galloway Courier, 20 Aug.). James Jr. had written to John, 17 Sept., suggesting John “take the farm and assume me as a managing partner.“ John replied, 18 Sept.: “there would be great risk for you in venturing on so large a concern, & in a place so far off & so new to you in all ways, more especially as you have so little practical experience in the details of farming. … In no circumstances could I undertake the lease myself, for I could not now stand the anxiety & tear & wear of such a concern.“ On 19 Sept. he wrote: “A place so distant & isolated, requiring so much outlay … it seems to me, might give rise to endless disappointment & vexation to everyone connected with the farming of it; & I think your father will be of this opinion too when he considers the details.“ He then wrote, 20 Sept.: “I feel that I know almost nothing of farming & may have made a mistake in regard to it. … Wd your father go with you to see the place if I paid the expenses?“ James replied, [21] Sept.: “My Father thinks it extremely probable that Galson will be got very cheap, but how to raise the necessary capital for renting a place of its size is of course the difficulty with him. … My father is anxious to go and see the place.“ John replied, 23 Sept., that he hoped to see James’s father on Wed., 25 Sept., to discuss it: “I have sent the documents to your uncle in Chelsea, asking him what he thinks of the project, & whether he would be ready in any circumstances to advance the half of the £1800 you need for its execution; & I hope to have his answer by Wednesday’s post, so as to show it to your Father“ (MSS: NLS Acc. 9086). till now, nor having at present any leisure to consider it, I can only say that it looks very
wild and dangerous indeed. A miserable barren drownedJohn A. Carlyle misread “drowned“; when he sent TC’s letter on to James Carlyle Jr., 25 Sept., he wrote: “What your uncle means by ‘doomed’ relates, I suppose, to the languid fixed habits & incapability of change amongst most of the inhabitants of the Western Islands“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). Country, cut off from all the world: it wd seem to me a far likelier thing if a man had skill in sheep and other husbandry, and such a command of money, to go at once to N. S. WalesJames Carlyle Jr. had previously thought of going to Australia; see 36:96TC to JF, 13 April 1860. with one’s faculty and resource, and there plant it down with at least a noble chance of spreading & growing!— My notions, however, in this sudden hurry, are positively worth nothing in regard to the practical affair: but I can say at once that I have at present no such sum as £900 or anything resembling it, whh I could conveniently disburse; or should incline to sink in any Enterprise not of the most pressing necessity. All the less, as money affairs have gone a good deal awry with me, during last year,—owing to badness of trade says Chapman, owing to I know not what;The mid-Victorian economy was marked by several short-term booms and slumps, and political uncertainty in America had affected global trade.—and till once this Book is done, I cannot go into the business at all, to take real order with it.TC wrote in his London checkbook, 24 Sept.: “as marked in / the Pass Book, Balance in my / favour is £128..13..1.“; he added, possibly later, “£140 from Fr Chn was paid / by then (I suppose)“ (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). As TC only kept money for daily expenses in his London bank account, it seems unlikely he was looking to see if he had enough to give James; he kept more money in the Dumfries bank account where, Sept. 1860, he had £3028..12..9 (Robert Adamson to TC, 6 Sept. 1860. MS: NLS 607.559).

I think young Jamie a fine honest spirited fellow; and tho’ perhaps rather sudden and headlong as young men are, capable of doing well in almost any arena where his bodily health did not suffer,—or whh were not quite below his just aspirations in regard to employment. But I own, it has always seemed to me that he is quite unlike Scotch Farming, that his true scene is not there at all, most likely;—and that his Father perhaps ought, tho’ I can well understand how painfully, to ask himself whether in actual fact that is not so?__ Kindest regards to him and to everybody. We both got home yesterday: I riding, Jane by rail. Thank Jean for writing. Yours in utter haste / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S[LS], [24 Sept.]. MS: NLS 19.3.52.21. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 266–67.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p:
Oh my Lady! kind and dear! It is “all right“! or more properly speaking it is all wrong! any way, we are back at Chelsea, with, for outlook, a dead wall (moral
as well as material!)For TC’s description of the outlook onto the “high brick-wall,“ see 7:172TC to JWC, 21 May 1834. to which we may attach what interest we can! and already Mr C has resumed his writing, and I have resumed my house-keeping, (in Mazzini phraseology, my “livings-cares or—what shall I say?—the Cares of Bread“)Coterie speech; see 33:252JWC to TC, 25 June 1858.—more power to our several elbows! My young maids had every thing scrubbed and scowered to “look as good as new“; and ran out to receive me after the manner of Rose and Julia!Possibly Lady Sandwich’s maids, otherwise unidentified. And behind them, with more deliberation and less vivacity, came Mr C! who had arrived a few minutes before me, “in spite of having fed and rested his horse by the way“ (perhaps in virtue of that!) and in spite of having had a strange encounter—with a Being not often met on english highways at the present day—An adder! no less! And no contemptible one, for it was “certainly more than a yard in length, and of a horrid dark green colour,“ and it “crumpled itself all up as it saw him! (no wonder, the wonder is isRepeated on MS. that he didnt crumple himself up too!) and it “quickened its pace accross the road, and disappeared amongst some long grass.“ I should like to hear Friz’s ideas of the stranger-creature, which passed “within a foot of his head.“ What a mercy he didn’t take a notion of setting his foot on it! It was near Blacknest GateBlacknest Gate, S entrance to Windsor Great Park. that the meeting occurred. Some people go coasting over the whole world without ever having an adventure; but Mr C, born under a luckier star, can’t make an innocent little journey of twenty miles without an adventure with a “french Cook“ in going, and with a yard-long adder in coming back!

I am off to Fortnum and MasonsHigh-class grocery in Piccadilly, much expanded since its establishment by William Fortnum and Hugh Mason in 1707. for coffee with “the flavour of William’s“Lady Sandwich’s French cook; presumably his name was anglicized from Guillaume.—and to see a friend who is passing thro’Not further identified.—and to do a variety of things. And so “no more at present“ from your grateful and loving Jane Carlyle

ps.p: I hope the young LadyPossibly Lady Elizabeth Bertie; see TC to JCA, 19 Sept. did not get her cold increased by that long waiting at the Station

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 30 Sept. MS: NLS 517.26. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I know not precisely where you are, nor have any definite guess hitherto of what your next movements are to be: but I calculate this may still find you at Dumfries,John A. Carlyle was to meet James Carlyle in Dumfries on 25 Sept.; see TC to [JAC], 24 Sept. or follow you thence direct to where you are. I have not quite five minutes left; and must be very brief.

From James AitkenTC’s nephew living in London. I have always gathered some vague understanding that there was a likelihood of your coming to London after Annandale: Js Carlyle’s Note,John A. Carlyle had included a letter from James Carlyle Jr. with the letter he sent TC about Galson farm; see TC to [JAC], 24 Sept. too, had the expression, “When you go South.“__ So soon as your mind is made up, I shd be glad if you wd inform me. I do not wish to influence your determination at:—of course the sight of my Brother again, one of the few firm friends still left me in this universe, wd be very welcome: but, on the other hand, I am an “imprisoned creature“ (literally “beating hemp in the Correction House“)See 30:137TC to JF, 6 Dec. 1855. & must not flatter myself or anybody with the hope that poor I can make any place agreeable or worth visiting.John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 2 Oct., “I have had another invitation to Chelsea. … I propose starting tomorrow. … I don’t intend to stay long“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). He stayed 5–14 Oct.— I will say only if you do decide on coming, the spare-room is all in complete state (as I said once already), and is still, and at all times, “ready“ for you, “as a pocket whistle“Coterie speech; see 31:160TC to JWC, 8 Aug. 1856. cd be.— Let us know when you fix.

Yesterday I had Jamie Aitken and Tom Carlyle (of Birmingham,TC’s paternal cousin; see TC to JCA, 25 Aug. who had come up express for the visit: Tom is of a kind of ghastly likeness to his Father,—“Uncle Frank,“ come back with some mournful admixture of BellhoodTom Carlyle’s mother was Elizabeth Bell. in feature & mind. I was as kind to him as I cd manage, poor soul.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HP, 2 Oct. MS: Mitchell Lib., Sydney, Australia. Pbd: Parkes 1:159–60.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY PARKES

docBody.p: We shall be happy to see you on your return to Town.Parkes was sent as a commissioner of immigration and was touring Britain to encourage emigration. He arrived 4 Aug.; he wrote to TC, 25 Sept., enclosing Gavan Duffy’s letter of introduction: “There is scarcely another man living whom I should so like to know and yet I have not called upon you with my letter partly from the pressure of business engagements but much more from a confused fear that I might be considered an intruder. I am now on the eve of leaving London for a week or ten days. … Should it be agreeable to you I shall be happy at the earliest opportunity to pay my respects in person to one whom I have so long admired & honoured from a distance.“ In his letter, 23 May, Duffy wrote: “I have not sent you a single letter of introduction from Australia, and if I break this salutary rule now it is in favour of a man whom I wish to present to you as a specimen of our public men in this new world. Mr Parkes goes to England as agent for the government and Legislature of New South Wales, and he has long held a foremost place in the parliament of that country. / Of the rest I will not speak as you will judge for yourself. But that I desire to introduce Mr Parkes to you is sufficient evidence how much I esteem him.“ Tea is at 8p.m.; in general my Wife and I here over it, and nobody else.Parkes vividly recalled his first visit to Cheyne Row: “I found my way to Chelsea, and with a strange feeling of mingled curiosity and reverence, I knocked at the famous door from which celebrities were often turned away. My knock was answered by a demure young person who at once ushered me into the presence of the grim philosopher and his gentle wife. The evening meal was of the most frugal—thin cakes, I think of oatmeal, and a cup of richly-made tea. After tea my host sat down on the floor with his back straight up against the wall and his legs stretched out at full length, and, charging and lighting a long white clay pipe, he happily puffed away, stopping at short intervals to talk on all manner of things in the style of one of his later books. He spoke unreservedly of great men whom he had known, and he asked many curious questions about Australia, which showed the original light in which he viewed some well-threshed-out subjects of colonisation. For instance, he contended that, if governing men could only free themselves from the trammels of custom and be truly wise, they would remove the Sovereign and the Court and all the machinery of Government to Australia, where the field for national life was so wide, attractive, and unencumbered, and so leave the contracted spaces and the murky atmosphere of England behind them. … He spoke of America and of the Civil War then raging, which subjects were renewed again and again in later conversations“ (Parkes 1:160–61). Have the goodness to name some Evening that will suit you,—and then come, if you hear nothing to the contrary.
In haste Yours sincerely T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WHT, 13 Oct. MS: Trinity. Hitherto unpbd. William Hepworth Thompson (1810–86; ODNB), regius prof. of Greek at Trinity Coll., Cambridge 1853–66.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM HEPWORTH THOMPSON

docBody.p: As I suppose you have not quite forgotten me, I send compliments by my Brother, Dr Carlyle the Bearer of this;—whom a small interest of his own brings round by Cambridge, at present, on his journey to the North. He wishes considerably, for some reasons, to see and examine more or less a bit of Scottish Antiquity called Maitland Manuscript,The Maitland Folio and Quarto MSS, collections of poetry by various Scottish poets, including Sir Richard Maitland of Lethington (1496–1586; ODNB), courtier and writer. The Folio contains versions of “Christ’s Kirk on the Green“ and “Peblis to the Play“ (both described as anon. but also attrib. to James I of Scotland; see also 4:405TC to G, 25 Sept. 1828), two of the poems that John A. Carlyle had been working on; see TC to JAC, 4 Dec. 1860. They are held by the Pepysian Lib., Magdalene Coll., Cambridge. whh lies in some of your Colleges under lock and key, and is not to be got at (as indeed nothing is!) without beginning at the right side, and advancing under guidance.

I can certify with great confidence that my Brother will do the Maitland Manuscript nothing but kindness, and possible benefit, if admitted to it;—and secondly, that if you can help or guide him towards this small object, you will not grudge for my sake to do so; whh will be remembered as a favour done me. And this is all at present;—except to say that I shd like very well to see you in Chelsea again, by some lucky opportunity; and that I am always, with many kind regards and remembrances,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-WW[WIWH], 14 Oct. MS: NLS 517.27. Hitherto unpbd. William Whewell (1794–1866; ODNB; see TC to EOT, 27 June 1840), master of Trinity Coll., Cambridge, 1841–66; known to the Carlyles since the early 1840s; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 137 and 144; Whewell had not then approved of TC; see TC to FDM, 21 Nov. 1840.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM WHEWELL

docBody.p:
May I allow myself the liberty of recommending to you the Bearer, Dr Carlyle my Brother, for a little help whh he requires in regard to some Library matter,—not, I believe, in Trinity, but in some other of your Colleges;
Magdalene Coll.; see TC to WHT, 13 Oct.—a matter probably not of much difficulty, if one knew how to start on it by the right road. Should you be able to afford him any furtherance in the thing, I make no doubt you will be so obliging as do it; and to me it will be a sensible favour.
I remain, with many regards,
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JN, [14 Oct.]. Addr: Oakley Villas / Adelaide Road / N.W. PM: London, 14 Oct. 1861. MS: NLS 554.60. Pbd: Scudder 31–32.
div3.head: JWC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dr Carlyle left this morning for Cambridge—then back to Edinr! so he is disposed of!—

As for Mr C, he is in the highest degree out of sorts—having been all the week put out of his routine—and forced to make himself amiable—for his visitor— He is now in the reaction—a hopeless state of matters for persuading him to go out to tea with me— So you perceive there remains only myself available— And by myself it is too likely I should do no good to your party. But we can try— If I dont hear to the contrary I will drive over for an hour on Thursday evening. Dont wait tea for me if I am not in time—

My love to your womankindPresumably Neuberg’s sister and niece, Rosetta and Gertrude Frankau; possibly also their niece Sally Braun (b. ca. 1838 in Bavaria), listed in the 1861 census as a visitor in the Frankau-Neuberg household.—
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [14 Oct.]. Addr: Holme Hill / Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 14 Oct. 1861. MS: NLS 607.583. Dated by John A. Carlyle’s departure; see JWC to JN, 14 Oct. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
We have been to Lady Sandwich’s, and staid near a fortnight, and have been back as long, and John Carlyle has been here a week. It has been an
unsettled sort of time; but I am going to make a vigorous effort to subside into the old, regular, dull way; and such efforts with me always begin in sorting up my drawers, and paying off my letter-debts— I begin with you; to whom it was my intention to have written from Harewood Lodge. Indeed I had meant to write such a many letters from there!—where I should have no household cares (“Livings-cares“ or “the cares of Bread“ as Mazzini calls them.) and my time and soul entirely to myself till three oclock every day, (Lady S’s hour for coming down). But that was a fond imagination soon dispelled! Oh my Dear! just imagine what Mr Carlyle went and did! The very first day after our arrival—it had rained heavily all morning but suddenly the sun came out—and Mr C went and spread his silk pocket-handkerchief on the wet grass of the lawn, and sat down on it with a book! and in spite of remonstrance continued sitting there for an hour! tho there was a capital seat under a tree within three yards of him!— That is the sort of thing your wise men do!— The consequences of course were pretty severe— He took lumbago; and tho’ it was not bad enough to double him up—it was quite bad enough to make him wretched—and impatient to escape out of the precincts of civilization back to his own den where he might growl to his hearts content. It was such a pity! for the place was most lovely, and there was no racket of company—and Lady Sandwich lets him do exactly as he likes; and except for that lumbago he could hardly have managed to feel discontent, and hardly have managed to fail being bettered by the change. And for myself I should have enjoyed the ‘beautiful Nature,’ and the daily drive in an open carriage, and the emancipation from “Livings-cares“—and all the rest of it, amazingly—if He had only been getting on well. But there was the constant apprehension, on my spirits, of being snatched away—like Proserpine—that day or the next—besides the worry which a husband with a pain anywhere feels it his duty to share with the wife of his bosom!

So on the whole that visit was a failure, tho’ never Hostess took more pains than that dear old Lady Sandwich (80 years old) took, to make it a signal success— In fact luck has not been on my side this great long while back— Let us hope that I shall have a fortunate ‘first foot’ next neyearsThus in MS, for “newyears.“ morning—to bring things round! I had so set my heart on seeing you this summer in your new home! But it wasn’t to be! And so it is no use grumbling about it— That invalided CookMatilda. was only discharged from St Georges Hospital some two weeks ago—what they call cured—but that doesn’t mean fit for any active service—and I dont think she will ever be that again. I got her into a Convalescent Hospital at Walton on Thames.The Metropolitan Convalescent Institution, Walton-on-Thames, 17 mi. (27.5 km.) SW of London; it received “free of charge, poor convalescent patients from the various London hospitals, dispensaries, and from their own unhealthy and ill-provided homes“ (Herbert Fry’s Royal Guide to the London Charities [1917] 174). where she would be kept in all the
comforts of life, without a penny to pay, for one month, But after?— It is really time some former mistress should take her up—for she has lain very heavy on me for a long time now,—Considering that she was just five weeks my servant—

The Welsh girl whom I put in her place continues to do very well and the Hampshire housemaidMargaret (“Button“) Sullivan and Maria Chamberlayne. is also a success— They agree wonderfully considering one is Roman Catholic and the other a Wesleyan Methodist— But they are too young to found any prospect of continuance on them— Girls here, I observe, only strive to do well and to keep a place as long as they are learning their work—having learnt it they must be off to new work and new ways!

My little cook is now up to most cooking that we need— She has a nice easy place of it—and is better off every way than she ever was in her life— But she takes away my breath sometimes— By asking me “if I think it would be a good thing for her to go out to her Sister in Australia“?Ellen Sullivan was in Mantell’s service in New Zealand; see JWC to JGCO, 7 May. or “if I think she would make a good kitchen-maid, to be under a mancook so as to rise to be head Cook in a family“?!! She doesnt call this a family! I dare say she will stay on where she is so comfortable till she has got all the good to be squeezed out of the place—but such speculations coming quite naively out of the little creatures head make me feel I hold her by a most insecure tenure.

How do your new ones go on?The 1861 census listed four servants at Holme Hill: William Haugh (1838–1915), gardener; Jannet McKinnlee (b. ca. 1838), housemaid; Mary Healady (b. ca. 1805), cook; and Mary Johnston (b. 1836), dairymaid.

Poor Mr Adamson! he hasn’t long survived his wifeRobert Adamson, the manager of TC’s bank in Dumfries, d. 10 Oct.; his wife, Ann, d. 10 Jan; see TC to CBCBU, 21 Jan.— Oh dear dear! how all the people of my time are getting wed away!“The flowers of the forest are a’ wede awa’,“ generally taken as a lament for the fallen at the battle of Flodden Field, 1513; the phrase apparently predated the ballad written by Jean Elliot (1727–1805; ODNB); an earlier version had been written by Alison Cockburn, b. Rutherford (1713–94; ODNB); JWC used to play it for TC; see 30:272Ellen Twisleton’s Account of Life at Craigenputtoch.—
My kindest love to the Dr—
Do write soon—does Mrs Grierson come to Holme Hill?— How she must miss you!—
God bless you dearest Mary
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

ps.p: I was asked suddenly by a LadyProbably Miss Raikes rather than the young Lady Elizabeth Bertie. staying at Lady Sandwich’s “if I knew such a place as Thornhill in Scotland“! “Know it“! I said—“certainly I do—what are you wanting with it?“ (She was addressing a letter) Oh “it is the posttown for DrumlanrigDrumlanrig Castle, about 31½ mi. (5.5 km.) NNW of Thornhill, owned by the dukes of Buccleuch. and I want to know if it is enough to put on my letter?“ It made me feel more intimate with her than I had felt before, that she should be addressing a letter to Thornhill.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 17 Oct. MS: NLS 517.28. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I got yr Letter yesterday morning; and will forward it tomorrow, whh is the American post-day:Presumably to their brother Alick in Canada.—along with it, shall go a Copy of the riding Photograph,TC and Fritz in Hyde Park, 2 Aug.; for the original photograph, which included a standing Frederic Chapman, see John Clubbe, Froude’s Life of Carlyle (1979) 559; for the cropped photograph, signed by TC 18 Oct., see opp above . and a P.S. to indicate how we are.—

Thomas Carlyle and Fritz in Hyde Park, 2 August 1861
Charles Gavan Duffy, Conversations with Carlyle (1892)
In reading it, I found a great many little things whh I did not know of before,—Margt Austin’s affairs &c &c.John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 17 June: “[I]f you have any news from Gill in regard to that burble of partnership between Margaret’s husband & his brother, please let me know it. Such partnerships, now that both brothers are married, should be dissolved!” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). Margaret Austin’s husband was Thomas Stewart; his brother James Stewart (b. ca. 1831), m., 23 April, Agnes Tennant (ca. 1837–74) of Hillend Farm, Lesmahagow; for the brothers and Hollybush Farm, see 35:230 TC to SGSOUC, 8 Oct. 1859
. The details about poor old Mary Grier are absolutely painful: yet what remedy, poor old creature? Unless she cd be got into some room quite under your own eye, and away from Nancy altogether;Possibly the neighbor, Nancy Crocket (b. ca. 1803), living in Assembly St., Dumfries; Jean wrote, 6 Aug.: “Nancy’s nursing seems to be mostly when there is somebody there she makes a great fuss. Mary said ‘she’ll no be out lang enow when thou’s here but I mony a time lie mysel lang enough.’” For Mary Grierson’s condition, see also TC to JCA, 3 Aug.
—whh would be difficult to adjust; and might perhaps worsen the matter instead of bettering it, after all! I can give you no advice; except what you do not need, “Help it if you can”;—and for this end, silence in a great many cases, and patient endurance of what cannot be cured, may be a very necessary element in one’s procedure.

The Dr came duly on the Saturday night; staid with us 8 days; and went away, for Cambridge and Edinr, Monday morning last. He was very agreeable, much more so than usual; and I am truly gratified to have seen him
again, poor good soul. I got out of sleep the first evening (owing a little, not wholly, to the increase of talk and excitation, on the thinnest of all human skins); and into sleep I never cd get fairly again,nor have yet quite done, tho’ I am coming on;—but we had some pleasant walks, plenty of free communication; and looked forward to a time when a certain skin, relieved of its harness, wd no longer be such a tissue of raws, or liable to injury from the wind blowing on it, as now. Ah me,—but we must not complain.— On Monday I wd have written after him to Cambridge, had I rightly known how; for in truth I was very sad. Not till this morng (Thursday) did there come any news: “Was to leave Cambridge this morning”; be abt Peterborough (an old Cathedral &c still in that Cromwell Country) tonight; and at home in Edinr before bedtime tomorrow.

The last pair of sponges you sent me cost, I think, 12/;—if this coming pair be as good, I think they will pretty much be all I shall need in the world! No hurry abt them nor abt the trowsers either; the old are not yet done: but they are in fact telling me daily that they will be. If they have Orleans stripe of a black-grey or blue-grey colour, still better if of a nut-brown or analogous shade, and the cloth be good,—you might send me little clippings; and I will have trowsers of both kinds. I mean to send an old pair to Mary’s; and Boyd of CummertreesWilliam Boyd (1811–90), master tailor, Cummertrees. will produce a perfect fit, as usual, according to the type sent. It has some peculiarity abt the waistband (an invention of my own behind there), and differs from Boyd’s wont abt the bottom of the legs. Please remind him of those points when the time comes.

I have got a kind of cold, whh, after wavering about as lumbago, has settled into phlegm in the windpipe; and is troublesome to breathing in late nights. I have remedies on foot,—your old hareskin See 36:24 TC to JCA, 10 [11] Dec. 1859
. again called into duty, as one;—and I expect to put down my Baltic friend again (for it was bathing there that got me that weakness in the breast).TC had caught a cold while visiting the Isle of Rügen on the Baltic Sea in 1858; see 34:170 TC to JWC, 5 Sept. 1858
. Don’t make me another hareskin at least not till you hear. Jane is on the outlook; and if a skin be procurable, there is sewing-talent, and ample time, in one of the maids here.

Your Jim is improving, and doing well: be thankful! Adieu, dear Jean; my kind love to all. Yrs ever affecte
T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 17 Oct. MS: NLS 517.29. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I was very wae to part with you on Monday; yet thankful to have seen you:—had there been a moment my own, I wd have sent a Note after you, on speculatn, to “The Hoop,“Hoop Inn, Bridge St., Cambridge; see also 15:73TC to MAC, 7 Sept. 1842.—for Neuberg’s Note (inclosed, if I can find it!) furnished me an excuse;—but there proved not to be one minute, that day. Neuberg wished to let his Algerine FrenchmanPresumably a French Algerian; not further identified. &c see you: Jane is off by herself (picking up Miss Jewsbury) on that errand: it is in that way that I have the table to myself, and can write tonight. We got no word of you till this morning; were growing impatient; and rejoiced to hear that all yr little matters had gone well, and that you were to be home again, in your own bed,—by the time this will arrive, or before it.

I recovered my sleep in a great measure; but still need certain artillery agt that wheezing in the breast, whh keeps me unpleasantly awake in the middle part of my night, and is quite new withal, & wd fain alarm me, but does not. I have my little blue friend (whh has done me a great deal of good) still sensible in the inner man; & tomorrow morning I design to send “Ol. Ricin[i]“Oleum Ricini, castor oil; this and TC’s “blue friend“ (mercury, taken as a laxative) had long been TC’s remedy both for biliousness (see 15:95TC to JAC, 19 Sept. 1842) and for colds; see 29:183TC to JAC, 1 Nov. 1854. with a plain hint to him that he must withdraw!— Work is going on too: on the whole I am not so feckless and suffering as you might suppose by what you saw. It was a real regret to me that I was so weak queasy and useless when you came to see me. Let us hope I shall have got this Burden of (Prussian) Iniquity off my back before very long; and be in case to give you a joyfuller meeting.

If Edinr feel solitary, why not come back to yr other quasi-home at Brompton?When in London, John A. Carlyle often lodged at 48 Brompton Row; see 36:41TC to JCA, 14 Jan. 1860. Especially if Maitland Ms. & Christ’s KirkSee TC to WHT, 13 Oct. do not promise satisfactorily? Dante I dare hardly counsel you to grapple with. It is far from wise to get into any great mass of heavy work, when one is perhaps on the point of being old witht knowing it! I had no notion what my real age was till this Fritz & I tried a fall or two;—and it always threw me, not I it as in former cases.Referring to Frederick rather than Fritz, the horse. Keep yourself innocent comfortable by all methods, and renounce hard labour; that is really the rule when one passes sixty.John A. Carlyle was 60 on 7 July. I recommend above all things a perfectly comfortable bedroom & lodging! Why shd you not “take
all,“ or whatever part will suit, of Miss O.’sMiss O. unidentified. or any House? Those that come after us—well a little money, not much, is perhaps all that they will be the better of!— Write to me, any way,—oftener, more at large, and soon as possible. And so good night, dear Brother! Yours T.C.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WM[WMAN], 19 Oct. MS: Mantell. Quot: Hansons, NE 492. Mantell wrote “1860“ on the MS; it was written in 1861 after the Carlyles’ meeting with Henry Parkes, early Oct.
div3.head: JWC TO WALTER MANTELL

docBody.p: “Good gracious Alive“! dear Mr Mantell—(allow me to use that favourite ejaculation of London House-maids; it expresses so concisely my emotion at this instant of time!) Oh good gracious alive!— I was taking it quietly, the letter due to you; was fancying at least a week between me and the Australian Mail;The mailships for Australia and New Zealand left the morning of the 20th of each month; see JWC to WM, 22 Feb. and “did design“Coterie speech; see 12:259TC to RMM, 14 Sept. 1840. to make you a handsome return for your two letters and the little drawing— And behold! here I have just received a note from Geraldine dated ‘The Waiting Room’ of some Railway;Probably Waterloo Bridge Station; Jewsbury wrote to Mantell, 19 Oct., that she was “going today to see Mrs Hargreaves.“ The Hargreaves lived at Silwood Park, Sunninghill, Berkshire (see 32:53JWC to EDW, 15 Dec. 1856). Jewsbury also reported: “Carlyle is still in the bonds of Frederick and in a somewhat dangerous condition to approach“ (MS: Mantell). excusing herself for not having come to bid me goodby on the plea that “being the last hour for the New Zealand Mail “she had had to leave everything to write to you, as you “were disappointed last month.“

Now if it was the very ‘last hour,’ I am too late as it is! But will scramble a few lines, on the chance of some female exaggeration. Only; hurry is an element in which I can do no good, and the nice long letter intended for you in my head is BurkedSuppressed; William Burke (1792–1829; ODNB) and William Hare (b. 1792 or 1804; ODNB) murdered people in Edinburgh by smothering them, in order to sell the bodies to surgeons for dissection. for this time!
Please God I will question some competent Authority about these Mails, and avoid mistakes in future

Meanwhile just what is uppermost—first, thanks for your letters— When I read the last to Mr C he said “thats all well, write to him and give him my kind remembrance and encourage him (!) to do the poor fellows all the good he
can!Mantell was involved in the negotiations over the reserves set aside for the New Zealand Maori. The Times, 17 Oct., reported: “The Secretary for Native Affairs is Mr. Mantel, a son of Dr. Mantel, the geologist. He is very familiar with the native language.“ Gideon Algernon Mantell (1790–1852; ODNB), geologist and paleontologist. and to be—patient with fools!!“—a singular advice from Mr C don’t you think?—that last! George Cook is in raptures! Geraldine ditto— They are “so glad that you are using your talents“— And I am “so glad“ that you have talents to use!— It is decidedly cheering in so stupid and absurd a world to see a man fit for the place he has to fill—

One word more about Ellen’s SisterMargaret Sullivan.— She is in my service, much to her own content, and also to mine. I really do not think that either on this side the Globe or the other she could easily find a situation better suited for her or which she would better suit than the one she has got into as my Cook. So it would be a pity, I think, that she should be snatched away—like Proserpine—to try unknown fortunes in another hemisphere. Her sister may rely on her being kindly treated where she is. and having as good a master here, as she could possibly find in the “Mr Pyke“(?)Possibly Vincent Pyke (1827–94); having emigrated to Victoria, South Australia, in 1851, he moved to New Zealand, early 1860s, where he was appointed commissioner in charge of organizing a goldfields department 1862. she wrote to her about. She is also very happy in her fellow-servant,Maria Chamberlayne. who is amiable and wellbred and—writes verses!

And now goodby I must despatch this in all haste to Dilberoglue who will know whether to direct it to Aukland or to Wellington,Auckland is in the N part of North Island, New Zealand, and Wellington, the capital, is on the S tip of North Island. Mantell lived in Wellington. and who will moreover send it back if too late—

Do you know anything of Mr Parks the Representative of SidneyHenry Parkes had been one of four liberal M.P.s for Sydney City in the lower house of the first legislative assembly of New South Wales, 1856–58; he then became M.P. for East Sydney, 1859–61, but was currently touring Britain to encourage emigration.—who is in England at present engaged in some Australian business that seems to have a strong flavour of crimping.Luring men into the armed forces; Parkes was introduced at a meeting on emigration at Droitwich, Worcestershire, 10 Oct.: “It had been determined by the Legislature of New South Wales to appoint a commission … to come to this country, and proceed from one large town to another, to explain to the people of those towns the advantages held out by the colony of New South Wales to all those who were disposed to emigrate from this country“ (Times, 14 Oct.). He spent an evening with us last week, and was very entertaining, and I liked his face with large wide nostrils—like a good dog! But oh dear! I am short of time you see!
All honour attend you / Sincerely yours / Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady S[LS], 22 Oct. MS: NLS 19.3.52.49. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY SANDWICH

docBody.p: I intended to write you this very day (at the end of a Chapter of King Frh, when there is “holiday“ for half an hour, if we be in luck!) a word of petition for some news again: and, behold, the news is come; and of the best kind possible, That you are coming home to us again almost directly! I accept the omen; and will hope the next Chapter may go a little better than the last did.

That was a sad procedure of your faithful and obliged but demented Juba, to take himself for a lapdog; and spring upon his poor Lady, with such sorrowful result! Surely it was not you, of all persons, that needed such a bit of help to make front against the daily difficulties that the day brings. You say nothing of it, this time; but I am not sure it is yet altogether off,—but will hope to see it so before this week end.— On the other hand, your little LadiesPerhaps her granddas., Emily and Anne Montagu; see TC to Lady SLS, 24 July. were a comfort to me to think of as beside you. The “morning rays“ are so bright and beautiful; and gild,—in that loving relation especially,—all the other parts of life. Courage, courage: the sun always shines, whether we are in the morning of it or the uncertain afternoon!—

I have done very little good since quitting Harewood & its hospitable solitudes. My work went unusually ill (no part of this sad work has ever gone well); and I have been in a kind of crisis as to health,—changing lumbago for breast-cold, to little advantage; losing sleep, and pining about in a very useless manner,—only fairly a little better, since the last few days. If I can hold out till about the middle of next summer,—perhaps! But there is a great mass of dirty quagmire ahead still. After whh, however, I mean to rest till the end of the chapter, and be perceptibly less miserable. Ah me, ah me, what a change since I began this thing!—

Ld Ashburton has arrived; Baby & Ladyship well; self still considerably gouty:—they were quite fixed at first for a Winter in NubiaNubia, a region in S Egypt and N Sudan; once an independent kingdom. For the Ashburtons’ 1859 trip there, see 35:15TC to LOA, 30 Jan. 1859. again; but the Doctors have relented, and prescribe The Grange instead, whh I am very glad of. The Grange, I am convinced, if he will sit quiet there, will mend him shortly; and “Nubia“ may—stay where it is! But he got yr address; and will probably have himself written. Good b’ye, then, dear Lady,—till Thursday next. Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-HP, 22 Oct. MS: Mitchell Lib., Sydney, Australia. Pbd: Parkes 1:161–62.
div3.head: JWC TO HENRY PARKES

docBody.p: Is it a compliment to my judgement or my mercy, your sending the little book of Poems to me rather than to my Husband, “on second thoughts“?Henry Parkes, Murmurs of the Stream (Sydney, 1857). Parkes wrote on the title page: “Mrs Carlyle / With the Author’s respectful compliments / Birmingham Octr 19, 1861.“ Parkes recalled of his first visit to Cheyne Row: “nothing could excel the charming manner of Mrs. Carlyle, whose conversation sparkled with quaint humour and womanly sympathy with noble effort“ (Parkes 1:161). TC later gave the book to Mary Aitken, writing inside the front cover: “Mary Aitken, Dumfries, / With my Blessing: / (T.C. Chelsea, 1868).“
Any how, I am decided to take it as a compliment to something, which you think I have more of, not less of, than my Husband has! and so I thank you heartily

My Husband, who is up to the roots of his hair in work, has bade me thank you in his name for your kind invitation,Parkes wrote later: “Immediately after this visit … I visited the birthplace of Shakespeare at Stratford-on-Avon. While there I wrote to Mrs. Carlyle, asking her acceptance of a small volume of verse which I had published some years before, and suggesting that, as a break to his literary toil on ‘Frederick the Great,’ her distinguished husband should spend a day or two with me at Stratford“ (Parkes 1:161). which “would be a fine thing to accept, he says, if he were situated like other men“!— And I was to explain to you how it was “impossible for him to take any holiday, or have any peace or satisfaction, till this infernal—&c &c“
But Heaven forbid I should [jest]Word unclear. on so wide and woful a theme!

Also I was to tell you, that he “found the AlmanacPresumably one of the many Australian almanacs; for example, Waugh’s Australian Almanac for the Year 1861 (Sydney, 1861). a great curiosity. and that you were “not to suppose that he wished any foul play to the wretched scoundrels of Criminals! only he could not approve of wild attempts to wash black men white!—the thing being hopeless!—
Please come back when you are again in London—
docBody.name: Jane W Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG[AGIL], [25 Oct.]. MS: Pierpont Morgan Lib. Pbd: Gilchrist 98. Dated on MS in another hand, probably Anne Gilchrist’s.
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: I am very sorry for your anxiety—but it is the price one has to pay for the joy of such nice children!— Mr G said you were always in Beatrice’sThe Gilchrists’ eldest da., Beatrice, recovered from scarlet fever, but her father, Alexander Gilchrist was to die from it 30 Nov.; see vol. 38. room— If you ever come down stairs, and have time, I should like to see you— I believe I have had the scarlet fever—

I dont forget that I owe you the price of the first detachment of brown flourUnidentified; for a previous provision of flour by Anne Gilchrist, see 33:221JWC to AGIL, 15 May 1858.—and will pay it with transport when you tell me what it is—

Also I would like to have half a sack of white from the same manGerman flour traditionally contained the whole grain: “In many parts of Germany the entire meal is used; and in no part of the world are the digestive organs of the people in a better condition“ (Isabella Beeton, Book of Household Management [1861] 831).—if he would send that quantity— Would he?— I got some of the German flour I told you of and it is surpassingly beautiful but Mr C cant endure to eat it! it is so tasteless he says— Perhaps he is right—and the flour like Women and Birds and many other things cant be preeminently beautiful and preeminently anything else at the same time—
Would you write the address on the envelope and the order on the paper;—What a nuisance I am to you—

Do you want any books?— Mr C stupidly forgot again about all the year round and sent it off the day after it came—but I have scolded him and he will mind next dayThat is, the next time they received their copy of All the Year Round, published weekly on Sat.— JWC

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AG[AGIL], [ca. 26 Oct.]. Pbd: Gilchrist 98–99. Dated in relation to Beatrice’s illness; presumably written after JWC to AGIL, [25 Oct.], and after JWC was informed of the seriousness of Beatrice’s condition.
div3.head: JWC TO ANNE GILCHRIST

docBody.p: [ca. 26 October 1861]

My Dear Mrs. Gilchrist: I am most sincerely sorry for you in this long solitary confinement. I am sure both your health and spirits must be suffering from it. Do you see any near prospect of getting away with the dear little girl?
or do you never think of sending away the other children to your mother’s;Henrietta Burrows lived at Earls Colne, Essex; see 36:242JWC to TC, 12 Sept. 1860; there were three other children. and so delivering yourself from the tantalizing wretchedness of being so near them and yet separated from them?

What a pity about that new woman! [servant]“[Servant]“ has been inserted in the printed text; unidentified further. if you were to gain nothing but flesh in compensation for cleverness as well to have gone on with the other!Presumably one of the two servants recorded at 6 Cheyne Row in the 1861 census (taken 7 April): Susan Littlejohns, age 29, cook, and Mary Ann Severett, age 20, housemaid. If you had only your feet and hands and heart free again; however, you will be able to remodel your new arrangement one away or other. But it is particularly vexatious to have such a complication, with sickness in the house! I am feeling the cold severely—off my sleep and all that sort of thing!
When lying awake in the dark night I think of you and your troubles on the other side of the wall!

I have no news to tell you but that I was in a room the other day with Miss Frederica Johnstone! a large, fair, goodish looking woman, over forty. She didn’t seem in low spirits on account of her lover in penal servitude, and her own egregious folly in the newspapers!Frederica Johnstone (1818–64) had become engaged, 1858, to Vincent Collucci (b. ca. 1830), an Italian artist; during his absence in Italy in 1859 she broke off the engagement and asked him to return her personal letters. He demanded £2,000 for them, to which she agreed, but on receiving the money, he handed her a package which she later discovered to contain old newspapers. Collucci was tried, found guilty of obtaining money under false pretences, and given three years’ penal servitude. The Times reported, 24 Oct., the trial at the Old Bailey; in an editorial, 25 Oct., it commented: “Miss Johnstone dealt with him very sensibly after a while, and was, perhaps, actuated as much by benevolence as fear in yielding to some of his demands.“

I send a letter from Madame VenturieEmilie Venturi, in Italy; JWC apparently replied, as Venturi wrote, 26 Dec. 1861, thanking JWC for her letter of 31 Oct.: “I am delighted to know you liked Charlotte Cushman. She is a dear good soul, with far less of the actress in her than most actresses, & worth loving, which to my way of thinking few artists are“ (MS: NLS 1774.218). It was due to her that JWC had agreed to meet Cushman, who wrote to JWC, 16 Nov. 1861: “I want to write to Emilie Hawkes—did she not make you see me—& how much do I not owe her“ (MS: NLS 1774.216). in case it might amuse you to read it—if not, have no delicacy as to returning it unread. Tell me if you have any leisure or spirits to read an amusing novel. I have one on hand— Give poor little Beatrice a kiss for me,
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JJR, 29 Oct. MS: Yale. Pbd: Sanders, “Carlyle’s Letters to Ruskin“ 218; Cate 93.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN JAMES RUSKIN

docBody.p: You are abundantly kind and obliging. If it please Heaven, I will come to Denmark Hill some day again, and stay dinner! Shd November 17th prove favourable in point of weather,TC had ridden out to Denmark Hill, Sun., 27 Oct., to ask after John Ruskin, who was in Switzerland; see TC to JAC, 30 Oct. John James Ruskin wrote, [28] Oct., saying how disappointed he had been that TC had not stayed longer. He then invited TC to return “before ½ past 4 on Sunday fortnight [17 Nov.] … when there will be a full Moon“ (MS: Yale).—more especially a certain paltry little “breast-cold“ whh I have caught, be tolerably shaken off,—Novr 17 shall be the day. In the opposite case, I will at least be punctual to give notice the day before. So that if you hear nothing, it is all right.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 30 Oct. MS: NLS 525.83. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Thanks for your long good Letter; thanks for the Rulhière and the short one,TC refers to Claude-Carloman de Ruhlière, Histoire de l’anarchie de Pologne et du démembrement de cette république; suivie des anecdotes sur la révolution de Russie, en 1762, 4 vols. (Paris, 1807); see Works 19:45; and to a one-vol. edn. in English of Ruhlière’s The History, or Anecdotes, of the Revolution in Russia, in the Year 1762 (1797); see Works 18:434. TC’s copies: HCC. whh had arrived punctually some days before. I am glad you are established in your old place, among your old connexions,—and that Erskine, for one item, is to be yr neighbour again this winter.Thomas Erskine spent much of each winter at 16 Charlotte Sq., Edinburgh. One finds few such companions left in the world; I may say that, here in my circles, I have none such at all.

It was not you that took away my sleep while you were here; it was a bad combination of many things, and a “crisis“ that had come, as I sometimes told you. I ought to have applied to my blue friend weeks, perhaps months before:—I am now a great deal better by his help; and going on, almost up at the old level; sleep &c not to be complained of at all. The ph[l]egmatic windpipe (whh was very annoying in your time) has yielded mostly to a warm hareskin,—has changed itself latterly, I think, into a weak cold in the nose, and does not annoy me farther. In fact I am as well as I was this time twelvemonth; & tho, weak and old, expect to get my vile burden shuffled off,
on honourable terms, in the course of 8 or 10 months, if I luck. I do not overwork myself, at least try not to do so, or to neglect any wise precaution; but it is frightful to see how little work is to be had out of me; how much of each whole day is spent in [cere]moniesThe first two syllables of “ceremonies“ are unclear. in refections and preparations; hardly four hours of it good for any real exertion, 20 spent in looking back and forward upon these! The Printer has started work again; but it must be at the slowest rate, for a couple of months to come, or he will catch me straightway. Oh if I were but done! You will then be able to come & see me witht danger to sleep!— I sometimes think of a sail to America; of a—great variety of things. Courage, courage!

Henry Watt called here the other night; I suppose he must be with you abt this time. I have never seen Browning yet, except a glimpse on the streets. Ruskin, whom I rode out to ask for, last Sunday, is in Lausanne,—till decr next.Ruskin was in Lucerne, 152 mi. (244.5 km.) NE of Geneva. He wrote to TC and JWC, 7 Nov. 1861, that he hoped to be home by Christmas (MS: NLS 555.11). Woolner has got some fine public work to do at Manchester (sculptures for a Court-House),Thomas Woolner had been commissioned to decorate with statues and high-reliefs the New Assize Courts, Manchester, designed in 1859 by Alfred Waterhouse (1830–1905; ODNB). Woolner worked on them between 1863 and 1867; the statues were of kings and law--givers, and there were two high reliefs of historical subjects, and a third of the Judgment of Solomon with the figures of the Good Woman and the Drunken Woman; see Woolner 339. whh I am willing to hear of. Craik’s BookGeorge Lillie Craik, A Compendious History of English Literature and of the English Language, from the Norman Conquest. With Numerous Specimens, 2 vols. (1861). Craik referred to Carlyle twice; discussing the “preponderance … of the element of narrative“ in Victorian prose, he credited Macaulay and Carlyle with giving “a new eloquence to the language“ (Craik 2:533). He later contrasted Carlyle favorably with Gibbon: “Carlyle’s Germanisms are a thing of a different nature altogether from Gibbon’s Gallicisms. Nor, if his flashing narrative may sometimes elude or perplex a dull apprehension, is it ever ambiguous or obscure from any affected and unnatural indirectness such as Gibbon habitually indulges in“ (Craik 2:538). I have not seen, but mean to look at it one day. We have very cold weather (fierce n.e. winds with foggy sky) for a week past.— Write to me soon, dear Brother, and at large. Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 30 Oct. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: London, 30 Oct. 1861. MS: NLS 553.237. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Dear Neuberg,—I have lost the “Arrest of Trenck,“Friedrich von der Trenck (1726–94), Prussian officer, author, and adventurer; for his arrest and TC’s footnote, “Copy of the Warrant, once penes me [was in my possession],“ see Works 16:131. See also Works 16:157. after all: it was on a margin of the Ms., and has not been printed.
Did not you say you had (with wise precaution) taken note of it yrself? If so, it will now be a godsend to me,—& I shall rid myself of it, & you of it, forever & a day!—

Thanks for the Lützow negative.Presumably Leo Adolph Marquard von Lützow, Die Schlacht von Hohenfriedberg oder Striegau am 4. Juni, 1745. Ein Beitrag zur Geschichte des zweiten schlesischen Krieges (Potsdam, 1845); see Works 16:110 and 119–20. TC’s copy: HCC, where he comments: “an excellent, faithful account, the best I have seen of any battle.“ The “negative“ is unexplained.— I have not yet found the French-Scandal Ms.Unexplained; possibly referring to the scandalous libels pbd. following Voltaire’s induction into the French Academy of Arts, 9 May 1746; see Works 16:210. but shall probably.
docBody.name: T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-[JAC], 31 Oct. MS: Eton Coll. Hitherto unpbd. Addressee identified as John A. Carlyle to whom TC had written the previous day.
div3.head: TC TO [JOHN A. CARLYLE]

docBody.p: Thursday, Octr 31. Last night in walking to the Post-OfficeTo mail TC to JAC, 30 Oct. (Knowing I shd gain no time), I remembered this late Note of Jean’s,Only one page of Jean’s letter has survived: “John is doing as well as it is possible for anyone to do in his place. James saw Mr Gordon the other day & he said ‘He’s a longheaded fellow John; he’s treading on the heels of his seniors already.— He will undoubtedly get promoted if he goes on as he has begun.’ I try to be very hopeful that both James and he shape to go on so well, when so many are very different indeed. / Old Mary Greer is a shade easier although she is getting less bulk every day—she is less helpless than she was having in part got back the use of her leg; & can now get out & into bed with less help & can even walk a little with someone supporting. She has taken a fancy to have our wee Mary for nurse & she has been with her both yesterday & today.“ Mr. Gordon was possibly James Gordon (1809–84), provost of Dumfries, banker, and solicitor, for whom their son John was perhaps working. and that you might like to see it.
Today is sunnier with less wind; still very chill.—Poor Jane had 2 almost sleepless nights, and is staving off a cold (I hope, with success!)— Otherwise all well. Farewell again!
docBody.name: T.C.

div1.p: Volume Divisions of the First Edition of Frederick the Great (1858–1865)

The first edition of Frederick the Great had different volume divisions from those of later editions. To help with clarity in the period of the writing of Frederick, this appendix gives the detail of the books in each volume of the first edition. Anticipating at first a shorter work, the words “In Four Volumes“ appeared below “By Thomas Carlyle“ on the title pages of volumes 1 and 2. Following this listing of the books of the first edition is a breakdown of the volume divisions of Frederick in the centenary edition (Carlyle, Works, the edition used for reference by CL).
History of Friedrich II. of Prussia, Called Frederick the Great. By Thomas Carlyle. London: Chapman and Hall, 1858–1865.

“Double-Marriage Project, and Crown-Prince, Going Adrift under the Storm-Winds. 1727–1730. “
“Fearful Shipwreck of the Double-Marriage Project. February–November 1730.“
“Last Stage of Friedrich’s Apprenticeship: Life in Ruppin. 1732–1736.“
“First Silesian War, Awakening a General European One, Begins. 1740–1741.“
“First Silesian War, Leaving the General European One Ablaze All Round, Gets Ended. 1741–1742.“

“The Surrounding European War Does Not End. 1742–1744.“
Index to vol. 3.
“Second Silesian War, Important Episode in the General European One. 1744–1745.“

“The Seven-Years War: First Campaign. 1756–1757.“
Index to vol. 4.
