div1.p: Thomas Carlyle, History of Friedrich II. of Prussia Called Frederick the Great. Works. London: Chapman and Hall, 1897–1898 (Centenary Edition)

Notes on the Carlyles’ contemporaries referred to more than once in the present volume are given below, cross-referenced to earlier information. Some relatives or old friends who had died before the starting date of this volume are retained because of frequent references to them. Otherwise, individuals are accounted for in headnotes and footnotes as they appear in the letters.

Adamson, Robert (1787–10 Oct. 1861; see 10:23TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838), bank manager of the British Linen Co., Dumfries, where TC had an account; m., 1820, Ann, b. McMillan (1795–10 Jan. 1861); they had two das., Jane (b. 1824) and Helen (b. 1826).

Airlie, Henrietta Blanche, b. Stanley (1829–1921), 7th countess; m., 1851, David Graham Drummond Ogilvy, Lord Airlie (1826–81), 7th earl (see 26:288TC to RF, 23 Oct. 1851). They lived at Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire (now Angus). Their children were Henrietta Blanche (1852–1925), Clementina Gertrude Helen (1854–1932), David Stanley William (1856–1900), Maude Josepha (1859–1933), Lyulph Gilchrist Stanley (1861–1947), and Griselda Johanna Helen (1865–1934).

Aitken, Jean (“Craw “) Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they lived on Assembly St., Dumfries. They had two sons, both named Alexander, who d. in infancy (1834–36 and 1855–56); their surviving sons were James or Jamie (1836–71), who worked in a mercantile house in London from 1858 and lived in Islington; Thomas (1841–69), who was at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854); and John (1843–1911). Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (1848–95), who m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.
Anderton, Sarah; see Dilberoglue.

Ashburton, William Bingham Baring (1799–1864; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and later vols.), 2d baron; politician and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. He m., first, 1823, Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–57; ODNB; see 11:40TC to MAC, 8 March 1839, and 26:ix–xv26:introduction); they and the Carlyles first met in 1839 and became close friends. Ashburton m., second, 1858, Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903); JWC expected not to like her, but was swiftly won over. Their da., Mary Florence, was b. 26 June 1860. They lived at Bath House, Piccadilly, London, and The Grange, Alresford, Hampshire;
they also had a farm at Addiscombe, near Croydon. Where it is necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (1831–74), m., 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–69), farmer at Hollybush; Grace (b. 1833), m., 1856, William Yeoward (b. ca. 1824), of Toronto, Canada; Jessie (b. 1836), m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (b. 1844), m. , 1866, her cousin James Carlyle; Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James (b. 1848).
Bain, Alexander (1818–1903; ODNB; see 18:199JWC to TC, 11 Sept. 1844), psychologist, known to the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1855, Frances Anne, b. Wilkinson (1821–92).
Baring, Louisa (1804–88), and Lydia Emily (1814–68), Lord Ashburton’s sisters; they lived at 23 Princes Gate, London.

Barnes, Dr. Alfred Brooke (ca. 1802–67), physician, living at 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea; m. Susannah (ca. 1804–ca. 1855); their children were Rev. Brooke Cremer (b. 1833), Dr. Herbert Sedgwick (ca. 1835–65), and Isabella (see below); their eldest child, Laura Susannah (b. 1829) was deceased.
Barnes, Isabella Emily (b. 1837), became close to JWC from their first meetings in 1859; see also 35:188. She m., 1862, John Simmonds (b. 1829).
Bertie, Lady Elizabeth Emily (1838–1923), eldest da. of Montagu Bertie (1808–84), 6th earl of Abingdon, and Lady Elizabeth Lavinia, b. Vernon-Harcourt (1816–58).
Binnie, Mary, b. Gillespie (ca. 1794–1866), JWC’s second cousin, widow of Thomas Binnie, living at Prestonpans; she had a son, Thomas (b. 1824), and a da., Mary (see Godby).

Blunt, Abel Gerald Wilson (1827–1902), m., 1851, Frances Mary, b. Forssteen (1820–99); they had seven children, including Reginald (1857–1944). Gerald Blunt was appointed rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea in 1860. His older brother was Henry George Scawen Blunt (1821–99), m., 1846, Charlotte, b. Daniell (1818–86).

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875), Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close to JWC (see 21:82JWC to SS, 29 Oct. 1846, and 24:221JWC to TC, 5 Sept. 1849); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. They had one surviving son, George Pringle (1827–65), who suffered ill health. Three other sons d. in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831). They had lived at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127TC to JWC, 12 Sept. 1843) and moved in 1858 to Upper Stenhouse, Liberton, S Edinburgh.

Brookfield, William Henry (1809–74; ODNB; see 20:156JWC to WHB, 1 April 1846), well-connected clergyman and school inspector; m., 1841, Jane Octavia, b. Elton (1821–96); they had three children (see 36:27736:biographical note).

Browning, Elizabeth Barrett, b. Moulton Barrett (1806–29 June 1861; ODNB), poet; m., 1846, Robert Browning (1812–89; ODNB), poet, TC’s friend since the mid-1830s (see 30:74TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1855, and 133TC to RB, 4 Dec.1855). Robert Wiedeman Barrett (“Pen “) (1849–1912) was their only child. They had been living in Florence since 1847.
Bullock, John (1815–90) from King’s Lynn, Norfolk, letter-carrier, who had succeeded John Piper as the Carlyles’ postman; see 33:64TC to JWC, 1 Sept. 1857.

Butler, Charles (1802–97; see 28:314TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853), U.S. lawyer, financier, land speculator, entrepreneur, and philanthropist; welcome in Britain for his part in handling the threat by some U.S. states in the 1840s to repudiate their bonds; met TC, Nov. 1853, and looked after his Illinois bonds and other American investments; m., 1825, Eliza, b. Ogden (1803–78). They had five children: Abraham Ogden Butler (1832–56), two other sons who d. in infancy, and two das., Emily (b. 1840) and Anna (d. 1877).

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario; m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91). They had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), John (1839–1924), Alexander (see below), James (1846–1924), William (1849–1935) and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–84), who m., 1852, Robert Sims; Janet (1836–1916); and Margaret (1847–1935); see 1:166TC to AC, 23 Feb. 1819. An unidentified son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153TC to AC, 4 May 1843), Alexander and Janet’s son; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and other writings of TC.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–1859). Their children were James (Jr., the younger) (1835–71), who had been working in Glasgow as a clerk but had come home to help on the farm, he m., 1866, his cousin Catherine Austin; John (1836–1901); Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jessie or Jenny) (1843–74).

Carlyle, John (ca. 1792–1872), TC’s half-brother; emigrated to the U.S. in 1837, then moved to Canada (see 12:228TC to AC, 15 Aug. 1840); he lived on a small farm at Mount Pleasant, nr. Brantford, Ontario; m., 1817, Margaret (Peggy), b. Benn (1798–1867). They had five children: Janet (1818–89), Mary (1821–50), John (1825–97), James (1830–1900), and William (1833–1911); the two youngest were schoolteachers.

Carlyle, John Aitken (Jack, “The Doctor “) (1801–79; ODNB), TC’s brother,
physician, and translator; m., 1852, Phoebe Elizabeth Hough Watt, b. Fowler (1810–54), wealthy widow of Fitzjames Watt (1809–48), from Leek in Staffordshire, with four sons (see Watt brothers). She d. in childbirth; the child was stillborn.
Carlyle, Margaret Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; she had lived with James and Isabella Carlyle at Scotsbrig. TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.
Chamberlayne, Maria, from Wiltshire, servant at Cheyne Row from July 1861. Her mother was Ann Chamberlayne, who worked for the Ashburtons at The Grange.
Chapman, Edward (1804–80; ODNB), senior partner in Chapman & Hall, TC’s publisher since 1842 (see 14:37TC to JF, 5 Feb. 1842); m., 1841, Mary, b. Whiting (b. ca. 1820).
Chapman, Frederic (1823–95; ODNB), Edward Chapman’s cousin and junior partner in Chapman & Hall; m., 1861, Clara, b. Woodin (d. 1866).
Charlotte (“Tall Charlotte “) (b. ca. 1826), the Carlyles’ servant, Sept.–Nov. 1860.

Chorley, John Rutter (1806–67; ODNB; see 19:135TC to JWC, 9 Aug. 1845), poet and scholar of Spanish literature, reviewer for the Athenaeum; highly regarded by TC. He helped supervise the building of the soundproof room in the attic of 5 Cheyne Row in 1853 (see 28:245TC to JCA, 11 Aug. 1853, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 154) and assisted in proofreading Frederick (see 34:146TC to JWC, 19 Aug. 1858).

Chrystal, Jeannie, b. Welsh (Babbie) (1818–95), JWC’s cousin; m., 1853, Andrew Chrystal (ca. 1811–83), a wine merchant from Glasgow (see 24:186TC to JWC, 10 Aug. 1849, and 26:81JWC to JW, 11 May 1851); they had a da., Mary (1857–1937). Her regular correspondence with JWC ended after her marriage.

Cooke, John George (known as George Cooke) (b. 1819), stockbroker; he had met JWC in 1856 (see 30:252JWC’s Journal, 18 May 1856) and became a close friend. She described him in 1864: “a man between thirty and forty; tall, strong, silent, sincere; has been a sailor, a soldier, a New Zealand settler, ‘a Man about Town,’ and a Stock Broker!!! “ (Bliss, JWC 319). He lived at 47 Mount St. He had five sisters, including Charlotte (b. 1811), Margaretta (b. 1815), and Louisa (b. 1817).

Craik, George Lillie (1798–1866; ODNB; see 8:207JWC to SS, 20 Sept. 1835), author, prof. of English lit. and history, Queen’s Coll., Belfast, 1849–66; friend of the Carlyles since 1835; m., 1826, Jeannette, b. Dempster (d. 1856; see 10:159JWC to TC, 30 Aug. 1838). They had one son, George Lillie (b. ca. 1825), and three das.: Mary (b. 1827), Isabella (1829–42; see 15:221JWC to JW, 8 Dec. 1842), and Georgiana (1831–95), novelist.

Cushman, Charlotte Saunders (1816–76), actor. Raised in Boston, she came to Britain 1844, where she became friendly with Geraldine Jewsbury, among others; see 20:109JWC to JW, 19 Jan. 1846. She returned to the U.S. in 1849, but moved
to Italy in 1852, spending winters there and much of the summers in England. From 1858 she lived with the American sculptor Emma Stebbins (1815–82). Friendly with Sarah Anderton Dilberoglue, with whom she had acted in Boston in 1852.

Darwin, Erasmus Alvey (1804–81; see 8:152TC to JAC, 15 June 1835, and 9:148TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1837), the Carlyles’ close friend since 1835; brother of Charles Darwin (1809-82; ODNB). Erasmus lived at 57 Queen Anne St. from late 1852; the house number was changed to 6, spring 1860.

Davidson, David (1811–1900), rtd. maj., army engineer, and inventor; childhood friend of JWC. He invented telescopic sights for rifles, shown at the Great Exhibition (1851), and the collimating telescope, 1855; knighted 1894. He m., 1849, Margaret, b. Buchanan (ca. 1822–99); by 1861 they had four sons and four das. They lived at Woodcroft, Clinton Rd., Morningside, Edinburgh. His aunt, Janet Davidson (1782–1869), lived at Craighope House, Court St., Haddington (see 32:196JWC to TC, 23 July 1857).

Dickens, Charles (1812–70; ODNB), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–79); separated from her 1858; see 33:233TC to RWE, 2 June 1858. Their children were Charles Culliford Boz (1837–96), Mary Angela (Mamie) (1838–96), Kate Macready (1839–1929), Walter Landor (1841–63), Francis Jeffrey (1844–86), Alfred D’Orsay Tennyson (1845–1912), Sydney Smith Haldimand (1847–72), Henry Fielding (1849–1933), Dora Annie (1850–51), and Edward Bulwer Lytton (1852–1902).

Dilberoglue, Stauros (1818–78), Greek businessman, philanthropist, and art collector. Born in Smyrna, he moved with his family to Corfu, where they were naturalized Ionian. Stauros lived in England from the mid-1830s; he was a partner in Cavafy & Co., which traded from 31 Threadneedle St., London. He m., 1859, Sarah Anderton, b. Coxon (ca. 1827–69; see 28:21–22JWC to KS, 28 Jan. 1853), actor (Anderton was her stage name). They lived at 13 Barnsbury Park. He became a naturalized Briton in 1861. His sister, Calliope (b. 1835), m., 1858, John George Honiere (b. 1814), general merchant.

Dods, William (1795–1873, see 33:79JWC to GEJ, 11 Sept. 1857), Haddington bank agent; childhood admirer of JWC; he m., first, Harriet, b. Shirreff (ca. 1804–53); they had seven sons: Peter (1828–1905; see 35:25635:biographical note), John (b. 1830), William (b. 1834), George (b. 1836), James (b. 1838), Charles (b. 1840), and Henry (b. 1842); and two das.: Christina (b. 1846) and Harriet (b. ca. 1848). He m., second, 1854, Jane, b. Wilkie (ca. 1809–85). His brother was Thomas Dods (1800–1878; see 33:88JWC to WDO, 19 Sept. 1857).
Donaldson sisters of Tenterfield (Sunny Bank), Haddington: Jean (1770–30 March 1860), JWC’s godmother; Jess (1774–1 June 1860); and Catherine (Kate) (1779–1852); friends of JWC’s mother.

Donaldson, Betty, b. Cundale (ca. 1785–1866), m. Stuart Donaldson (1776–1849), brother of the Donaldson sisters); she lived at 21 Craven Hill, Bayswater. There were nine surviving children: George Hay (1810–72), m., 1844, Emma, b. Russell (1814–85), living at 2 Park Place Gardens, Bayswater; John William (see below); Sir Stuart Alexander (see below); Jane Watts (1814–86); Catherine Anne (1817–95), m., 1842, Samuel Rawlins (1800–1885), probably living at 27 Hornton St., Kensington; Eliza (1819–80); Isabella Sarah (1820–89); Janet (1822–94), m., 1850, William Skilbeck (d. 1905), probably living at 5 Clifton Gardens, Bayswater; and Helen Kay (1826–1913), m., first, 1847, Thomas Bayley (d. 1858); m., second, 1860, Edward Griffith (ca. 1816–71).

Donaldson, John William (1811–10 Feb. 1861; ODNB), philologist, tutor at Cambridge; see 15:63TC to JWC, 31 Aug. 1842, and 35:25635:biographical note. TC had liked and admired him; see 31:160TC to JWC, 8 Aug. 1856.
Donaldson, Sir Stuart (1812–67; ODNB), businessman and politician, lived in Australia 1835–59; m., 1854, Amelia, b. Cowper; they had five children.

Downshire, Arthur Wills Blundell Sandys Trumbull Windsor Hill (1812–68), 4th marquis of Downshire, m., 1837, Caroline Frances, b. Stapleton-Cotton (1815–93); known to the Carlyles since the mid-1850s; see 32:149JWC to MR, 18 May 1857, and 151TC to JAC, 22 May 1857. They had three children, Alicia Maria (1843–1928), Arthur Wills Blundell Trumbull Sandys Roden Hill (1844–74), and Arthur William (1846–1931).
Duffy, Charles Gavan (1816–1903; ODNB), Irish nationalist, lawyer, and politician; emigrated to Australia 1855. He m., 1846, his second wife, Susan, b. Hughes (1826–78).
Dunwoodie, Isabella; see McTurk.

Eichthal, Baron Charles d’, known to the Carlyles since 1835; John A. Carlyle had lived with the Eichthal family in Munich, 1827–28; see 5:277TC to GE, 17 May 1831; see also TC to JAC, 6 Aug. 1830, and 5:134TC to GE, 9 Aug. 1830.

Eliot, George (1819–80; ODNB), pen name of Marian (previously Mary Ann) Evans, author; her novels were much admired by JWC. From 1855 she lived with George Henry Lewes (1817–78; ODNB; see 11:205TC to UC, 16 Oct. 1839), author and journalist, known to the Carlyles since 1835.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erskine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB; see 10:18TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had two widowed sisters who lived with him: Christian
(1789–1866), who m., 1817, Charles Stirling; and David (1791–1867), who m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson.

Farrer, Annie Louisa (ca. 1826–62; see 23:108TC to JAC, 11 Sept. 1848), member of the Ashburton circle; she had an older sister, Mary, who m., 1855, Matthew Edward Tierney (1818–28 Dec. 1860), 3rd bart., lt. col. Coldstream Guards; and five brothers (see 25:228JWC to TC, 23 Sept. 1850). Their mother was Mary, b. Anstruther (d. 1860; see 27:39527:biographical note).
Ferme, Helena Shortess, b. Howden (1810–91), m., 1845, John Ferme (1797–1883); they had five children; see 32:24932:biographical note.

Forster, John (“Fuz “) (1812–76; ODNB; see 6:118TC to GE, 15 Feb. 1832; 11:7TC to JF, 17 Jan. 1839; and TC to JF, 25 Jan. 1839), historian, journalist, and biographer; ed. of the Examiner 1847–55; sec. to the Lunacy Commission 1855–61, and a commissioner from Feb. 1861; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–94), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB); they lived at 46 Montagu Sq.

Froude, James Anthony (1818–94; ODNB), journalist and historian; m., first, 1849, Charlotte Maria, b. Grenfell (d. 21 April 1860); they had two das., Georgina Margaret (1850–1935) and Rose Mary (b. 1852), and a son, Pascall Grenfell (1854–79). He m., second, 12 Sept. 1861, Henrietta Elizabeth Warre (d. 1874; her father, John Ashley Warre [1787–1860], had m., as his third wife, Charlotte Froude’s sister Caroline). They had a son, Ashley Anthony (1863–1949), and a da., May (b. 1867).

Gaskell, Elizabeth, b. Stevenson (1810–65; ODNB), writer; m., 1832, William (1805–84; ODNB), Unitarian minister, living in Manchester; they had four surviving children: Marianne (1834–1920), Margaret Emily (Meta) (1837–1913), Florence Elizabeth (1842–81), and Julia Bradford (1846–1908). She met the Carlyles in 1849 (see 24:50–51JWC to JW, 17 May 1849) and had been friendly with JWC in the early 1850s.

Gilchrist, Alexander (1828–61; ODNB), biographer; m., 1851, Anne, b. Burrows (1828–85; ODNB), also a writer. They had four children: Percy Carlyle (1851–1935), Beatrice (1854–81), Herbert (1857–1914), and Grace (1859–1947). The family lived at 6 Cheyne Row 1856–62.

Godby, Mary, b. Binnie (1826–86), m., 1848, Frederick Godby (1819–57), chief clerk of General Post Office, Edinburgh; they had four children: Hardy Augustus (b. ca. 1850), Mary and her unidentified twin (b. ca. 1853), and Binnie (1855–60). Mary Godby moved in the late 1850s to London, where she was matron of a “Post-office Establishment, “ St. Martin’s-le-Grand (see Carlyle, Reminiscences 163).

Graham, William (ca. 1774–22 Sept. 1860; see 1:274TC to WG, 15 Sept. 1820, 21:96TC to JAC, 20 Nov. 1846, and other vols.), TC’s old friend from Burnswark, 3 mi. (5 km.) N of Ecclefechan; his sister was Elizabeth (1784–21 May 1861); both had been ill for a long time; see 28:364TC to JWC, 28 Dec. 1853.
Grierson, Helen, b. Sibbald (1789–1862), m., 1815, William Grierson (1773–1852), merchant; they had one surviving son, Thomas Boyle (1818–89), with whom she lived at 31 Drumlanrig St., Thornhill.

Grierson, Mary, b. Tait (ca. 1775–1861), m., 1811, John Grierson (ca. 1770–1828); his first wife (m. 1793) was TC’s maternal aunt Jean Aitken (d. 1810); see 4:3TC to MAC, 6 Jan. 1826, and 423TC to JAC, 26 Nov. 1828.

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who had emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838) and Mary (b. 1840). In Canada they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.

Hawkes, Emilie (ca.1819/20?–93: ODNB), da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca. 1791–1855; ODNB, portrait painter), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for women’s rights; unhappily married to Sydney Hawkes, whom she divorced in Jan. 1861; see 30:215JWC’s Journal, 12 Nov. 1855, and 235JWC’s Journal, 27 March 1856. She m., 6 June 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–66). A strong supporter of Mazzini and the Young Italy movement, she wrote Joseph Mazzini: A Memoir (1875).
Hill; see Downshire.

Howden, Dr. Thomas (1787–1868; see 24:153JWC to JAC, 28 July 1849), partner of JWC’s father; m. Helena Shortess, b. MacNaughton (1785–1858), and lived at Maitlandfield, Haddington. They had 13 children, including Helena Shortess (see Ferme), Jane (1820–93), and Agnes Catherine (1829–1906) who lived with them. One of their sons, also Thomas (1812–1900), medical practitioner, lived in JWC’s old house in Lodge St., Haddington, with his second wife, Jessie Cunningham, b. Mylne (1833–90); his first wife was his cousin Agnes, b. Howden (1826–44).

Hunt, James Henry Leigh (1784–1859; ODNB), poet, essayist, and journalist; m., 1809, Marianne, b. Kent (ca. 1788–1857). They had nine children. They had first met the Carlyles 1832 (see 6:135–36TC to AC, 19 Feb. 1832) and had lived at 4 Upper Cheyne Row 1833–40; see also Carlyle, Reminiscences 138. Their eldest son was Thornton Leigh Hunt (1810–73; ODNB), poet and essayist; he edited his father’s works.

Irving, David (1778–10 May 1860; ODNB), scholar, biographer, and librarian; m., first, 1810, Anne Margaret, b. Anderson (d. 1812), with whom he had a son, Robert (b. 1811, d. by 1860); m., second, 1820, Janet, b. Laing (ca. 1788–1865), with whom he had two sons, James (b. 1822), a surgeon with the East India Company in Bengal, and David (1824–45); and two das., Janet (b. 1828) and an unidentified da.
Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB; see 1:92TC to RM, 12 Feb. 1817, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.
Jane (“old Jane “) (b. ca. 1789), the Carlyles’ servant Aug. 1860.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–80; ODNB; see 12:103–4TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; a friend of the Carlyles, particularly of JWC, since 1841. For her sister, Maria Jane (1800–1833), also a writer, see 30:215JWC’s Journal, 12 Nov. 1855. Her brothers were Thomas Smith (b. 1802), Henry Richard Smith (1803–73), Arthur (b. 1815), and Francis (Frank) Harding (1819–78), who m., 1853, Emily, b. Vandeburgh. Jewsbury lived with Frank in Manchester until summer 1854; now living in London at 41 Markham Sq. She met Walter Mantell (see below) late 1856 and fell in love with him; he did not reciprocate, but they remained close and exchanged over 500 letters in the course of their friendship.
Laing, David (1793–1878; ODNB), antiquary and librarian of the Signet Library, Edinburgh, from 1837 until his death.

Langley, Samuel (b. 1823), impoverished writer, from Cork. TC paid Langley to do some museum research for him 1859–60, and gave him various charitable donations, 1859–66, from Lady Harriet Ashburton’s bequest; for the bequest, see 34:82–83TC to LOA, 29 July 1858, and for contributions to Langley, see 35:25935:biographical note.

Larkin, Henry (1820–99), collector or cashier for the Chelsea Steamboat Co.; partner in an engineering business. His Extra Physics and the Mystery of Creation (1878) included an appendix (written in 1858) giving an analysis of Sartor Resartus; also author of Carlyle and the Open Secret of His Life (1886). For TC’s early contacts with him, see 25:322TC to HL, 29 Dec. 1850, and 27:78TC to HL, 29 March 1852. He worked on TC’s indexes and maps from 1856; see 34:57JWC to TC, 19 July 1858. He lived at Elm Cottage, Old Brompton Rd., having previously lived with his brother John Richard Larkin (1818–76), who also helped TC with maps for Frederick, at 2 Little St. John’s Wood Villas, Blackstock Lane, Highbury. He also had a brother Richard (b. 1825) and a sister Ann (b. 1821). He m., 1862, Louisa, b. Wagstaff. His mother, Charlotte, b. Brett (ca. 1785–1862), lived nr. Hoxton.

Lincoln, Abraham (1809–65), lawyer and politician; president of the U.S., inaugurated 4 March 1861. He m., 1842, Mary, b. Todd (1818–82), and they had four sons, only one of whom survived into adulthood. He was assassinated 14 April 1865, less than a week after the end of the Civil War.
Mackenzie; see Stewart-Mackenzie.

Macready, William Charles (1793–1873; ODNB), actor-manager; retired 1851, the Carlyles’ friend since 1839. He m., 1824, Catherine Frances, b. Atkins (1806–52); they had 10 children, of whom at least five d. young. He moved to Wellington Sq., Cheltenham, early 1860, and m., 3 April 1860, Cecile Louise Frederica, b. Spencer (1827–1908), with whom he had a son, Cecil Frederick Nevil (1862–1946).

McTurk, Robert (1793–30 May 1860), old friend of JWC; m., 1827, Janet, b. Hastings (ca. 1802–71); they had one son, James Hastings (1832–ca.
1844). They lived at Hastings Hall, Moniaive, Dumfriesshire. His sister Isabella (ca. 1802–99), m., 1836, William Dunwoodie (1790–1848), farmer at Townhead, Dumfriesshire; they had five das. His father, James McTurk, had owned Strathmilligan, 8 mi. (13 km.) N of Craigenputtoch, where JWC’s maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh, had lived.

Mantell, Walter Baldock Durant (1820–95), politician and naturalist; b. in Sussex, England, he settled in New Zealand in 1840. He held various official posts connected with purchasing land from the Maori, taking leave of absence in 1855 and coming to Britain to protest against unfulfilled promises. He met Jewsbury late 1856, and corresponded extensively with her on his return to New Zealand in Oct. 1859. He was elected to the New Zealand House of Representatives, 1861, and held the post of Native Minister for a few months, before resigning again in protest at the treatment of the Maori; see also 33:276–77.
Matilda, elderly widow, cook at Cheyne Row June 1861; she went into St. George’s Hospital on 3 July, stayed there until late Sept., then went to a convalescent home.

Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–72; see 11:225TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839, and 28:xiii—xiv28:introduction), Italian revolutionary; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s. He was usually based in London, but continued to encourage active Italian resistance to Austrian domination. His mother was Maria, b. Drago (1785–1852).

Mill, John Stuart (1806–73; ODNB), utilitarian philosopher and economist, administrator at India House since 1823; m., 1851, Harriet Taylor (1807–58), widow of John Taylor (1796–1849), who strongly influenced his thinking. He met TC in Sept. 1831 (see 5:398TC to JWC, 4 Sept. 1831); they remained on friendly terms even after the MS of vol. 1 of The French Revolution was burned while in Mill’s keeping (see 8:66–68TC to JFR, 7 March 1835), but later became estranged because of many differences in temperament and attitudes to social questions; Mill also believed that TC and other friends disapproved of his marriage.

Milnes, Richard Monckton (1809–85; ODNB; see 9:8TC to JAC, 14 July 1836, and 12:9–10TC to RWE, 6 Jan. 1840), author, and M.P. for Pontefract 1837–63; lived at 16 Upper Brook St., London, and Fryston Hall, Yorkshire; the Carlyles’ friend since the late 1830s despite political differences; Milnes supported religious and civil liberties, and championed progressive causes, such as education for the working class and prison reform. He m., 1851, Annabella, b. Hungerford Crewe (1814–74); they had two das., Amicia Henrietta (1852–1902) and Florence Ellen (1856–1923), and a son, Robert Offley Ashburton (1858–1945).
Napoleon III (Louis Napoleon) (1808–73), emperor of France from 1852. He m., 1853, Eugénie, b. de Montijo (1826–1920); their son was Napoleon Eugène Louis Jean Joseph (1856–79), prince imperial.

Neuberg, Joseph (“The Beauty “) (1806–67; see 11:231TC to JN, 21 Dec. 1839, and 25:33925:biographical note), a Jewish German businessman who had worked in Nottingham; naturalized British 1845, and retired from business; m., 1841, Marian (d. 1848; see 23:77JWC to JN, 22 April 1848). He was introduced to TC, whom he had long admired, by Emerson, 1848; helped TC as an unpaid sec., translated his work, and twice accompanied him on visits to Germany (1852 and 1858). From 1856 Neuberg lived at 25 Oakley Villas, Adelaide Rd., with his widowed sister, Rosetta (or Rosette) (ca. 1816–98), who had m., ca. 1851, Adolph Frankau (1820–56; see 32:32TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1856), and her two children, Frederick Joseph (b. 1854) and Gertrude Rosette Adolphine (b. ca. 1856). After Frankau’s death, Neuberg managed Frankau’s company, which imported meerschaum pipes and fancy goods, at 25 Clements Lane, Lombard St., London.

Newnham, Ann, b. Mattock (b. 1809), cook, who sometimes helped out at Cheyne Row; see 33:198JWC to MR, 29 March 1858. She m., 1839, Samuel Newnham (b. 1807); they had four children: Samuel Richard (b. 1843), m., 31 Aug. 1861, Louisa, b. Prentice (b. 1844); Ann (b. 1846); Hannah (b. 1848); and Benjamin (b. 1854).

Oliphant, Margaret Oliphant Wilson (1828–97; ODNB), novelist, biographer, reviewer, and misc. writer; she m., 1852, her cousin Francis Wilson Oliphant (1818–59; ODNB); their children were Margaret Wilson (1853–64), Marjorie (1854–55), a son who d. at birth (1855), Cyril Francis (“Tids “) (1856–90), and Francis Romano (“Cecco “) (1859–94). Her mother was Margaret Oliphant Wilson (ca. 1789–1854) and her father Francis W. Wilson (ca. 1788–1858).

Palmerston, Henry John Temple (1784–1865; ODNB), 3d Viscount Palmerston, politician; m., 1839, Emily, b. Lamb (1787–1869), widow of 5th Earl Cowper (1778–1837). Whig prime minister 1855–57 and 1859–65.

Parkes, Henry (1815–96; ODNB), Australian politician and journalist; he m., 1836, Clarinda, b. Varney (1813–88), and they emigrated 1839. He entered politics in 1854, and was sent on a lecture tour of Britain, 1861, to encourage emigration.

Pepoli, Elizabeth, b. Fergus (1792–1862; see 8:223JWC to TC, 12 Oct. 1835, and 13:86JWC to TC, 9 April 1841); old Kirkcaldy friend of the Carlyles; m., 1839, Count Carlo Pepoli (1796–1881; see 8:194–95JWC to JCA, 13 Aug. 1835), poet, prof. of philosophy at Bologna, and political exile after the failed revolution against papal govt., 1831; he returned to Bologna 1859; she lived at Felsina House, 11 St. George’s Ter., Kensington.
Piggott, Sarah (b. ca. 1844), the Carlyles’ servant Sept. 1860–June 1861.

Plattnauer, Richard, political refugee from Prussia; see 22:10JWC to HW, 5 July. Friend of the Carlyles since the mid-1840s; see 18:194JWC to JW, 29 Aug. 1844; had been tutor to the Downshire children; see 32:151TC to JAC, 22 May 1857. He suffered periods of insanity.

Pott, Janet, b. Hunter (1827–1912), JWC’s cousin (see 28:367JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1853, and 29:39JWC to MR, 3 March 1854); she
m., first, 1847, Dr. Andrew Pringle (1820–58), of Lann Hall, nr. Thornhill. They had three sons: Andrew (b. 1850), Robert Hunter (b. 1852), and John James (b. 1855); see 29:228JWC to MR, 30 Dec. 1854. She m., second, 1859, Gideon Pott (1824–1905), farmer of Knowesouth, nr. Jedburgh; their son George was b. 21 Dec. 1860.
Raikes, Miss, elderly friend of Lady Sandwich, not further identified; see 33:60TC to JWC, 31 Aug. 1857.

Rennie, George (1802–60; ODNB), sculptor and politician; old Haddington admirer of JWC; see 2:17JBW to EA, 15 Jan. 1822. He m., 1824, Jane, b. Rennie (1800–1866), whom JWC thought “a perfect fool “ (see 7:253JWC to EA, 1 Aug. 1834). They had three sons: George (b. ca. 1826), retired army officer; William Hepburn (1829–74), auditor general in Hong Kong and lt. gov. of St. Vincent 1871–72; and Richard Temple, barrister; see 35:48–49JWC to BB, 3 March 1859.
Robson, Charles, of Robson, Levey, & Franklyn, printers, 23 Gt. New St., Fetter Lane. Robson had been TC’s printer since 1837.

Ross, Katherine Susan (Kate) (1834–27 Nov. 1860), da. of John Sterling (1806–44; see 8:125TC to JSM, 1 June 1835). She m., 1856, Alexander J. Ross (1819–87), theologian, and they had two das., Charlotte Susan (1857–82) and Katherine Mary (1858–80). They lived in Brighton. JWC had been particularly fond of Kate Sterling but strongly disapproved of her marriage; see 27:187JWC to TC, 27 July 1852, and 30:234JWC’s Journal, 25 March 1856.
Rouse, James (ca. 1827–95; see 31:25731:biographical note), the Ashburtons’ doctor; TC liked him.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–97); marriage annulled 1855. He lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), wine merchant, and mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–1871). He was J. M. W. Turner’s foremost admirer and was strongly influenced by TC.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145TC to AC, 7 April 1832); close friend of JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859. Her father was Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65TC to JWC, 9 March 1842).

Sandwich, Mary Anne Julia Louisa Harriet, b. Lowry-Corry (1781–1862; see 23:103TC to MAC, 3 Sept. 1848), dowager countess; da. of Armar Lowry Corry (1740–1802), 1st earl of Belmore, Irish politican. She m., 1804, George John Montagu (1773–1818), 6th earl of Sandwich; her children included Lady Harriet Ashburton and John William Montagu (1811–84), 7th earl of Sandwich. He m., 1838, Mary, b. Paget (ca. 1823–59); they had six children: Edward George Henry (1839–1916), Victor Alexander (1841–1915), Sydney (1842–60), Oliver George Paulet (1844–93), Emily Caroline (1847–
1931), and Anne Florence Adelaide (1849–1940). Lady Sandwich lived at Hinchinbrook in Huntingdonshire and at 46 Grosvenor Sq. in London.
Silvester, John, livery stable owner, Upper Church St., Chelsea. His wife was Phoebe (ca. 1800–1865).

Sinclair, Sir George (1790–1868; ODNB; see 24:18–19TC to SGS, 10 April 1849), politician; m., 1816, Lady Catherine Camilla, b. Manners (1792–1863). They had a son and three das. (see 36:28636:biographical note); the youngest, Olivia Sophia (1823–94), became a travel writer. Sir George’s sister Catherine (ca. 1801–64) was also an author. His father was Sir John Sinclair of Ulbster (1754–1835; ODNB), politician and agricultural improver.

Southam, Charlotte, b. Watson (1842–1905), the Carlyles’ maid until June 1861; orphaned in childhood, she had been adopted by her uncle and aunt, Thomas (1806–64), a waterman, and Elizabeth (b. ca. 1805) Southam, whose surname she took; Elizabeth is often referred to as Charlotte’s mother; they lived in Lawrence St., near Cheyne Row. Charlotte worked for the Carlyles June 1858–Aug. 1860 and Nov. 1860–June 1861, and then continued to visit and correspond with them both. She m., 1866, Adolphus James Mills (b. 1842), a carpenter; they had five sons: Adolphus Berby (b. 1869), Thomas (b. 1871), Alfred George (b. 1875), Ernest (b. 1876), and Edward (b. 1880).

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–95; ODNB), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–69; ODNB; see 12:59TC to JAC, 27 Feb. 1840), Whig politician, who succeeded as 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, 1850; living at Alderley Park, Cheshire. Both were friends of the Carlyles. Lord Stanley was nicknamed Lord Ben after Sir Benjamin Backbite, a character in Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s School for Scandal (ca. 1780) (see 35:26435:biographical note). They had nine surviving children: Henry Edward John (1827–1903); Alice Margaret (1828–1910), m., 1853, Augustus Henry Lane Fox-Pitt-Rivers; Henrietta Blanche (see Airlie); Maude Alethea (1833–1915); John (“Johny “) Constantine (1837–78); Edward Lyulph (1839–1925); Katherine Louisa (1842–74; ODNB); Algernon Charles (1843–1928); and Rosalind Francis (1845–1921).
Stebbins, Emma; see Cushman.

Sterling, Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–71; ODNB; see 9:103TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836, and later vols.), soldier; awarded KCB, 21 July 1860. Friend of the Carlyles since 1837. He m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67JWC to HW, 12 Nov. 1844, and 19:9JWC to HW, 9 Jan. 1845). Guardian, 1844–53 (see 28:318JWC to KS, 19 Nov. 1853), of the younger children of his brother John (1806–44; ODNB): Anna Charlotte (Lotta) (1833–67), Katherine Susan (Kate) (see Ross), Julia Maria (1836–1910), Hester Isabella (1843–1908), and John Barton (1840–1926); though not of John’s elder son, Edward Coningham (1831–77; see 19:9JWC to HW, 9 Jan. 1845).

Stewart-Mackenzie, Mary Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–1862; ODNB), chief of Clan Mackenzie; she m., second, 1817, James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843); on their marriage the name Mackenzie was added to that of Stewart. They lived at Brahan Castle, Ross-shire. They had six children, including Lady Louisa Ashburton, and George Augustus Stewart-Mackenzie (1824–52) who m., 1850, Maria Louisa, b. Marriott (b. ca. 1826).
Sullivan, Margaret (“Button “) (b. ca. 1841), from Limerick, Ireland; servant at Cheyne Row from early June 1861; previously at 47 Mount St.

Tait, Robert Scott (1816–97), portrait painter and pioneer photographer; a friend of the Carlyles since 1853; living at 14 Queen Anne St., Cavendish Sq. His first portrait of TC (now at Carlyle’s House), painted 1854–55, was shown at the Royal Academy in 1856 (see 31:84TC to AGI, 5 May 1856); his painting A Chelsea Interior (also at Carlyle’s House), painted 1857–58, was shown at the Royal Academy in 1858. He took photographs of the Carlyles and their house as preparation for the painting, and he also took photographs for TC’s use in Frederick. He m., 1859, Harriet, b. Wilson (b. 1832); they had a da., Mildred (21 May 1860–1950).

Tauchnitz, Christian Bernhard (1816–95), Leipzig printer and publisher; he began the Collection of British and American Authors series, 1841, which included The French Revolution, 3 vols. (Leipzig, 1851). He also pbd. Neuberg’s trans. of Carlyle’s Selected Works (as Ausgewählte Schriften, 6 vols. [Leipzig, 1855–56]) and of Frederick the Great, 13 vols. (Leipzig, 1858–65); see 32:138TC to JN, 1 May 1857.

Taylor, Henry (1800–1886; ODNB; see 6:40TC to MAC, 10 Nov. 1831), author and civil servant; m., 1839, Theodosia Alice, b. Spring Rice (1818–91; see 10:168JWC to TC, 9 Sept. 1838); they had two sons, Aubrey (1845–76) and Harry, and three das., Ida (1847–1929; ODNB), Eleanor, and Una.

Tennyson, Alfred (1809–92; ODNB), poet; poet laureate from 1850. Friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s, TC and Tennyson had a strong mutual regard; he m., 1850, Emily Sarah, b. Sellwood (1813–96).

Thackeray, William Makepeace (1811–63; ODNB; see 9:271JWC to TC, 3 Aug. 1837, 288, and later vols.), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the 1830s. He m., 1836, Isabella, b. Shawe (1816–93), who was mentally ill from 1840. His das. were Anne Isabella (1837–1919) and Harriet Marian (1840–75); they lived at 36 Onslow Sq., London.

Trollope, Anthony (1815–82; ODNB), novelist and post office surveyor; he m., 1844, Rose, b. Heseltine (1820–1917); they had two sons, Henry Merivale (b. 1846) and Frederick James Anthony (b. 1847). From 1861 they lived at Waltham Cross. His brother was Thomas Adolphus Trollope (1810–92; ODNB), writer and historian; he m., 1848, Theodosia, b. Garrow (1816–65); they had a da., Beatrice (Bice) (b. 1853).

Twisleton, Ellen, b. Dwight (1828–62), of Boston, Mass.; JWC’s close friend and confidante; she wrote, 1855, an account of JWC’s early married life at Craigenputtoch (see 30:267–74Ellen Twisleton’s Account of Life at Craigenputtoch). She m., 1852, Hon. Edward Turner Boyd Twisleton (1809–74; ODNB), also a close and respected friend of the Carlyles (see 28:184TC to JWC, 5 July 1853); they lived at 3 Rutland Gate.
Varnhagen von Ense, Karl August (1785–1858; see 9:382TC to JOST, 25 Dec. 1837), Prussian soldier, diplomat, and biographer; see 34:282–8334:biographical note.

Venables, George Stovin (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist; contributor to the Saturday Review from its founding, 1855, and to the Times, 1857–88; friend of Tennyson and of Thackeray, who claimed he was the model for Warrington in Pendennis (1848–50).
Venturi, Emilie; see Hawkes.

Watt brothers, John A. Carlyle’s stepsons: Thomas Fowler (1838–62), went to sea in 1856 (see 32:29TC to IC, 12 Nov. 1856), then joined the army in Jan. 1861; Henry (b. 1839), at sea from 1854 (see 29:121TC to JCA, 30 June 1854); Arthur (b. 1840), at school in Edinburgh from 1856; and William (b. 1842), at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich, from 1858.

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (b. ca. 1853), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201JWC to TC, 29 Aug. 1856), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860).

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–67), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67TC to JWC, 10 March 1842, and 16:219JWC to JW, 26 June 1843), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.
Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.
Welsh, Jeannie (ca. 1798–1828), JWC’s maternal aunt; for her death, see 4:358TC to JAC, 16 April 1828, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 127–29.

Welsh, John (d. 1853; see 28:286–87JWC to HW, 12 Oct. 1853), JWC’s maternal uncle, retired brass and copper founder, who had lived at 20 Maryland St., Liverpool; m., 1808, Mary, b. Colliver (d. 1838; see 10:200TC to AC, 15 Oct. 1838); their children were Helen (ca. 1813–53), Walter, Alexander, Jeannie (see Chrystal), John (1820–60), Margaret, and Mary.
Welsh, John Amelia (“Jackie “) (ca. 1809–64), illegitimate da. of JWC’s paternal uncle William (1790–1819; see 14:90TC to JWC, 25 March 1842) and Elizabeth Scott.

Welsh, Margaret, b. Kissock (1803–88; see 13:44JWC to MW, 22 Feb. 1841, and 20:128JWC to MW, 28 Feb. 1846), widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George (1793–1835), living at 19 St. Johns Grove, Richmond, nr. London. Her son was John Welsh (1824–59; ODNB; see 15:37JWC to MW, 20 Aug. 1842), F.R.S., meteorologist, whom JWC described as “worth all my cousins tied up in one bundle! “ (35:58).
Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.
Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.
Welsh, Mary May (1829–85), da. of JWC’s paternal uncle Robert; m., 1859, as his second wife, Dr. Robert Martin Craven (1824–1903; see 35:26735:biographical note).

Welsh, Robert (1786–1841; see 13:118TC to JWC, 29 April 1841, and 14:217JWC to MW, 8 July 1842), JWC’s paternal uncle, Edinburgh solicitor; m., 1821, Mary, b. May (b. 1796). Their children were John May (1824–56; see 19:98–99JWC to MR, 12 July 1845), Sarah (b. 1825; d. before 1832), Elizabeth (b. 1828), Mary May (see above), Sarah (1832–56), Robert (b. 1833), Annabella (1834–55), and Grace (1836–63), who m., 1859, William Henry Dobie (b. ca. 1809).

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–1879; see 16:12JWC to JW, 8 Jan. 1843), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. Two of his sisters, Margaret (Maggie) and Mary, lived with him (see above).
Whitworth, Joseph (1803–87; ODNB), engineer and inventor; TC had met him in 1847; see 22:57TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1847.

Wilson, Thomas (b. 1811), scholar; see 26:30426:biographical note. TC helped to find him a teaching appointment in Weimar, Dec. 1853. By June 1861 he had married a German woman and was living in 4 Paragon, Blackheath, although he was soon to return to Germany.
Woolner, Thomas (1825–92; ODNB; see 26:37TC to TWO, 21 Feb. 1851, and 29:176–77TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854), sculptor and poet; he moved to 29 Welbeck St., autumn 1861.
Wynn, Charlotte Williams (1807–69; ODNB; see 19:102TC to JAC, 17 July 1845), diarist; friend of Varnhagen von Ense. She lived at 43 Green St.
